Title: Discovering the United Kingdom Part II: Edinburgh, Scotland

My husband and I had the wonderful opportunity to travel in Europe for a month this June. The first part of the trip was in the United Kingdom (UK). Our full itinerary and information about Bath and Manchester can be found here. Today, I’m going to talk about my favorite part of the UK trip: Edinburgh, Scotland! Who wouldn’t love a country that’s made the unicorn one of its official animals?
I don’t think I’ve ever stepped foot into a country and been immediately as wowed by the architecture as I was when we first got to Edinburgh. From the train station, to the narrow streets of downtown, Edinburgh is cute, cute, cute! You have very old, windy cobblestone streets with stone buildings everywhere and, atop the dormant volcano in the center of town, a honest-to-goodness castle (Edinburgh Castle) overlooking everything. Yes, there are a lot of stairs to get from the train station to the heart of the city, but the walk is filled with wonder and beauty. And the streets really are filled with the sound of bagpipes. At least, in the tourist areas where there are plenty of street performers.
What a gorgeous place, the kind that you think of when you think of traveling in Europe.
Our AirBNB had a view of Edinburgh Castle and was quite close to the main tourist attraction, a one-mile stretch of road called “The Royal Mile”. It’s named as such because it starts at the entrance to Edinburgh Castle and finishes at Holyroodhouse Palace, the place where the royals still stay when they visit Scotland.
Along the Royal Mile, you’ll see a cathedral, churches, pubs, shops galore, an example of the “skyscrapers” they had in the 16th century, and, my favorite, the Writer’s Museum featuring three famous Scottish artists: Robert Burns, Sir Walter Scott, and Robert Louis Stevenson. We weren’t familiar with Robert Burns’ work before the visit, but he was a poet who had quite the sense of humor. Just check out his poem entitled, Address to a Haggis, and you’ll see what I mean. The Scottish seem to all have a sense of humor about things too. There were marvelous shops with clever names and pubs galore (maybe the source of the humor??).
The Royal Mile is well-worth the walk, though it gets very crowded with tourists, so it’s best to go early in the day. At the very end, near the palace, you have the Scottish parliament building and a beautiful view of Arthur’s Seat. You can climb Arthur’s Seat to get an amazing view of the city. It was quite rainy when we were visiting, so we skipped the hike, but it’ll be the first thing I do when we return.
We took a tour of Edinburgh Castle in the rain and we still had an amazing time! Our guide was fantastic and the stories behind the castle were incredibly interesting. From the castle you have a nice view of the city. Within the castle walls you can see the National War Memorial (one of the most beautiful I’ve seen), the Scottish Crown Jewels, and a plethora of rooms and museums including the room where Mary Queen of Scot gave birth to her son James and an exhibit on prisoners of war. You should purchase tickets ahead of time as I noticed a sign outside both days we were there saying the tickets were sold out for the day.
One of the top two things we did on our entire trip to Europe was to have tea at the Balmoral Hotel. Tea takes place in the incredibly fancy Palm Court complete with a harpist playing from the balcony. I have been to a lot of teas in my time, but this one is hands-down my favorite. The ambiance is just not-to-miss!
Why did we end up doing tea here instead of somewhere in London? Well, I found out that the Balmoral is where JK Rowling finished the final book in the Harry Potter series, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows. She was too famous to work in cafes by this point and her regular life was too distracting at home, so she upped her productivity by hiding is the Balmoral Hotel. I wanted to spend the night there, but at well over $1000/night it was quite a bit above my price range. So, we settled for tea and I am so glad we did. This was my husband’s first time having a proper afternoon tea and he loved it. I did too.
The weather all weekend was cloudy and rainy. Despite it being June, it was wet almost the whole time we were in the UK. Residents there are so sweet. We had many of them apologize for the weather (as if it’s their fault) and tell us that unfortunately this is pretty normal. We didn’t mind at all. Bad weather meant that we could spend more time inside the establishments that make Scotland famous: pubs!!
We tried to stop into as many pubs as we could, but there is a limit to how many pints a person can have in one weekend (shocking, I know). We found two favorites. First, we stopped into Cloisters Bar, which is located in an old church parsonage building. The clientele here seemed more local and the staff were quite friendly. They had a good amount of food options as well as beers.
Then, there is a the uber-touristy pub called the “Wee Pub”, the smallest pub in Scotland. It is now connected to a larger bar, Biddy Mulligan’s, but you can grab your pint and go sit in the very cute Wee Pub. Here, we met a man from London who was dog sitting for his friends and we had a very interesting conversation about American politics and perhaps the fall of our great nation into another civil war. It was incredibly eye-opening to hear what the rest of the world thinks is going to happen here in the US, I’ll tell you that.
One more word on the food in Scotland. Haggis is actually pretty good. It’s included with any Full Scottish Breakfast and we had three wonderful breakfast places right across the street from our AirBNB in the Grassmarket area. Do give it a shot!
In less than an hour after arriving, we decided to return to Scotland for a longer trip. We kept hearing about other places we’d really like to see: castles galore, Stirling’s Wallace Monument, Isle of Skye, and Loch Ness, of course. So, no doubt we’ll be back and the Highlands will certainly be on our itinerary!
This post first appeared on amberrfield.com. If you’re interested in similar updates you can follow me here or there!

Stepping off the train at Waverley Station, I was instantly enveloped by the vibrant energy of Edinburgh. The city’s majestic skyline, dominated by the imposing Edinburgh Castle perched on its rocky throne, seemed almost to greet me. My senses were immediately awakened by the eclectic mix of old and new; the historic charm of cobblestone streets interspersed with bustling modern cafes and shops. One of my most memorable moments occurred within the first hour — a bagpiper playing a soulful tune on the Royal Mile, his kilt swaying in the brisk Scottish breeze, provided the perfect welcome to this enchanting city.
First-time visitors can expect a delightful blend of history and modernity in Edinburgh. From exploring the medieval alleys of Old Town to enjoying the contemporary art in the National Galleries, there’s something for every taste and interest. The locals are warm and welcoming, ever ready to share a tale or recommend a hidden gem. What struck me the most was how seamlessly Edinburgh marries its rich past with the vibrancy of contemporary culture. While my initial expectation was a city steeped solely in history, I was pleasantly surprised by its forward-thinking spirit and lively atmosphere. Prepare to be challenged by its steep hills — but rest assured, the views from the top are absolutely worth it!
Although the post describes 10 experiences in Edinburgh, United Kingdom, you can explore 71 experiences in Edinburgh, as well as thousands of other cities across the globe on Travel Ninja. Watch the video below for more information, and download the app at Travel Ninja.
Climbing Arthur’s Seat was one of the most exhilarating experiences of my time in Edinburgh. Imagine a clear, crisp morning with the sun rising over the Firth of Forth, casting an ethereal glow on the city. The ascent started near Holyrood Palace, weaving through the ruins of St. Anthony’s Chapel, a reminder of Edinburgh’s rich medieval history. Hikers of all sorts pepper the path — from eager tourists snapping pictures with their smartphones to local fitness enthusiasts jogging up the steep inclines. Everyone seemed to share a silent camaraderie, exchanging nods and smiles along the trail. The mixed accents and languages created a lovely, international symphony that added to the vibrant atmosphere.
When I finally neared the summit, a light breeze carried the distant sound of bagpipes from the city below, blending tradition with the modern panoramic view of Edinburgh. The city sprawled out in a magnificent tapestry of ancient and contemporary architecture, from the historic Edinburgh Castle to the sleek modern buildings of the financial district. The hike itself costs nothing, and I packed a small picnic, making it an incredibly budget-friendly adventure. Along the way, I met a fellow traveler from Australia, and we shared stories and laughs, reveling in the sheer beauty of the moment. Descending during the quieter off-hours, as the sun set, I felt a deeper connection to Edinburgh’s capacity to harmonize its storied past with the vibrant pulse of its present. It’s a place where every stone has a story, and every visitor adds a chapter.
Visiting Edinburgh Castle was an unforgettable blend of history and vibrant energy. As I walked up the cobbled streets, I felt a surge of anticipation mix with the chatter of diverse visitors — families, solo travelers, and history buffs all eager to explore. The entrance fee was around £18, but the ticket was more than worth it for the immersive experience. From the moment I stepped inside, the dramatic skyline views of the city below took my breath away. I was particularly captivated by the eerie silence of the Crown Jewels room, juxtaposed with the lively banter in the Great Hall. Each stone seemed to whisper tales of battles fought and royal ceremonies celebrated.
One moment, I found myself deep in conversation with a friendly staff member who shared a fascinating story about the castle’s role in the Wars of Independence. This interaction highlighted how the castle isn’t just a relic of the past but a vibrant part of Edinburgh’s living history. Wandering through the serene off-hours, with fewer crowds, allowed me to truly absorb the subtle sounds — the fluttering of flags, distant bagpipes, and the soft murmur of wind through ancient stone archways. This visit significantly deepened my appreciation for Edinburgh’s unique blend of tradition and modernity, illustrating how the city harmoniously balances its rich heritage with dynamic present-day life.
Stepping onto the Royal Mile was like diving headfirst into a live tapestry of history and modern-day vibrance. The cobblestone streets echoed with centuries of stories, while vibrant street performers and pipers filled the air with music. I was immediately struck by the mix of tourists, locals, and performers — an eclectic blend that embodies the heart of Edinburgh. Strolling past historic landmarks like St Giles’ Cathedral and the imposing Edinburgh Castle, every corner seemed to unveil another layer of the city’s rich tapestry. Even during the quieter off-hours, the aura of the Royal Mile was palpable, as though the stones themselves whispered secrets of the past.
One of the highlights was chatting with a local shop owner who shared tales of how the street has transformed over decades, blending tradition with a contemporary touch. Simple pleasures, like a delicious Scottish breakfast at a café for around £10, included nurturing interactions that highlighted the warmth and friendliness of the Scots. Observing the city’s signature mix of old and new — from ancient buildings to modern boutiques — it became clear how deeply rooted Edinburgh’s culture is in juxtaposition. The experience was enlightening, deepening my appreciation for how Edinburgh maintains its heritage while embracing the future. It’s a must-visit for anyone eager to feel the pulse of this historical yet vibrant city.
Visiting the Edinburgh International Festival was nothing short of magical. The moment I walked down the cobbled streets towards the stunning venues, the air buzzed with a palpable energy. Imagine a throng of people from all corners of the world, mingling and sharing excited whispers about the performances they were about to witness. I was surrounded by a delightful mix of locals in their traditional kilts, international travelers, and fervent art enthusiasts. The iconic Edinburgh Castle loomed majestically in the background, embodying the city’s rich history, while the innovative art installations and modern performances celebrated its vibrant, contemporary spirit.
The sounds of traditional Scottish bagpipes intertwined with modern electronic beats, creating a soundtrack that’s uniquely Edinburgh. During an off-hour stroll, I soaked in quieter moments — artists rehearsing, street performers practicing, and quaint cafés bustling with animated conversations. My tickets totaled about £50, which wasn’t too steep considering the world-class talent on display. One memorable interaction was with a local vendor selling handmade crafts; our chat about the city’s fusion of heritage and innovation truly deepened my appreciation for Edinburgh’s culture. It was a thrilling reminder of how much this city treasures its past while passionately embracing the future.
The Royal Edinburgh Military Tattoo is an experience that transcends mere performance; it feels like you’re stepping into a grand historical tapestry illuminated by the stunning Edinburgh Castle backdrop. The atmosphere is electric as thousands of spectators gather, their chatter weaving a symphony of international dialects. Bagpipes wail, drums thunder, and the synchronized marching of soldiers from myriad nations is simply spellbinding. The mix of traditional Highland dancers and modern pyrotechnics perfectly encapsulates Edinburgh’s blend of the old and the new. I found myself exchanging stories with a cheerful Canadian couple and a history teacher from France, each of whom added richness to the night’s collective awe. This blend of global camaraderie was a delightful reminder of how shared experiences can bridge cultures.
Cost-wise, tickets can range from £25 to £300 depending on your seating preferences, and it’s worth splurging a bit for a good view. Off-hours, the venue is quieter but retains an almost sacred aura, allowing one to ponder the legacies etched within its ancient stone walls. An endearing interaction with one of the ushers, who shared tales of past Tattoos and his pride in the event, deepened my appreciation for the cultural tapestry of Scotland. This visit was more than just a spectacle; it was a lens into Edinburgh’s soul, a city where the echoes of history harmonize with the pulse of modern life. If you’re planning a trip, make this a non-negotiable stop; it’s worth every penny and moment.
Strolling through the gateway of the Palace of Holyroodhouse felt like stepping into a living tapestry of history and elegance. The grandeur of the Baroque architecture left me awestruck as I walked along the cobblestoned courtyard. The atmosphere buzzed with a mix of curious tourists, diligent historians, and locals proud of their heritage. Each room seemed to whisper stories of royals and revolutions, with curated displays of regal artifacts that took us back in time. The cool Scottish breeze, juxtaposed with the warmth of the sun filtering through ancient windows, added a tangible vitality to the experience. I paced myself to soak in the details, which I was pleasantly surprised cost only £18 for adults and £16 for concessions — undoubtedly great value for an afternoon immersed in history.
During quieter off-hours, the palace exuded a tranquil, almost meditative ambiance. I exchanged thoughts with a friendly visitor from Wales, who shared her fascination with the well-preserved state apartments and the ruins of Holyrood Abbey. A chatty guide brought Mary, Queen of Scots’ chambers to life, highlighting tales that bridged the gap between the past and the present. This visit wasn’t just about crossing a landmark off my list; it deepened my appreciation for Edinburgh’s unique blend of tradition and modernity. The Palace of Holyroodhouse is a living reminder of Edinburgh’s storied resilience and vibrancy, seamlessly blending its historical significance with its modern-day cultural pulse.
A visit to an Edinburgh whisky tasting tour is nothing short of magical. As I stepped into the dimly lit room with its rich oak barrels and polished copper stills, the warm scent of aged whisky filled the air. The venue was an eclectic mix of history and modernity; old wooden beams contrasted with sleek glass tasting stations. The hum of excited chatter from visitors, both locals, and international tourists, set a vibrant atmosphere. During off-hours, the pace slowed down, and there was a serene, almost meditative quality to the experience, allowing for deeper reflection and quiet exploration of the detailed process of whisky making.
The mix of people was fascinating — an older gentleman passionately discussed whisky nuances with a curious young couple from Australia, while a group of friends from London laughed and snapped photos. I engaged in a lively conversation with one of the knowledgeable staff members who explained the region’s rich traditions and how they’ve evolved into today’s contemporary culture. All this for an affordable £25, covering the tour and multiple tastings. This blend of past and present, seen through the lens of a single glass of whisky, enriched my understanding of Edinburgh’s culture and social life, emphasizing its ability to honor tradition while embracing modernity.
Wandering through Princes Street Gardens was a fantastical experience that highlighted Edinburgh’s intricate dance between tradition and modernity. The lush greenery, framed by the grand Edinburgh Castle on one side and the bustling Princes Street on the other, creates a vivid juxtaposition. During my visit, I was enveloped by the melodic chimes of the Scotsman Steps blending with the bustling energy of street performers and locals enjoying a quiet afternoon. Families with children, tourists with their maps, and joggers in their element painted a diverse picture that felt distinctly Edinburgh. The gardens were a living museum of serene natural beauty and historical monuments, from the Ross Fountain to the Scott Monument.
During the quieter morning hours, I relished the tranquility, sipping coffee from a nearby café (about £3) while perched on a bench with a view. An elderly local gentleman struck up a conversation, sharing tales of the city’s history and his childhood memories of the Gardens, making the experience even richer. There was no entrance fee, making the journey light on the wallet but heavy on cultural enrichment. This outing offered a window into the city’s soul, reflecting how Edinburgh cherishes its heritage while embracing the present. It deepened my appreciation for the city’s harmonious blend of the old and new.
Walking into the Scottish National Gallery is like stepping into a vivid tapestry of art and history nestled in the heart of Edinburgh. The atmosphere is a thrilling blend of hushed reverence and palpable excitement, with an eclectic mix of visitors ranging from curious tourists to passionate art students sketching in corners. The grandeur of the neoclassical architecture, crowned with light streaming through expansive windows, accentuates the aura of timeless elegance. Whether it’s a weekday or a less crowded hour, the gallery offers a serene sanctuary where one can immerse themselves fully without the bustling crowd, whispering to each other in awe of the masterpieces around them. Entry is wonderfully free, although donations are welcomed, making it an accessible cultural experience.
As I ambled through the halls, I found myself in engaging conversations with both the friendly staff and fellow art enthusiasts, each interaction layering my understanding of Edinburgh’s rich cultural fabric. One elderly local, a retired professor, shared fascinating anecdotes about some lesser-known works, giving me a deeper appreciation of the gallery’s diverse collection. This blend of tradition and modernity is palpable; historic pieces sit comfortably alongside contemporary works, reflecting Edinburgh’s unique cultural dynamism. The gallery not only houses Scotland’s national treasures but also serves as a reflection of its evolving identity, making it a truly enriching experience both for the seasoned art lover and the casual visitor alike.
Wandering through Dean Village felt like stepping into a hidden gem nestled within modern Edinburgh. Walking along the cobbled streets, the gentle hum of the Water of Leith accompanied my every step. The historic architecture, with its quaint cottages and ivy-clad buildings, created a picture-perfect scene that seemed straight out of a fairy tale. Despite its tranquil atmosphere, there was an undercurrent of energy, a blend of locals and tourists appreciating the serenity. I stumbled upon a charming cafe where a cup of coffee and a slice of cake cost me around £7. Sipping my warm drink, I marveled at the village’s peacefulness, in stark contrast to the bustling city center just a short walk away.
During my visit, I chatted with a couple from Germany who shared their love for Edinburgh’s seamless blend of old and new. Their enthusiasm mirrored my own. This interaction highlighted how Dean Village captures Edinburgh’s unique spirit, balancing tradition with modern living. Exploring off-hours, I found a rare quiet, broken only by birdsong and the occasional passerby. This reflective silence allowed me to appreciate the village’s history and charm deeply. This visit gave me a deeper connection to Edinburgh’s culture, showing a side of the city that values historical preservation while simultaneously embracing contemporary life. If you ever find yourself in Edinburgh, take a moment to breathe in Dean Village’s beauty — it’s a budget-friendly escape into another era.
As you can see, Edinburgh is brimming with incredible experiences waiting to be discovered. But this is just the tip of the iceberg! In March of 2023, I visited Edinburgh (for the second time) for my birthday. It was an amazing holiday, crammed full of sightseeing and activities. There was one thing in particular, however, that I noticed on this trip to the Scottish capital, and that was the number of sculptures I came across, particularly the amount of animal-related statues.
As a fan of critters and public art, I set out to document as many as I could find and have put this article together so you too can follow the trail of Edinburgh’s animals, whilst stopping off at some of my recommendations for a visit to the city.
Starting at the central Edinburgh Waverley station, head down to High Street, part of the famous Royal Mile of Edinburgh's Old Town. Heading towards Edinburgh Castle in the west, you’ll come across St Giles’ Cathedral, its grandeur impossible to miss. Look into the sky in front of the cathedral and you’ll notice Scotland’s magnificent national animal, the unicorn — though a very tiny one.
This structure is called the Mercat Cross and is a 19th-century replacement of the 15th-century original. This octagonal…

Admittedly, at first glance, a publication with a name like Where Cars Don’t Go might not seem like the place to write about a trip to Scotland’s national capital. Still, Edinburgh, a strikingly historic city, turned out to be one of the most walkable places I’ve ever explored.
Sure, there are buses, taxis, and the occasional tram — but Edinburgh also boasts an incredibly compact city centre, pedestrianized streets, and stunning walking paths through its urban core and surrounding hills.
So in Edinburgh, just do as the old Sesame Street song suggested:
How do you get from here to there? What do you do? Well, if you’re visiting your neighbour, here’s my advice to you. Simply walk across the street and look both ways with care; that is how you get from here to there! You use your feet!
So yes, we used our feet! In fact, we did not take a single taxi or bus the entire time we were there! Well… Let me amend that. We did take a “tour” on the Hop on Hop off bus and the Ghost Bus, but those are stories for…

Title: The Land of Lochs and Bens
Content:

I arrived in the Harry Potter city of Edinburgh — and don’t be fooled by the name. You don’t pronounce it EdinBURGH you pronounce it EdinBRUGH. The Scots, with their quick tongues, will correct you as swiftly as they can down a pint. You will either be marked as one of many tourists, who have been drawn by the promises of fairytale castles, the beautiful Lochs, and the towering Bens. Even worse, you might be labelled as a Brit if you speak with just a hint of a British accent.
I visited Scotland in the Autumn. I’ve been told that was the right time to visit Scotland. The fantastical vibe of Edinburgh was only enhanced during this time. With a light sizzling, the cobblestones were covered in water, and the grey clouds hung above the city, adding to the dramatic effect of the city.
Edinburgh is one of those cities, that has adventures hiding almost everywhere. Every alleyway will lead you into a labyrinth of mystery, where you get the feeling that just around the next corner, you will find yourself in the middle of a scene from Harry Potter, an English detective story, or on the way to cross into fairy tale country.
The first thing you notice in Edinburgh is the castle. On a hill in the middle of the city, you see the castle. It served as the guiding point for me, allowing me to orientate myself, simply by fixing my gaze upon this old castle.
The second thing you notice is the people. Even in autumn, Edinburgh is crowded with tourists. People walk The Royal Mile, Victoria Street, filling up the many pubs and cafés. People are coming to this place, for the same reason I did. We’ve seen pictures of Scotland, we’ve heard the stories, we’ve been allured by the sights and finally convinced ourselves to buy that ticket.
While I was in Edinburgh, I had the chance to visit the closest thing to a mountain that Edinburgh boasts of. Arthur’s seat — An ancient, extinct volcano that takes up the east of Edinburgh. The hills are shrouded in mythology, some say it was the location of Camelot, hence the name. There is more tangible evidence of it serving as old Iron Age hill forts.
To get up there, you are faced with a light hike, but the views offered from the top will make up for it. At the top of Arthur’s Seat, you will be offered the most panoramic and scenic view of Edinburgh that you can ask for.
When you are at the top of the hill, on your east you have the sea, on the west, you have the city, the north is sheer mountains. Right in the middle you have Edinburgh.
Edinburgh was just the first of my stops during my time in Scotland. I went there alone and had planned absolutely nothing. I had zero plans, zero expectations, and zero connections — I would just let it play out however it would play out.
After leaving Edinburgh, my next stop was just a short train ride away — Glasgow. The capital of Scotland. This was where I got my first taste of the Scotland I wanted to see, as I boarded a packed day tour to the western Scottish highlands.
On this tour, organized by the friendly staff at Rabbies we went through much of the western Highlands. We got the chance to hear the tales of old clan rivalries, saw castles that had been standing for hundreds of years, visited the beautiful area of Glencoe, and finally, visited the port city known for its whisky — Oban. I already wrote a story about Oban and one of the wonderful people I met there.
Despite having travelled for many years, this was my first experience with a planned day tour. To no fault of the lovely driver at Rabbies, I discovered this wasn’t how I like to explore. It was a lovely tour, and we got to see many of the breathtaking landscapes that Scotland offers, but I like travelling at my own pace.
Getting in and out of a bus, and getting to know the local history, without having time to explore the area is not how I like to travel. When I see the vast untamed beauty of nature, I want to explore it at my own pace. The hills and mountains that just go on seemingly forever. Imagine rolling hills that look like they’ve been plucked from a painting, and then you have to leave to go on to the next scenic destination. Seeing so many beautiful places almost seemed overwhelming, and it was as if I got a sense of diminishing returns as we went from one breathtaking location to another.
That being said, it is hard to describe the beauty of the landscape. The rolling hills of Glencoe, the place where 30 of the McDonald’s were slaughtered in 1862, to the iconic road features in Skyfall.
As drive through Glencoe, you will be faced with three mountains. In Gaelic the mountains are called Aonach Dubh, Beinn Fhada, and Gearr Aonach. These are the mountains that are together known as the Three Sisters of Glencoe, also known as Bidean Nam Bian. All three of the sisters are recognized by their dramatic peaks, with their tops playing hide and seek with the clouds.
After a day spent in the highlands, we headed back towards Glasgow. The tour back, offered as many scenic views as the way up to the towering mountains. As we stopped at a nondescript city on the coast, we got a final view of the rolling hills and mountains, as the sun was setting.
It seemed like the perfect end to the tour, and it had only increased my hunger to tour more of the highlands.
After having spent a few days in Glasgow, meeting with other travellers, where I went to my first rugby match, I decided to leave Glasgow and venture into the highlands. I didn’t know where I was headed, so I just booked a train that headed north and picked a city at random, that city turned out to be Fort William.
As I was venturing north, equally occupied by writing and obsessing over the scenery. A fellow traveller, a Scotswoman, laughed at me for trying to capture all the scenic sights we saw. My camera was as if glued to the window when I wasn’t writing. Then while obsessing over trying to write and capture all this wonderful landscape, I heard the name Fort William as we were stopping. In a rush, I packed all my things and ran out of the train.Running out, I heard the Scotswoman say something, but it was lost to the panic of me losing my stop.
As I got out of the station of Fort William, I looked around and saw…Nothing.
I panicked and ran out of the train at the wrong station.
So now, I was standing in the middle of nowhere, but why not get the best out of it? So after asking at the nearby town, when a bus or train was going anywhere. To my surprise, I was told that in a couple of hours, a bus towards Fort William would go through the city.
I was just at the precipice of the highlands, where forest meets mountains — and I decided to get the best out of it. So I left my stuff at a nearby inn and started hiking.
As I wandered through the forest, the air became crisp. I was immersed in the sound of the forest, that seemed to know no man. The scent of pine, the sound of animals moving through the forest, and a sense of calm descended upon me.
Within what seemed like the blink of an eye, a few hours had passed, and I had to hurry back to the city, to not be left, yet another time in this beautiful area.
When we finally arrived at Fort William, it was dark, windy, and rainy. I looked around at night and thought to myself that it was good I had just booked a night here. There was nothing in sight, TripAdvisor gave a few hints of things to do in Fort William, but all was out of season. When I googled things to do here, all that came up was day tours. I had ventured deep into the Scottish Highlands, to a city that had nothing to do.
How wrong I was.
As I finally arrived at my hostel, I was wet, on the verge of falling asleep, and hungry. I was met by what looked like a big family’s house. It was Fort William Backpackers, and within it, I would find my home for the remainder of my time in Scotland.
It is said that the people make the experiences, and I can only agree with this after my experiences at Fort William. There were about 15 people at the hostel, and it all seemed like one big family. We did daily activities, hosted a movie night, went karaoke singing, and celebrated Guy Fawkes night together.
Despite all the adventures I had already been on in Scotland, there was one thing I didn’t know that I needed. Fort William was known for one thing: Ben Nevis. The highest mountain in the UK — One of the reasons why so many people make a pilgrimage to Fort William in the first place. Something I was wholly unaware of.
Let’s call it fate, would have it that I was in the city located at the base of the highest mountain in the UK, and I knew I had to hike it.
The hike up the mountain was fairly easy. At least, until halfway up the mountain, where the trail disappears, and you are left at times climbing. It seemed like everywhere I went, I saw beautiful scenery. Everywhere was Ben’s (Gaelic for mountain), stretching as far as the eye can see.
As I hiked up the mountain, the weather got worse and worse. Caught in the middle of first a rainstorm, and then as I climbed higher, a beginning blizzard.
As I finally found myself at the top of the mountain, the blizzard kicked in. I was caught in the middle of a white-out and simply had to wait it out. At the top of the mountain, you find a small observatory that is now more of a ruin than anything else. It was at the pillars of this old observatory that I found shelter while waiting out the blizzard.
Half an hour later, the weather improved to a degree that I dared move down again.
Having conquered the highest mountain in the UK on my last day in Scotland was something of a symbolic victory. Despite having conquered the mountain, I can only say that I am by no means done in Scotland — 10 days had gone by in the blink of an eye, and suddenly, my journey had come to an end.
There are more stories to tell about Scotland, but for now, let me leave you with some scenic pictures of my journey.
Thank you very much for reading, if you like this, I have a full travel list here!

Title: Three Edinburgh Hidden Gems

Edinburgh is by far the most visited city in Scotland, indeed one of the most visited cities in the UK, yet most visitors rarely venture beyond the Old Town. Although that part of the city is beautiful and historic, only seeing that small segment means missing out on a unique variety that only Edinburgh can offer. There are any number of places to go, all with their own character and virtues, but I’m going to suggest just three. Both to keep it simple and to encourage a little more adventure for those with the time and inclination.
Sitting in a steep valley that runs straight through the northern reaches of the city centre New Town, the Water of Leith runs eastwards towards Leith Shore and the Firth of Forth. Nestled on the banks of this shallow but rapid river is the ancient site of Dean Village. Some of the housing down here dates back to the 16th and 17thcenturies with Tudor style wood beam construction and some early Scottish Baronial mixed with French influence. The area was once the home of a thriving wool industry, with water powered mills dating as far back as the 16th century. Today it is a regularly photographed little gem that’s extremely easy to miss.
The easiest way to find this fascinating little spot is to head for Stockbridge, at the heart of New Town. There you can join the walk beside the Water of Leith and head west beside the river. This has the added bargain of taking you past the delightful St Bernard’s Well. You’ll quickly find yourself in an oasis of nature, during the summer it’s filled with bird song. Keep an eye out for herons and wagtails. It can be breath-taking to realise that you’re still in the middle of the city on this walk, as it feels like you couldn’t be further from it. Eventually you’ll come to the vibrant yellow Tudor style buildings and the staggering red brick Scottish Baronial Well Court that distinguish the heart of Dean Village. Stop to take it in, grab a photo or two from the footbridge, but don’t forget that just across the river is the old Dean School buildings that now house the Scottish National Galleries of Modern Art.
If quiet little spots of ancient history are your thing and, if you’re visiting Edinburgh, I assume they are, you shouldn’t miss Crammond. This is a little more off the beaten track than Dean Village, requiring a bus ride at the least. To be honest, if it wasn’t for Crammond, there’d be almost no reason to head out in this direction. Yet this small village area, that’s been swallowed by the city over time, really does make the journey worthwhile. If you’re interested in the second world war this is also worth the trip. The same can even be said if ancient Roman ruins are your thing.
From the city centre you’ll want to head to Drumshaugh Pl to the west end of Princes Street. There you can get the 47 bus to Crammond Pl. The trip shouldn’t take any more than about 35 mins but will take you through endless bungalows into what appears to be the depths of suburbia. The bus terminates at this Crammond Pl so there’s not too much worry about missing your stop. From the bus you might want to check Google maps or something to make sure you’re going the right way. Having said that it’s a simple and brief walk down to the old village that is instantly recognisable for it’s pretty, secluded and historic construction. The kirk (church) that sits in the heart of the old community dates back to the Middle Ages and many of the old buildings are early modern at the latest. You might want to go on the hunt for the ruins of the Roman fort or, if the tides are right, take the wartime causeway out to Crammond Island. In the Village you can find a good pub lunch or a tasty wee café, then maybe take the waterfront walk along Silverknows.
For bird lovers keep an eye out for the multitude of waders on the mudflats here, where the River Almond runs out into the Firth of Forth. There are reasonable views of the bridges to be had here, although not as good as from South Queensferry. Along the waterfront walk it turns from mud flats to semi-sandy beach. Generally, you’ll find a lot of locals with their families or walking their dogs around this area. It’s definitely a weekend favourite for many Edinburgh natives.
Not just a great place to visit, this is a part of the city it’s well worth considering staying in. There are a few hotels and BnB’s in the area, although it’s very much a residential spot. This won’t be for everyone, but if you’re looking for a little taste of living like the locals, this might be the place for you.
Bruntsfield sits beside the Bruntsfield Links, a green space that run into one of the city parks known as The Meadows. The area is rich with cafés, grocers, even one of my favourite book shops. There are exceptional bus links to just about everywhere you might want to go and it’s an easy, pleasant walk through the park to get to the Old Town and museums. There’s a significant student, graduate and academic population in the area due to proximity to the University of Edinburgh and Napier University. The broad, cobbled, and tree lined streets of neighbouring Marchmont make for a delightful residential area with a few eateries and handy shops if you’re going self-catering.
There are entertainments down the main road in Tollcross or walking through Bruntsfield and Polwarth to Fountain Park. The architecture in the area is probably some of the best in Edinburgh for residences, with the grand tenements with broad bay windows on full display. There’re also some quirks like the Wild West street just a few minutes’ walk into Morningside or Colinton Tunnel, a brief bus ride away.
So, whether you want a quiet moment, a taste of many eras of history in one place, or the chance to live like the locals, these three suggestions should be a little guidance. Don’t forget that there’s much more than these few places I’ve mentioned. If you want to know more then keep following my writing as I provide further information and insight into this beautiful city I love.

Title: The Magic of Edinburgh, Scotland
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I arrived in Edinburgh on a sunny afternoon at the beginning of March from the train station, having come in by cross-country Scotrail from Glasgow. I didn’t know what to expect, but in my heart, I knew that the main vein of Scotland would be pure magic. Motivating. From the first glimpse of the stony edifices of Haymarket, to the towering spires of the cathedrals and Scott Monument, I was sold. I exited Edinburgh Waverley with a pounding heart — both from the heavy hiking backpack I sported and the cool air that surrounded me. There were thousands of voices, honking car horns, blaring sirens, laughter, and in the distance, I could even make out the screech of bag pipes.
My first accommodation, the Cowgate Hostel, located near the famous Cowgate arches and the Grassmarket, was tucked on a lower road that I had no idea how to get to; and I soon found myself wondering the maze-like hills of the Old Town, gazing up with wistful eyes to the chimney stacks on the rooftops and marvelous stonework. I could see already how masterminds of the creative world, like J.K. Rowling, found their inspiration in this place.
Having put my belongings in storage at the hostel for now, I headed back out through Fleshmarket Close to reach the main road where Edinburgh Castle and several other attractions could be found. Though I didn’t go into the castle, as it was extremely crowded, I did indulge in the views from the parking lot to the right and left of me, the sound of Braveheart and Highlander impersonators, and the overflow of Tartan. I ended up jumping souvenir shop to shop, just looking at the woolen scarves and kilt packages that were available. In one of the shops, I happened to find a display of surname books.
Now, my mother has for many years told me about her Scottish grandparents, the Lapps. A few years ago, after discussing the surname with a friend of mine whose Scottish lineage is clear (there’s even a fiefdom with their name still in existence), and learning that Lapp is Jewish, German, French, and even a designation of people from Lapland, I decided to search for Lapp on this wall of heritage books. Not one Lapp. But I did find Taylor, an ancient Scottish clan from the 13th century.
I was delighted, especially since the clan had been weaponsmiths, and one, the Black Taylor, wielded a battle ax. It kind of reminded me of my father. When I mentioned it, he was kind of excited by the possibility of being from a place where one of his favorite movies (he’s a Highlander fan) had been set.Thus, I found myself even more engaged with Scotland, seeing how my predecessors could have indeed hailed from Scotland…even if it wasn’t the side of the family that I had imagined.
Throughout the two weeks I spent in Edinburgh, I invested most of my evenings to dancing at the National Dance Centre for Scotland, Dance Base. The studio is located on the upper floors of buildings that make up the Grassmarket area but is state-of-the-art and one of the best studios I have ever been to. I’ll be discussing more about Dance Base later on in the article. When I wasn’t dancing, I was walking all around Old Town and New Town, enjoying the assortment of cafes and free attractions that are available.
Though the weather wasn’t always agreeable, since it rained half the time, I could still find things to do.
Although I spent a little over 2 weeks in Edinburgh for the purpose of dancing and working on a novel, anyone who is going to Scotland to see the sights and learn the history could easily get the majority of must see attractions and must do activities finished within a week or less.
I talked with another American named Grace who had lived in London for a few years and was heading back to the States once she left Edinburgh about how small the city is. We were both surprised, especially since she’d come from places like California and London and me from the sprawling metropolis of Tokyo, Japan and New York City. Edinburgh is compact, but that doesn’t mean it is lacking in things to do. You just need to pace yourself if you have more than 3 days in Edinburgh.
The places I went while in Edinburgh:
Other recommendations (that I didn’t visit personally):
I recommend going to Holyrood Park on a nice day, because when the wind blows, it can be brutally cold, even when the sun is shining. You should also wear the proper shoes, since the mud can be slippery. I had come right from a dance class and was wearing my worn out trainers, causing me to take a few heart-stopping slides while working my way up and down the slope. It’s definitely something you should do, though, because you feel like you are in Scottish Highlands, what with the sweeping views of Leith and Portobello Beach, snow-capped hills in the winter, and the horizon. I took paths less traveled around the knolls, finding my way to quiet lakes and dancing blades of grass. It seemed like I had been transported to the fantasy lands of my mind for just a moment. Then I turned around to head back towards the Parliament House.
I did the crags one day then tackled the Queen’s Drive path another day. The Queen’s Drive brings you around the backside of Arthur’s Seat. If you hard enough, you can see Cragmillar Castle in the distance from one point.Another day I took a walk towards Dean Village then continued up to the Inverleith Park and Royal Botanical Gardens. Dean Village was quaint and small, and there’s not much more to see there than the preserved buildings in a picturesque layout. The Water of Leith walk was closed off, but I did get to walk a little of it before climbing a narrow flight of steps to a sloping road that eventually brought me to the Inverleith Park. There was a small pond there where ducks were swimming. From the top of the hill, you get a marvelous view of Old Town in the distance with the sun in the backdrop that’s definitely worth seeing as the sun begins to dip low.
Since the Scottish air was still cold and damp, not much was growing in the Royal Botanical Gardens, but the exhibits in the buildings were interesting, and the shop had some sustainable items that are worth a look-see. The gardens were a nice place to sit down to read a book or have a snack or two, so keep that in mind if you plan on going when the weather is a bit warmer.The other place for fantastic views would be Calton Hill. Though I could have chosen a less gray and dreary day to visit the monuments and observation center, I was also glad that it was less crowded than usual. This allowed me to take my time going from point-to-point and seeing all that Calton Hill and the world beyond had to offer.
One of my favorite spots, though, was Greyfriar’s Kirk, nestled among the brick buildings beyond the Greenmarket. I wondered the cemetery for at least 30 minutes, snapping pictures of the elaborate and intricate headstones and murals, as well as the fresh sakura blossoms on the trees. With the spire of a cathedral rising above the annexed rows of buildings, the gravestones, and the trees to capture my gaze, I felt like I was seeing a whole new world, and in my mind the Harry Potter theme started to play. Go figure that the Elephant House, where J.K. Rowling is said to have written much of the Harry Potter series is not even a two minute walk from Greyfriar’s Kirk.
Indeed, there is something scintillating about Edinburgh that is hard to put to words. You see a world beyond the one that exists now, especially as you begin to delve deeper into the history and the culture. You can almost feel the ancient energies still at work in Auld Reekie, even with the graffiti, weathered billboards, and boisterous voices throughout the night at beer gardens.
I found myself taken with Edinburgh and promising that one day I would be back. This was one part the location and energy. The other was thanks to the wonderful experiences I had at Dance Base.
One of the things that I indulged in while visiting Edinburgh was jumping from cafe to cafe throughout the day to do work and drink coffee. Seeing how I am always concerned about my budget, I rarely eat or drink out when I travel, but seeing how the cafe culture in Edinburgh is thriving and I needed a place to work, cafes were the wisest option.
My first choice was Black Medicine Coffee Co., located on South Bridge Road, a short walk from my accommodations. Black Medicine Coffee Co. has some awesome history, so check out the website to learn more about how long they have been in business and more about the building where the cafe is located. But you’re more interested in the coffee and food, I’m sure. On different days, I enjoyed the cappuccino, a long black, and a flat white. Every caffeinated concoction was as good as the last, with a smooth finish and gracious sized cups for the price. They also have vegetarian/vegan food options, as well as a broad selection of soups, sandwiches, breads, and sweeter treats to satisfy you. The free wifi at Black Medicine was speedy. I could even log into my MMORPG without any issues and experienced zero lag.
Next, I went to Coffee Angel, a little further down on the same road. Coffee Angel serves up some of the best paninis I’ve had in a long time. They come fresh out of the sandwich press with a free side of tortilla chips. The almond croissants are delicious as well. If you order a pot of tea, you honestly get a whole pot of freshly brewed tea that fills about 2.5 tea cups, if you are drinking it on your own. There are a number of electrical outlets in the cafe, too. I did have some wifi connection problems on my computer, but my phone connected flawlessly.
Lastly, I went to Frederick’s Coffee and Wine, another highly-rated cafe for coworking and cakes. Though I didn’t find any coworking space, as it was rather crowded, the chairs were comfortable. You also get service right at your seat, and the hall staff brings everything right to you. I got myself a pot of Japanese Cherry tea. The delicate green tea and sakura flavor blended well with the Raspberry-Pecan slice and scoop of vanilla ice cream that I ordered. Frederick’s also has more substantial meals, a broad selection of crafted coffees and teas, and all-day breakfast on Sunday. If you want to connect to the free wifi, ask the server for the password. They don’t mind how long you stay, either.
Doing as I usually do when traveling, I stayed at multiple accommodations in Edinburgh: the Cowgate Hostel, Safestay Edinburgh, and the High Street Hostel. This worked out in my favor when the weather was dismal for a few days. Each location was within walking distance from the next, so I never really left Cowgate Road or Old Town.
For the budget backpacker, I recommended either the Cowgate Hostel or High Street Hostel for your stay. Cowgate Hostel is cheaper that HSH and Safestay for good reason — it’s a bit rough around the edges and right across from a beer garden that lasts until 03:00 in the morning. There’s little to keep the noise from echoing throughout the building, and the beds aren’t that comfortable; but overall, the bathrooms are spacious, and the kitchen was nice. I didn’t have any problems here, save for the one night a group of French guys came back from drinking and could be heard vomiting in the bathroom right next to my bunk bead. Like I said, no sound barriers.
High Street Hostel was nice in terms of noise level. The rooms were quiet 9 out of 10 times, and the way the beds are built means you don’t get any shaking. Plus, the mattresses were supportive but also soft enough. I slept well every single night, which says a lot. You also get two pillows. The kitchen/lounge area was really nice, too. However, the problem I had with High Street Hostel was the staff. The kitchen was supposed to open at 6:30 AM, but every morning, the person who was opening it was late and gave me an attitude when I asked. Oh, and if you like drinking, be sure to be there for “Thorsday,” for the pub crawl.
If you have a slightly higher budget, stay at Safestay on the Royal Mile. There are single, double, and dormitory style rooms available, a guest kitchen, discounts on food and drink, plenty of space to find a lounging spot, and even storage for your belongings. The free wifi is speedy (so don’t both upgrading to the high speed). I had no problems connecting. There was a lack of charging points in the dormitory room, and people tended to get possessive of their outlets, which led to some awkward exchanges when you wanted to charge your phone or computer. But the en suite toilets and showers were great. You spend a little more, but you’ll be pretty comfortable here.
Overall, I would rate Safestay the highest, HSH at the middle, and Cowgate the lowest in terms of comfort.
Other hotels and hostels that I recommend:
There’s also a number of guest houses and bed-and-breakfasts near the Edinburgh Zoo that I saw when traveling on the Airlink bus to the airport.
So what is this Dance Base I keep praising so highly? Dance Base is Scotland’s National Centre for Dance, a collection of professionals and recreational dancers that is warm, welcoming, and wholesome. The studio is open to everyone, whether you have disabilities or are looking for a safe place as a member of the LGBT+ community. There are accessible facilities, like genderless bathrooms and changing rooms (along with traditional designated ones), elevators for those with wheelchairs, and dance classes open to those with handicaps and disabilities as well.The professional classes are done early in the morning as well in the evening, and you get free access to shows. Professionals can ever hire studios for rehearsal or shows.For general classes, there are several levels, ranging from absolute beginner to intermediate-advanced. I took a range of classes, finding that each one had something challenging about it. My drop-in schedule was full, and that is only a small piece of all the classes that are offered at Dance Base, so if you can stay for a term, do it. I took Contemporary twice a week, Improvisation, Bollywood, West African Dance, Lyrical Jazz, Ballet and Ballet Fusion, Hip Hop, and even a folk dance based workout class that was absolutely wild. Every teacher was welcoming and taught all levels flawlessly.I was pushed. I learned new methods for teaching in the future. I felt myself grow as a dancer, especially because the community here is so cheerful and open. It was amazing to sit down and just start talking about Martha Graham or other dance experiences with professionals, new and old, and the instructors. Dancers from all across the globe were here; and no one showed any negativity. You walk in feeling like you are part of a family.
So, if you are looking to further your dance training while you travel the world, I give Dance Base two thumb’s up.
My trip to Edinburgh was, in one word, awesome. I am so happy to have gone to this amazing and historical city and was able to take part in multiple dance classes with beautiful souls from all around the world. Edinburgh has a little something for everyone, though — not just dancers. If you like hiking, photography, history, art, cafe-hopping, coffee, bagpipes, the magical world of Harry Potter, flowers, murder mysteries, beer, and Scottish accents, you can find something that will delight you here, for however long you decide to stay.
Interested in visiting Glasgow? Check out the article “Glasgow Travel: What I Did In Glasgow” HERE. Or maybe you’re more for the British side of the UK? I visited London recently too.
Have questions or comments about my trips? Want more info? Leave a comment or shoot me a message!

A Scotsman accosted us on Edinburgh’s Lawnmarket Street, and when he found out Teresa and I were Americans, he immediately told us this joke:
“Donald Trump was visiting the Isle of Lewis — you know that’s where his mother was from? — and he came across an old man in a field digging up little potatoes. ‘In America, we grow the biggest potatoes!’ Trump boasted. ‘They grow this huge,’ he said, making a big circle with both hands.
“‘Oh, we have no need o’ that in Scotland,’ said the old man. ‘We only grow them big enough to fit in our mouths.’”
The ambush-raconteur smiled at our laughter, then told us Trump was a grave danger not only to America, but “to thee whole warld.”
Ah, Edinburgh, how we have missed ye! Teresa (my beloved spouse and co-flâneur) and I have not been here in five years. Before Covid, we spent nearly every summer holiday in the Scottish Highlands. Now suddenly, accidentally, we are back! (We had planned to spend a summer in Scandinavia — a plan we had to abruptly cancel). In…

Title: 10 WAYS I ENJOYED SCOTLAND WHILE IN EDINBURGH
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Listen
Share
If you’re like me (part Scottish) then a trip to Edinburgh, Scotland will be a bit more than relax and snap. I found it very important to visit the place my last name originated and was pleasantly surprised with my overall experience. I did my research and opted to bed down in Edinburgh. There, I’d have a wide range of cultural and historical amenities within walking distance or a quick cab ride. Edinburgh is a very beautiful city, and it’s lush charm is a mix of Vancouver and Prague rolled into one. With a 5-day itinerary in hand, I knew I’d have to make the most of it and pancake what I could, so I could deliver an article worthy of your time. So if you’re ever down for the Scottish experience, here are Travel Daddy’s 10 WAYS I ENJOYED SCOTLAND WHILE IN EDINBURGH…
I can honestly say without apprehension that Edinburgh has the best Taxi drivers I’ve seen or experienced on the planet. They’re prompt, courteous, knowledgeable, friendly, humble, and honorable. It’s actually quite a contrast from what I experienced in Santiago, where my safety was threatened. I would be more apt to describe them as mobile micro tour guides, possessing a high social IQ and left you with the impression that most -if not all- actually drive tourists around because they like it!
Tip them you cheap bastard — they deserve it!
2. WHISKY A DO
Oh mighty Scotch Whisky- the nectar of the Gods! Aside from Coffee and a choice Cab, nothing assaults the palette like a dram of fine aged whisky. Whether it be blended, aged or cheap, Scotland IS the mecca of Whisky. There are several options to get your fix; for me, the day tour to Loch Ness had an added bonus of visiting a legit distillery- DEANSTON.
After the tour and tasting, I couldn’t resist purchasing their premier 23 yr old. It ran me high, but every bit worth the cost since you can’t get it anywhere but there. A few days later as I exited Edinburgh Castle, I saw THE SCOTCH WHISKY EXPERIENCE, conveniently nestled on the 1st right side corner. It is home to the World’s Largest Collection of Scotch Whisky.
It Cost what!?!?!
My arrogance was quelled when upon bragging to the hosts/scotch experts that I’m on my 3rd bottle of Johnny Walker Blue ownership, they redirected my attention to truly rare and expensive whisky. I actually considered selling my house for the novelty. My son doesn’t really need to go to college right? I was even more exasperated to learn that some “poor” chap a week prior purchased a $25,000 Pound bottle and spent a total of over $40K Pounds. I’ll get there one day. There’s also a cool whisky chart which matches the flavor to the brand, for novice drinkers like myself.
Buy a bottle — Live a little!
3. LOCH NESS & HIGHLANDS DAY TRIP
I booked this day tour offered by The Hairy Coo through Trip Advisor. They offer many other tours throughout Scotland, but this one was convenient and enticing, especially with the whisky tour. The 10 hour itinerary was well thought out and included key stops like the Highland Hairy Coos, Glencoe, Whisky Distillery, Fort Augustus — home to Loch Ness, the Commando Memorial, Cairngorm Park, and Pitlochry. You can check the full itinerary here. Although Loch Ness was beautiful and worth the trip, you’ll be sorely disappointed to not catch a glimpse of it’s most famous inhabitant.
TOUR HIGHLIGHTS
What a Bridge!
On your return, you’ll cross and witness three amazing bridges adjacent to each other, one of which — The Forth Bridge- is a UNESCO site. The tour guide was friendly, knowledgeable and brimming with that Scottish wit.
Well worth the day — at least once!
4. FINE DINING
So many options- so much quality. Edinburgh is definitely a foodie destination for fine dining. You should check out my list of 10 AMAZING RESTAURANT & FOOD EXPERIENCES IN EDINBURGH. From traditional dishes like Haggis, Neeps & Tatties, to exclusive restaurants booked up months in advance, Scotland definitely has the food chops to satisfy your taste buds.
Food is most definitely a worthy Splurge- do it!
5. SO MANY PUBS… AMAZING SPEAKEASIES… GREAT NIGHTLIFE
As expected, I encountered more pubs in a 1 mile radius in Edinburgh than anywhere I’d been outside the U.K. People love to drink, and a pubs like The Advocate, The Cafe Royal Circle Bar and The Bow Bar, stood out for me as great places to knock down a few cold ones. If you fancy top-notch cocktails then there are some speakeasy type bars of high caliber like Panda & Sons and Head & Tails. For a speakeasy in the truest sense you’ll have to search the alleyways for Bullard & Worth — I won’t give you the address, but instead give you a clue. Most locals don’t even know how to find it, and it’s location on google maps was incorrect (purposely?). I had to ask several people and store owners in what felt like a treasure hunt.
Success at last…
I finally found what I had been looking for- approached, knocked, and was rewarded. The bartender was as an amazing conversationalist as he was a cocktail wizard. I’ll say no more so good luck!
As far as clubbing there are a ton of options from clubs teeming with college-aged patrons, salsa dancing, hip-hop lovers and live music. My article 10 BEST NIGHTLIFE IN EDINBURGH SCOTLAND will give you a list of good recommendations when you’re in town.
Edinburgh has great nightlife — party on!
6. CRASH A TRUE SCOTTISH WEDDING… THEN GET KICKED OUT
There I am- minding my own business at Ghillie Dhu, when I’m approached by a kilt-wearing Scotsman who wants me to buy him a pint. I oblige and as a reward he takes me upstairs to the reserved hall to see a “true Scottish wedding” as he put it. After a few drinks and introductions to the groom, I’m taking it all in being particularly wary of my visitor status. I stand to the side respectfully and silently appreciate how folks from all walks of life celebrate life’s milestones similarly but in their own unique way.
Uh-Oh….
Unfortunately, no one told the bride and ten minutes later, I’m being awkwardly escorted out of the wedding by the stoic security. No love lost though- since it was worth the experience and good blog fodder. I’m not encouraging you to intrude on someone’s big day, but try to synch with the locals in some way and get a true experience as to how folks live and celebrate.
People are different, but the same — even in Edinburgh!
7. SEE LEITH THEN WALK AIMLESSLY UNTIL PORTOBELLO
I took a cab down to Leith- a historic and artsy port Northeast of Edinburgh’s city center. It’s a must-see with top-notch restaurants, pubs and home to the Royal Yacht Britannia. The weather was great so I opted for a stroll along the canal, then made my way back inland toward the Leith Links (public parks). After catching some cricket and picnics, I headed back to the shore for some photography.
How’d I get Here?
Two hours later I’m in Portobello and realized with no cab in sight, I’d have to trek it back to the city. Using the street signs, I self-navigate past Holyrood Park and if not for my impending dinner reservations, would have walked back all the way. A kind local gives me exact change for the bus fare back to my hotel and I fulfill my dinner plans.
Great scenery & photos off the beaten path — dress for the walk!
8. STUMBLE UPON A TRADITIONAL MUSIC BAND COMPETITION
It’s a Sunday and I finally decide upon Princes Street Gardens, which is literally a stone’s throw from my hotel. With camera in hand, I knew I’d score some great shots by way of the park’s natural beauty. It’s descended location gives an almost serene respite from the bustling streets above. It isn’t long before I hear an army of bagpipes and drums. I was pleasantly surprised to spectate dozens of traditional bands practicing and performing in a competition- free to the public. I snapped away and appreciated the unique experience. The park is not open 24/7, and is worth a visit especially with kids in tow.
The Edinburgh 2019 Pipe Band Championship was amazing- the Gardens are still worth a visit!
9. BE AMAZED BY HISTORY IN OLD TOWN
There is history everywhere in the buildings, streets and closes (alleyways) of Edinburgh. If you’re a history buff or lover of things ancient, then Edinburgh is a mine of activities. Edinburgh Castle was built upon remnants of an extinct volcano, and from its elevated point you can see much of this beautiful city. A great portion of New Town with this area has been categorized as a UNESCO Heritage Site. As you descend down the cobbler streets, you’ll probably catch one of the many guided tours such as the Harry Potter Walking Tour. Much of the books and films were inspired by the streets and architecture of Old Town Edinburgh. I personally find it fascinating to walk among buildings that are older than the U.S. as a nation.
History can be awesome- don’t miss it!
10. WALK THE ROYAL MILE
The ROYAL MILE is the main street running from Edinburgh Castle all the way down to Holyrood Park. You’ll find a variety of top tourist sites like Arthur’s Seat, Edinburgh Museum, Scottish Parliament, St. Giles Cathedral, and Holyrood Palace. You can stop at several pubs and eateries along the way, easily spending a full day experiencing all it has to offer. I definitely had a blast and have the pics to prove it.
Grab your camera- This is Edinburgh!

Hi there! It’s good to see you here.
This photo is exactly where I am now — an uphill climb to see as much of the world as possible. Yet, some places capture me instantly when I arrive. Edinburgh, the city and its people, is one of those. While I write short posts with photos, this one is a longer read with even more pictures and will be in several parts.
My daughter and I decided to visit Scotland. I knew I needed a month, but because of our schedules, I only had a week. At first, our plans involved a rental car and too many stops until I realized I only wanted to see Edinburgh on this first trip. Thanks to my daughter, we enjoyed our trip, and I hope to return to a different location in Scotland at least every other year.
The city exceeded my expectations. Why? I felt immediately at home. If you’ve read my other posts, you know that a city’s vibes either make it for me or not. I have no idea why I feel the energy in things, people, and places, but I do. Edinburgh, for me, is calm and reassuring. Not so in London (as I will discuss in a later post), where we’d just left. There, I feel discombobulated. My brain hears English being spoken but doesn’t feel at home. I anticipated the same thing in Scotland, but thankfully, it didn’t happen.
We took the train from London into Edinburgh Waverley, in the city’s heart. The station is magnificent. After looking at the bus routes and getting tips from our apartment host, we decided to walk to our apartment. I’m glad we did. Here are some scenes along the way.
Our Airbnb in Marchmont near The Meadows had a lot of light, even on a somewhat gloomy day like the one above. Our flat had two bedrooms and two baths, with windows in both bedrooms, a necessity for us both. We had a pleasant morning visitor every day who watched us eat breakfast. The apartment was stocked with things to eat related to Scotland, which was a nice touch.
Our hosts at the apartment we rented in Marchmont were fabulous. They provided transportation tips and suggestions for food, even meeting with us to have a beer and a chat and answer all my questions. (I cannot get Scottish citizenship because of UK rules. They don’t like older adults, it seems.)
The Meadows is a large park near the University of Edinburgh. The paths through the garden were the easiest way to reach most of the places we decided to see daily. Edinburgh has a decent bus service, but we used our feet to take it slow and see the city center on this first trip.
We were in the city the week after Fringe, the year of a garbage workers’ strike, and our Airbnb hosts were apologetic about the city’s look. Having frequented New York City, I was surprised at how clean this city was, even amid a garbage strike. All the people, whether tourists or residents, kept the garbage in the taped-off areas with signage, and the rest of the city was kept clean.
Our landlord insisted we could not visit Edinburgh without a trip to Holyrood Park and a hike up to Arthur’s Seat. Up to the challenge (well, my daughter more than me), we set out for the hike up the hill the next day. It was worth it for the scenery alone.
If you’ve never been to Edinburgh, the main downtown area with tourist attractions is easy to wander. We began at the Palace of Holyroodhouse and walked up the Royal Mile to Edinburgh Castle, stopping in shops after lunch in a small cafe, then visiting one of the cathedrals.
Even with the level of tourists at the end of the Fringe, it was a pleasant walk without the usual hassle of packed streets and impatient tourists.
Here are more photos; I’ll have more in the next post.
You can find me on my website at IstanbulMiami.com and additional posts at RSHampton.substack.com.

Title: Edinburgh Whirlwind Trip: Starting the First Year of My Twenty-Something
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
