Title: I’m a Little Edinburgh Fringe Worm with no cash, so please read this and share as if it’s poignant so people come to my show
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
Nobody cares about the fact I’m going to Edinburgh Fringe and neither should they. I’m a comedian going on a jolly for a couple of weeks in a great city with loads of my pals and trying to make people laugh. Yes it’ll probably bankrupt me and I’ve done everything in my power to not lose money hand over fist but even so, nobody is forcing me, it’s fucking great at it’s core (once we overthrow the Tories up there charging thousands for August rents). I could use this piece to get extremely angry about class and how it’s easy to do it if you’re secretly loaded, but we all know that, so allow me to drivel on for 800 words (681 from here on in, OK and that used up five, we’re nearly there) and hopefully encourage you to tweet the link to this piece with one of the following quotes above the link so people think I’ve made some sort of life-changing point;
My show is about…..WOMEN. Does that make you uncomfortable?! Probably not. You might even know one. It came from working in women’s media and being told every day what to be angry at, what to be turned on by, what to be repulsed by, who to be angry at and why you must always, every single day, be told how to ask for a pay rise. There’s an entire industry dedicated to books about work. Can you believe it? Titles like ‘How To Get What You Want At Work And Shag Your Colleague Respectfully’ and ‘How To Boss Bitch Your Way Into Millions Of Pounds And Shit On Everyone You Know.’ People buy them! Where is the book that says ‘Here’s How To Never Fill In A TimeSheet Ever Again’ — I would buy that. Read books about shagging and love and mad stuff! Not the thing you do all day! I digress.
My show is about how sometimes I’m not angry at the right things and I do stupid shit and that true equality is ripping the piss out of men and women. The day Mother’s Day cards contain a joke is the day Gloria Steinem can have a quick fag break to relax before cracking on with the serious stuff.
And of course, there are properly awful things going on for women at the moment, but you all know about that too. I’m just inviting you to come and laugh at me for 45 minutes in the back of a pub and maybe sling me a tenner at the end for my efforts. (If you don’t, you’re sexist) A lot of Edinburgh shows are about something moving, poignant, tragic or dark, I’m here to tell you that my parents are both alive, sadly were very supportive of me, and never ask me if I’m going to get married. They fed me almost exclusively Findus Crispy Pancakes and Spaghetti Hoops for about 12 years as well so in many ways, they’re legends. I’ve got nice pals, big dark roots that I can’t afford to dye, and my life has mostly been pretty good, despite my job on the ASDA checkout and Morrisons chicken counter, so you can see my issue. In many ways, making a show out of almost exclusively stupid sexual decisions is actually harder. No pun intended. Well it is now, I wrote it and then realised.
Please come and see Woman In Progress at Southsider, 6th — 17th August, at 5.45pm. You won’t regret it, straight away at least. It’s with PBH Free Fringe, so just pay what you want at the end!
Follow me on Instagram if you liked this [at]alexandrahaddow
Thanks and hopefully see you there!

Title: Edinburgh — This Majestic City: ‘The mix old and modern, tradition and innovation was intoxicating’
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

This publication brings together interesting articles related to cyber security.

--
Listen
Share
I stepped foot in Edinburgh many decades ago and immediately fell in love with the place. That first sight of the city will never leave me, and I still adore the way it holds its head high. It was the strongest against Brexit, it has more graduates as a percentage than virtually any other place on the planet, and it hosts world-class innovation and research. While its infrastructure is never at a scale that the mighty London can achieve in terms of innovation, it is livable, walkable, and a fairly safe place to live.
And, so, I just loved this quote [here]:
The mix of old and new, tradition and innovation, sums up my city. Around its ancient building exists world-leading research and innovation, and, like Glasgow, it is focused on technology and scientific advancements. The city nurtured three of our cybersecurity spin-outs, and I believe we could not have succeeded as well as they did without the help of the city — in supporting investment, collaborations, and most of all, attracting the talent needed to build high-impact companies. While Brexit was a major spanner in the works, the city has managed to showcase its economic resilience — more to do with its people and businesses than by politicians — and continues to build its place on an international stage.
For students, it’s a great place to come and study and is in the Top 10 cities of the world for this. In the QS World guide, the rankings for the best city to study are [here]:
For a relatively small city, a Top 10 finish is amazing. But, it’s not a big city, and that’s a good thing! Many people can live and work within an area that allows you to walk to work, or, at least, get a bus. In fact, Edinburgh buses are great. While we have a new tram, most Edinburgh people still use the bus to get around. You are typically just 30 minutes away from anywhere in Edinburgh.
And, so, if you like hills — Edinburgh has seven of these, and an extinct volcano to walk around. For beaches, you choose whatever style you like, and for parks, you’ll find one at every turn. But, the best thing, is that it is a truly enterprising and innovative city, that prides itself on its love of education and scientific advancement.
Cities are key to our future. They are economic drivers and places to innovation. Care for your city, and let it live.

Title: Edinburgh
Design System Day 2023
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
This week in Edinburgh, GDS hosted its first in-person Design System Day conference. Here are a few of my highlights from the day.
Dynamic Earth felt like a strangely appropriate place to host Design System Day 2023: the giant globe hanging above our heads was a fitting metaphor for the planetary consequences of national scale design decisions.
Samantha Ernstzen and Jennifer l’Anson reflected on the process of creating the Scottish Government Digital Design System.
Their purpose was refreshingly succinct:
“to enable teams within the Scottish public sector to design and build digital products that are accessible, usable and consistent for people accessing public services in Scotland.”
Adoption is always a challenge. Even with a strong design system, people can still put together bad forms with good components! We’ve all seen examples of digitised forms recreating the paper original, mirroring the many-boxes-per-page approach of the pre-digital era.
The challenge isn’t just educating government departments in how best to use a design system, it’s also getting external suppliers to embrace it.
Mandating use of an existing design system isn’t enough: we need to support agencies and consultancies in adopting it and implementing it successfully!
Ciandelle, Calvin and Steve gave a quickfire summary of all the updates GOV.UK have been making, including improving accessibility.
One newly released development is the Exit this page feature. It allows a user to quickly close down a page if they are in danger: particularly useful for those suffering domestic abuse. It may look like just a small button, but took about five years of work to research and implement!
Massive news: designers were delighted to hear that a new crown’s gonna drop — watch this space for a slightly modified GOV.UK logo coming soon!
Katrina Birch facilitated a fantastic panel on trauma-informed research and design.
70% of people have experienced trauma, and 1 in 10 will suffer from PTSD at some point in their life. We should be aware of trauma and the risk of vicarious trauma when conducting user research around difficult topics. Shout out to Chayn, getting an honourable mention for their excellent resources on the topic.
Tash Willcocks closed out the day with her thoughts on the elephant in the room: teams.
Design systems are enablers of scale and consistency, but developing and establishing them requires conditions of high trust and psychological safety.
In short, to save the parrots, we must use the shallot and master the elephant (I promise it made sense, you had to be there).
Thanks so much to all the volunteers and GDS-ers that made Design System Day 2023 possible: it was a glorious gathering of passionate practitioners!
A final quote from the day, sums up nicely the role of design in most organisations:
“We’re not here just to build components and patterns. We make impact through multiplier effects.”
Looking forward to next year!
--

Title: FREE SHOW AT EDINBURGH FRINGE
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
HOW TO MAKE THE BEST OF IT
I recall standing outside the Pleasance Dome flyering my show a few years ago.
I was exhausted and knew I had to fill a big room and faced losing cash so I was anxious and desperate to make sure people came to see me.
I had rented a good flat and paid for amazing posters and had what I believed to be a fabulous show.
Then I spotted a couple of people who had seen me at a showcase show and had taken my flyer after the gig as they liked my stuff. I brightened up and as I approached them I watched a comedy promoter hand them two free tickets to his latest newly signed act’s show.
They took them. They were FREE.
He had a HUGE wad of free tickets and was giving them to people all around the Pleasance Dome. I lost the sale. I watched and my heart sank as people didn’t give a fuck how funny I had been at the 1pm showcase show.
They had free tickets and free is everything in this current climate.
No doubt the fringe this year yet again will release the BEST EVER SALES AT THE FRINGE and sit back as they manipulate the figures and the PR will spin it good.
I know that the figures aren’t always true, for ONE BIG SELL OUT there are hundreds of smaller shows underwriting them in the big venues and those comics were doing it on their own cash in the hope of a crowd.
Performers go home skint, owing money and are artistically broken.
I have no issue with the big paid venues, I just see issues that the Free Festival can resolve.
On the last weekend of the last few fringe’s I watched BIG NAMED ACTS give away TWO for ONES on the last Thursday and Friday. That’s not a great financial sign and was I aggressively flyered for a comic whose face graces the BILLBOARDS to buy tickets for his ‘EXTRA SOLD OUT SHOW’ which is a weird oxymoron. It can’t be sold out and still have tickets to sell.
Also audience members must be horrified to find out they had paid full price for tickets and realised half the audience were in for free or HALF PRICE and that’s an insult to early bird ticket buyers.
People were so scared of losing face.
This year am back at The Counting House Ballroom as is my daughter comedian Ashley Storrie.
Last year both me and Ashley had a BUMPER run and played to full rooms every day. I had people sitting on the floor of my venue and Ashley had people standing in her room and outside for a chance to get in.
They put cash in the buckets. We left with a profit, a very good profit if truth be told. We also told the crowds if they donated silver and bronze coins we gave that to the homeless and later on we dished it out fairly round the city’s street collectors.
I encouraged other comics and acts to get up and pitch their shows to my big comedy loving full capacity crowd. I tweeted about other comics gigs and helped flyer for other shows. It felt like THE FRINGE.
The people who came to the shows were brilliant.
Dealing with hard cash was weird. I felt like a mid price day time sex worker, I haven’t had that much money in my bag in years. We generally don’t carry much cash as a society now. It reminded me of when I owned a pub and used to count the takings.
People no longer see the Free Festival shows as ‘well it’s free it must be shit’ and I don’t believe they ever did. This is a nice neat rumour and label put on it by the same people who resent the free shows but have no issue giving out free tickets at a paid venue for a show that can’t shift a ticket.
When I did all the big “paid” venues I made thousands of pounds but the financial cut left to me was woeful and I STILL made a profit am one of the few who did. My accountant was stunned by the business model that means you pay for seats in advance and a venue is guaranteed their cash and cut NO MATTER WHAT before you step foot in the capital. The artist takes all the risk. Every seat you dont sell the venue has already been paid for that, the loss is not theirs….it’s YOURS.
Think of it this way…
Imagine you hired a bus with twenty seats, you paid the company for twenty seats….if you only sold 6 of those seats, you lose money.
Now think of that in a 200 seater venue at the fringe where the market is SATURATED with comics giving away FREE SEATS AND TWO FOR ONE SEATS every single day. Now you see my point.
Tax was a well worn phrase when talking about the free venues.
“Yes, but do the free festival comics declare their takings?” one comedy promoter asked me.
I don’t think anybody has the right to assume anyone is fucking their taxes based on a dislike of their business model. If you have an issue with people not paying their due tax please go check some Tory peers before you nitpick at comics you avaricious cunts. While you are at it please make sure the big venues who boast “BEST YEAR EVER” are not putting their profits into an offshore account to avoid taxes in UK.
I pay my tax.
I love the fringe and the past few years doing free fringe shows means I have loved it more. It felt like the old days. It felt good and it felt fair.
I encouraged the people who were skint and living under austerity to come see our shows for free. I also encouraged people who saw the show to take money OUT OF THE BUCKET if they needed some cash.
some tips for acts putting on a FREE SHOW….
Me and My daughter Ashley Storrie are back at the Counting House this year.
--
--
I am an award winning Scottish stand up comedian. writer and actor. I podcast weekly and wrote my autobiography Handstands in the Dark —

Today marked the conclusion of our journey. We had been traveling for nine days and were eager to get home. It had been a while since we had unwinded and slept in our bed at home.

We went to a cafe and had a tuna sandwich with coffee. We strolled beside the Tay River. The River Tay is the longest river in Scotland and the seventh-longest in Great Britain.

Title: How was my experience at Edinburgh University and student Accommodation?
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
In the heart of Scotland lies a city steeped in history, culture, and academia: Edinburgh. Home to one of the world’s most prestigious universities, the University of Edinburgh, the city attracts students from all corners of the globe. Among the many challenges that come with starting a new chapter in a different city, finding the perfect accommodation stands as a pivotal moment in a student’s life.
Picture this: a vibrant young student, full of ambition and excitement, stepping foot into the historic cobblestone streets of Edinburgh. For many, this marks the beginning of an incredible journey towards higher education and personal growth. But behind this exciting new chapter lies a quest for the perfect place to call home during these formative years.
For Jamie, a student hailing from London, the search for student accommodation Edinburgh was both thrilling and daunting. Having been accepted into the University of Edinburgh’s prestigious business program, Jamie found himself faced with the task of finding accommodation that suited not only his budget but also his need for a conducive environment for studying.
The quest began online, scrolling through countless listings and options. From shared flats to purpose-built student accommodations, the choices seemed endless. Each listing had its unique charm, promising proximity to the university, modern facilities, and a vibrant community of fellow students.
After much deliberation, Jamie narrowed down his options to a few promising prospects. He decided to visit Edinburgh in person, a decision that would prove invaluable in his search. Stepping into the city, he was greeted by its rich history and the blend of old-world charm with a bustling modernity — a juxtaposition that captured his heart instantly.
His first visit was to a student housing complex located conveniently close to the university. As he walked through the doors, he was met with a lively atmosphere — students chatting in the common areas, engaging in study groups, and overall, a sense of community that was palpable. The rooms were modern, compact yet cozy, equipped with all the essentials a student could need. The allure of being surrounded by like-minded peers was tempting.
However, Jamie wanted to explore other options before making a decision. He ventured into the heart of the city, where charming old buildings were converted into student flats. The historic ambiance was undeniable, but the rooms were often smaller and lacked some of the modern amenities he had seen in the purpose-built accommodations.
Then came the visit to a shared flat — a common choice among students looking for a more independent living experience. The prospect of living with a few roommates excited Jamie. The flat was spacious, with each room uniquely decorated, reflecting the personalities of its occupants. The idea of creating a home away from home with fellow students felt appealing, fostering a sense of camaraderie.
After careful consideration and weighing the pros and cons of each option, Jamie ultimately chose to reside in the purpose-built student accommodation. Its proximity to the university, modern amenities, and the vibrant community it offered aligned perfectly with his aspirations for his university life.
Settling into his new accommodation, Jamie found himself surrounded by a diverse group of students — each with their own stories, cultures, and ambitions. The communal spaces became a hub for socializing, studying, and forging lifelong friendships.
Living in student accommodation in Edinburgh wasn’t just about having a place to stay; it was an integral part of Jamie’s university experience. It became the backdrop for late-night study sessions, impromptu gatherings, and the formation of lasting bonds.
As Jamie delved deeper into his studies, he realized that the choice of accommodation had a profound impact on his overall university journey. The convenience, the sense of community, and the support from fellow students made navigating the challenges of university life more manageable.
Looking back, Jamie reminisces about the thrill of finding the perfect place to live in Edinburgh. It wasn’t just a roof over his head; it was the cornerstone of his university adventure — a place where he didn’t just reside but truly belonged.
For any student venturing into the vibrant city of Edinburgh, the quest for accommodation may seem like a daunting task, but it’s a journey filled with choices that shape an unforgettable university experience — a journey much like Jamie’s, filled with exploration, decisions, and ultimately, a place to call home.

Title: Gregarious Glasgow
Content:
Sign up

Sign up

Listen

Glasgow, Edinburgh’s younger and cheekier brother. A winter’s visit to this exciting city filled me with a lot of excitement. The journey began with a night bus from London Victoria to Buchanan Street Station, north of the English/ Scottish border. As soon as I arrived on the bus, I was surrounded by the echoes of the thick Glaswegian accent. Coupled with that were men chewing away on Sainsbury’s 5 packs of donuts and mothers and daughters arguing about who had the window seat. Presumably the views from the Megabus up the M40 and M6 overnight weren’t to be missed. On arrival at 7am into Glasgow, it was still dark. I was due to visit one of my oldest friends, Greg Bond, however I would first be met by his namesake, Greggs, who provided me with a coffee and Pan au Chocolat to welcome me to Scotland. The sun only lights up the city 30 minutes after it would in London, which is also known for its excellent weather. I wandered through the chartered streets of the city where I was surprised by an incredible orange and yellow sunset that crept over the Lanarkshire hills and the schemes that fill Glasgow’s skyline.
Arching past the Glasgow Necropolis (the cemetery) and the Tennents beer factory, I wandered to the East End of the city to meet Greg and his girlfriend, Jess. We soon headed to Tibo Bistro, a local Scottish brunch eatery where I tried my first full Scottish breakfast. This included, black pudding and haggis, both of which I hadn’t tried for a very long time but were incredibly tasty. Glasgow has an excellent selection of restaurants, notably to add, the Ubiquitous Chip, which I previously visited in 2016 on my first visit to this city (I would highly recommend both of these places). The rest of the day would be spent hopping around bars and watching football, the hoops (Celtic) no less were playing at home and some of the bars refused to show the premier league but rather would show the Scottish games. It’s understandable, really. You got a real sense of how strong the local identity is in Glasgow. Not only from the accent and their pride towards either Rangers or Celtic Football Clubs but also from their use of language. Words you would never use in the South of England, or internationally in this language. ‘Spu*k’, ‘C*nt’ and ‘Sh*te’ are all very much on the table and part of the local tongue. Jess mentioned this is just part of the Glasgwegian identity and people of all ages, with the exception of really formal events or in the company of elderly family, would people liberallly use these words. For example, Jess said ‘I don’t want to sp*nk all my money away travelling’. The sense of irony was real for me here.
We stopped for a bite to eat at a chicken burger joint, complemented naturally by a pint of Tennents, of course. Here, we met Greg’s friends Gus, with whom he shared his birthday event with that evening and Zac, who I’d met many moons ago while he and Greg were at university here. We then headed to a bar called the rum shack, where we met more of their friends, most of whom were from Greg and Gus’ former and current hockey clubs. Being in Glasgow and with a lot of sporty, sociable folks, this made for quite a drink heavy evening. We played a game called ‘ou l’est le poulet’, which literally translates from French as ‘where is the chicken?’. Here, Gus and Greg identified themselves as the ‘chickens’ and they organised a kitty of money for drinks for them and whoever could find them throughout the night. They selected 15–20 bars within a few miles radius of the rum shack and they said the first to meet us at the one they were at will be able to benefit from the complimentary drinks from the budget. The first there would receive a Champagne reception. Luckily, I was with two local Glaswegian blokes who knew Greg, Gus and the city very well so we made it to this grand reception after stopping at only 2 other pubs on the way to the Ivory hotel. The Ivory was an eyesore geographically away from the collection of other proposed pubs. We thought we’d go and check it just to be sure, but we didn’t genuinely believe that they’d actually be there. As the rest of the groups arrived, we then settled into the drinks from the kitty as well as some tasty nachos. The night continued from the Ivory hotel to another bar in town. After 12 hours on the beers on the back of a night bus, I decided to call it an evening before my flight home in the morning back to London town. All in all, I’d highly recommend this city for food, drinking and a good time watching sport. But keep an eye and an ear open for the Glaswegian tongue.

Title: Slow Train from Edinburgh
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
When Henry was a wee one I read to him every night. He’d pick two or three picture books from his bookshelf, and we’d cuddle in the couch or his bed, and read together. As a train fanatic he had quite a few train books, and Slow Train from Oxmox was one of his favorites.
The little book was about just that, a slow train goes through the country and encounters animals and assorted obstacles. It’s whimsical and cheerful, perfect for a night time story.
When I spent a little over two weeks in London in April, one of my goals was to venture outside the city and explore other parts of UK. I picked Edinburgh for the second weekend. For years Edinburgh Yarn Festival was one of the go-to fiber events in Europe, and I’m still kicking myself for not making it in 2019, because no one knew that was going to be the last one. Regardless, Edinburgh the city still held my intense interest and I decided that was my destination for the weekend.
The train from Kings Cross Station in London to Edinburgh is a little over five hours on LNER line (LNER stands for London North Eastern Railway and is pronounced with the letters spelled out, not “liner” as I first thought), and the route goes along the east side of England, at some point right by the beach. The views are stunning. — Side note, after the trip I rewatched Harry Potter movies. I can’t tell you how thrilling it was to see the LNER trains in the background every time they were in Kings Cross Station.
I took off from London on Friday morning, spent Friday evening to Sunday morning in Edinburgh. I booked the return trip to leave around 1:30pm, so I’d have lunch in Edinburgh and be back in London for dinner. The train ride is very comfortable with free wifi and electric outlets, so I could listen to my audiobook while knitting, or napping. I had a window seat facing forward as I picked, and most of the time the seat next to me was empty.
About an hour outside of London, suddenly there was loud metal screeching and the train lurched forward, eventually came to a stop, but not before there was a big thump, hitting something big. Soon the conductor’s voice came through the scratchy speaker, yes, there was a deer on the track and the train hit it; yes, the engineers would have to check out the damage, and no, no one could get off the train. Of course they would keep the passengers updated. But what about Bambi??
So we wait. Every ten minutes or so the conductor came on the speaker, still checking the damage, getting help from the next station, possibly moving everyone to another train. Just how big was Bambi? Maybe Bambi was a big boy with big horns, big enough to cause the train to lose air pressure. The next, closest, station was fifteen minutes away, and from the conductor’s voice, the engineers wondered aloud if the train would be able to go that far with the damage, or have another train fetch all the passengers. Neither option seem comforting when you are in the middle of the beautiful but remote English countryside. I looked on Google Map and the only thing nearby was a tiny nursery school. I wondered where the kids came from.
More than an hour after the thump, a train materialized itself on the track next to our train, going the same direction(!), and very slowly came to a stop(!!). Passengers started moving around, gathering their bags— are we being rescued? How do we all fit in that already packed train? Before we knew it, just like how it came, the train slowly started moving again, and minutes later, gone.
Now what? I’m sure I wasn’t the only one started calculating how much water and food might be in our luggage and in the dining car.
Apparently the other train dropped off some engineers, because soon there were a bunch of people in bright neon green and orange garb walking along the tracks, toward the head of our train.
More waiting. Thirty minutes later the train moved! And continued to run like nothing happened, till it unceremoniously stopped at the next station, Peterborough, where everyone was ordered to pack their things and depart, find their own ways. I guess all this was announced in the running gargles from the conductor, and I wasn’t the only one confused once we landed on the cold platform. Now it’s up to this tiny station to deal with hundreds of unexpected passengers heading to London, already delayed for hours.
You got to give it to the British for efficiency. The little station handled the glitch better than most American airports. The digital display spelled out clearly how many trains are passing and heading to Kings Cross in the next hour, which cars had seats, and what section of the platform had the best chance to get on the train. No one checked tickets. The bathroom queue went from over fifty to none. By the third train most people were out of the station and on their way to London.
I arrived at Kings Cross past 11pm, more than four hours after planned, cold and hungry. I was ready for a hot meal and warm bed.

Share
Edinburgh during the fringe is a glorious celebration of the artistic spirit, with any tourist walking down the Royal Mile sure to be deluged with flyers from young people eager to promote their low-budget show. While having a coffee in George Square, I was approached by someone hawking a one-person re-enactment of the Titanic disaster, an improvised musical called Shamilton and a lady (with a haystack hairdo) impersonating Melania Trump.
But the image that most visitors will take away from the 2022 fringe is of overflowing rubbish bins and gutters strewn with discarded coffee cups and takeaway meal cartons. The binmen were on a two-week strike. The dispute has since spread through much of the rest of Scotland.
The refuse collectors are protesting about a 5% pay offer which they rightly point out will not match the rate of inflation. The pay “rise” is thus, in real terms, a pay cut. Small wonder that they are protesting.
But the speed with which Edinburgh descended into slovenliness is an illustration of the theme I wrote about in my last book, More; that our standard of living depends on the efforts and co-operation of millions of strangers. It is not just that we eat food that was grown on the other side of the world or rely on communication tools made in Asia. We depend on our fellow citizens to educate our children, keep us healthy, defend our borders and clean our streets.
This co-operation faces two interlinked threats. The first is that international trade in goods and services relies on a willingness to trust other countries, and to place economic interests above strategic desires. The first great era of globalisation in the late 19th century saw vast levels of migration from Europe to the “new worlds” of North and South America, and monetary co-operation that allowed the Bank of England to borrow from its counterparts in France and Russia when its gold reserves were low. But it all disintegrated with the outbreak of war in 1914; world trade (as measured by exports as a proportion of GDP) did not recover until the 1970s.
The late 19th century era has been dubbed the “pax Britannica” as Britain was the centre of the international monetary system (the gold standard) and, through its navy, ensured that global seaborne trade was safe from piracy. And the post-1945 era could be dubbed the “pax Americana” as the US supported its European (and Japanese allies) both militarily and economically. The collapse of the Soviet Union and the post-Mao change in Chinese economic policy brought most of the world into the global trading system.
Might we see another great reversal? There is little evidence of it in the data so far. But the rhetoric is headed in one direction: sanctions on Russia, tariffs on China and a determination in many countries, after the pandemic, to ensure that some strategically important goods are produced at home. The recent sabre-rattling of China over Taiwan might be an indicator of the next tipping point.
The second threat to co-operation lies in domestic politics. In part, this stems from globalisation which is perceived in many western countries as being good for the highly-educated elite but bad for ordinary workers. There has definitely been a slowdown in the growth rate of real earnings of the average worker in recent decades and in most countries, rising inequality. There is a vigorous debate among economists as to the causes of this shift with technological change playing at least as big a role as globalisation.
But this sluggish growth in real incomes has broken the contract between politicians and the people they govern, in which votes are supplied in return for increased prosperity. That has fuelled the disillusionment with politicians that was the subject of an earlier book of mine, The Last Vote. This discontent has meant constraints in democracy in some countries where its roots are shallow, such as Russia and Hungary. And in western countries it has led to the rise of “nativist” politicians like Donald Trump and Marine Le Pen, who imply that a “globalist” elite is plotting to undermine their countries.
How serious is this threat? It is easy to forget that Donald Trump lost the popular vote in both 2016 and 2020, taking office only because of the vagaries of the electoral college system. But his attempt to cling on to office in 2020 showed how tenuous are the institutional supports for democracy in the US; it was only the honesty of a few Republican officials in swing states that prevented him from stealing the election. In this category, one might add the outrageous attempt by the Conservative party to prorogue the British Parliament in 2019, a step that was blocked by the Supreme Court in an 11–0 decision.
In her book “How Civil Wars Start”, Barbara Walter details her research into the crucial factors that can cause a descent into chaos; excessive factionalism, the politics of resentment and the existence of armed groups. In particular, she refers to the existence of “anocracy” where a nominal democracy exists but the institutional structure that supports it (independent courts, a free press etc) have been undermined.
Anocracies can often descend into dictatorship, as Russia has shown. But they can head in another direction, as happened in Lebanon in the 1980s and Yugoslavia as the state’s authority disintegrates into regional and religious factions. Ms Walter is not predicting a re-enactment of the US Civil War of the 1860s, with uniformed armies fighting pitched battles, but a steady descent into chaos.
And if one looks at history, it is replete with examples of states disintegrating in the face of internal and external challenges. The western Roman empire was declining long before Rome was sacked in 410CE or Romulus Augustulus, the last emperor, was deposed in 476CE. The Hapsburg dynastic empire, steadily assembled over many centuries, disintegrated within weeks in 1918. Chaos is as likely an outcome as dictatorship.
The concept that Britain is only “four meals away from anarchy” has been used by MI5 to assess strategic risks and variations of the quote have been attributed to Lenin and the scifi writers Larry Niven and Jerry Pournelle. The original quote seems to have come from Alfred Henry Lewis back in 1896 who wrote” that the only barrier between us and anarchy is the last nine meals we’ve had” .
Back in the 1970s, a time when the country was rocked by high inflation, strikes and energy shortages, there was talk that Britain was “ungovernable”. There have been moments since then, notably during the riots of 2011, when the veneer of society has worn very thin.
The very connections that supply us with our food, energy and gadgets are also a source of our vulnerability, which could come in the form of embargoes, blockades or cyberattacks. Specialisation, which is at the heart of the modern economy, means that few of us have the means or the expertise to support ourselves.
Turmoil in America also affects the rest of the developed world since the post-1945 global settlement is built on the US’s economic and military strength. In 410CE, faced with Saxon incursions, the British wrote to Rome to appeal for help (according to one historical account). The emperor Honorius replied that they must look to their own defence. Isolationists in the US argue that Europe should do the same.
One can map out a future for the world in which the bonds that tie together the US and Europe disintegrate in the face of Russian and Chinese pressure, declining living standards provoke unrest at home which leads to violence on the streets, and public services break down leading to an even further decline in welfare.
This outcome is still only a possibility rather than a probability. But it is an outcome we should all consider before voting for those who would destroy the global economic structure.
--
--
Former Economist and FT columnist. Author of More, Paper Promises, The Last Vote and The Money Machine

Title: My Job as a Student Ambassador — The University of Edinburgh
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

This society is dedicated to honoring the lifetime work and achievements of Paul Ewing, geology teacher at Arbroath High School. He inspired 100s of students into the scientific field of geology and the wider geosciences. This society aims to inspire 100s more!

--
Listen
Share
I am a Student Ambassador with the University of Edinburgh. My job is to give tours of the university to visitors, prospective students and to anybody who is interested in the university. I mostly work for the department of Student Recruitment and Admissions and for Edinburgh Global, but I can be contracted by any department of the university. I am expected to help out on Open Days, School Visits, Alumni Events, teacher training sessions and on visits from International Delegations of other Universities.
On Open Days I give out leaflets, show people around the campus and just make them feel in general comfortable around the university.
In some cases I go on Schools visits either with my department of the School of Geosciences or the general student recruitment team.
Being a Student Ambassador is a real job with real pay. I even have a LinkedIn entry on it!
https://uk.linkedin.com/in/hunor-de%C3%A1k-458503121
I conduct university tours around the Central Campus/King’s Buildings, do office work, take part in student Q&A sessions, help with student support staff training, represent the university on school visits and help to organise/run university Open Days. I work for the Student Recruitment & Admissions, Edinburgh Global and Go Abroad Edinburgh.
Student Ambassadors are the face of the University of Edinburgh to prospective students, their parents/carers and teachers/advisers. The Student Ambassador team consists of 75 students, both UG and PG, from a range of Schools, Colleges, backgrounds and nationalities. The scheme is primarily designed to support the work of the Student Recruitment and Admissions Team and Edinburgh Global, however, from time to time Student Ambassadors have the opportunity to work for a range of other departments from around the University.
This is the official spiel. Looked over by university officials and decided in advance. To be honest I don’t really like this description, as it removes the honesty from my work.
In reality being a student ambassador is so much more than a job! It is a gift and an experience.
I get to work with a diverse range of people, and a diverse age range of people. I showed Primary school pupils around Appleton Tower, I introduced Scottish food to new students from around the globe and helped run an event at St Cecilia’s Hall for the old Alumni who graduated with the university 40–50 years ago. As a Student Ambassador I met such a nice number of people.
I worked under the wings of so many interesting university leaders as well.
Through the scheme I met so many fellow Student Ambassadors, that if I would have a thousand hands with hundreds of fingers I wouldn’t be able to count them! I met people from St. Petersburg, Florida, Vienna, the Netherlands, south California. I saw a wide range of departments from helping to host a music night to the alumni at St Cecilia’s Hall to handing out goodie bags to the newly graduated students of the University. I have done everything from office work for ERASMUS+ to waste management and moving boxes in the dungeons.
Being a Student Ambassador helped to improve my speaking skills, trained me to work better as a member of a group and gave me a greater range of confidence.
The University of Edinburgh is an ancient Scottish institution that educated the great Men of the Scottish Enlightenment, revolutionised the world of science and produced global leaders.
The university is a warm and welcoming place where I built up lots of skills for employment.
Step into the world that is the University of Edinburgh!
Originally published at https://blogs.ed.ac.uk on February 9, 2020.
--

This society is dedicated to honoring the lifetime work and achievements of Paul Ewing, geology teacher at Arbroath High School. He inspired 100s of students into the scientific field of geology and the wider geosciences. This society aims to inspire 100s more!

Title: Edinburgh: A City of Magic, Memories, and The Fringe
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Peter Drake, a teacher from Hexham in Britain, spent many years in the classroom encouraging the learning of science. In recent years, Peter has found a new path in writing, music, and the arts. Today, he uses his experience to inspire others, proving that life after teaching can be just as rewarding and full of new adventures and doesn’t need to take place in the classroom.
Some cities make an impression the moment you arrive. Others take a little time, revealing their beauty and character slowly. Edinburgh, however, is in a category all of its own — a place that doesn’t just leave an impression but sears itself into your memory, heart, and soul. For me, Edinburgh’s allure is most powerful during that extraordinary moment each year when the Edinburgh Festival Fringe transforms the city into the beating heart of global creativity.
Every August, this historic Scottish capital erupts into life, laughter, noise, and energy. Streets that are usually relatively calm thrum with a chaotic symphony of buskers, actors, dancers, musicians, and visitors from all corners of the world. Cafés spill over with animated conversation, parks host pop-up performances, and every available space — from traditional theatres to tiny basements — is pressed into service for the arts. If ever a city could wear joy like a cloak, it is Edinburgh during the Fringe.
I feel deeply connected to Edinburgh, not least because of my own unforgettable experience of the Fringe. Some years ago, my play, The Prisoner’s Friend, was performed during the festival. Seeing a piece of writing, crafted over months of quiet work, take on a new life before an audience of strangers in such a vibrant setting was a defining moment for me. There is something intoxicating about watching people react to your words — to hear them laugh, to see them fall silent with emotion, to feel that invisible thread of understanding stretch between stage and audience. For anyone who has created, performed, or even simply spectated during the Fringe, the memory leaves an indelible mark.
During that month, the city itself becomes more than just a backdrop; it feels like an active participant in the festival. The ancient streets and winding closes seem to lean in, listening. The grand, stern buildings of the New Town provide a dramatic stage set, while the narrow, atmospheric lanes of the Old Town whisper history and secrets around every corner. There’s a profound sense that Edinburgh is uniquely suited to house such an explosion of creativity — a city proud of its culture, deeply aware of its own myths and legends, yet refreshingly willing to let loose and celebrate the new.
Of course, part of what makes the Fringe experience so powerful is the sense of freedom it offers. Nowhere else in the world can so many performers, both seasoned professionals and complete beginners, share space so democratically. Whether your production has a massive budget or is fueled solely by passion and a few hand-painted posters, the Fringe offers a platform. It is, at heart, a celebration of taking a risk, of putting yourself and your art in front of the world without guarantees or safety nets.
That spirit permeated everything during the time I spent there. Days were crammed with rehearsals, flyering on the Royal Mile, frantic last-minute set changes, and post-show discussions in packed pubs. Nights were filled with laughter, new friendships, and a thrilling sense of community. For one glorious month, you become part of a tribe — a massive, sprawling, creative tribe that welcomes anyone willing to leap into the unknown.
I often think about those August days and nights, and the way they stand in contrast to the quieter months when the festival has packed up and the city breathes a little easier. Yet even outside of August, Edinburgh remains magnificent. Climb Arthur’s Seat for a panoramic view of a city that seamlessly marries medieval and modern. Walk through the peaceful elegance of the Georgian New Town, with its perfectly symmetrical streets and squares. Explore the mysteries of the Old Town, where narrow closes and hidden courtyards make you feel as though you might step into another century.
And always, whether it’s August or April, the city’s commitment to culture shines through. From the National Museum of Scotland to the Scottish National Gallery, from the historic libraries to the storytelling centres, Edinburgh is a place where history, art, and ideas are not just preserved but celebrated.
For me personally, the emotional connection to Edinburgh will always be anchored in that heady, transformative experience of the Fringe. It’s not just about the performances or the audiences — it’s about being part of something larger than yourself. It’s about feeling, even for a brief time, that you are contributing to a shared celebration of imagination, creativity, and human connection.
Every year when August rolls around, I feel a twinge of longing. I picture the crowds gathering, the pop-up stages going up, the laughter echoing down the cobbled streets. I imagine first-time performers nervously stepping onto stages, writers seeing their characters come to life, audiences discovering unexpected delights in hidden venues.
Few who have performed at the Fringe ever forget it. The highs are high, the lows can be humbling, but the memories are golden. Whether your show draws a full house or plays to a handful, whether you win awards or simply win the respect of your peers, the experience changes you. It reminds you that art matters. That risk matters. That connection — raw, real, immediate connection — is what we all crave, and occasionally, in a special place like Edinburgh during the Fringe, we find it.
In a world that sometimes feels increasingly fragmented and divided, that spirit of celebration and connection feels more precious than ever. And so I will always hold Edinburgh close — not just as a stunning city of history and beauty, but as a place where, for a brief, shining moment, anything feels possible.
For another of my articles (how to prevent the onset of dementia) please click here
Peter Drake is a retired teacher from Hexham, a historic town in the UK and spent many years inspiring students in classrooms across Britain. Today, he focuses on writing, music, and community projects, finding new ways to keep learning and sharing knowledge beyond the school environment. Peter’s story shows that there is life after teaching, especially when negativity is banned and creativity leads the way.

“This is a city of shifting light, of changing skies, of sudden vistas. A city so beautiful it breaks the heart again and again.”
― Alexander McCall Smith
As the sun rises, I watch the city of Edinburgh slowly revealed… a dark foggy nothingness giving way to a thousand rooftops accented by a spire here and there, dark and unfocused at first, but gradually taking on shape, form, and color. Finally, the edge of the sun peeks over the horizon and dazzling light spills into and across the room, putting a sudden and audible end to muffled conversations.
The bride and groom touch, and she whispers something softly into his ear. Both turn to look out the open window. On the table beside them, a once-full bottle of fine malt, a dozen empty glasses, and a stone jug of spring water sit where they were last touched.
“Wow… Look at that!” from the kilted man wearing the splendid red uniform tunic.
I have no words to adequately describe the scene being painted below as the sun continues its steady, lazy morning stretch, revealing a hilltop here, a wisp of smoke from a chimney there, the ancient castle perched to our left, and the blue ocean in the distance bathed…

Title: My First 6 Months In Edinburgh
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
Let’s all collectively ignore that this article is late (I need a lot of grace these days 😭)
Hi guys! It’s been a HOT minute (ironically😅). I know, I take full responsibility for my prolonged absence. The past several months have been a lot; mentally, emotionally, and physically. I can only say thank God for His grace through it all.
I have a lot to say and so much gist for you guys
The first thing I’d like to share is the different aspects of my first half-year on the other side of the globe.
Transportation
One of my favourite things about living here is the transportation system. Gone are the days of fighting passengers to enter a bus and fighting bus conductors for change. The transportation system I have experienced here (mostly buses) is more comfortable and seamless.
Most buses I’ve used are double-decker with an upper level for passengers to sit. Bus fares are paid with exact amounts, prepaid bus cards, free bus travel cards, or contactless payment methods. And yes, I said free bus travel. Scotland has free bus travel for under 22s, over 60s and disabled travellers.
There are accessibility accommodations on buses such as designated seats for elderly travellers, disabled travellers, and people with buggies.
For the most part, you don’t have to wait endlessly for the bus. Bus delays are often communicated on electronic displays at bus stops and Google Maps (which is usually more accurate). Any changes in bus stops or bus routes are well communicated to passengers in advance.
Besides the buses, there are trams and trains, modes of transportation that I wasn’t familiar with before living here. Cycling is also a thing here (I’ve even tossed around the idea of getting a bicycle a few times).
Since being here, I have learnt to embrace walking as part of my everyday life. These days a 21-minute walk is just a nice little exercise. The roads are well-designed to accommodate pedestrian traffic and motorists obey traffic rules, so I no longer have hypertension whenever I cross the road.
Compared to how clueless I was when I first arrived, I’ve largely settled into making my way downtown, walkin’ fast faces pass and I’m home-bound (tadadadadada). Ma da mi loun, I’m not a serious geh😜
Every once in a while though, I miss the thrill of rushing around and the fun of Danfo drama, I’m a Lagos girl after all.
Advice: Wear comfortable shoes, walking becomes a part of you
Weather
The stark difference in weather has been the most jarring part of moving to Edinburgh. I’ve never lived in a place with four actual seasons before and it’s an experience I can’t fully express. So far, I’ve experienced Winterrrr 🥶, gorgeous Spring, Summer (ish), and Autumn-yet to be decided.
Winter almost broke me😭
It was cold, or as the wobble-headed narrator of the Oversimplified YouTube channel says “STUPID COLD!” I made many a perilous journey to and from class, but like they say, what doesn’t kill you makes you stronger 💪🏽. I held out hope every freezing day, for the relief of a warm summertime that everyone seemed to eagerly expect.
UNFORTUNATELY, it was all a SCAM! 😭
Spring was cold, Summer was cold, Autumn is COLD.
Oh, and apart from the low temperatures, there are wind speeds that go over vehicle speed limits and rains that appear out of nowhere. It is a fascinating experience.
Am I used to it? I don’t think it’s something to get used to honestly. I want to get used to nice things; like someone spending money on me, living a baby girl lifestyle, you know, nice things.
Advice: Expect any weather, and always carry an umbrella
The Environment, The People
Scotland is beautiful and Edinburgh is stunning.
As erratic as the weather can be here, the skies are a deep and beautiful shade of blue, the sun (when it decides to grace us with its presence) shoots down golden rays to illuminate the greenery, and on the rarest of occasions, I have seen the most perfectly coloured rainbows adorn a pale-bright sky.
The city is a spectacular landscape surrounded by hills and dotted with the most luscious trees and shrubs. Breathtaking (see Exhibit A below). Exploring Edinburgh’s rich scenery, heritage and uniqueness deserves a post of its own (coming soon? fingers crossed)
Now for the people.
At this point, I’m pretty sure Scottish people don’t speak English. They speak a language only they can understand. Fair warning: if you can understand English, don’t expect to automatically understand Scottish English.
Picture this: You go to eat at a fancy with a whole bar section for drinks. You look at the list of nice-sounding beverages and decide you're too broke (for now) to afford them, so you walk up to the bar and ask for a glass of water. You’re greeted with a smile and a nod. “This is going well.” you think as the bartender fills a glass with tap water (don’t worry, it’s clean). You’re about to stretch your hand when the bartender asks “Dyu like some aeyce?” Now you’re lost. “What is aeyce?” “Does it cost extra?” “How do I respond?”.
The bartender senses the activation of your flight-freeze response and points at the ice bucket next to the counter. Ice. He’s asking if you want ice 🤦🏽‍♀️
Excuse me for that long scenario, I haven’t written fiction in a while and I quite enjoyed that.
Back to the story.
Their weird rendition of English aside, I see Scottish people like regular people, with the good and the not-so-good. There’s a general “mind your business” vibe here which isn’t necessarily good or bad. However, seeing some of the effects of this way of life has made me appreciate that the cultural system of community involvement in personal and interpersonal matters can be quite valuable.
Edinburgh is full of people from all over the world, which is expected of any tourist city. Going from a racially homogenous place like Nigeria to a vastly multicultural hub like this is like exploring a whole new world. I have heard many new languages, seen many new faces and experienced many new cultures.
Side note: I finally ate Chinese, Indian and Italian food; it was all delicious, you should try them too.
Community (Nigerian shops, Nigerian students, Nigerian food)
This probably goes without saying, but there are Nigerians in Edinburgh. There are Nigerian grocery shops and hairstylists in Edinburgh. Just as in places like London and Manchester, there is a flourishing Nigerian community in Edinburgh.
When I arrived at my school, I was surprised to be surrounded by Nigerians in class and at the hostel. In some ways, it felt like I never left Nigeria. Ironically, I have learnt more about Nigeria in Edinburgh than I ever learnt in Nigeria.
Having a community of people who can relate to my perspective is refreshing. I’ve made some great friends here who are simply amazing.
Side note: I’ve also made friends from other countries; trust me, it’s not as hard as it seems.
I’m loving my time here in Edinburgh, and getting that nice abroad weight gain (no exhibits here). I’ll share more about my life in Edinburgh as time goes on. Let me know any specific things you want me to talk about😊.
I’ll try not to disappear for too long next time. Thank you for your constant support and patience. I love you guys!
--

Title: Edinburgh’s cycle storage challenge
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Since 2016, Edinburgh council has slowly been rolling out on-street storage for cyclists. In the last year, the number of hangars has doubled from 100 to over 200.
64% of Edinburgh households live in flats, and we know that finding somewhere to store a bicycle is one of the more important barriers to people moving around on two wheels. With about 300,000 people in capital in such a predicament, and with 6 spots per cycle hangar… you can do the maths.
One hangar location near Stockbridge has 142 people on the waiting list.
It is therefore not a surprise that the new hangars are massively over-subscribed. The waiting list has grown to 3,400, including those in the queue for an existing hangar and those who have requested one.
This latent demand for cycling is being realised, and in a big way. As new hangars go in they become a visible part of our public realm and more and more people become aware of them.
As things stand, the council will need to install a further 560 hangars to meet demand. Over 1,000 people joined the queue in the last year or so; if replicated this year, that’s another 170 hangars required on top of that.
Yet the council only has plans for around another 160.
Each cycle hangar takes up the space taken by one car. Parking permits are a significant source of revenue for the council. But so are cycle hangars…
At full price, a cycle hangar spot costs £72 per year. That compares favourably with car parking, which is either free in most of the city, or £36.50 for a zero carbon emissions car (except in the very centre of the city, where it’s £73.70).
Taking that £36.50 figure, each hangar will generate 12 times as much revenue as a car parking spot. That doesn’t take into account maintenance costs of the hangars, but after all the negative externalities associated with cars… it’s a good investment.
Indeed, if the council were a private business, they’d push those prices up even higher to meet demand.
Cycle hangars have been so far placed in the more prosperous parts of the city; Marchmont, Newington, Bruntsfield, Portobello — you get the picture. This is efficient work from the council as most of the demand for the cycle hangars is located in these areas.
However, conscious of the social inequity of providing such infrastructure in only the richer parts of town, a number of hangars have been located in areas of high deprivation. Even better, these are provided at a subsidised cost of only £1.50 a month.
This has not been successful. Some of these hangars are those few that have not been populated by bicycles. It is my view that the barriers to cycling for those on the lowest incomes remain the relatively large capital investment associated with the bicycle itself. The low cost and low risk associated with Lothian Buses’ excellent service is difficult to beat.
An interactive map of hangars, waiting lists and demand can be found here: LINK
This article has been based on a Freedom of Information request to Edinburgh City Council, which you can find here: LINK
While there is precise location data for existing hangars, requests for hangars are made on a street-by-street basis. I have used the postcode associated with each street and used the centroid of that postcode area to map requests.

I stood at the gated entrance on Candlemaker Row of the 16th-century Greyfriars Kirkyard. The wind whipped the leafless trees, and the sky threatened to rain. The weather was suitable for exploring a graveyard, especially one that proclaims to be the most haunted graveyard in the world in one of the most haunted cities, Edinburgh, Scotland.
Although I had not been there before, there was something familiar about the place as soon as I walked in.
It was my second visit to Edinburgh, and this time, I returned in January when the hordes of tourists were gone. I had seen the city’s most well-known sights, like Edinburgh Castle, Holyrood Palace, and the Royal Mile, which left me free to explore lesser-known places.
Greyfriars Kirkyard piqued my interest as I read a list of suggested things to do in Edinburgh. The graveyard was established during the reign of Mary, Queen of Scots, and was full of victims from the Black Plague and the witch hunts of the 16th and 17th centuries, in which around four thousand…

Content:

Last time I lived in Edinburgh it was 1993. I moved there with a bunch of friends after university. As you might expect from a group of people who’d spent more time in the pub than in the lecture theatre, none of us had managed to get a proper graduate job.
It was the middle of a recession so we figured we’d go hang out in Edinburgh, continue the party lifestyle, do some temp work and maybe even find a job to make our parents proud.
At that time no one had heard of She Who Must Not Be Named, although funnily enough 1993 was the year that she moved to Edinburgh. She’d already sketched the outline for the Harry Potter books but in 1993 J.K. Rowling began writing in cafes such as Nicolson’s (now Spoon) and no doubt was influenced by the city’s history and architecture.
Our Edinburgh at that time revolved around nights out at indie and alternative clubs like the Mission in Victoria Street, Evol or FBI in the Cowgate, various pubs in the Grassmarket and around the University, live music at the Preservation Hall or the Ensign Ewart and visits to the many art galleries and museums (all of which were free).
We’d walk all over the city and I truly loved it. But all good things come to an end, and…

Title: 4 reasons why the Kimpton Charlotte Square is the most romantic hotel in Edinburgh
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

The world is vast, beautiful, abundant and rich. Explore it.

--
1
Listen
Share
Edinburgh’s charm is so idyllic, it’s been a muse to writers for centuries. It’s only fitting that this is where the Kimpton Charlotte Square sits, a serene hideaway, full to overflowing with everything needed for a romantic escape. I recently stayed two nights there on a wedding anniversary tour of Edinburgh where I found four reasons why this hotel is the most romantic in the city.
Follow the author to be notified when new luxury travel articles are published.
Close your eyes and imagine a scene from a classic piece of literature (one of the cheerier volumes). What you dreamed up likely comes very close to the Kimpton Charlotte Square. A wicker basket props up black Mary Poppins umbrellas next to a stately Georgian door. Red bicycles fitted with silver bells patiently wait for their next outing on a herringbone tile floor. A dancing fire in a massive stone fireplace warms the room and the mood. A couple chats animatedly in the library and garden greenery weaves its way from the outdoors in, bringing a taste of a summer garden with it. This was what greeted us as we explored the common rooms on our first night. Even story settings don’t get as romantic as this.
On our second night, we decided to take a dip in the indoor swimming pool. There’s nothing like a spontaneous swim, taken purely for fun (with no attempt to get a workout in) to bring up memories of the exciting first rush of love. Do try it.
When the day draws you and your love outside, Edinburgh is at your feet, literally. Kimpton Charlotte Square is in New Town (built between 1767 and 1890 while Old Town is medieval). Shops full of Harris Tweed tartan handbags and beautifully packaged shortbread biscuits, plus one-of-a-kind treasures are two to ten minutes away on foot. Edinburgh wasn’t bombed as badly as London was during WW2, so the gorgeous period architecture is laid out in unbroken ribbons along the city’s cobbled streets. The baked goods in Edinburgh are second-to-none. If you’ve never tried chocolate and caramel-topped millionaire shortbread, you haven’t lived. Don’t miss out; it will transform your expectations of dessert forever. Cabs or buses are plentiful when it’s time to go to Old Town. Or, if you don’t mind a very scenic walk, Old Town can be reached in about 20 minutes on foot. As you’re bound to get distracted constantly by fabulous shops and scenery, plan for more.
Discovering a tin full of goodies in the room was my first delightful foodie surprise. Rich chocolate bars and well-chosen savoury snacks fed my habit of late-night snacking on both nights of our stay. Even better was dinner on our second night. We ate our fill at BABA, a restaurant that feels like the best version of a Middle Eastern bazaar. BABA is a vibrantly hued maze of open areas that buzz with conversation, and intimate tables framed with heavy velvet curtains, made for a quiet meal. My hummus and pita bread was so wonderful, I nearly skipped to dessert. I’m glad I didn’t though, as the cod with grilled celeriac and cashews was tender and flavourful. My husband had the pork with red pepper ketchup, feta cheese and banana chilies, which he must have loved as he cleaned his plate.
For variety, there are two other restaurants on-site, Aizle (featuring a six-course tasting menu) and The Garden, a scenic, light-filled café that serves coffee and sandwiches until 3 PM.
After dinner and a day of exploration, I craved a hot shower and soft bed. I got both in our beautiful one-bedroom partitioned suite that overlooked the front steps of the hotel and Charlotte Square beyond. The suite’s sitting room and bedroom are separated by a partial wall under a high ceiling. Of all the room’s brilliant décor, I liked the drawing of wily rabbits best — its outright whimsy juxtaposed nicely with the downy velvet drapes and refined upholstered sofa. The super king bed’s duvet was so nice — crisp, spotless, and had just the right weight. Snuggling under it while watching TV and reliving our day surrounded by a beautiful room full of beautiful things was wonderful and terribly romantic.
As I write this, I want to go back and package up the room to bring home and make ours, but I suppose the fantasy needs to stay in Edinburgh where it fits to tailor-made perfection.
The Kimpton Charlotte Square is a fantastic hotel in a city that falls in my top three world-wide. I particularly recommend the hotel to couples looking for a romantic getaway as it is the most romantic hotel in Edinburgh. Tip: For access to the best selection of room types and seasonal specials, book directly on Kimpton Charlotte Square’s official website.
It wasn’t until I caught sight of the building that I realised I had been a guest of the hotel before, years ago. At that time it had another name. I am delighted with the improvements Kimpton has made. I liked the hotel very much before, but it is even better now, particularly in the areas of interior design and cuisine. Kudos to Kimpton!
My gratitude to Naomi Cameron of 3x1 for expertly arranging my time at the hotel. Thank you, Naomi! You’re a credit to your company.
--
--

Title: The Grand Scotsman
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
On my way out of Edinburgh I stopped for my final EB in the land of kilts, sporrans, and Harris Tweed. My suitcase was bulging with Scotch Whiskey miniatures, a framed picture of puffins, and a natty little hat that would absolutely suit the Canberra winter, but not the Scottish Summer.
I was catching the train from Edinburgh Station down to Guildford to see my Dad before flying home to Aussie. Being so close, six hours of trains, I couldn’t possibly pass up the chance to pop in. My train wasn’t until 11am, so PLENTY of time to feast first.
I had seen the menu in the window a few days before on one of my walks and decided it looked like the sort of place that would either do a really good EB or monumentally stuff it up by trying to be too innovative.
I was seated in a booth with a brass topped table, and green velvet seats which I sank into. Looking around, there was nary a hard chair in the joint. Even the wooden dining chairs had a plush cushion to rest the weary buttocks.
I ordered a latte, orange juice, and classic Eggs Benedict that included Ayrshire Smoked Bacon, Toasted Muffin, Poached Eggs, Hollandaise Sauce. The menu kept it simple, so I thought, it going to be plain and simple.
It wasn’t, of course it wasn’t. I was in the Grand Cafe. They had the date on either side of the name. 1905. The chandeliers sparkled. The stained glass was clean. The stairs marble.
It came on a hand-turned ceramic plate, with spotlessly clean, shiny, cutlery (flatware, for the Americans). Baby spinach and toasted onion flakes adorned as garnish. The sauce, while pale, WAS HOUSE MADE!
Hallelujah.
I’ll be honest. I devoured it. It looked appetising, smelled fabulous, and tasted tangy with lemon as the acid in the sauce. The eggs, which I forgot to photograph because I was too busy scoffing them, where cooked to perfection with golden yolks and no egg snot.
After I had eaten, I used a few drinks mats to write some tanka about my Edinburgh stay. A couple of days before I had bunked off the conference to go and see some wildlife in the wild.
puffins and gannetsfish cold North watersnear island homes -I dine on eggsat the Grand
Would I go back? Hell yeah, and Capitaine Haddock, if you haven’t been there yet, you’re local, make it happen.
Location: The Grand CafeAddress: 20 North Bridge Edinburgh Scotland EH1 1TRWebsite: grandcafeedinburgh.co.uk
EB Price: £11.95 (GBP)

Title: Did You Know…There’s a Hidden City Beneath Edinburgh Haunted by Its Own History?
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Short Mind-Blowing Fun Facts! 😱 Discover the World with Us! 🌎

Member-only story
--
1
Share
When you walk the charming cobbled streets of Edinburgh’s Old Town, it’s easy to fall in love with the history. The gothic spires. The storytellers. The whiskey.
But beneath your feet lies another version of the city — one that most people don’t talk about unless they’re on a ghost tour.
One that’s still very much alive in its own way.
Welcome to the Edinburg Vaults, a network of stone chambers built in the late 1700s beneath South Bridge. They were meant for businesses and storage. But the vaults were dark, damp, and poorly ventilated — so they were quickly abandoned.
But not forgotten.
Soon after, the city’s poorest moved in. Families without homes, criminals, the sick, the unwanted.
People lived — and died — in these cold, airless rooms.
Disease spread quick. Murders went unnoticed.
And when the authorities eventually sealed the vaults, many believe they buried more than just stone and wood. They buried people alive.

Title: Liberal Arts Blog — Edinburgh: Raphael, “The Holy Family,” Velazquez “Old Lady Frying Eggs,” and Church “Niagara”
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Liberal Arts Blog — Friday is the Joy of Art, Architecture, Design, Film, and All Things Visual Day
Today’s Topic: Edinburgh: Raphael, “The Holy Family,” Velazquez “Old Lady Frying Eggs,” and Church “Niagara”
Last week, Vienna. Two weeks ago, Stockholm. Three weeks ago, Moscow. This week, Edinburgh — as we continue the tour of European art galleries to which I have never been. The first of today’s picks is from the Italian Renaissance, the second from the Spanish Golden Age, and the third from the Hudson River School of mid-19th century America. Experts — please chime in. Correct, elaborate, elucidate.
RAPHAEL (1483–1520) “The Holy Family with the Palm Tree” (1506)
1. What is most striking about this scene is the prominence of Joseph.
2. Most Holy Family scenes have a focus on Jesus or Mary.
3. Can any experts provide any enlightenment on this score?
NB: Raphael is most famous for “The School of Athens” — one of four frescoes in the “Stanza della Segnatura” in the Apostolic Museum in the Vatican in Rome. Tragically, he died young, allegedly from too much sex, on Good Friday, 1520, which was, according to Vasari, also his birthday.
https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Raphael_The_Holy_Family_with_a_Palm_Tree.jpg
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raphael
DIEGO VELAZQUEZ (1599–1660) “Old Lady Frying Eggs” (1618) — “chiaroscuro” and photographic realism
1. The eggs look like fried eggs from a distance but if you look closely you will see that they are swimming in a liquid and are probably better described as poached.
2. Case study in “chiaroscuro” — “with a strong light source coming in from the left illuminating the woman, her utensils and the poaching eggs, while throwing the background and the boy standing to her right into deep shadow. Here the chiaroscuro is very intense, so much so that it would be impossible to see the wall at the bottom of the painting but for the basket hanging from it; it simultaneously manages to combine the murky darkness and high contrasts of light and shadow with the use of subtle hues and a palette dominated by ochres and browns. The composition is organized as an oval with the middle figures in the nearest plane, thus drawing in the viewer.”
3. “The realism is nearly photographic and shows everyday plates, cutlery, pans, pestles, jugs and mortars, capturing the special shine on a glass surface and the light’s play on the melon carried by the boy. The boiling pan is particularly well-captured, with its reflections and the whites of the eggs. Velázquez also worked particularly hard on the detail of the two figures’ hands.”
NB: Velazquez was the great painter of the second half of the “Spanish Golden Age” (the “Siglo de Oro”) under the reign of Philip IV (1605–1665). El Greco (1541–1641) — was the master of the first half under Philip II (1527–1598).
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Old_Woman_Frying_Eggs
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diego_Vel%C3%A1zquez
FREDERICK CHURCH (1826–1900) “Niagara Falls, from the American Side” (1867)
1. Church was a member of the “Hudson River School” of American artists. Their theme was “sublime” nature and the “awe” it inspires.
2. Nothing captures this theme better than Niagara Falls which became a metaphor for the “manifest destiny” of the United States.
3. This is Church’s largest painting (8 feet by 7 feet) and the only one of his paintings in a European collection.
NB: Church’s most influential rendering of Niagara (from the Canadian side) was painted ten years earlier. See second link below.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Niagara_Falls,_from_the_American_Side
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Niagara_(Frederic_Edwin_Church)
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frederic_Edwin_Church
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hudson_River_School
BACKGROUND ON THE SCOTTISH NATIONAL GALLERY, THE MOUND, AND EDINBURGH’S NEW TOWN AND OLD TOWN
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scottish_National_Gallery
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Mound
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Town,_Edinburgh
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Old_Town,_Edinburgh

Title: Typewronger Books — Edinburgh’s Hidden Gem
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
That the love of typewriters is a thing, becomes evident from Somsubhra Banerjee’s article that inspired this one. Such passion for outdated technology does not come naturally to me. Yet, I came to appreciate the charming appearance of typewritten verse in 2022 after my visit to Typewronger Books in Edinburgh, Scotland.
It was not love at first sight. I slowly descended the steps to an unpretentious-looking bookstore’s entrance. In true Harry Potteresque style that is so characteristic of Edinburgh, Scotland, the “entrance” gave away absolutely nothing. I might as well have opened what looked like a basement door and found myself in Diagon Alley on the other side!
Little did I know, that I would spend the next two hours with family rummaging through entertaining accounts written by independent writers, some graduates of the University of Edinburgh’s famous creative writing programs, and many other intriguing but unknown gems. Well, that shouldn’t be surprising in the world’s first city designated as a “City of Literature” by UNESCO.
It turns out that this bookstore specialises in selling, but also repairing old typewriters. That someone would take the pains to get an old dysfunctional typewriter repaired for a cost sounded absurd to me.
The book wizard at the front desk was kind enough to share snippets of how many writers still prefer to write on typewriters. Or how he has a typewriter there which when my daughter click-clacked, would generate a tweet! And, how he had sold metres and metres of books as “home office decoration” during the great golden age of Zoom (2020–22)!
What fascinated me the most, however, was how captivated I was with all the typewriters they had on display. Turquoise, mint green, plain white but also the classic grandfather typewriters — black with black keys and golden alphabets etched on them.
Since that rainy afternoon, seeing typewritten words on the paper now mesmerises me. Those stark black and white angular letters seem to have a personality of their own. Have you read verses of poetry that just feel more alive on Instagram because they are typewritten? There is magic in them. If I can now see it, could this be some kind of literary spiritual awakening I underwent at Typewronger?
Typewriters haven’t gone completely out of fashion despite their more sophisticated and user-friendly competitors such as laptops and tablets. Surprisingly, they have held on to their niche and achieved cult status. It makes me wonder if some part of our current less efficient, cumbersome, but infinitely more charming and deeper way of writing, will unexpectedly preserve itself despite the advent of easier, lazier AI tools. Anyway, I digress…
It makes me wonder why. Perhaps, a typewriter, the way it feels to exert your fingers on its keys and the resulting click-clack sound allows a writer to feel like a music composer. After all, music is just a more mystical form of writing, isn’t it?
Or does it allow her to take on the identity of Hemingway, or perhaps, Anne Lamott, as types away? Similar to the purpose a bottle of rum would serve, or perhaps, an old, white, soft-beyond-description t-shirt. Is it a getting-into-character exercise for literary minds? Or does it evoke nostalgia for a lost, golden era of literature that she painfully tries to access, but only through its relics — typewriters?
Who knows? Do tell me if you give writing on a typewriter a shot one fine day. And if you were to bust it, you now know where to get it repaired!
--
--
Harvard-based public policy advisor, meditator, author of the “Buddha Balance Journal” and a joyful work-in-progress. Substack: https://bit.ly/3XX5Sid
