Title: Our guide to Edinburgh – walks and sightseeing
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Newly remote workers traveling the UK

--
Listen
Share
We stayed in Edinburgh during the abnormally sunny month of June and we had the best time. Edinburgh has everything you could possible want in a city: gorgeous architecture, breath taking views, exquisite restaurants, cosy pubs, shops and boutiques galore and even a beach for good measure. It quickly made its way up my favourite list of cities, and I was super sad to be leaving.
Basically, Calton Hill > Princes St & George St loop >The Mound > Lawnmarket > Edinburgh Castle > Grassmarket > Greyfriar’s Bobby memorial > Cow Gate > Royal Mile. If you cover all over these places, you’re going to have a great day; great landmarks, awesome architecture, and plentiful cafes, bars, pubs and restaurants for a refreshment en route. We loved Grassmarket and it’s lively atmosphere. In summer, the restaurant tables overflow out on to the pedestrianised street area, and it’s a delight to see.
You’d never believe this beach was on the coast of Scotland. Although we were very lucky with the weather on one of the days, it’s equally as wonderful even when it’s a bit colder. It’s a large stretch of golden sand with rippling waves; there’s an adorable high street just beyond the promenade, both which are full of cafes and shops. Well worth a whole day out — we’d recommend The Velvet Easel Art Gallery on Portobello High Street, the art and jewellery in there was beautiful. We also stopped at Bross Bagel for a snack, another amazing find.
One of my favourite things to do in Edinburgh was to go a run around Arthur’s Seat and Holyrood park before work. While the way up can be quite painful while jogging (I walked a fair bit of it), the view and tranquility at the top is worth the effort. There’s a lake you pass at the top of the hill, and then you’ll reach the edge and be able to look over the whole coast. Once you reach the lake it’s either flat or downhill the whole way back, so at that point it’s plain sailing!
The views and features along this route rival any other; discover vast fields, woodlands, rivers and waterfalls, and breathtaking views across over to Cairngorns.
Dunkeld now has to be one of my new favourite towns. Not only is the high street to die for, but the pub on the river is one of the most beautiful places I’ve ever had a meal. The terrace has an outdoor bar, a large marquee, as well as copious amounts of seating, including picnic tables in and out of the marquee, sunny tables, and cute little bar stools and barrels by the river – something for everyone; you can read more about this pub/hotel in our other Edinburgh blog!
We decided to try and do a run walk to explore the water of leith. It follows the river from Leith right through the centre of Edinburgh. We discovered parts of Edinburgh that we never would have including Stockbridge (which had an open air food market called the Neighbourgood market) and also somewhere called Dean Village. Although there’s not much to do at Dean Village, the village sit upon the stream and its houses are stunning, a really tranquil place to walk through and I feel so grateful I got to explore it.
We loved exploring the views across Loch Katrine – but it would have been even better had we cycled round! There’s a wide paved path following the whole Loch round – And there’s even a bike hire centre at the car park!
Having said that it’s only because we scaled the hillside that we were able to get these amazing views, not quite so achievable on a bike!
While we didn’t actually visit Edinburgh Castle itself, we explored the surrounding area. It’s located at the end of the high street, and the closer you get to it, the prettier everything becomes. It’s also a stone’s throw from Grassmarket, a wide street made for pedestrians and pubs, filled with cafes, restaurants, pubs, shops and bars. Would fully recommend an afternoon of exploring that area, taking in the atmosphere and treating yourself to a pint and a view or two.
For a date night to remember, we recommend booking a night at the zoo. It’s an adult’s only event at Edinburgh Zoo, where you can wander round a kid-free zoo, grab a drink and a bite to eat from the couple of food stands, and even watch a bit of live music. It’s just an event they do during the summer of course. It’s well worth it! A lovely, chill atmosphere.
It’s got to be one of the most incredible things about Edinburgh, the fact that there’s a tremendously tall hill smack bang in the middle of it all. Although it’s quite a feat to climb, it’s well worth it. The views across Edinburgh in one direction and the bay in the other are spectacular.
Another breathtaking bit of greenery in the city, quite literally. Calton Hill is yet another steep trek, but again the views and the architecture are worth the effort.
One of our highlights of our time here was an Airbnb experience run by Julie — a sheep herder and her pack of dogs.
The experience began just driving there. We stopped in a beautiful hill side cafe and then carried on the drive through the most incredible valleys and glens.
When we arrived Julie warmly welcomed us, we met some sheep, and she then proceeded to exhibit her pack of working dogs — in all the various stages of training. Starting with the least experienced to the most, and then a finalé of two dogs working together.
All of her work in training is anything but tyrannical or dictatorship. Instead, she practices something she calls the ‘natural way’.
Hope to see you again really soon, Edinburgh!

The moment we entered our rental flat Roshan began exploring the whole place, and he was enthralled.
“Daddy let’s stay here and don’t want to go back to London,” he said.
All three of us exchanged looks in surprise. Was this the same kid crying non-stop about thirty minutes ago?
“Yes, this is our house until we leave this city,” said his father, holding him back from his excitement of running from room to room.
We had bought some eating stuff from Southport Morrison hoping that we may not get anything at night when we arrived in a new country. But we were wrong. Even in the night we were able to get some basics like milk, bread, butter, cheese, and some other crispy stuff for eating from a shop, very close to our stay.
After some light dinner we decided to sleep soon so that we would be refreshed in the morning to start our tour. As soon as I touched the bed, I dropped off to sleep and enjoyed a deep and peaceful sleep. I was up early in the morning.
Raindrops like slug trails trickled down the windowpane. Steely clouds hung low, heavy with more rain, smothering the town.

Title: Lost in Edinburgh
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Edinburgh. It was a decades-long dream for this American to be there. And there I was, about halfway between Edinburgh Castle and the Palace of Holyroodhouse on the Royal Mile.
Alone.
The friend I was traveling with and I had just parted ways for the afternoon. She had other interests. I had to see Holyroodhouse, having read every fictional and nonfictional account of Mary, Queen of Scots, I could find over the years. Having watched every movie or program I could find. Having a general interest in history and specific interests in the British Isles.
Holyroodhouse is special to me. Even before Mary, there had been the wedding of James IV and Margaret Tudor in the abbey while the palace was under construction. Later, James VI would live at Holyrood until he became King of England and took up residence in London. So much happened here.
In between, there would be burnings and cannon attacks and repairs. Holyroodhouse has seen some things.
And I was going to see Holyroodhouse.
Alone.
That turned out to be the best part. My visit to Holyroodhouse was the beginning of my discovery of the joy of solo travel.
The Royal Mile is the road that slopes gradually from Edinburgh Castle at the top to Holyroodhouse at the bottom. It’s actually made up of several streets that run together west to east, starting with Castlehill, which runs into Lawnmarket, followed by High Street, on to Cannongate, and finally, Abbey Strand. It is roughly a mile long(an English mile) and takes just under a half hour to walk.
The Royal Mile is a busy thoroughfare, overrun by tourists and populated by colorful locals. Walking it alone gives you the opportunity to stop where you want and enjoy the view. If you’re walking and talking, you might miss some things . . ..
Like this guy playing his heart out for you although bagpipes are difficult to ignore!
This wizard floating in mid air.
This guy doing . . . his thing.
There’s always something to see on the Royal Mile, whether it’s the colorful characters or the rows of shops. So, so many shops.
But, finally, you end up here, at Holyroodhouse.
It was incredible to tour it alone, absorbed in my own thoughts. It was just me and Holyroodhouse. There were other tourists, but I hardly noticed them. I was having a moment with history, and that’s all I cared about.
Pictures aren’t allowed in Holyroodhouse, so I had to put away the potato I use for photography. (I suck at photography, and there’s no point in pretending otherwise, okay?)
Holyroodhouse is massive. You can tour parts of it online via the Royal Collection Trust. There is so much to see, from the state apartments (including the chambers of Mary, Queen of Scots) to the Throne Room and the Great Gallery. I stood at the spot where Mary’s secretary, David Rizzio, was murdered by her jealous husband, Lord Darnley, and his gang of assassins.
This spot, this murder, was the beginning of the end for Mary, Queen of Scots.
I stood there.
Outside, I was able to pull out my potato again and take some pictures of the ruins of the abbey that dates back to King David I of Scotland (1128, to be exact) and the grounds of the palace.
As I strolled the grounds (not the whole 10 acres, but some of it!), I wondered if Queen Mary had once walked where I was walking. Did she appreciate the lush beauty of the place?
Did she ever stand and admire this incredible view?
Finally, it was time to leave. My stomach was grumbling for fish and chips. (I gained five pounds on fish and chips in the UK and Ireland.)
The half hour walk back to the hotel would justify the fish and chips, so I decided to hoof it. I’m a avid walker anyway, so it seemed like a good chance to stretch the old legs, too.
There had been some instruction from our tour director about finding Princes Street if we got lost and following it and . . . more words. Who’s really listening when you’re trying to photograph Edinburgh Castle with a potato?
I set out in the direction of Princes Street. For some reason, my phone wasn’t getting any kind of connection, so I had no access to maps, and the paper one I had was kind of vague. Nevertheless, I set out confidently in the wrong direction.
Before this happened, I would have thought being lost would terrify me. I got lost in my car in the city I live in once when I was new to the area, and it was enough to keep me from going back until Google Maps became a thing. But then again, I did see a dead body on a stretcher and a swarm of cops arresting a bunch of people that day (the middle of a week day!), so there’s that.
But, I wasn’t scared in Edinburgh. Maybe it’s just Edinburgh, or maybe I’m older and wiser and more savvy now. I know what to look for and how to avoid a sketchy area, not that I saw any in Edinburgh. I’m sure they are there. As I strolled along, I realized I was relaxed and trusted myself. I was happy.
At one point, I spotted three people — two women and a young man — with a large map, so I approached them, hoping to get some directions. They stared at me nervously as I asked what street we were on. They spoke to each other — in German, I think — and looked, frankly, kind of terrified. (What were they saying? “It’s an American. Does it have a gun? What should we do?”) I tried to ask them if they knew the name of the street we were on, but I think they were even more lost than I was.
When I turned, I saw the ultimate “get unlost” solution: a tour bus driver! He was parked on a side street and vacuuming the steps of his vehicle with some little handheld thing. He cheerfully pointed me in the right direction, and off I went.
I think Edinburgh is still so vivid to me because I walked it alone, taking in every site, processing it all deliberately and thoughtfully. When there’s no extraneous chatter or other distractions, it’s easier to simply be in a place, be a part of it.
Upon finding Princes Street, I was still a bit turned around. I wanted to get some pictures of the Sir Walter Scott monument, and I knew I needed to go west. Waiting to cross a street, I asked a woman standing next to me if I was headed in the right direction. She responded that she thought so, and then said, “I’m so sorry, but I’m in a hurry, and I’m late,” before darting across the street and disappearing into the crowd.
“That’s fine. I’ll be fine,” I said because she did look distressed.
I continued on my way, still feeling happily lost and not minding at all now. If I wandered up and down Princes Street, I would eventually see the cross street that led to my hotel.
Then, I saw the woman, running back toward me, waving at me. Nearly out of breath, she pointed in the sky, “Do you see that spire ahead in the distance? Walk toward that. That’s the monument!” She turned to run off again, and I shouted “Thank you!” after her. She turned to wave, still trotting along, and I thought how kind it was of her to come back for me that way when she was in such a hurry.
And then I had my moment with Sir Walter Scott. I love Ivanhoe. His other books are good, too— the other Waverly novels — but Ivanhoe is special. I wrote about a book from my grad school studies , The Superhistorians, in another article. The author included Sir Walter Scott among his chosen great historians although books like Ivanhoe were historical fiction and Scott did take liberties with historical fact. But, he brought history to life and he did so by putting people at the center of it. He made history a riveting story.
As a history major who had been drawn to history initially through historical fiction, it meant something to me to stand before the monument to Scott and reflect on his work. It was yet another moment between Edinburgh and me.
Then it was time for fish and chips. And Guinness.
The main thing I learned from being lost on my own in Edinburgh was that it wasn’t a big deal. I have been interested in the idea of solo travel for awhile, and it seems to me there has been a explosion of interest in and information about it over the last couple of years. There are many articles online about why people are taking up solo travel, which typically include the freedom of being able to do what you want when you want with less expense, along with being able to immerse yourself fully in the experience. Solo travelers often note a boost to self confidence and self-knowledge that come with the experience. Solo travel can also be less stressful than traveling with others.
Would the imagery of the Royal Mile still be so vivid to me if I had walked it with another person? Would I have been as immersed in Holyroodhouse with someone else waiting for me to finish in a room or drawing my attention to something else? Would I have had that connection with a stranger that still reminds of how awesome human beings can be? Would I have enjoyed reflecting on the influence of Sir Walter Scott on me, a history and English major while standing before his statue?
Those memories are my own special memorie s— mine alone.
After Edinburgh, the idea of solo travel became more than just an idea to me. I now see it as something I can actually do.
--

Title: Secret Edinburgh — Inside Tips From The Locals
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Edinburgh. Known for its inspiring history, its eclectic catalogue of festivals and with it, an ever-present army of selfie-snapping tourists. (Can’t be helped, just comes with the territory, y’know.)
And whilst there are many wonderful attractions in Edinburgh, like any popular city, at times the main sights can become a little overcrowded, which isn’t ideal if you like your delights, day-tripper free.
Anyway, if this sounds a bit like you, then read on. We’ve been in touch with the locals who know this city best to put together the off the beaten track, things to see and do, places to eat, drink and generally watch the world go by.
(And to make things easy to follow, we’re going to be categorise each local tip with either EAT. DRINK. SEE. PLAY. Hopefully quite self-explanatory so we’ll get on with it…)
Dean Village (SEE. PLAY)What the locals say:
Ashley
IG: @ashleyWanders
“One of my favourite hidden gems in Edinburgh is the Water of Leith Walkway, a 20km riverside path that winds through the heart of the city. It’s a fantastic spot for a leisurely walk and a lovely natural oasis where you can go to escape the hustle and bustle (and it’s an absolute godsend if you need respite from the crowds during the Fringe Festival in August).”
What we say:
One of the most underrated scenic sites in Edinburgh. Although Dean Village is located about a 5–10 minute walk from the busy Princes Street. ‘Busy’ just doesn’t appear in Dean Village’s dictionary. What once was at the heart of Edinburgh’s manufacturing industry, the now quaint village is now a picturesque residential area, with old millstones, a temple and an ancient viaduct scattered throughout. If you follow your nose around the walkway, you’ll find the Dean Gallery and the Scottish National Gallery of Modern Art, both free, both brilliant.
Bruntsfield (EAT. DRINK. PLAY)What the locals say:
Charlotte Ballantyne
IG: @justmuddlingthroughlife
“Edinburgh has plenty of suburbs to explore, each with their own atmosphere, to get away from the sometimes overwhelming city centre. Brunstsfield is full of local, independent shops, that’re away from the more common high street. Grab a coffee in Artisan Roast or The Chocolate Tree, browse for a new outfit in Biscuit Clothing or pick up some toys in Gulliver’s, then have a delicious meal in Three Birds or Montpellier’s!”
What we say:
Bruntsfield is a cultural hub, bursting at the seams with exciting things to see and do. The best part about it? Tourists often overlook it, which means you’ll get the chance to experience this suburb like a true local. As Charlotte mentions, there’s plenty of restaurants serving up the best local produce, there’s also no shortage of good pub grub and countless independent shops that’ll make your time in Bruntsfield a brilliant one. If you’re looking to stay out a little past your bedtime and the busy Grassmarket bars aren’t your cup of tea, there’s more than enough stylish, typically Scottish pubs and bars to wet your whistle.
The Stand Comedy Club (DRINK. PLAY)What the locals say:
Charlotte Ballantyne
IG: @justmuddlingthroughlife
“This tiny little underground venue is legendary in Edinburgh, having been the place where many world-famous comedians got their start. It’s open every night of the week, hosting both newcomers and better-established names — Monday nights are ‘Red Raw’, where any beginner can take part, with tickets priced at just £3. If you’re lucky, more famous comedians will often make a surprise appearance to test out new material, especially in the months leading up the Fringe in August!”
What we say:
Established in 1995 in the basement of an Edinburgh pub, the club has grown to become one of the UK’s best comedy venues and a mainstay of the Festival Fringe. The club is also no stranger to hosting famous acts, with the likes of Kevin Bridges and Frankie Boyle learning their trade at the venue and if you’re lucky, they sometimes pop back to practice new material. (You might also be happy to know the club has banned stag and hen parties, which mean most of the people you find there are indeed the locals and are there for a L plate free, good time.)
Stockbridge (EAT. DRINK. PLAY)What the locals say:
Iveta Zalcaite
IG: @ivetazalc
“My favourite part of the city was is Stockbridge, if you’re looking for a truly local experience; this area is packed with lots of independent shops and cute cafes. That definitely isn’t covered in tourists!”
Kieron Roulston
IG: @kieronroulston
“Stockbridge Market on a Sunday is an excellent opportunity to go exploring Edinburgh’s new town — don’t get a taxi, take a walk down from George Street via Circus Lane and take in the different character of Edinburgh’s Mews”
What we say:
Edinburgh is full of downright lovely places, but Stockbridge has to be up there as one of the loveliest. It’s stunning architecture, charming village-like atmosphere, and its abundance of local cafes and restaurants, make it popular with the Edinburgh locals. We could sit here and list the all of its main attractions, but we don’t want to be here ALL day, so our top 3 Stockbridge picks are: Inverleith Park, the Royal Botanic gardens and the Stockbridge market (Sunday only) at Jubilee garden. Do take Edinburgh local Kieron’s advice and take the time to walk down from George Street, he knows what he’s talking about.
Blackford Hill (PLAY)What the locals say:
Charlotte Ballatyne
IG:@justmuddlingthroughlife
“For stunning views of Edinburgh, skip the crowds on Arthur’s Seat and instead head to the south side of the city to climb Blackford Hill, where you’ll get incredible views of Edinburgh Castle, Holyrood Park, and all the way over the Firth of Forth on a clear day. You can take a direct route straight up and down if you’re short on time, or spend a little longer wandering through the Braid Woods nearby.”
What we say:
If there’s one thing Edinburgh is not short of its stunning views, both of and throughout the city. But a lot of the time, stunning views comes with a stunning amount of selfie sticks carrying. This is particularly true of Arthur’s Seat, which does have a fantastic view of the capital, but can get a little crowded. If you take Charlotte’s advice here and head up to Blackford Hill you’ll get amazing views and decent snaps, minus the crowds. Lovely.
Books! (PLAY)What the locals say:
Nathan Young
IG: @nathanyoung2202
“Edinburgh is home to some amazing antique bookstores; the first one to pay a visit to is Armchair books in West Port. Deceiving on first looks, once inside, it’s an Aladdin’s cave of assorted paraphernalia, soft toys and hand-written notes. If you’re looking for first editions of certain books, it’s highly likely you’ll find what you’re looking for, they offer Victorian and second hand books for most genres.
Next on the list is Old Town Bookshop, Victoria Street. This is a bookworm’s dream — with editions dating back to the 1600s and a variety of genres as well as maps and art for pickings. Summerhall bookshop features an array of varied exhibitions and events hosted there. It also has a small gallery and a café inside where you can purchase a Scottish Breakfast roll to kick off your day.”
What we say:
To be honest we couldn’t put Nathan’s description better ourselves. Edinburgh is scattered with many independent bookshops, a lot of them teeming with more than just the books. The pick of the stores would have to be Armchair books; it’s cluttered, it’s messy and its disorganised, but this makes it the best place to browse. Whether it’s fiction or nonfiction, it really doesn’t matter, there’s enough to browse that you could probably spend your whole time in the city exploring the shelves, searching for that hidden gem you didn’t know you wanted.
Dr Neil’s Garden (PLAY)What the locals say:
Sally Cholewa
IG: @choggzy
“Tucked away in Duddingston, just outside the city centre, this established botanical garden is full of twisting and winding paths lined with beautiful plants. It makes for a wonderfully secluded and quiet spot. There are often community events happening including traditional Scottish storytelling. The ‘secret’ garden even has its own curling museum as Duddingston loch is where the first official rules were established.”
What we say:
Otherwise known as Edinburgh’s secret garden, these gardens are THAT secret that a lot of the locals would struggle to point you in their direction. This stunning area is the handy work of Dr Andrew and Nancy Neil, built at the foot of Arthur’s Seat in the 60s. They’re more than just beautiful wildlife and winding paths to the locals; this serene spot is a place of inspiration, meditation and contemplation. The perfect place to plonk yourself and unwind.
Whisky, Gin & Beer (DRINK)What the locals say:
Charlotte Ballantyne
IG: @justmuddlingthroughlife
“Scotland is famous for its whisky, and there are plenty of options to sample it in Edinburgh — try a tasting in Whiski Rooms on North Bank Street, Bow Bar on Victoria Street, or Usquabae on Hope Street. There’s plenty of other alcohols produced in this country too though — take a tour of the Edinburgh Gin Distillery in the West End, or Pickering’s Gin in Summerhall. Or if you’re a craft beer fan, try Red Squirrel on Lothian Road, or St Andrews Brewing Co. on Potterrow. Edinburgh is a very international city; so expect to rub elbows with locals, expats, and a few visitors alike in most of the city’s pubs and bars!”
What we say:
Apart from bagpipes, haggis, or going one better with a deep-fried Mars bar (yes, they do exist). If there’s one thing you’re going to do in Edinburgh, it’s try some traditional Scotch whiskey, or equally, if whiskey isn’t your preferred weapon of choice, you might want a tipple of some sort. Like any city nowadays, Edinburgh has a plethora of bars and pubs to choose from. But where do you go for something different, yet traditional, that’s not heaving with tourists? You can’t argue with Charlotte’s recommendations, and here’s some more of our favourite Edinburgh drinkeries…
Jupiter Artland (SEE)What the locals say:
Charlotte Ballantyne
IG: @justmuddlingthroughlife
“Located a half hour bus ride from the city centre, and only open during the summer months, Jupiter Artland is hidden surprise for art lovers. The grounds of this old manor house have been transformed into something like an adult playground, full of modern art installations specifically designed for the park, incorporated into the landscape, which encourage you to explore and interpret as you please.”
What we say:
Most people look after their garden with a bit of mowing and the odd hedge trim every now and again. But when Robert and Nicky Wilson moved into Bonnington House, a Jacobean manor with a 100-acre estate, they decided to do a hell of a lot more. Transforming their land into a contemporary art park and gallery, showcasing work by leading sculpture and land artists.
When exploring this spectacular garden and grounds, you’ll find cutting edge sculptures and installations from the world’s best, who are given complete freedom to produce whatever they like. And due to the sheer size of the estate, escaping the crowds isn’t something that even needs to enter your mind. Like, ever. Enjoy.
--
--

Title: 20 fun facts about Edinburgh
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Our Moscow guide Dasha traveled to the UK on New Year holidays, and here are her impressions about Edinburgh.
I fell in love with Edinburgh — the place where castles and gardens compete with whisky and beer — and actually it impressed me even more than London.
Nothing can be compared to this atmosphere of medieval times, amazing grey buildings, peaceful local life and true Scottish spirit.
This is where peace and history go to relax, and you should too. Or write a sequel to Harry Potter. Joanne Rowling won’t mind as long as you’re happy.
Set the tone for this historical adventure by plunging into the history of Edinburgh and exploring its gems. Let the story begin with… 20 fun facts about Edinburgh.
1. Edinburghers have called this area home since 7th century AD. See if you like what they’ve done to the city that is sometimes called the Athens of the North” and decide for yourself if you agree with Robert Louis Stevenson that “Edinburgh is what Paris ought to be”.
2. The massive and gorgeous Edinburgh castle is built on an extinct volcano. The last time the volcano erupted was 350 million years ago.
3. The volcano`s crater got the name “Arthur`s Throne”.
4. From the ancient times the Edinburgh castle has an unofficial name — The Key from the Country.
5. The first people on Castle Rock appeared there about 1000 years BC.
6. Edinburgh was the first city in the world to have its own fire service in 1703. But it was a volunteer fire brigade, that`s why it took a lot of time to gather people and come to the burning place before it`s too late.
7. Edinburgh is the greenest city in the UK, since there are 112 parks in the city.
8. The first king of Great Britain James I (a Scottish king James VI) was born in the Edinburgh castle.
9. The city has a nickname — Auld Reekie (Old Smoky) which was given to the city in connection with an era when a lot of coal and wood were burnt for heating and the air was full of smoke.
10. The Stone of Destiny which is kept in the Edinburgh castle is still used for the crowning of English Monarchs.
11. J.K.Rowling used to go to the Nicolson`s café during a hard period of her life and she started to write the first book about Harry Potter exactly there. Now there is a restaurant on that place called «Spoon».
12. One more literature fact — Ebenezer Scrooge from the famous novel by Charles Dickens «A Christmas Carol» was also born in Edinburgh when the author misread the tombstone of a real person with the same name. He read «Meanman» instead of «Mealman», which means «corn trader».
13. Actually people started producing whisky not in Scotland, but in Ireland in 5th century. However, there are over 100 whisky distillers in Scotland. Well played!
14. The unicorn is a national animal of Scotland, while thistle and heather are floral emblems.
15. The number of heritage buildings in Edinburgh is bigger than anywhere. There are about 16 thousands historical buildings of different epochs.
16. Edinburgh is also standing on seven hills like Rome and Moscow.
17. About 13 million tourists visit Edinburgh every year.
18. Edinburgh is an art city. Every year in August the world best concert and theater troupes come here for the Summer Art Festival. Edinburgh is the world’s number one festival destination.
19. The Princess Street Gardens is a sneaky way to move from Old Times to New Era, as the gardens break the city into two parts.
20. Royal Mile is the most famous street in the city, it was the favorite street for walk for Scottish and English monarchs.
Original source: https://friendlylocalguides.com/blog/20-fun-facts-about-edinburgh

Title: 📸 — Glasgow & Edinburgh, Scotland
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Hi there! Maeghan & Oli here - we're taking a break to travel the world and hope you'll join us for the ride. 🌏✈️ 👫 www.alittledetour.ca

--
Listen
Share
After Oli’s full recovery from food poisoning, we made our way to Scotland!
Back in July we toured Norway together with our friend Theresa, who flew in from Calgary. We traveled well as a group and kept bugging her to join us again on our little detour and we managed to convince her to join us for our final leg in Scotland!
We met up in Glasgow for just one night (Halloween!) and then made our way Edinburgh for some hiking, exploring and history. There was a lot to see and not enough time… Within the first 48 hours, we all agreed: this is a place we will come back and visit.
Here are our first few days together!
See more on our website www.alittledetour.ca🌏✈️👫
We left Glasgow and made our way to Edinburgh. The city is super cool and the medieval influence is very visible the moment you drive into the city limits.
We got to our Airbnb which was the biggest apartment Oli and I have stayed in during our entire year long travel! We had a beautiful view of the city, the university and the beautiful fall colours.
“Although the origin of the name is uncertain, some claim that there is a connection between Edinburgh and King Arthur. Arthur’s Seat may have been the location of legendary Camelot.” — — Earth Trekkers!
There are these areas of the old town that they call “Close” and it is essentially a square or alley that connects all the houses. They would use them to sell things — like the Fish Close, was for the fisherman to sell fish. Our tour guide told us to try and explore as many as possible.
So Theresa picked one.. and we followed her down it, but it turned out to be a rocky hallway that pigeons lived in, there was poop everywhere and they chased Maeghan right out.
We also learned about where the saying “shit face” came from. The wealthy people of Edinburgh would live on the ground level floors of the tall beautiful buildings because the top floors were a fire hazard— so locals would pay more for lower-level apartments, for safety.
But since toilets were not a thing yet… they used chamber pots and would simply yell out the window as the person was dumping them out.
Since this caused much chaos, the city put in a new rule: you can only empty your chamberpots at 7 in the morning, and 10 at night.
Problem is, 10 at night is when the pubs would close. So combine drunk people pouring out onto the streets with people pouring chamberpots out of their windows, and you can picture how you might come home after a night of drinking: shit-faced drunk.
On our last night we caught up with an old friend of Maeghan’s from Calgary. Anton homeschooled with Maeghan and we had the chance to discuss politics, homeschooling, the weather and our exotic spouses. ☺️
See more on our website www.alittledetour.ca🌏✈️👫

Content:

11

Scotland’s capital is one classy city. Edinburgh boasts quaint cobbled streets, many hidden hide-outs, excellent shopping, eerie dungeons and a big boss of a castle that rivals even Hogwarts. No wonder it’s famous for putting on a heck of a festival every year. Even better than that, it lasts the whole month of August, and jam-packs in so many diverse acts that the festival programme is published as thick as the phone book. The Edinburgh International Festival is the world’s largest arts festival and it’s no surprise that it attracts acts and tourists from every continent, as well as the locals, in droves. This is a city which takes great pride in its culture, where the best of the best hope to make a name during the festivities.
So don your finest kilt if you have one, embrace (don’t slate) the sounds of bagpipes, and drink Tennents until you are fully wearing your beer goggles. It’s going be one heck of a month.

Title: Am I a Pilgrim, yet ? | Walking Edinburgh to Dunfermline.
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
This 21 mile walk from the Scottish Capital to the centre of Dunfermline is a pilgrimage of my own making. It didn’t aim for any church or holy site; instead I aimed to go see my Uncle’s artwork being exhibited in the centre of Dunfermline. Ever one to make something harder than it should be in the search for growth, I planned out how I could walk from my front door to his paintings. A week before the route was being tweaked and twiddled with, down to where I can stop for an emergency piss if the need arose. Turns out, not many people walk from the centre of Edinburgh, across the Forth and onto Dunfermline. The only snippets of adventures I could find dipped in and out of my route; but none of them were complete. Perfect, an adventure is to be had.
I am not religious, nor have I ever been, yet through walking and adventuring I have found a sense of mindfulness. A spiritual freedom you may call it. At around 10 miles I experience a deep sense of joy and zen. Runners have told me they experience something similar, but I have yet to find that point running; instead I feel every excruciating second of the bloody thing. Yet, via walking I zone into a different world, one of my own making. At mile 15 I usually land hard like a Ryanair aeroplane before bouncing up back into my mindfulness. For this walk, though, I would hit mile 20. What then would that bring me?
It’s 6:30 am and my HipHop mix alarm is sudden and loud. ‘Damn it feels good to be a Gangsta’. True, maybe. Today I’m hoping it feels good to be a Pilgrim; whatever that is. January is in full flow, but storms have passed and there’s clear cool air in the city. Not many are trundling about as I leave, espresso heavy on my stomach, at around 7:30 am. Deliveries clatter and clang into Sainsbury’s, high vis workers smash down the lorry’s back doors and floors. It cuts the crisp morning air. I begin to look forward to the promised remoteness of much of my trek. Before long I am passing a quiet Haymarket Station; it is the weekend, no commuters are jousting up and down the road today. Air is blue, the moon is full and bright against the wisps of clouds. Their fast movement across its face does not bode well for the wind later on.
Edinburgh has a fair amount of old railway lines that have been tarmaced over and converted into sheltered paths. The one I spring onto is a familiar one for me; during lockdown I would glide down here to the beach, filled with regret when I get there that I didn’t pack more warm clothes. Even in the height of summer Cramond is a windy bitch. A jogger huffs past and a cyclist dressed all in black whizzes past. My espresso gurgles and shifts; what was my toiletry plan again? I stare down at my phone like a lost tourist coming out of Waverly. A Tesco is marked at the very end of my railway route and before I dive between two golf courses. My breakfast stop. Tree’s sway and lurch in the wind as the dark blue sky turns to pink, then a light gold. The sun is on its way behind me as a veer off from my Northern path to the West.
A Tesco employee stares at my walking stick in a bit of a stunned silence as I ask about toilets. Seconds pass before he forces out a ‘No’. Not quite the spiritual guidance I was looking for on my Pilgrimage, I admit. But perhaps this area doesn’t get many wanderers this early on a Saturday. I dart off and onto a well-to-do road. Cameras, locked gates and larger financed cars come and go as I wander through. The houses get larger and more elaborate, the gates get more defensive and taller. This road is very clean, I will say. Although there seems to be no sign of life I can’t help feel eyes on me. Perhaps a Pilgrimage is a trial of sorts. This is my first one today; do not shit yourself in a posh neighbourhood. It would be caught on multiple cameras and posted online as a VR experience before I reach the Forth Road Bridge.
The road comes to an abrupt end, turning into a path which seems meagre and slim compared to the vastness of the properties behind me. I’m now sandwiched between two golf course, various signs tell me not to litter or even contemplate becoming a member; they can tell I’m not quite up to scratch by the stick I’m swaying about. A dog walker, the first of the day, looks tired and fed up. He looks up under his hat but his eyes are sunken, sad. Is it golf that has made him like this? Or the weight of owning a castle? Or perhaps he doesn’t belong here, like me, but comes to envy and depressed about the life some lead. Either way we slink past each over on this wee pathway. More big houses flank me as I pop out onto a new street, these are chopped up into flats, though. Suddenly I dive down a windy old road and into some trees. At the bottom of this glen like snake I come across a small field of ponies. It is cold and damp down here, the houses look sodden. Then, just as I’m getting the heebie jeebies I turn sharply onto a stone bridge that spans a smooth, icy cold river. I stop for breakfast.
Before me the river is escorted into the distance by forestry and steep green banks. Tops of the trees are on fire from the ever so slowly rising sun. A golden morning stabs across the landscape, splicing my view into harsh warms and glassy colds. A dog comes to inspect my backpack and the fallen crusty crumbs of my pork pie. Their walker takes no heed of me. A few minutes pass watching the silk like water flow away from me and I head off up and out of the crossing. On my left a helter skelter of a building seems to have been slapped together in a rustled puzzle box. Is it a community centre? A church? I place a bet with myself and lose it all immediately. It’s a steak restaurant; I have driven past it numerous times on the way to the bridges. It brings a nice pang of realisation how far I have to go yet, seen as though the road takes a while and goes almost directly to them. I, though, must turn hard right towards the shore. North once more, away from the city and into the Dalmeny Estate.
A large muddy puddle welcomes me into the estate via a metal gate. I spend a few seconds staring it down. I’m mile 7 into my walk. If I get my feet wet now then the next 15 will be less than ideal. I jump it and slip with my walking stick. Luckily I’m alone and swan off up the long, straight road. To my right now there is a line of soldier like trees being pierced with brilliant gold. Their shadows barcode the road before me as it stretches off into a wide left leaning corner. My left is all ploughed farm fields, topped with bushes and trees as they slope uphill. I stop to take some photos for my own personal stash of farm related memories. A country lad at heart. Snowdrops welcome me at the various twists and turns of my golden road and before long the landscape opens up wide into rolling fields. A deep warm stench of hay and manure catches the wind here and there and now I begin to see some new faces.
“Morning!” A deep, booming voice bellows at me as a runner flies past. It startles me as I’m now zoning out into my zen-like world of farm equipment and muddy trails. “You alright!” I shout back. An exhausted “Aye.” Floats back to me. A few more people, dog walkers, general walkers and runners go past and each say good morning, how are you doing, beautiful day for it. It’s a social extravaganza here in the estate. My flurry of networking peters out and I slope down into more forestry. Thin, tall pines guard the shoreline that I can see spanning the view between their dark barks. The sun has yet to reach down here. A quietness settles around me, shells appear in the muddy path. I see a small opening onto the beach and jump driftwood onto the pebbly, sandy shore. It’s wonderful. Expansive and calm with the tide out, the sea is a far off foe I will conquer later in the day. For now it offers a definitive end to my Northern direction. Cramond Beach to my right is busy with people, but they are distant and seem to be across a dreamlike void. Cramond Island sits amongst the warm light of the morning, ships moving slowly behind it; their bright red hulls a stark brush stroke on an otherwise fair, cold view. I sit on the driftwood and stretch my legs. Silence. A swish of leaves above me as a gust of wind hits. Nothing. A leaf rustles onto my trainers. I cry, just a little.
On my walks I often cry, or get to a point that holds me to a tear or two. Sometimes it’s the silence, the calm. Or sometimes it’s a memory spurred from what I’m seeing, what I’m thinking or what I’m hearing. This Pilrimage has a density heavier than most due to death itself, which hit my family from all sides in all ways in 2021. For reasons I’m yet to really figure out myself, I have never posted about it on socials, or anywhere, really. A percieved lack of permission from who knows who, or a unwillingness to put any of it to solidified, permenant digital ink? I do not know, but I will say, on this walk I carried everyone with me, every step.
I’m just about to hit mile 8 and this is where my first tear drops of the day. But what a view for it to happen to. I spend longer than I probably should watching the world, not really do much. Voices behind me in the woodland break my train of thought. Runners coming up through the path I’m yet to tread. I look left expecting, foolishly, to see the red arches of the rail bridge spanning the water. Nothing in sight. I have a long way to go. Fife taunts me slightly as I dive back into the woods, it knows I’m coming for it. But it also knows how many trials I have to face on my wee Pilgrimage.
Shortly I see a bright square of stone drawn onto the curving coastline through the woods. Above it is a bright blue sky with textured clouds. The sun hits it hard, bright. A castle of light stone sits proudly upon the sandy waters of the Forth. But it is a way away yet. I trundle on through beautiful woodland, red trunks vear up to swaying canopies. Sometimes the sun strikes in and searches out the shining shells and sand that pop up here and there. Now and again a fallen tree crosses my path. Some old and mossy, some new and yet to be traversed properly. I cross a rolling stream of turquoise as it tumbles down into the grassy banks of the beach. It guides me along its shore before it spits me out onto another expansive view of the beach. This time there are less pebbles and more shimmering sand. My guide curves its way down to the sea through the banks. Following it with my eyes it leads me to the castle, now much closer. Mile 8 done. There’s an Eminem joke in there somewhere.
Green grass mixes with yellow sand like a paint palette. I pick up speed. My surroundings have me excited with this adventure. Castles, beaches, forests and farms. Dalmeny House solidifies my enjoyment as it pops up, looming proudly on my left. Vibrant, flat green grass rolls right up to its walls. It is a set piece, a view with a view and it stops me in my tracks. But the magic falters. Seemingly it is being renovated, or gutted. Ugly metal fences hug it horribly and metal work pokes out here and there. Windows boarded, taped. A pile of shite on it’s flanks. No matter, I have the castle I have been walking towards for the last few miles. My bright stone castle on the water. Once I get to it the magic falters again. No Entry. Fair enough. But, it too is boarded up, closed off, hiding. Recent work is obvious, but it is a shy place. Seaward it stands out and proud, but us landlubbers can only catch glimpses as it peers through shrubbery and trees. Perhaps I need some energy or water because my mood takes a bit of a dip. The next two miles are a slog, they are cold and my golden sun disappears for a long while. Where the hell are the bridges?
Maybe that was one of my trials of my Pilgrimage, a featureless forest that seems to never end. More likely it is my need to have a little rest and some food. Luckily the red metal work of the Rail Bridge begins to appear between the leaves. Then I find an opening and stumble down a muddy bank to a bunch of rocks. Perfectly there is a large fallen tree that acts as a seat. I sit, eat and admire the view. The Forth Rail Bridge spans across the water right before me. South Queensferry nestles underneath all three of the bridges to my left; my next destination before crossing the middle bridge. The wind is scathingly cold here. Boats bob about, waves lap hectically. I scoff my face and stretch my legs. My uncle messages me, “Where about are you?” I send a photo of the bridge back. Next up, South Queensferry.
Before I get into the meat of the town a woman walks out from her car in front of me and stops dead for seemingly no reason. I check my stride and go to pass her but she absent mindedly wanders to the side I’m going around. It is no big thing, but after marching for 11 miles now it was a strange feeling to me, stopped dead by a person not paying attention to anything. I leave her in my dust and enter a quiet town. Behind me the Forth Rail Bridge stands tall. Walking beneath it is nothing compared to taking a step back and viewing it. I always remember seeing it when I was younger on the TV and it seemed mystical to me. When I first moved up to Scotland it was the one thing I was desperate to see. Now, walking underneath it and having it as part of my adventure I felt a sense of connection to it. To bring myself back down to earth I finally found a toilet in South Queensferry and made sure I left my mark for any following Pilgrims. A miracle occurred there.
Soon enough I was dodging folk on pavements as I stormed up the hill towards the beginning of the bridge I was to cross. Once I got underneath it I felt a sting of excitement about what I was about to do. It’s cold, dark concrete consumed me as I looped up to the road from the town. Stopping briefly to adjust my backpack and jacket, I set out to go across. Then it hit me. A fear so deep, so bubbly and heavy that I almost fell to the floor. It wraithed inside of my stomach and my eyes became like a small tunnel. I staunchly marched forward as fast as I could, but once I’d reached the water the fear consumed me. Tiny gaps every 10 ft or so let me see the waters far below. Every coach that stormed past me bounced the large metalworks that struck up high and mighty above me. Wind blew and gust in a menacingly horrible way; it seemed determined to shove me over the edge. This was not enjoyable. I had hoped to grab some good photos of the Rail Bridge I adored so much whilst on here, but now… Get me off here! Metal creaked. The floor bounced. The wind blew. A cyclist went past and was nearly blown into me. Madman. At one point I swept past a porta-loo; what a way to go, blown into the Forth by a cubicle of shite. I could not get across to the otherside quick enough. But, had I known what I was about to tackle I may well have just stayed on the bridge.
It’s hot in the sun now. Face warm from the wind and no doubt the nerves I settled down on the steps that climb from the bridge to a road. Everything on this side of the Forth seems quiet and empty. No cars, nor people, mill about or make any sound. I take a moment. Now I convince myself that my Pilgrimage does indeed have trials, and the bridge was the biggest one by far. Never again! I proceed underneath its shadowy archways after a few more bites to eat. The road I’m on heads up and over a small hill before it dips suddenly down to swoop under the large motorway. In amongst the swirling, busy roads sits a boarded up house. It’s wee, messy and depressing. Concrete hugs the landscape and even in the yellow light of the day it is cold. This has become quite a tour of infrastructure, if that is the type of thing you’re into. I video call my wife.
Not as impressed by my feat of terror crossing the bridge as I thought she would be, she asks what my onward route is. Docks, Rosyth and forests, I reply. The sun is beating down now and I’m exposed to its warmth and the cold wind as I plod along. Down below me I see a grandfather and his granddaughter, fitted out with wellies, traversing a wind swept nature reserve. At least, these are the facts I project down upon the scene. Reeds and grass ebb and flow in the eager gusts. They shelter but chat enthusiastically. I stand for a while as they bounce away into the hazy grasses; tall bridges loom above them off into the choppy waters. I turn and continue along the most tedious road I’ve ever walked up.
Large metal buildings at the docks creak and boom as machinery, cranes, buildings get closer and more imposing. On the other side of the road there’s just shite. Sewerage works, quarries, a large car park where a bored looking guy in a JCB backhoe moves around asphalt. Usually I love a big of heavy machinery action, but I just want to get out of this tundrum place. It takes longer, it seems, than my whole walk completed beforehand to reach the pathway I need to dart up to get away. A pigeon coop castle stops me in my tracks, but the litter strewn path forces me to move on swiftly. My walks are all about moods and mindfulness; I find it difficult to reach those heady heights when bags of dog shit wave at me as I pass them as if I’m some kind of royal shitter.
The mood does not improve as I’m spat out into a disused industrial park. Large blue offices with smashed windows and fenced off to the nines greet me. Two lads saunter in front of me, neither see me until I whizz past them. “Eh!” One of them exclaims. Who knows what stories they have to hand to fling out at the drop of a hat. But I have wasted time watching families explore nature reserves and need to speed through my next section. I turn out of this and onto a roundabout. The housing estate across from me, and which I now need to navigate, is a familiar one to me. In my hometown you are looked down upon if you live on the wrong side of the river. And those that do look down upon those who live on the wrong side of the river, but also the wrong side of the railway. I won’t say which my current view stands in this chart of a made up class system. But, I look up to the right to a bus stop I need to pass and see a group of young lads, hand down their trousers and on their wee willy winkies and I decide to just head the opposite direction. If the Tesco employee was suspicious of my walking stick, or staff, wand? Then these chaps will want to make a few awkward inquiries; always trust your gut.
Pleasantly surprised by the streets and back alleys I wind down, I make my way quickly though Rosyth. I came across many cats but no people, until I reach the local football ground. It’s rugged and harshly laid out and windswept, much like everything else this side of the Forth it so far. A game is on and it has drawn quite a crowd. Shouts, punts of a football and conversation echo around the fields. I pass unnoticed as two posties discuss the ins and outs of the club. Before disappearing around a corner of wild bushes I witness the worst throw-in I’ve ever seen. But the managers shout enthusiasm, which is humbling and just all round nice, really. I spot a box of a school across the flat fields. More importantly I get my first view of Dunfermline. “I’m coming for you!” I point with my stick. Before long I’m turned onto a busy, loud road. Cars speed past kicking up dust, cups and I spot a perfectly new boot on the side of the road. How did it get here? Distantly I see a line of trees leading up a hill. My next stop to aim for; a cemetery.
What seemed like a mile or two later I cross in a rare gap of speedy cars and vans and onto a country lane. Straight as an arrow it heads to the cemetery where I pause briefly before heading into. I scan around; it is both old and new, both forgotten and intensely remembered. My road strikes right through it and around left, but the loop also goes right and back to where I’m standing. Lines and lines of graves fall into formation up the hill, around the loops and over through some trees. Some are old, almost green but many are shiny, bright, shaped intricately. There are plenty of flowers, more than I have ever seen in a cemetery. A freshly dug pile of dirt faces me directly straight on through the middle; orange in the glaring sun through the bare branches. I head right, along a long row of varying scales of gravestones to a bench. Thanking the folk on the plaque I sit and re-sock, eat and drink. I am alone only a few minutes before a blue car creeps into the cemetery, up the middle and begins to loop towards me. It stops. A woman of vibrant red lipstick and matching jacket steps out. She does not look around. Red roses are grasped firmly in her hands and she heads quickly to a grave. Roses planted, she says something. I look in my bag for some more food, I do not want to encroach upon such a moment. When I look up she is driving past me, eyes fixed ahead. She’s gone.
Part of me wanted to go see who she had just visited. Ultimately I decided against it and let the place drift in my mind. A beautifully colourful windmill danced in the middle of the rows. Around it some stones had faded flowers, some fresh, some well trodden, some slightly overgrown. I wonder, for the faded ones, what was the very last time they were visited. Why did the visits stop? Are they forgotten or are they remembered elsewhere? The cleaner ones make me weep; grief is all still too near for me. If I cry at an empty beach what hope do I have here? A van chugs into the entrance and stops, a bunch of guys jump out and begin to offload flowers; watering them in a very old tap that sits right near the gate. Another two cars enter to navigate the back end of the cemetery. I take it as a cue to leave, I have no purpose here.
Up upon the hill the cemetery swoops down from where I see the wartime graveyard, clean, green and precise in its purpose. Their white stone shines even in the shadows of the canopy above. My path turns muddy, leafy. Farms and fields replace roads and graves. This scenery is where I feel most at home. Dug out pathways, faded metal gates, long grasses and upturned troughs. Calmness descends over me and I stand for a while on a particularly exposed, high field and close my eyes to take in the sounds. Birds, wind, a distant gunshot. I move on.
Through a forest I pass silently in thought. A very recent fallen tree breaks my path in two; it has also stripped another tree of all its branches as it fell. Quite a sight to see, the sound must have been tremendous. Leaves crunch and slide as I navigate around it. I then bump into a runner with a bushy 80’s style moustache. He looks as surprised to see me rustling through the woods as I am of him. He hops one of the branches needlessly; it would have looked amazing in slow motion, I admit. Old walls of battered, mossy stones replace the leaves. They lead me to proper farmland, tractor markings and wide, open fields of various stages. Dodging puddles of depths unknown I march on towards a huddled collection of farmhouses and out buildings. A wee woman walking her dogs hurries past me; distrust in her eyes. A right angled turn left and I’m now facing North once more, and technically shouldn’t deviate from this direction until I meet my Uncle.
I am deep into mile 20 now. Dunfermline has been quite hidden down in the cemetery and winding farm pathways but now it taunts me openly. An adjustment of my backpack and a swig of water and I am set onto a thin line of a path on the edge of a busy road. It twists and turns before deciding to dive down into the town and before I know it I am encompassed by buildings and buses. It seemed like a click of a finger from farm to town, which is perhaps why this place is quite popular. My last trial is to find my way through the streets to where the gallery is; I immediately fail. Instead of heading right I take a wrong turn and find myself in a wee glen, complete with babbling brook. Another tree crosses my path, fallen fairly recently by the worn path being defined beneath it. I duck under and realise I now need to climb out of this quite beautiful place. How many trees have crossed my path today? 4? 5? I recount in my mind as I hustle up a zig zagging pathway. Onto solid ground and an uphill street leads me into the centre of town. I’m hot, sweaty and energy levels are in danger of plummeting right at the last. I head to Tesco and grab a Lucozade before my Uncle pops around the corner with a massive smile on his face.
Over a well earned pint we chat about all things worldly, both important and unimportant in life. Our food takes 5 working days to appear but I’m content. His artwork is awe inspiring, and a deep sense of pride grabs me as we view it and discuss it. There’s a deep, heavy therapy in the artwork that is echoed by the other pieces in the exhibit. Truly amazing to see. A few hours later I am dropped off at the station to head back on the next train that shows. As I whizz back along my 6 hour journey in 20 minutes I view my trials one by one, and a zen like sense of achievement washes over me. Immediately, though, I am distracted by a group of lads sat behind me; they are talking heavy Warhammer and a discussion has just broken out about one of them using the wrong paint for the wrong army. I waddle home from the station in Edinburgh, retracing my very early steps. My Pilgrimage is done and I am home once more. I never expected to find God, nor spiritual enlightenment, but I wish I had found more toilets and a steadier way to get across the Forth. In the morning I fly to Portugal, and have heard from reliable sources that Pilgrims do well there. But we shall see.
--
--
Walking to find a sense of self and mindfulness. 'Am I a Pilgrim, yet?' is my current series- not religious, but mindful.

Title: Edinburgh, Take 2!
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

I'm on the journey I've waited for my entire life - and I want to remember it! Updates on my adjustment to British life, foreign travel, and all things abroad.

--
Listen
Share
Mist rises. Saturday morning lacks the alarm clock. A full backpack sits in on a desk, waiting for me to pick it up and go. My second trip to Scotland’s capital. My first journey alone.
Sure, there are plenty of people to invite, but it’s mid-semester and students are swamped with projects. Not me — I only have two classes — so the desire to leave Stirling lures me to Edinburgh.
I rise at 7:32 despite no alarm. Twenty minutes. A comb strikes through my hair, gloss rubs across my lips, and I exit my bedroom with no regrets. The 7:52 bus doesn’t come until around 8:00; only four students sit at the stop. When I reach the train station, I catch a breath and keep going. I can’t back out now. I’m doing this for myself.
I buy a ticket for the 8:30 train and wait in the cold, open-aired platform. The squeaky wheels rush into the station and I enter with old women and old men. There’s an empty window seat, just for me. I listen to headphones and try not to drift back to sleep; only an hour until I arrive to my first destination.
Before I came to Scotland, when I watched videos of the best sites to visit in places like Edinburgh, I learned one of the cafes is marked as the location JK Rowling scratched the Harry Potter series on napkins. As soon as I step out of Edinburgh Waverley, I walk nine short minutes to The Elephant House, a near hole-in-the-wall restaurant with humble service (and filled with decorative elephants!). I order a cinnamon latte to get in the fall spirit, grab a seat at the front window, and open my laptop to Word. For the next hour, beside an Uber driver reading his morning paper, I write and edit and complete a chapter of my new novel, Floor Number Nine. It is the perfect rainy October morning. And While the street view is gorgeous, it makes me feel special when tourists stop in front of the window to take photographs of the cafe. For all they know, I’m a local!
When the waitress asks to take the empty plates, I understand I’ve overstayed my welcome, so I quickly save the final page of the chapter and stuff the laptop inside my backpack. Raincoat on, I flip the hood over my hair and search the next destination, the Writer’s Museum.
This free attraction is a short walk, tucked in a courtyard behind the skinny Lady Stair’s Close. It’s a quirky house with an open door and a sign which reads: Robert Louis Stevenson — Downstairs. Glad to get out of the rain, I step into the warm museum, greeted by photographs and displays. Stephenson’s original works, family portraits, and even household furniture (that I could touch!). After this exhibit, I return upstairs to a warm living room, complete with a fireplace, chandelier, wooden paneling, and old couples enjoying their morning tea. I learn this building was built in the 1620’s and belonged to Lady Stair.
Upstairs, exhibitions of poet Robert Burns and famous writer Sir Walter Scott decorate the traditional rooms. From chess boards, to cotton caps, to quill pens, I explore the artifacts of writers I’d read in grade school.
Returning to the rainy city, I walk a few blocks until I reach St. Giles Cathedral. This time, I don’t take pictures; I focus on the moment, soaking in the gorgeous stained glass, gazing at the vaulted ceilings, and listening to a pastor read Psalms to a quiet audience.
The National Museum of Scotland is not far from this cathedral. While this modern building seems bland on the exterior, its structure is fascinating. Totaling 6 floors, this museum is a maze of ancient and modern exhibits. I spend an hour and a half starting upstairs and working my way down. The map lists highlighted attractions, so I go in search for these — the canteen of Bonnie Prince Charlie, the clay creations of Picasso, ornate jewelry crafted by women centuries ago. What I find most intriguing is Dolly the cloned sheep. When I spot the thick glass case, I step as close as possible to the famous animal, surprised to learn the embryo was cloned in a Scottish laboratory. It is surreal, staring into the real eyes of the sheep I briefly studied in ninth grade biology.
I check the time on my phone and decide to move on to the next location. I’ve made plans to visit Dean Village, a quaint section outside of the inner city. Google Maps says it is a twenty-five minute walk, and I head down the street with an eager spirit. The rain is gone, fog rolls above the Edinburgh Castle, and I’m immersed in the perfect autumnal aesthetic.
I see a pub with a recognizable heading: Greyfriar’s Bobby. The church behind it is surrounded by a famous kirkyard (graveyard) where a dog, Greyfriar’s Bobby, is buried. While I don’t understand the significance of the dog or his master, I pass the pub and enter the church, expecting to find another intricate cathedral. While the interior is less impressive (I accidentally get lost, enter a set of closed doors, and find myself in the office rooms in the second level of the church), a guide leads me to the dog’s grave. Covered with a half-empty bush, the stone is planted directly in front of the church, marking the loyal dog who lived for sixteen years.
Large tour groups stroll through the foggy graveyard; I make my own rounds, using the time to take photographs of the fog-covered steeples and creepy tombstones. The perfect October location.
When you pass the statue of the beloved dog, right beside the Greyfriar’s pub, you are supposed to rub its nose for good luck. Not knowing this, I (uneducated American that I am) simply stroke the bronze fur and continue down the path on Google Maps. I have to see Dean Village, after all!
But another cathedral catches my eye. And after stopping inside, I recognize the brand names of giant stores across the road — I’ve made it to the shopping district. Princes Street, specifically. Across from me lies a Starbucks, an Urban Outfitters, a Primark, and a TopShop. I know where I’m headed after the village.
As directed by Google Maps, I hike down a hill under a bridge. It is darker now, and quieter, but I’m confident the destination will be worth the trek. The closer I get, however, (a sign on a building reads: Dean Village — This Way), the emptier and emptier the streets become. Eventually, as I step into the picaresque location, I walk alone. The cobblestone streets are wet. I slip clumsily down the hill onto my back, and no one is there to help me up.
This is okay. Laughing, I continue to walk down the street and cross a bridge. At first, the lack of shops and people makes the village underwhelming, but then I take gorgeous photos of the landscape, and I am fully content.
Tired and ready for rest, I return to Princes Street and enter the Starbucks. Here, I charge my phone, find some free WiFi, and eat a snack to prepare for the rest of the afternoon.
On the way to the Sir Walter Scott monument, I am captivated by a baroque-looking steeple. The cathedral, St. Mary’s Cathedral, is enormous, and I’m shocked I’ve never heard of the church until now. I walk down a broad street, full of wide marble buildings and Scottish flags, until I reach the front door and stroll inside. Again, my breath is taken:
Of course, photographs never capture the true atmosphere of cathedrals!
The Sir Walter Scott Monument is the largest and tallest monument to a writer in the world. As a creative writing major, this should impress me — and it does, however, this is the only site which requires a fee to enter. So I don’t. I do walk around the garden, stare up at the statue of Scott himself, and take plenty of photographs with the structure.
For the rest of the evening, I pass the time until my 5:30 train with shopping. Urban Outfitters has a 70% off sale. The Primark consists of three whole stories. I dip into Top Shop (because I’ve never been to a physical store before) as well as H&M, and before I know it, I’m racing through a line to purchase souvenirs before rushing to catch the train.
My first trip alone in the nation’s capitol. Needless to say, I am proud of myself and all the locations I am able to visit. Days like these help solidify my decision to study abroad; I need them, because if I’m honest, sometimes I feel like I made a mistake in thinking I could last four months here. Foreign travel, especially without any friends or relatives to travel with, is frightening. But it is also thrilling, and it calls me. Days like this prove I am up for the challenge.
--

Title: The Best Immersive at Edinburgh Festival Fringe 2023
Content:
Sign up
