Title: Am I a Pilgrim, yet ? | Walking Edinburgh to Dunfermline.
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
This 21 mile walk from the Scottish Capital to the centre of Dunfermline is a pilgrimage of my own making. It didn’t aim for any church or holy site; instead I aimed to go see my Uncle’s artwork being exhibited in the centre of Dunfermline. Ever one to make something harder than it should be in the search for growth, I planned out how I could walk from my front door to his paintings. A week before the route was being tweaked and twiddled with, down to where I can stop for an emergency piss if the need arose. Turns out, not many people walk from the centre of Edinburgh, across the Forth and onto Dunfermline. The only snippets of adventures I could find dipped in and out of my route; but none of them were complete. Perfect, an adventure is to be had.
I am not religious, nor have I ever been, yet through walking and adventuring I have found a sense of mindfulness. A spiritual freedom you may call it. At around 10 miles I experience a deep sense of joy and zen. Runners have told me they experience something similar, but I have yet to find that point running; instead I feel every excruciating second of the bloody thing. Yet, via walking I zone into a different world, one of my own making. At mile 15 I usually land hard like a Ryanair aeroplane before bouncing up back into my mindfulness. For this walk, though, I would hit mile 20. What then would that bring me?
It’s 6:30 am and my HipHop mix alarm is sudden and loud. ‘Damn it feels good to be a Gangsta’. True, maybe. Today I’m hoping it feels good to be a Pilgrim; whatever that is. January is in full flow, but storms have passed and there’s clear cool air in the city. Not many are trundling about as I leave, espresso heavy on my stomach, at around 7:30 am. Deliveries clatter and clang into Sainsbury’s, high vis workers smash down the lorry’s back doors and floors. It cuts the crisp morning air. I begin to look forward to the promised remoteness of much of my trek. Before long I am passing a quiet Haymarket Station; it is the weekend, no commuters are jousting up and down the road today. Air is blue, the moon is full and bright against the wisps of clouds. Their fast movement across its face does not bode well for the wind later on.
Edinburgh has a fair amount of old railway lines that have been tarmaced over and converted into sheltered paths. The one I spring onto is a familiar one for me; during lockdown I would glide down here to the beach, filled with regret when I get there that I didn’t pack more warm clothes. Even in the height of summer Cramond is a windy bitch. A jogger huffs past and a cyclist dressed all in black whizzes past. My espresso gurgles and shifts; what was my toiletry plan again? I stare down at my phone like a lost tourist coming out of Waverly. A Tesco is marked at the very end of my railway route and before I dive between two golf courses. My breakfast stop. Tree’s sway and lurch in the wind as the dark blue sky turns to pink, then a light gold. The sun is on its way behind me as a veer off from my Northern path to the West.
A Tesco employee stares at my walking stick in a bit of a stunned silence as I ask about toilets. Seconds pass before he forces out a ‘No’. Not quite the spiritual guidance I was looking for on my Pilgrimage, I admit. But perhaps this area doesn’t get many wanderers this early on a Saturday. I dart off and onto a well-to-do road. Cameras, locked gates and larger financed cars come and go as I wander through. The houses get larger and more elaborate, the gates get more defensive and taller. This road is very clean, I will say. Although there seems to be no sign of life I can’t help feel eyes on me. Perhaps a Pilgrimage is a trial of sorts. This is my first one today; do not shit yourself in a posh neighbourhood. It would be caught on multiple cameras and posted online as a VR experience before I reach the Forth Road Bridge.
The road comes to an abrupt end, turning into a path which seems meagre and slim compared to the vastness of the properties behind me. I’m now sandwiched between two golf course, various signs tell me not to litter or even contemplate becoming a member; they can tell I’m not quite up to scratch by the stick I’m swaying about. A dog walker, the first of the day, looks tired and fed up. He looks up under his hat but his eyes are sunken, sad. Is it golf that has made him like this? Or the weight of owning a castle? Or perhaps he doesn’t belong here, like me, but comes to envy and depressed about the life some lead. Either way we slink past each over on this wee pathway. More big houses flank me as I pop out onto a new street, these are chopped up into flats, though. Suddenly I dive down a windy old road and into some trees. At the bottom of this glen like snake I come across a small field of ponies. It is cold and damp down here, the houses look sodden. Then, just as I’m getting the heebie jeebies I turn sharply onto a stone bridge that spans a smooth, icy cold river. I stop for breakfast.
Before me the river is escorted into the distance by forestry and steep green banks. Tops of the trees are on fire from the ever so slowly rising sun. A golden morning stabs across the landscape, splicing my view into harsh warms and glassy colds. A dog comes to inspect my backpack and the fallen crusty crumbs of my pork pie. Their walker takes no heed of me. A few minutes pass watching the silk like water flow away from me and I head off up and out of the crossing. On my left a helter skelter of a building seems to have been slapped together in a rustled puzzle box. Is it a community centre? A church? I place a bet with myself and lose it all immediately. It’s a steak restaurant; I have driven past it numerous times on the way to the bridges. It brings a nice pang of realisation how far I have to go yet, seen as though the road takes a while and goes almost directly to them. I, though, must turn hard right towards the shore. North once more, away from the city and into the Dalmeny Estate.
A large muddy puddle welcomes me into the estate via a metal gate. I spend a few seconds staring it down. I’m mile 7 into my walk. If I get my feet wet now then the next 15 will be less than ideal. I jump it and slip with my walking stick. Luckily I’m alone and swan off up the long, straight road. To my right now there is a line of soldier like trees being pierced with brilliant gold. Their shadows barcode the road before me as it stretches off into a wide left leaning corner. My left is all ploughed farm fields, topped with bushes and trees as they slope uphill. I stop to take some photos for my own personal stash of farm related memories. A country lad at heart. Snowdrops welcome me at the various twists and turns of my golden road and before long the landscape opens up wide into rolling fields. A deep warm stench of hay and manure catches the wind here and there and now I begin to see some new faces.
“Morning!” A deep, booming voice bellows at me as a runner flies past. It startles me as I’m now zoning out into my zen-like world of farm equipment and muddy trails. “You alright!” I shout back. An exhausted “Aye.” Floats back to me. A few more people, dog walkers, general walkers and runners go past and each say good morning, how are you doing, beautiful day for it. It’s a social extravaganza here in the estate. My flurry of networking peters out and I slope down into more forestry. Thin, tall pines guard the shoreline that I can see spanning the view between their dark barks. The sun has yet to reach down here. A quietness settles around me, shells appear in the muddy path. I see a small opening onto the beach and jump driftwood onto the pebbly, sandy shore. It’s wonderful. Expansive and calm with the tide out, the sea is a far off foe I will conquer later in the day. For now it offers a definitive end to my Northern direction. Cramond Beach to my right is busy with people, but they are distant and seem to be across a dreamlike void. Cramond Island sits amongst the warm light of the morning, ships moving slowly behind it; their bright red hulls a stark brush stroke on an otherwise fair, cold view. I sit on the driftwood and stretch my legs. Silence. A swish of leaves above me as a gust of wind hits. Nothing. A leaf rustles onto my trainers. I cry, just a little.
On my walks I often cry, or get to a point that holds me to a tear or two. Sometimes it’s the silence, the calm. Or sometimes it’s a memory spurred from what I’m seeing, what I’m thinking or what I’m hearing. This Pilrimage has a density heavier than most due to death itself, which hit my family from all sides in all ways in 2021. For reasons I’m yet to really figure out myself, I have never posted about it on socials, or anywhere, really. A percieved lack of permission from who knows who, or a unwillingness to put any of it to solidified, permenant digital ink? I do not know, but I will say, on this walk I carried everyone with me, every step.
I’m just about to hit mile 8 and this is where my first tear drops of the day. But what a view for it to happen to. I spend longer than I probably should watching the world, not really do much. Voices behind me in the woodland break my train of thought. Runners coming up through the path I’m yet to tread. I look left expecting, foolishly, to see the red arches of the rail bridge spanning the water. Nothing in sight. I have a long way to go. Fife taunts me slightly as I dive back into the woods, it knows I’m coming for it. But it also knows how many trials I have to face on my wee Pilgrimage.
Shortly I see a bright square of stone drawn onto the curving coastline through the woods. Above it is a bright blue sky with textured clouds. The sun hits it hard, bright. A castle of light stone sits proudly upon the sandy waters of the Forth. But it is a way away yet. I trundle on through beautiful woodland, red trunks vear up to swaying canopies. Sometimes the sun strikes in and searches out the shining shells and sand that pop up here and there. Now and again a fallen tree crosses my path. Some old and mossy, some new and yet to be traversed properly. I cross a rolling stream of turquoise as it tumbles down into the grassy banks of the beach. It guides me along its shore before it spits me out onto another expansive view of the beach. This time there are less pebbles and more shimmering sand. My guide curves its way down to the sea through the banks. Following it with my eyes it leads me to the castle, now much closer. Mile 8 done. There’s an Eminem joke in there somewhere.
Green grass mixes with yellow sand like a paint palette. I pick up speed. My surroundings have me excited with this adventure. Castles, beaches, forests and farms. Dalmeny House solidifies my enjoyment as it pops up, looming proudly on my left. Vibrant, flat green grass rolls right up to its walls. It is a set piece, a view with a view and it stops me in my tracks. But the magic falters. Seemingly it is being renovated, or gutted. Ugly metal fences hug it horribly and metal work pokes out here and there. Windows boarded, taped. A pile of shite on it’s flanks. No matter, I have the castle I have been walking towards for the last few miles. My bright stone castle on the water. Once I get to it the magic falters again. No Entry. Fair enough. But, it too is boarded up, closed off, hiding. Recent work is obvious, but it is a shy place. Seaward it stands out and proud, but us landlubbers can only catch glimpses as it peers through shrubbery and trees. Perhaps I need some energy or water because my mood takes a bit of a dip. The next two miles are a slog, they are cold and my golden sun disappears for a long while. Where the hell are the bridges?
Maybe that was one of my trials of my Pilgrimage, a featureless forest that seems to never end. More likely it is my need to have a little rest and some food. Luckily the red metal work of the Rail Bridge begins to appear between the leaves. Then I find an opening and stumble down a muddy bank to a bunch of rocks. Perfectly there is a large fallen tree that acts as a seat. I sit, eat and admire the view. The Forth Rail Bridge spans across the water right before me. South Queensferry nestles underneath all three of the bridges to my left; my next destination before crossing the middle bridge. The wind is scathingly cold here. Boats bob about, waves lap hectically. I scoff my face and stretch my legs. My uncle messages me, “Where about are you?” I send a photo of the bridge back. Next up, South Queensferry.
Before I get into the meat of the town a woman walks out from her car in front of me and stops dead for seemingly no reason. I check my stride and go to pass her but she absent mindedly wanders to the side I’m going around. It is no big thing, but after marching for 11 miles now it was a strange feeling to me, stopped dead by a person not paying attention to anything. I leave her in my dust and enter a quiet town. Behind me the Forth Rail Bridge stands tall. Walking beneath it is nothing compared to taking a step back and viewing it. I always remember seeing it when I was younger on the TV and it seemed mystical to me. When I first moved up to Scotland it was the one thing I was desperate to see. Now, walking underneath it and having it as part of my adventure I felt a sense of connection to it. To bring myself back down to earth I finally found a toilet in South Queensferry and made sure I left my mark for any following Pilgrims. A miracle occurred there.
Soon enough I was dodging folk on pavements as I stormed up the hill towards the beginning of the bridge I was to cross. Once I got underneath it I felt a sting of excitement about what I was about to do. It’s cold, dark concrete consumed me as I looped up to the road from the town. Stopping briefly to adjust my backpack and jacket, I set out to go across. Then it hit me. A fear so deep, so bubbly and heavy that I almost fell to the floor. It wraithed inside of my stomach and my eyes became like a small tunnel. I staunchly marched forward as fast as I could, but once I’d reached the water the fear consumed me. Tiny gaps every 10 ft or so let me see the waters far below. Every coach that stormed past me bounced the large metalworks that struck up high and mighty above me. Wind blew and gust in a menacingly horrible way; it seemed determined to shove me over the edge. This was not enjoyable. I had hoped to grab some good photos of the Rail Bridge I adored so much whilst on here, but now… Get me off here! Metal creaked. The floor bounced. The wind blew. A cyclist went past and was nearly blown into me. Madman. At one point I swept past a porta-loo; what a way to go, blown into the Forth by a cubicle of shite. I could not get across to the otherside quick enough. But, had I known what I was about to tackle I may well have just stayed on the bridge.
It’s hot in the sun now. Face warm from the wind and no doubt the nerves I settled down on the steps that climb from the bridge to a road. Everything on this side of the Forth seems quiet and empty. No cars, nor people, mill about or make any sound. I take a moment. Now I convince myself that my Pilgrimage does indeed have trials, and the bridge was the biggest one by far. Never again! I proceed underneath its shadowy archways after a few more bites to eat. The road I’m on heads up and over a small hill before it dips suddenly down to swoop under the large motorway. In amongst the swirling, busy roads sits a boarded up house. It’s wee, messy and depressing. Concrete hugs the landscape and even in the yellow light of the day it is cold. This has become quite a tour of infrastructure, if that is the type of thing you’re into. I video call my wife.
Not as impressed by my feat of terror crossing the bridge as I thought she would be, she asks what my onward route is. Docks, Rosyth and forests, I reply. The sun is beating down now and I’m exposed to its warmth and the cold wind as I plod along. Down below me I see a grandfather and his granddaughter, fitted out with wellies, traversing a wind swept nature reserve. At least, these are the facts I project down upon the scene. Reeds and grass ebb and flow in the eager gusts. They shelter but chat enthusiastically. I stand for a while as they bounce away into the hazy grasses; tall bridges loom above them off into the choppy waters. I turn and continue along the most tedious road I’ve ever walked up.
Large metal buildings at the docks creak and boom as machinery, cranes, buildings get closer and more imposing. On the other side of the road there’s just shite. Sewerage works, quarries, a large car park where a bored looking guy in a JCB backhoe moves around asphalt. Usually I love a big of heavy machinery action, but I just want to get out of this tundrum place. It takes longer, it seems, than my whole walk completed beforehand to reach the pathway I need to dart up to get away. A pigeon coop castle stops me in my tracks, but the litter strewn path forces me to move on swiftly. My walks are all about moods and mindfulness; I find it difficult to reach those heady heights when bags of dog shit wave at me as I pass them as if I’m some kind of royal shitter.
The mood does not improve as I’m spat out into a disused industrial park. Large blue offices with smashed windows and fenced off to the nines greet me. Two lads saunter in front of me, neither see me until I whizz past them. “Eh!” One of them exclaims. Who knows what stories they have to hand to fling out at the drop of a hat. But I have wasted time watching families explore nature reserves and need to speed through my next section. I turn out of this and onto a roundabout. The housing estate across from me, and which I now need to navigate, is a familiar one to me. In my hometown you are looked down upon if you live on the wrong side of the river. And those that do look down upon those who live on the wrong side of the river, but also the wrong side of the railway. I won’t say which my current view stands in this chart of a made up class system. But, I look up to the right to a bus stop I need to pass and see a group of young lads, hand down their trousers and on their wee willy winkies and I decide to just head the opposite direction. If the Tesco employee was suspicious of my walking stick, or staff, wand? Then these chaps will want to make a few awkward inquiries; always trust your gut.
Pleasantly surprised by the streets and back alleys I wind down, I make my way quickly though Rosyth. I came across many cats but no people, until I reach the local football ground. It’s rugged and harshly laid out and windswept, much like everything else this side of the Forth it so far. A game is on and it has drawn quite a crowd. Shouts, punts of a football and conversation echo around the fields. I pass unnoticed as two posties discuss the ins and outs of the club. Before disappearing around a corner of wild bushes I witness the worst throw-in I’ve ever seen. But the managers shout enthusiasm, which is humbling and just all round nice, really. I spot a box of a school across the flat fields. More importantly I get my first view of Dunfermline. “I’m coming for you!” I point with my stick. Before long I’m turned onto a busy, loud road. Cars speed past kicking up dust, cups and I spot a perfectly new boot on the side of the road. How did it get here? Distantly I see a line of trees leading up a hill. My next stop to aim for; a cemetery.
What seemed like a mile or two later I cross in a rare gap of speedy cars and vans and onto a country lane. Straight as an arrow it heads to the cemetery where I pause briefly before heading into. I scan around; it is both old and new, both forgotten and intensely remembered. My road strikes right through it and around left, but the loop also goes right and back to where I’m standing. Lines and lines of graves fall into formation up the hill, around the loops and over through some trees. Some are old, almost green but many are shiny, bright, shaped intricately. There are plenty of flowers, more than I have ever seen in a cemetery. A freshly dug pile of dirt faces me directly straight on through the middle; orange in the glaring sun through the bare branches. I head right, along a long row of varying scales of gravestones to a bench. Thanking the folk on the plaque I sit and re-sock, eat and drink. I am alone only a few minutes before a blue car creeps into the cemetery, up the middle and begins to loop towards me. It stops. A woman of vibrant red lipstick and matching jacket steps out. She does not look around. Red roses are grasped firmly in her hands and she heads quickly to a grave. Roses planted, she says something. I look in my bag for some more food, I do not want to encroach upon such a moment. When I look up she is driving past me, eyes fixed ahead. She’s gone.
Part of me wanted to go see who she had just visited. Ultimately I decided against it and let the place drift in my mind. A beautifully colourful windmill danced in the middle of the rows. Around it some stones had faded flowers, some fresh, some well trodden, some slightly overgrown. I wonder, for the faded ones, what was the very last time they were visited. Why did the visits stop? Are they forgotten or are they remembered elsewhere? The cleaner ones make me weep; grief is all still too near for me. If I cry at an empty beach what hope do I have here? A van chugs into the entrance and stops, a bunch of guys jump out and begin to offload flowers; watering them in a very old tap that sits right near the gate. Another two cars enter to navigate the back end of the cemetery. I take it as a cue to leave, I have no purpose here.
Up upon the hill the cemetery swoops down from where I see the wartime graveyard, clean, green and precise in its purpose. Their white stone shines even in the shadows of the canopy above. My path turns muddy, leafy. Farms and fields replace roads and graves. This scenery is where I feel most at home. Dug out pathways, faded metal gates, long grasses and upturned troughs. Calmness descends over me and I stand for a while on a particularly exposed, high field and close my eyes to take in the sounds. Birds, wind, a distant gunshot. I move on.
Through a forest I pass silently in thought. A very recent fallen tree breaks my path in two; it has also stripped another tree of all its branches as it fell. Quite a sight to see, the sound must have been tremendous. Leaves crunch and slide as I navigate around it. I then bump into a runner with a bushy 80’s style moustache. He looks as surprised to see me rustling through the woods as I am of him. He hops one of the branches needlessly; it would have looked amazing in slow motion, I admit. Old walls of battered, mossy stones replace the leaves. They lead me to proper farmland, tractor markings and wide, open fields of various stages. Dodging puddles of depths unknown I march on towards a huddled collection of farmhouses and out buildings. A wee woman walking her dogs hurries past me; distrust in her eyes. A right angled turn left and I’m now facing North once more, and technically shouldn’t deviate from this direction until I meet my Uncle.
I am deep into mile 20 now. Dunfermline has been quite hidden down in the cemetery and winding farm pathways but now it taunts me openly. An adjustment of my backpack and a swig of water and I am set onto a thin line of a path on the edge of a busy road. It twists and turns before deciding to dive down into the town and before I know it I am encompassed by buildings and buses. It seemed like a click of a finger from farm to town, which is perhaps why this place is quite popular. My last trial is to find my way through the streets to where the gallery is; I immediately fail. Instead of heading right I take a wrong turn and find myself in a wee glen, complete with babbling brook. Another tree crosses my path, fallen fairly recently by the worn path being defined beneath it. I duck under and realise I now need to climb out of this quite beautiful place. How many trees have crossed my path today? 4? 5? I recount in my mind as I hustle up a zig zagging pathway. Onto solid ground and an uphill street leads me into the centre of town. I’m hot, sweaty and energy levels are in danger of plummeting right at the last. I head to Tesco and grab a Lucozade before my Uncle pops around the corner with a massive smile on his face.
Over a well earned pint we chat about all things worldly, both important and unimportant in life. Our food takes 5 working days to appear but I’m content. His artwork is awe inspiring, and a deep sense of pride grabs me as we view it and discuss it. There’s a deep, heavy therapy in the artwork that is echoed by the other pieces in the exhibit. Truly amazing to see. A few hours later I am dropped off at the station to head back on the next train that shows. As I whizz back along my 6 hour journey in 20 minutes I view my trials one by one, and a zen like sense of achievement washes over me. Immediately, though, I am distracted by a group of lads sat behind me; they are talking heavy Warhammer and a discussion has just broken out about one of them using the wrong paint for the wrong army. I waddle home from the station in Edinburgh, retracing my very early steps. My Pilgrimage is done and I am home once more. I never expected to find God, nor spiritual enlightenment, but I wish I had found more toilets and a steadier way to get across the Forth. In the morning I fly to Portugal, and have heard from reliable sources that Pilgrims do well there. But we shall see.
--
--
Walking to find a sense of self and mindfulness. 'Am I a Pilgrim, yet?' is my current series- not religious, but mindful.

Title: Edinburgh, Take 2!
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

I'm on the journey I've waited for my entire life - and I want to remember it! Updates on my adjustment to British life, foreign travel, and all things abroad.

--
Listen
Share
Mist rises. Saturday morning lacks the alarm clock. A full backpack sits in on a desk, waiting for me to pick it up and go. My second trip to Scotland’s capital. My first journey alone.
Sure, there are plenty of people to invite, but it’s mid-semester and students are swamped with projects. Not me — I only have two classes — so the desire to leave Stirling lures me to Edinburgh.
I rise at 7:32 despite no alarm. Twenty minutes. A comb strikes through my hair, gloss rubs across my lips, and I exit my bedroom with no regrets. The 7:52 bus doesn’t come until around 8:00; only four students sit at the stop. When I reach the train station, I catch a breath and keep going. I can’t back out now. I’m doing this for myself.
I buy a ticket for the 8:30 train and wait in the cold, open-aired platform. The squeaky wheels rush into the station and I enter with old women and old men. There’s an empty window seat, just for me. I listen to headphones and try not to drift back to sleep; only an hour until I arrive to my first destination.
Before I came to Scotland, when I watched videos of the best sites to visit in places like Edinburgh, I learned one of the cafes is marked as the location JK Rowling scratched the Harry Potter series on napkins. As soon as I step out of Edinburgh Waverley, I walk nine short minutes to The Elephant House, a near hole-in-the-wall restaurant with humble service (and filled with decorative elephants!). I order a cinnamon latte to get in the fall spirit, grab a seat at the front window, and open my laptop to Word. For the next hour, beside an Uber driver reading his morning paper, I write and edit and complete a chapter of my new novel, Floor Number Nine. It is the perfect rainy October morning. And While the street view is gorgeous, it makes me feel special when tourists stop in front of the window to take photographs of the cafe. For all they know, I’m a local!
When the waitress asks to take the empty plates, I understand I’ve overstayed my welcome, so I quickly save the final page of the chapter and stuff the laptop inside my backpack. Raincoat on, I flip the hood over my hair and search the next destination, the Writer’s Museum.
This free attraction is a short walk, tucked in a courtyard behind the skinny Lady Stair’s Close. It’s a quirky house with an open door and a sign which reads: Robert Louis Stevenson — Downstairs. Glad to get out of the rain, I step into the warm museum, greeted by photographs and displays. Stephenson’s original works, family portraits, and even household furniture (that I could touch!). After this exhibit, I return upstairs to a warm living room, complete with a fireplace, chandelier, wooden paneling, and old couples enjoying their morning tea. I learn this building was built in the 1620’s and belonged to Lady Stair.
Upstairs, exhibitions of poet Robert Burns and famous writer Sir Walter Scott decorate the traditional rooms. From chess boards, to cotton caps, to quill pens, I explore the artifacts of writers I’d read in grade school.
Returning to the rainy city, I walk a few blocks until I reach St. Giles Cathedral. This time, I don’t take pictures; I focus on the moment, soaking in the gorgeous stained glass, gazing at the vaulted ceilings, and listening to a pastor read Psalms to a quiet audience.
The National Museum of Scotland is not far from this cathedral. While this modern building seems bland on the exterior, its structure is fascinating. Totaling 6 floors, this museum is a maze of ancient and modern exhibits. I spend an hour and a half starting upstairs and working my way down. The map lists highlighted attractions, so I go in search for these — the canteen of Bonnie Prince Charlie, the clay creations of Picasso, ornate jewelry crafted by women centuries ago. What I find most intriguing is Dolly the cloned sheep. When I spot the thick glass case, I step as close as possible to the famous animal, surprised to learn the embryo was cloned in a Scottish laboratory. It is surreal, staring into the real eyes of the sheep I briefly studied in ninth grade biology.
I check the time on my phone and decide to move on to the next location. I’ve made plans to visit Dean Village, a quaint section outside of the inner city. Google Maps says it is a twenty-five minute walk, and I head down the street with an eager spirit. The rain is gone, fog rolls above the Edinburgh Castle, and I’m immersed in the perfect autumnal aesthetic.
I see a pub with a recognizable heading: Greyfriar’s Bobby. The church behind it is surrounded by a famous kirkyard (graveyard) where a dog, Greyfriar’s Bobby, is buried. While I don’t understand the significance of the dog or his master, I pass the pub and enter the church, expecting to find another intricate cathedral. While the interior is less impressive (I accidentally get lost, enter a set of closed doors, and find myself in the office rooms in the second level of the church), a guide leads me to the dog’s grave. Covered with a half-empty bush, the stone is planted directly in front of the church, marking the loyal dog who lived for sixteen years.
Large tour groups stroll through the foggy graveyard; I make my own rounds, using the time to take photographs of the fog-covered steeples and creepy tombstones. The perfect October location.
When you pass the statue of the beloved dog, right beside the Greyfriar’s pub, you are supposed to rub its nose for good luck. Not knowing this, I (uneducated American that I am) simply stroke the bronze fur and continue down the path on Google Maps. I have to see Dean Village, after all!
But another cathedral catches my eye. And after stopping inside, I recognize the brand names of giant stores across the road — I’ve made it to the shopping district. Princes Street, specifically. Across from me lies a Starbucks, an Urban Outfitters, a Primark, and a TopShop. I know where I’m headed after the village.
As directed by Google Maps, I hike down a hill under a bridge. It is darker now, and quieter, but I’m confident the destination will be worth the trek. The closer I get, however, (a sign on a building reads: Dean Village — This Way), the emptier and emptier the streets become. Eventually, as I step into the picaresque location, I walk alone. The cobblestone streets are wet. I slip clumsily down the hill onto my back, and no one is there to help me up.
This is okay. Laughing, I continue to walk down the street and cross a bridge. At first, the lack of shops and people makes the village underwhelming, but then I take gorgeous photos of the landscape, and I am fully content.
Tired and ready for rest, I return to Princes Street and enter the Starbucks. Here, I charge my phone, find some free WiFi, and eat a snack to prepare for the rest of the afternoon.
On the way to the Sir Walter Scott monument, I am captivated by a baroque-looking steeple. The cathedral, St. Mary’s Cathedral, is enormous, and I’m shocked I’ve never heard of the church until now. I walk down a broad street, full of wide marble buildings and Scottish flags, until I reach the front door and stroll inside. Again, my breath is taken:
Of course, photographs never capture the true atmosphere of cathedrals!
The Sir Walter Scott Monument is the largest and tallest monument to a writer in the world. As a creative writing major, this should impress me — and it does, however, this is the only site which requires a fee to enter. So I don’t. I do walk around the garden, stare up at the statue of Scott himself, and take plenty of photographs with the structure.
For the rest of the evening, I pass the time until my 5:30 train with shopping. Urban Outfitters has a 70% off sale. The Primark consists of three whole stories. I dip into Top Shop (because I’ve never been to a physical store before) as well as H&M, and before I know it, I’m racing through a line to purchase souvenirs before rushing to catch the train.
My first trip alone in the nation’s capitol. Needless to say, I am proud of myself and all the locations I am able to visit. Days like these help solidify my decision to study abroad; I need them, because if I’m honest, sometimes I feel like I made a mistake in thinking I could last four months here. Foreign travel, especially without any friends or relatives to travel with, is frightening. But it is also thrilling, and it calls me. Days like this prove I am up for the challenge.
--

Title: Edinburgh, The City Of Ghosts
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Edinburgh is a haunted city.
I don’t mean ‘haunted’ in the supernatural sense, although I could point with my eyes closed and manage to hit several Ghost Tour aficionados who would be only too happy to prove me wrong. No, I mean ‘haunted’ in the sense that the city is a duology — ancient meets modern, and the ghosts of old Dùn èideann certainly haven’t gone to rest.
I have a friend from elsewhere who described Edinburgh as ‘having a quality’, and it does. The city is at home in all of its guises: tourist trap, hyperactive university town, well-to-do business capital. It is at once surprising and satisfying to see a place that wears all sorts of coats throughout the year, and it looks fabulous doing so. She may be many things, but the one thing she never is — under-dressed.
She also bleeds history. Walk across North Bridge, and you’ll find yourself in the heart of Edinburgh’s Old Town. And by ‘old’, we mean OLD. Your feet will find the gaps between cobbled streets that haven’t been updated since they were first laid, and if you look up at any building, you’ll see the ghosts of Edinburgh’s past, beautifully rendered in the form of intricate cornices, gargoyles and ornate carvings. Find yourself a close (Scottish word for tiny little street) and you’ll realise how little has actually been changed. These narrow streets are thrilling reminders of a long ago world that somehow still exists here, quietly maintaining a link to Scottish history.
It’s easy, standing in the shadow of Castle Rock on a winter’s day, to hear the bustle that would have been. Edinburgh captures our past, and feeds it to us in tiny mouthfuls. You don’t HAVE to look, but if you do, you’ll see stories in the walls. You’ll see markings and numbers left over from the original craftsmen. You’ll see heavy brass doorbells that no longer sing, but sit now as silent sentinels. In some houses and flats, original features languish beside modern conveniences: a Belfast sink next to a toaster, elegant sash windows behind a widescreen tv or immensely high ceilings looking down at a state of the art computer. It’s a quiet kind of ghost, but an effective haunting nonetheless.
It helps that we love our history, and we do everything we can to preserve it. Hardly any older buildings in Edinburgh get demolished and built up again. We’re used to re-purposing what is old, because although it is old, it is not broken. It’s a part of us, of our bones. They may creak, but they still function. As a result, new shop names are placed under carvings and signs that still bear the moniker of a store from decades ago. These things, they tell us where we’ve come from, and it seems important to the deep consciousness of Scotland to know this, to feel it. It’s the reason we sing ‘Auld Lang Syne’ at Hogmanay, and still compete in Highland Games. It would be a travesty to lose this unconscious memory of who we once were, to be out of touch with the stories of our national identity.
There is grandeur, too, in the ghost of our city. St Giles cathedral is a towering exercise in gothic beauty, sitting as it does, amongst tourist shops and chain restaurants. George Heriots School is a literal castle, complete with turrets, grand chamber rooms and teachers who flit about, crow-like, in antiquated robes. It inspired Hogwarts, after all, and it’s easy to see why. The city’s ghosts have magic. It is a type of grandeur that we so often overlook in our modern lives. Most of us spend our days in front of screens, from the ever increasingly large screens of our smartphones, to the computers that fill our thousands of offices. If we tried, we probably could spend an entire day never looking up or away from the eye-straining technology we rely on. This is not necessarily an evil — technology has allowed us to progress faster in the last 100 years than in the preceding 1000, but it does mean that we are in increasing danger of losing something precious — our historic identity.
So if you find yourself walking the cobbled streets of Edinburgh, take a moment to look. Look past the throngs of people hurrying against the sideways Scottish wind. Look past the brightly coloured lights of Christmas, or the sheer spectacle that is the Edinburgh Fringe. Instead, look for things that breathe quietly but do not speak. Look for the things that tell little stories of the past. Don’t worry, Edinburgh’s ghosts are friendly, and like all good Scots, incredibly welcoming hosts.
--
--
An often nocturnal creature. Highly sensitive to dairy products and sad movies. Fighting through first book draft. If you see me, I should be writing

Title: The Best Immersive at Edinburgh Festival Fringe 2023
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up

Follow publication
Your guide to the ever-evolving world of immersive art & entertainment
Follow publication
--
Listen
Share
Part Two of our Three Part coverage of the 2023 Edinburgh Festival Fringe.Find Part One here.Find Part Three here.
In 1947, a post-WW2 Europe came together to celebrate the arts at the newly formed Edinburgh International Festival. Eight theatre companies who had not been invited decided to show up anyway, and the Edinburgh Festival Fringe was created — the first-ever “Fringe Festival.” Since then, cities around the world have formed their own versions of the Fringe, but the original remains the largest. In fact, it holds the record as the largest performing arts festival in the world.
For its 2023 edition, 3,553 shows graced 288 venues all across the city — transforming the medieval streets of the Scottish capital into a bustling hub of creativity. With so many productions during the festival’s three-and-a-half-week run, crafting an itinerary proved to be a daunting task. But with the help of a few Excel spreadsheets, a good pair of walking shoes, and a very full calendar, I was able to see 57 shows during my seven days in Edinburgh — a mere 1.6% of the overall lineup, but a solid dive into the Fringe’s immersive offerings.
Here are my fifteen favorite immersive shows from the 2023 Edinburgh Festival Fringe (including a few in the Edinburgh International Festival):
Big Kid Kindergarten — Play Immersive (USA)
As adults, we don’t often get the time, space, or permission to play. Interests become hobbies become side hustles, and unstructured play is set aside in favor of adulting. Big Kid Kindergarten invites us to reconnect with our childhood selves.
At the beginning of the experience, Soleil Kohl, our teacher for the next hour, asks us to close our eyes and connect with our inner five-year-old. A variety of familiar items are strewn across the room — legos, Play-Doh, coloring books, crafting materials, and plushies. We choose the songs that play in the background — nursery rhymes, Barney, Sharon Lois & Bram — the soundtrack of our childhoods. As our class time comes to an end, we tidy up the space and then cuddle up with a pillow for a quick nap time.
It’s a simple concept and straightforward execution, but a surprisingly emotional experience for some (myself included) largely due to the insight, guidance, and warmth with which Kohl facilitates.
Bodies — Ray Young (UK)
After a twenty-minute Scotrail ride away from the bustle of the festival city, I find myself floating in the pool at Deans Community High School. Colored lights, a sprinkler, and miscellaneous inflatables scatter across the surface of the water. We’ve all been given the identity of a specific international body of water and told that this pool is the gathering place where we’re all to connect. Twinkling projections fill the space and soothing music fills the air.
There’s an oft-used analogy of immersive theatre being likened to immersion in water. As such, the venue and conceit of Bodies seem quite fitting. Though the show offers little in terms of narrative, the space became a place for meditation, and a welcome moment of calm amongst the busyness of the Festival.
Brave Space — Aloft (USA)
We stand gathered around a sheet. When given the signal, our hands grasp its edges and we lift it above our heads, walk underneath, and then lower it beneath our feet. We’ve built a big top, but this one is more intimate than most — the quarters are cramped such that the delineation between stage and audience is blurred. Hoops spin unnervingly close by, acrobats swing from a trapeze directly above my head, and props are handed to us for safekeeping. At one point, I hold onto a piece of rope alongside four other audience members while the performers, kept aloft by the rope and their trust in a handful of strangers, twirl in the air.
‘Audience participation’ and ‘acrobatics’ are two phrases that don’t often appear together. The latter requires peak physical conditioning, hours of practice, and great technical ability… the former an unpredictable entity. By combining these two, Aloft has created a genuine immersive circus experience and necessitated the creation of a brave, trusting, space on both sides to make it work.
Club Life — Fred Deakin (UK)
In Club Life, Fred Deakin tours us through the Edinburgh underground club scene of the 80s and 90s that he helped shape. But this exercise goes beyond a typical bout of reminiscing — instead of simply telling us about the parties he lovingly crafted and DJ’d, Deakin invites us onto the dancefloor to experience them ourselves.
With a few DJ decks, vinyl records, and a cast of dancers, key moments in Deakin’s musical life are recreated onstage. From the genre agnosticism of Thunderball to the delightfully quirky Misery (“the worst club night that there ever was or ever could be,”) we dance our way through seven distinct parties from his past.
Part dance party, part autobiography, Club Life is an engaging and heartwarming deep dive into a creative soul.
Ctrl Room :_ — Black Hound Productions (UK)
In the not-so-distant future, technology has changed the face of the battlefield. Armed with lethal AI innovations, tech giant Polemas has become a global military powerhouse. As I enter the Edinburgh Army Reserve Centre, I’m greeted by a uniformed individual. Are they part of the show or an army member using the space? This blurring of show vs. reality was present throughout the experience and contributed to Ctrl Room :_ being the most immersive production I attended during the festival.
After choosing to align myself with the civilian resistance, I’m brought to their control room. Over the next 60 minutes, we identify an aerial strike drone, build explosive weapons, devise a military strategy, and attempt to decode a mysterious device. Meanwhile, our opponents at Polemas work through their own set of challenges, and every action, puzzle solved, and decision made by both sides influences the final outcome.
Throughout, our rebel leaders emphasize the urgency of the task at hand — some of the best acting I’ve ever seen in an escape room environment. The overall experience felt so realistic that at one point I found myself cowering under a table in genuine fear. As we exited the room for the finale, bulletproof vests on our chests and Molotov cocktails in hand, I mentally steeled myself for the battlefield… then breathed a sigh of relief when we were instead led to a cutscene in the initial briefing room.
Food — Geoff Sobelle (USA) [International Festival]
Food is a playful and thoughtful exploration of society’s relationship with food — from the grandiosity of the fine dining industry to the humble origins, and increasingly complicated reality of the agricultural systems that feed us.
While sitting around a large fine dining table, Sobelle hands me a wine menu with a very specific set of instructions: I should not drink the glass of wine he’s about to pour for me. Instead, I’m asked to smell the liquid and connect the scent to a year and memory. The odor of whiteboard marker fills my nose and I share an early high school memory. A mix of magic, cleverness, and absurdity brings this half of the show to life. An order of salmon rolls is conjured from thin air, an impromptu trip to the “Arctic” produces the freshest of arctic char, and our enigmatic waiter decides to scarf down all the leftovers. The magic elements may not be the most elegant I’ve seen — Sobelle’s sleight of hand is at times visible, but this is easily forgiven as the true magic lies in the delightful absurdity of the situation.
As the restaurant “closes” for the night, Sobelle pulls the tablecloth off — dishes and all — to reveal a large surface of dirt underneath. He crawls into the space, unaffected by the damage being done to his dress shirt and slacks. From here, a once chatty Sobelle guides us in a silent demonstration of the industrialization of farming, as well as the infrastructure and communities that we built around it.
They say it’s bad manners to play with your food, but for Geoff Sobelle I think we can make an exception. With charm and a healthy dose of playfulness, Food is a thoughtful and whimsical meditation on an important industry.
Funeral — Ontroerend Goed (Belgium)
“If you want to remember, remember.If you want to forget, forget.But sometimes, when you want to remember you forget.But sometimes, when you want to forget your remember”
So go the translated lyrics of the Latin song we’re taught at the beginning of Funeral. The show, by immersive stalwarts Ontroerend Goed, is a collective ritual celebrating finiteness and the knowledge that we are not alone in whatever endings we mourn.
From start to end, Funeral emphasizes the importance of community. In one of the most unique openings I’ve experienced, we’re directed to shake hands with each and every audience member as we enter the room. Later, we pass logs down from person to person until each individual has a post to sit on. At the start of the show, we are offered the chance to share the names of those we are mourning. As these names are read out loud, I feel my eyes prickle with tears, and look around the room to see my emotions mirrored in the faces of others.
The most notable display of community-building that Funeral initiated was inviting people to the venue’s basement for a cup of post-show tea. This created a space where audience members could unpack the experience together. While many shows at this year’s Fringe emphasized the importance of community and connection, Funeral’s poignant joint rituals and creation of space for discussion made it the most successful at exploring these themes.
Hayfever — Emerge Production House (UK)
Hayfever has the honor of being the “fringiest” show I had the pleasure of seeing at the festival.
As I walk into the room, a hot pink gorilla hands me two pieces of cardstock, one red and one green. We’re told that we’re actually in outer space and part of the studio audience for a TV show. At certain times, we can vote for an outcome using our colored cards, and at any point in the show, we can pause the action to request a monologue, a musical theatre number, an interpretive dance, or an on-the-spot “auction” of any item on stage. All the while, a drama about love, murder, xenophobia, and feminism unfolds.
It sounds chaotic, and once us audience members get the hang of things, it absolutely is. Heartfelt speeches are interrupted by songs about ham; during an auction, I deprive the male lead of his glasses; a monologue reveals the nefarious purpose this television program serves and the classist structures that keep it running. There’s too much going on, and the ambitiousness of the conceit often leaves me confused, but it’s just so much fun.
Klanghaus: Darkroom — KlangHaus (UK)
“Try and keep your eyes open.” But as I sit alone in the church basement, the lights starting to dim, the urge to shut my eyes is persistent. Eyes-open darkness is a very different sensation from eyes-closed darkness. Music fills the air, and I feel my body begin to relax. As the sound of waves crashing fills the room, the percussive reverberation of drums fills my chest. I didn’t notice at first, but live instruments are being played all around me. I’ve become so accustomed to pre-recorded sound within immersive audio experiences, so this realization catches me off guard and leaves me with a giant grin.
As the music calms to silence, the lights switch on and I’m escorted onto a couch. There, I unpack the experience with the two musicians who moved from instrument to instrument — counting their steps in the dark — to perform for me.
Whereas Klanghaus’ other Fringe show, Klanghaus: Inhaus, is a communal audio-visual experience, Darkroom is its antithesis — a solo experience in the dark. Both allowed me to engage in the music on a deeper level, but in the eyes wide open darkness of Klanghaus: Darkroom, I felt an intense, personal connection with the music.
Lucy and Friends — Soho Theatre, John Mackay and United Agents (UK)
After being recommended the show by a friend, I purchased a ticket to Lucy and Friends — an effort to diversify my Fringe showgoing. Halfway through the opening number, while covered in confetti and being crawled on by a tree cosplayer, I realized this show would probably count as immersive.
Lucy and Friends is a one-woman show where the role of “Lucy” is performed by the absurdly hilarious Lucy McCormick, and the role of “Friends” is played by the entire audience. Song sheets are distributed as we enter the venue, glasses of wine are shared with the audience, and we’re even tasked with cleaning up the theater. At the end of the show, a cell phone is passed around and audience members enter their contact info to start a group text chat.
Hilarious and unexpected, Lucy and Friends consistently caught me off guard while I absolutely laughed my head off.
Sensuous Governing — Sisters Hope (Denmark)
A line forms outside the Danish Consulate building, where a veiled figure in a white blouse and floor-length skirt stands barefoot. One by one, she beckons us forward and instructs us to remain silent as we fill out a cryptic questionnaire about the current state of our body, mind, and society as a whole.
Thus, began one of the most curious and thought-provoking experiences I had throughout my time at the Fringe. Over the next hour and a half I dance with a stranger, engage in a tender staring contest, and walk blindfolded up a spiral staircase. Throughout, the ethereal “Sisters” serve as my guide, their every motion a delicate dance whose tenderness I can sense even with my eyes bound.
It’s difficult to describe what makes Sensuous Governing so beautiful. It’s a strange experience, and will definitely leave some participants skeptical, but I also found it incredibly moving. As I exited the building, I locked eyes with another audience member. We tried to discuss what we had both just experienced but were at a loss for words — perhaps in part a side effect of having remained silent for so long. Finally, we both agreed, “That was really special.”
The Lost Lending Library — Punchdrunk Enrichment (UK) [International Festival]
At 314 floors high and with 78 spiral-side departments, this library is the largest collection of books and stories in the entire world. But, as the title suggests, it’s currently lost and we’ll need some expert-level storytellers to find it.
The Lost Lending Library by Punchdrunk Enrichment (Punchdrunk’s educational and outreach arm) is an enchanting immersive experience designed for children. The show is a fine example of entertainment talking to children rather than talking down to them, and in doing so creates a memorable experience for both kids and their accompanying adults. Throughout the performance, the actors engage directly with the young audience members, who field every query and conversation with an ease and creativity far superior to what you’d ever find in an adult audience.
Once we do find the library, even the most skeptical of adults is in awe. The set is absolutely gorgeous, filled with intricate details and surprises to be uncovered. It’s a real treat to see Punchdrunk’s immersive magic go to work at teaching the importance of storytelling. As we leave the library, we’re each handed a special “library card,” and from the squeals of excitement this garners, you can tell that Punchdrunk’s teachings have made a genuine impact.
The Most Toast — RGB Monster (UK)
The premise is simple: “Somebody in the audience will have eaten the most toast. We will find them.”
Armed with a large piece of chart paper, a permanent marker, and a wonderfully dry sense of wit, hosts Katharyn Henson and Ollie Horn interrogate the audience as to the quantity of their toast consumption. Approximations are not permitted. Uncertainty is dismissed. This is a serious scientific inquiry, and they accept nothing but precise measurements.
Charts are charted. Calculators are utilized. Integrity is called into question. Then, a winner is chosen and brought onstage for a celebration fitting of a toast-eating champion. The Most Toast is what happens when a brilliantly simple hook, a quick-witted pair of hosts, and an enthusiastic audience come together. It’s everything it’s advertised to be, but with a level of commitment that elevates its silliness into hilarity.
Two Strangers Walk Into A Bar — Tilda Cobham-Hervey (Australia)
I sit down at a bar. Someone hands me a suspiciously heavy tote bag and a headset, then tells me everything I’ll need is contained within. And that’s how my meet-cute begins… but maybe reality has different plans.
Through a series of audio prompts, worksheets, and semi-scripted dialogue, Two Strangers Walk Into A Bar creates the circumstances for a real-life rom-com to unfold. Except, instead of falling in love with a stranger, all that quirkiness and convenient serendipity sets you up to fall in love with that beautiful, messy, unpredictable thing called real life.
Humanity-affirming, grin-inducing, and absolutely charming, Two Strangers Walk Into A Bar is one of the most memorable immersive experiences I’ve ever had.
Without Sin — Without Sin (Ireland)
Two strangers enter a confessional booth and through a series of guided questions leave with a knowledge of the other far greater than what a typical 20-minute conversation would create.
As I step inside the dimly lit booth, I slip the provided headphones over my ears. Soothing music fills the space, and a voice instructs me to open the slot on my right where a deck of cards is placed. One by one, my companion and I take turns drawing from the pile and asking each other the questions written on them. “Have you ever taken something that wasn’t yours?” “What’s something you used to believe that you don’t anymore?” “Who are you most worried about disappointing?” We volley back and forth, sometimes offering elaborate responses, other times opting for more cryptic answers. Unable to see the face of our partner, all we can do is focus on the inflections in their voice.
The end of the experience arrives all too soon, and we are prompted to write a note to our partner. I reflect on the morsels of truth and vulnerability she shared and pen a heartfelt wish for a stranger I barely know, yet find myself rooting for. As we exit the booth, we embrace, squeezing each other tight through slightly teary eyes. Human connection is a beautiful thing, and Without Sin fosters it in a simple, but beautiful way.

It’s that time of year again!
The Edinburgh Festival for 2022 has begun, and the streets are already buzzing with anticipation. Data Thistle’s offices are right in the heart of Edinburgh, just off the Royal Mile, so we’ve been seeing the excitement grow along with the rest of the city over the last few weeks. It’s going to get busy out there folks, so make sure you’re prepared for everything the next few weeks has to offer!
After a rough couple of years with the pandemic putting a damper on things, it’s great to see the Edinburgh Festival coming out swinging for 2022. We’ve been listing the Festival’s events for many years now so we are so excited to see the amount of events up and running this year. To fully understand culture, it’s so important to experience it, and the Festival’s 75th year is sure to be a huge celebration that we can’t wait to be a part of. The Edinburgh Festival is just a small selection of the live events that we at Data Thistle promote, and every year we’re gaining a better understanding of how cultural data affects our day to day. If you’re in Edinburgh, make sure to check out our dedicated Edinburgh Festival website to find out what’s on and keep up to date with everything that’s going on around the city.
We’re expecting huge crowds for a whole host of events across the next few weeks, with everything you’d expect from the Fringe and Free Fringe, plus incredible music, dance and film at the Edinburgh International Festival, something for everyone at the International Book Festival, and a stunning display at the Edinburgh Military Tattoo.
Things are kicking off with The List’s exclusive Festival Party tonight at Summerhall so keep an eye out on our Instagram for all the madness there. We’ll be out and about over the next few weeks as well, checking out as much as possible and sharing it on our socials.
Find out what’s on by visiting our dedicated Edinburgh Festival website!

Title: 10 WAYS I ENJOYED SCOTLAND WHILE IN EDINBURGH
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
If you’re like me (part Scottish) then a trip to Edinburgh, Scotland will be a bit more than relax and snap. I found it very important to visit the place my last name originated and was pleasantly surprised with my overall experience. I did my research and opted to bed down in Edinburgh. There, I’d have a wide range of cultural and historical amenities within walking distance or a quick cab ride. Edinburgh is a very beautiful city, and it’s lush charm is a mix of Vancouver and Prague rolled into one. With a 5-day itinerary in hand, I knew I’d have to make the most of it and pancake what I could, so I could deliver an article worthy of your time. So if you’re ever down for the Scottish experience, here are Travel Daddy’s 10 WAYS I ENJOYED SCOTLAND WHILE IN EDINBURGH…
I can honestly say without apprehension that Edinburgh has the best Taxi drivers I’ve seen or experienced on the planet. They’re prompt, courteous, knowledgeable, friendly, humble, and honorable. It’s actually quite a contrast from what I experienced in Santiago, where my safety was threatened. I would be more apt to describe them as mobile micro tour guides, possessing a high social IQ and left you with the impression that most -if not all- actually drive tourists around because they like it!
Tip them you cheap bastard — they deserve it!
2. WHISKY A DO
Oh mighty Scotch Whisky- the nectar of the Gods! Aside from Coffee and a choice Cab, nothing assaults the palette like a dram of fine aged whisky. Whether it be blended, aged or cheap, Scotland IS the mecca of Whisky. There are several options to get your fix; for me, the day tour to Loch Ness had an added bonus of visiting a legit distillery- DEANSTON.
After the tour and tasting, I couldn’t resist purchasing their premier 23 yr old. It ran me high, but every bit worth the cost since you can’t get it anywhere but there. A few days later as I exited Edinburgh Castle, I saw THE SCOTCH WHISKY EXPERIENCE, conveniently nestled on the 1st right side corner. It is home to the World’s Largest Collection of Scotch Whisky.
It Cost what!?!?!
My arrogance was quelled when upon bragging to the hosts/scotch experts that I’m on my 3rd bottle of Johnny Walker Blue ownership, they redirected my attention to truly rare and expensive whisky. I actually considered selling my house for the novelty. My son doesn’t really need to go to college right? I was even more exasperated to learn that some “poor” chap a week prior purchased a $25,000 Pound bottle and spent a total of over $40K Pounds. I’ll get there one day. There’s also a cool whisky chart which matches the flavor to the brand, for novice drinkers like myself.
Buy a bottle — Live a little!
3. LOCH NESS & HIGHLANDS DAY TRIP
I booked this day tour offered by The Hairy Coo through Trip Advisor. They offer many other tours throughout Scotland, but this one was convenient and enticing, especially with the whisky tour. The 10 hour itinerary was well thought out and included key stops like the Highland Hairy Coos, Glencoe, Whisky Distillery, Fort Augustus — home to Loch Ness, the Commando Memorial, Cairngorm Park, and Pitlochry. You can check the full itinerary here. Although Loch Ness was beautiful and worth the trip, you’ll be sorely disappointed to not catch a glimpse of it’s most famous inhabitant.
TOUR HIGHLIGHTS
What a Bridge!
On your return, you’ll cross and witness three amazing bridges adjacent to each other, one of which — The Forth Bridge- is a UNESCO site. The tour guide was friendly, knowledgeable and brimming with that Scottish wit.
Well worth the day — at least once!
4. FINE DINING
So many options- so much quality. Edinburgh is definitely a foodie destination for fine dining. You should check out my list of 10 AMAZING RESTAURANT & FOOD EXPERIENCES IN EDINBURGH. From traditional dishes like Haggis, Neeps & Tatties, to exclusive restaurants booked up months in advance, Scotland definitely has the food chops to satisfy your taste buds.
Food is most definitely a worthy Splurge- do it!
5. SO MANY PUBS… AMAZING SPEAKEASIES… GREAT NIGHTLIFE
As expected, I encountered more pubs in a 1 mile radius in Edinburgh than anywhere I’d been outside the U.K. People love to drink, and a pubs like The Advocate, The Cafe Royal Circle Bar and The Bow Bar, stood out for me as great places to knock down a few cold ones. If you fancy top-notch cocktails then there are some speakeasy type bars of high caliber like Panda & Sons and Head & Tails. For a speakeasy in the truest sense you’ll have to search the alleyways for Bullard & Worth — I won’t give you the address, but instead give you a clue. Most locals don’t even know how to find it, and it’s location on google maps was incorrect (purposely?). I had to ask several people and store owners in what felt like a treasure hunt.
Success at last…
I finally found what I had been looking for- approached, knocked, and was rewarded. The bartender was as an amazing conversationalist as he was a cocktail wizard. I’ll say no more so good luck!
As far as clubbing there are a ton of options from clubs teeming with college-aged patrons, salsa dancing, hip-hop lovers and live music. My article 10 BEST NIGHTLIFE IN EDINBURGH SCOTLAND will give you a list of good recommendations when you’re in town.
Edinburgh has great nightlife — party on!
6. CRASH A TRUE SCOTTISH WEDDING… THEN GET KICKED OUT
There I am- minding my own business at Ghillie Dhu, when I’m approached by a kilt-wearing Scotsman who wants me to buy him a pint. I oblige and as a reward he takes me upstairs to the reserved hall to see a “true Scottish wedding” as he put it. After a few drinks and introductions to the groom, I’m taking it all in being particularly wary of my visitor status. I stand to the side respectfully and silently appreciate how folks from all walks of life celebrate life’s milestones similarly but in their own unique way.
Uh-Oh….
Unfortunately, no one told the bride and ten minutes later, I’m being awkwardly escorted out of the wedding by the stoic security. No love lost though- since it was worth the experience and good blog fodder. I’m not encouraging you to intrude on someone’s big day, but try to synch with the locals in some way and get a true experience as to how folks live and celebrate.
People are different, but the same — even in Edinburgh!
7. SEE LEITH THEN WALK AIMLESSLY UNTIL PORTOBELLO
I took a cab down to Leith- a historic and artsy port Northeast of Edinburgh’s city center. It’s a must-see with top-notch restaurants, pubs and home to the Royal Yacht Britannia. The weather was great so I opted for a stroll along the canal, then made my way back inland toward the Leith Links (public parks). After catching some cricket and picnics, I headed back to the shore for some photography.
How’d I get Here?
Two hours later I’m in Portobello and realized with no cab in sight, I’d have to trek it back to the city. Using the street signs, I self-navigate past Holyrood Park and if not for my impending dinner reservations, would have walked back all the way. A kind local gives me exact change for the bus fare back to my hotel and I fulfill my dinner plans.
Great scenery & photos off the beaten path — dress for the walk!
8. STUMBLE UPON A TRADITIONAL MUSIC BAND COMPETITION
It’s a Sunday and I finally decide upon Princes Street Gardens, which is literally a stone’s throw from my hotel. With camera in hand, I knew I’d score some great shots by way of the park’s natural beauty. It’s descended location gives an almost serene respite from the bustling streets above. It isn’t long before I hear an army of bagpipes and drums. I was pleasantly surprised to spectate dozens of traditional bands practicing and performing in a competition- free to the public. I snapped away and appreciated the unique experience. The park is not open 24/7, and is worth a visit especially with kids in tow.
The Edinburgh 2019 Pipe Band Championship was amazing- the Gardens are still worth a visit!
9. BE AMAZED BY HISTORY IN OLD TOWN
There is history everywhere in the buildings, streets and closes (alleyways) of Edinburgh. If you’re a history buff or lover of things ancient, then Edinburgh is a mine of activities. Edinburgh Castle was built upon remnants of an extinct volcano, and from its elevated point you can see much of this beautiful city. A great portion of New Town with this area has been categorized as a UNESCO Heritage Site. As you descend down the cobbler streets, you’ll probably catch one of the many guided tours such as the Harry Potter Walking Tour. Much of the books and films were inspired by the streets and architecture of Old Town Edinburgh. I personally find it fascinating to walk among buildings that are older than the U.S. as a nation.
History can be awesome- don’t miss it!
10. WALK THE ROYAL MILE
The ROYAL MILE is the main street running from Edinburgh Castle all the way down to Holyrood Park. You’ll find a variety of top tourist sites like Arthur’s Seat, Edinburgh Museum, Scottish Parliament, St. Giles Cathedral, and Holyrood Palace. You can stop at several pubs and eateries along the way, easily spending a full day experiencing all it has to offer. I definitely had a blast and have the pics to prove it.
Grab your camera- This is Edinburgh!

Before coming to the United Kingdom, as an Asian girl, the most common cities that have been heard of were London, Manchester, and Edinburgh. However, unlike the previous two cities, Edinburgh is the city I got highly recommended many times as it will give a different impression of a United Kingdom city from London and Manchester.
This recommendation made me put it on the top of the travel list to visit instantly once I have time. When I finally know there is a chance to travel to Edinburgh, I look forward to this trip and find out why this city can earn that acclamation from people there before.

Scotland’s capital city, unlike London or Manchester, emphasizes constructing a modern financial centre for people. The urban planning of Edinburgh has shown both the historical and contemporary image to tell its story to people who first visit this city.

Title: Edinburgh Declaration on Responsibility for Responsible AI
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
2
Listen
Share
Background: In 2022, the Trustworthy Autonomous Systems (TAS) programme funded by UK Research and Innovation (UKRI) brought together experts in key disciplines across the UK to investigate the responsibility dimension of AI-driven autonomous systems, especially in areas where we might realistically expect that AI systems will be used to complement or substitute for human decision making.
On the 10th of July 2023, the four Responsibility project teams met in Edinburgh, Scotland to share the preliminary findings of our research, and to identify any common ground across our very different approaches to the challenge, which range across computer science, robotics, philosophy, law and the social sciences. Our declaration here, which will soon be followed by an expanded version including concrete examples of application to AI and autonomous systems, reflects that common ground.
We hope it will start a wider conversation about what matters most when we talk about “Responsible AI’ and responsibility for autonomous systems.*
*This declaration is a collaboration among researchers in the UKRI Trustworthy Autonomous Systems (TAS) programme who work on Responsibility in the context of design, development, procurement, use, governance and regulation of AI and autonomous systems. It does not necessarily represent the views of the wider TAS programme, its partners or universities.
Preface: Our work has crystallised a shared belief in the possibility of responsible development and governance of AI and autonomous systems (AI/AS). However novel the challenges these technologies present, they are not beyond the reach of responsibility, as a set of mature social and technical practices that underpin trustworthiness. We have been here before, with other inherently risky technologies that seemed ungovernable. And yet, those technologies that became part of the trusted infrastructure of many societies — biomedical technologies, aviation, automobiles, steam power — are now largely governed in ways that enable innovation and its benefits without pushing all of the risk and cost onto unprotected publics.
We must advance AI/AS innovation toward its own stage of trusted maturity: by creating, promoting, and embedding robust and committed responsibility practices in the development and use of AI/AS. Our joint declaration proposes four shifts in the framing of responsibility that we believe are needed for the responsible development, procurement, use and governance of AI and autonomous systems, in the UK and beyond.
First, it may help to briefly clarify some of the different meanings that ‘responsibility’ can have in this context:
Four Key Shifts on Responsibility Needed to Achieve Responsible AI
1. Accepting responsibility over describing and ascribing responsibility
2. Seeing responsibility as relational over seeing responsibility as an agent property
3. Prioritising responsibility as attending to vulnerability over responsibility as blame
4. Focusing on sustainability of responsible AI/AS innovation over pace of innovation
ANALYSIS:
Our research projects draw from technical, social, and humanistic disciplines to study distinct forms of responsibility (moral, legal, causal, role or virtue) as they apply in practice to responsible AI and autonomous systems (AI/AS) development, deployment and governance. Much of our work describes how, when, and which of these notions of responsibility should be attributed to the different types of agents (human and machine) that make up sociotechnical systems like AI/AS.
A deep understanding of these dimensions is essential for the future of responsible AI/AS. Appeals to responsibility are only effective when we can be clear and specific about what it means in any given context. But we hold that however rigorous our research on responsibility, its future impact depends upon the collective will of the actors who shape and govern our tech ecosystem to act on it.
Responsibility can be analysed in minute detail, but if responsibility is never accepted, never taken by the actors with the power to do so, these studies will be impotent, their power to guide action wasted. Our research must, to have its intended impact, be paired with bold and ongoing commercial and public commitments to accept responsibility for the power and consequences of autonomous systems.
2. Seeing responsibility as relational over responsibility as an agent property
The single thread that binds our projects is the power of responsibility to enable and sustain trustworthy relationships between people, organisations, institutions and publics. How AI/AS impact these relationships is why responsibility matters in this context.
Yet responsibility is too often viewed solely as an isolated property of an agent or system. We seek to find the ‘responsible’ component that caused a harm or accident, or the ‘responsible’ human that is morally accountable or legally liable for it, without considering the relationships that such attributions of responsibility help to hold together.
Even when we seek to understand what makes an agent in some way responsible for an action or decision, it’s the human relationships affected by that action or decision that make this question so important for us to answer. These relationships, and the responsibilities they entail, vary and shift over time and in different contexts. For this reason, mere promises to ‘act responsibly’ or ‘design responsibly’ are less helpful than articulating the ongoing, evolving duties of care that publics rightly expect and that people, organisations and institutions must fulfil to protect the specific relationships in which they and AI/AS are embedded. We hold that the relationships that responsibility serves must move to the centre of ‘responsible AI/AS’ research and its uses.
3. Prioritising responsibility as attending to vulnerability over responsibility as blame
Most studies of responsibility in AI/AS focus on mechanisms for responsibility attribution and the distribution of blame, liability or other obligations to responsible parties. While this work is essential, it is often silent about the vital political function of responsibility: to establish conditions of legitimacy for the human exercise of power, by requiring those who use or unleash a power to demonstrate due care for the interests of those it makes vulnerable.
While we must do more to identify and hold accountable those who use AI/AS in irresponsible and harmful ways, responsible AI/AS is not merely about finding and sanctioning ‘bad actors.’ All who exercise and unleash the material and economic power of AI/AS, even with the best of intentions, must start attending — and be required to attend — responsibly to the vulnerabilities that AI/AS create, perpetuate, amplify or relieve.
Foregrounding the needs of the most vulnerable, led by their knowledge of the lived impact of new technologies, also generally results in better protections for all; it is the most reliable way to ensure that AI/AS are safe and beneficial for everyone. Otherwise, by unjustly endangering human lives and publics, those who build and deploy these tools surrender the social license for these technologies as legitimate powers.
4. Focusing on sustainability of responsible AI/AS innovation over pace of innovation
Much of the debate around AI and autonomous systems focuses on the ideal pace of responsible innovation — calls to speed it up (for those whose primary aim is economic growth and rapid realization of technology’s potential benefits) and calls to slow it down (for those whose primary aim is the safety, security and competent control of AI/AS).
While this debate exposes important concerns, we think both impulses result from a misplaced focus on the overall pace at which AI/AS innovation happens, rather than what is needed to make AI/AS innovation sustainable, in the UK and globally.
Some applications of AI/AS, for example in the health and climate tech areas, warrant accelerated research and development, in responsible ways. Others, such as the automation of moral and political human judgments with irreversible and severe consequences, arguably require delay or indefinite pause. Yet we call for centering the overarching question: how to make a responsible AI/AS innovation ecosystem sustainable.
Sluggish AI/AS innovation that stalls from lack of investment and public confidence will not serve the UK or the world well. Yet neither will rapid, unchecked innovation that lasts only a few years or decades before running out of public goodwill and available resources.
AI/AS are already placing great demands on our limited global resources (water, energy, rare earth minerals), new stresses on social and economic resilience, and growing challenges for security, human rights and social cohesion. These costs and stressors must be managed responsibly and holistically, with an eye to AI/AS innovation that can take us all much farther, not simply faster.
We invite those from across the ‘Responsible AI’ community and beyond to comment and help us develop and refine these provocations; in the coming weeks we will share an expanded version with concrete examples of applications of these four shifts in Responsible AI research and innovation.
Authors and Signatories

Content:

We are a group of ordinary yet extraordinary travel lovers sharing our experiences of exploring the world with the world.

Member-only story
