Dear Kin, Supporters, Friends, and Enemies,
Some of you may know I was currently planning to attend the Edinburgh Fringe 2024, with my debut hour “Burning Down The House.”
Some of you may have kindly made a donation to my GoFundMe appeal to get up there. (Will discuss this more & the action plan for it now a bit later in this post).
Some of you may have even experienced a WIP show, where each time a different audience member was comedically “saved,” from the apocalypse/a burning building by the end of the night.
It turns out the person I need to save most is me.
I’ve been doing a very good job at pretending for a while now, that I am not in physical pain from having Covid.
I’ve been in hospital several times for severe pain & breathing problems, there have been times where I’ve found myself unable to function cognitively with brain fog and memory problems, crying in the street unable to make a choice, or know where I am and I was recently diagnosed with Costochondritis, an inflammation of my ribs & chest, that could become chronic and lifelong if I don’t rest & focus on an anti-inflammatory diet & lifestyle.
So in true cosmic joke style it turns out the person on fire the whole time was me!
I have decided to really listen to and prioritise my physical body and needs and dare to imagine what a different way of doing things & living might look like…
I have also realised that so much of my creative work so far has been built on ignoring my body, it’s needs & any physical or emotional pain I might actually be in.
I wonder what kind of creative work I would make if I wasn’t always in survival mode?
What kind of work would I make if the source of all my material wasn’t just trauma & pain?
What would I make if my life was more easeful, held and had community, care & joy in it?
I have to admit for a long time now, sustaining a creative career in the arts has largely involved me pretending I am on an equal footing to others, when in fact I’ve been struggling with access to affordable stable housing & a lack of any supportive, nourishing context in my personal life, that would make true exploration, risk taking, play and expression possible.
Like many others I have bought into the punishing story that if I just worked hard enough, or contorted myself correctly, at some point my day would come..I’d get the shot to express myself, or say something, or be met with the resources that could liberate me from the chaos of surviving and afford to buy a stable home.
But right now my body is howling, saying what about now?
What about living right now?
And making choices that mean no one gets burned down in the making of things.
If the price of success and “a future” is your physical health, I’d say it’s too high.
My people pleasing self, still worried about letting people down, sat on the floor crying, making up excuses & justifications and blatant lies for how much ibuprofen could achieve!? How I had been met with motivating external validation in getting so many people to help fund this & bring it to life…
Including a network of incredible humans on a GoFundMe page & the Phoebe Waller-Bridge spirit of the fringe fund (it’s not called that I know, but I’m an annoying twat and I’ve been enjoying pissing people off by calling it the Hot fleabag priest award).
I also got some money from the Best in Class bursary, I have a big supportive agent & a lush director offering her time & energy for free…all these resources and a good venue and time slot, so that should make it ok to destroy myself right!?
Because I’m so bloody lucky!?
Yet with all of those things combined: A GoFundMe, a working class bursary, money from the fleabag God’s, an agent who will front some costs, a director in kind…I’m still only half way there to covering it!
With costs of accommodation & venue/tech/marketing fees, I’m still looking at coming away pulverised and in debt or best case scenario breaking even with a side of burnt ribs.
Also I simply cannot push or mask anymore, there’s not enough caffeine, ibuprofen or sugar that would get me through!
I should clarify here. The fleabag hot priest award will be returned to someone who needs it (don’t think it’s even arrived yet) and I’ve just returned the Best in Class bursary.
Also I am going to explain the options for the amazingly generous GoFundMe donations here:
I raised a whopping 2,319 quid on my Go Fund Me from some deeply generous souls, in a challenging time for many with rising living costs.
I’d love to return these funds to anyone who needs it, my email address is: charliegeorgecomedy@gmail.com please send me your bank details and I will be able to do this for you, please please don’t be afraid to do this, if you need it, it’s yours.
Another option available is that I had already started to make lifestyle changes as advised by medical professionals I’d seen since having Covid and begun reducing my gig schedule and volunteering at a local farm near where I live in Kent.
Getting my hands in the soil has been so healing for my nervous system and breathing and learning about growing has been transformational even in a short time.
This farm is challenging the “cost of living” crisis by providing affordable veg box schemes to the local community & offering some free in partnership with a local food bank. I’d love to offer your donations to this & my continued work with it, as they are doing great things for the community.
If you’d be happy for this option, you can also email me & I will ensure it goes there and can keep you updated on the work we’re doing. I regularly post pictures from there on insta anyway covered in dirt!
I was also going to offer another option of me doing a more accessible version of the show with access needs considered in London and this money would go towards that!…
But let me discuss that with my agent team and see what’s possible for showcasing my stand up in an accessible way and I will keep you posted/do an announcement…
Many of you know I’m late diagnosed neurodivergent and am committed to access & disability so would love to do something that supported other people who are living with chronic conditions who would find a festival environment too challenging to see work in…watch this space!
For now, I’m not sure where I’m at with gigs and gig life and the toll it takes on the body…
I’m honouring my final few contracted commitments over the summer, with lots of space for rest, healing and recovery in between.
My body has said a clear no to this model & format for expression right now.
Maybe yours says yes!
If so I salute you, go for it, play, experiment, take big risks, have fun!
All we have is now.
Say what you want to say & bring forth your gifts.
I still believe we all have them and they all have equal value and worth.
I love the arts & creative expression, it has always given me the opportunity, the dignity & the daring to examine, express and celebrate life!
I’ll never stop making.
I just need to find a different, healthier, slower way…
So for now, I’m out of the game.
Thanks for all your support and/or hatred of me & my work thus far, it’s all been really useful for the soil!
x Big Love.
Charlie George aka Kali Varghese*
--

After a few months of absence from posting anything on Medium or my WordPress blog, I am hoping the past week marks a turning point. This writing hiatus has been mainly due to dealing with the shock and grief of my dear sister’s death in December, exacerbated by what I am calling Political Depression: a feeling of paralysis in the face of catastrophic global events (about which I hope to write soon). And losing the inspiration I found from my experience of moving from Sheffield to the Aberdeenshire coast: once I had seen a full year through, I felt I have nothing new to say.
Nothing to do but to get away! It’s been hard to make time for a break for various reasons, but last week we managed to book a couple of nights in Edinburgh, a city we barely know, and do a pure tourist visit.
Just coming out of Waverley station into the spring sunshine with the expansive haven of Princes Street Gardens running through the city centre, and the castle on the rocky mound above, was an immediate lift to the spirits.

Title: 5 Reasons Glasgow Has To Be The City You Visit Next
Content:
Sign up
Sign in

Sign in

Member-only story
--
14

If I see one more Instagram post with the caption “Sing me a song of a lass that is gone” I’ll scream.
Scotland is full of tourists, taking snaps and posting them, but I’ve noticed one thing when I read about their trips.
They hardly ever mention Glasgow.
Have you even really seen Scotland if you haven’t been to Glasgow? A lot of people seem to think “it’s a waste of time” that could be better spent in Edinburgh or Glen Coe. Or checking off Outlander locations.
They are so wrong. Add it to your bucket list. Stay a while and absorb the vibe of the city. Glasgow rewards time spend there — and you will fall in love with the place!
Well, Outlander did get one thing right — Scotland is a tribal culture!
Think about the football teams. Rangers vs Celtic; Hearts vs Hibs. If you want to avoid a fight make sure you say you support Partick Thistle. All of this is based on old sectarian rivalries. Protestants vs Catholics.
But there’s city rivalry too. Glasgow is the friendly, blue-collar, ‘real’ Scotland. Edinburgh people are…

Title: Travel Massive Edinburgh meets Traveltech for Scotland Event Recap
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Traveltech for Scotland aims to support our traveltech pioneers & help boost sustainable tourism recovery through tech innovation. Jointly funded by Scottish Enterprise & the 2014–2020 European Structural and Investment Fund through SPRITE.

--
Listen
Share
It was great to meet more of the Travel Massive community at Travel Massive Edinburgh’s first event of 2021, on Thursday 28 January.
After introductions and updates from the Travel Massive Edinburgh chapter leaders Lesley, Susan and Katy, with a focus on the role of communities, including Travel Massive and Women in Tourism, we heard from Susan Russell, Head of Marketing, Underbelly, on how for the first time, Edinburgh’s Hogmanay had gone completely digital in 2020.
Susan shared some of the impressive audience engagement statistics and reminded us of the powerful combination of drone technology, poetry, music and film in the video clips she shared. We learned that the Edinburgh’s Hogmanay Fare Well piece has been viewed over 6.2 million times (direct views) on social channels and has generated around 650 pieces of media coverage. 150 drones were used in the piece, and this was Scotland’s first ever swarm drone show.
Josh Ryan-Saha, Director of Traveltech for Scotland, introduced the cluster’s aims and objectives and shared updates, also focusing on the power of community and letting people know how they can get involved.
We were then introduced to one of the entrepreneurs in the Traveltech for Scotland community, Elaine Ford, who shared information about her early-stage start-up, Electrek Explorer, a mobile app for electric vehicle tourism, offering opportunities for collaboration across the tourism sector in Scotland and striving to develop a solution towards a greener economy.
The event generated some great industry chat and facilitated valuable connections between members which was great to see. We look forward to more events in partnership with the Travel Massive community and thanks also to Ian Cumming and Maria Stoyanova of Travel Massive for their isupport for Traveltech for Scotland.
Watch the Travel Massive Edinburgh event recap video here, catch Edinburgh’s Hogmanay Fare Well again, including the poetry and music from the event. Watch Elaine Ford talk about start-up Electrek Explorer.
Keep in touch with Traveltech for Scotland via the weekly newsletter.

Member-only story

Last year in May, I traveled to the magical city of Edinburgh, Scotland. While it wasn’t my first time there — I had spent my birthday there the year before — I was excited to be going back to immerse myself in the city’s rich history and culture as much as I could.
The primary reason why I went back was Beyonce. Edinburgh was one of the stops of the European leg of her Renaissance World Tour, and since Dublin wasn’t one of them, I bought the tour tickets to the closest city — after all, Edinburgh is only 50 minutes away from the Irish capital by plane.
Whenever I think of this trip, I get super emotional. I lived some of the best five days of my life in ways I can’t fully express. Starting with the city itself as it is absolutely stunning. It is my favorite city in the UK for its majestic, medieval, Georgian, and neoclassical architecture and rich history. Walking in Edinburgh feels like a scene out of a movie where you’re the main character. Ok, the accent might be a struggle at first, but I always found the locals to be friendly and patient, making it easy to navigate and connect.
Secondly, the day of the concert — as well as all the previous Beyonce-themed parties I attended there —…

Title: Edinburgh, Scotland and the Romance of a Train
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
“Piled deep and massy, close and high; Mine own romantic town”
-Sir Walter Scott, Marmion
In Peterborough, the station where I had transferred onto my train, I had thought about how the blankets of grey across the sky do not mean gloom. They just mean a cloudy day. Yes, no sun. But also, no sun in my eyes. The muted tones were becoming synonymous with the UK in my mind.
But that day, by the time the train was gliding toward Edinburgh, those grey clouds had broken up enough that tides of sunlight washed over the land between them. The hills and farmland sped by, but I was sitting still. Laughter bounced up the cabin. A family was sitting behind me a few rows back, and at the heart of their babble was a high note of wonder — a little girl, enraptured by everything.
“Woooah! Woooah!”
“It’s another train!” exclaimed a deep, gravely voice. He animated his voice to match her bright wonder.
“Look grampy,” she chimed, “here it comes! WOOOAH!!”
Their chatter pulsed through the continuous hum of the train, then fell back under it again and again, as tidal as the waves of sunlight breaking through outside. Occasionally, amused laughter burst from the whole group. I smiled. The world was new and bright to her, and she was bringing that gift to the whole cabin. It was going to be a good weekend, I thought. Later, a group of rowdy guys took their place in the back. It wasn’t hard to make out their loud voices, but I could only understand every fourth word through their thick Scottish accents.
When I got off the train in Edinburgh, I was surprised to find a flood of people exiting the station with me, many of them donning green and orange. The woman in the tourist information booth told me there was a big rugby match today: Six Flags Ireland vs. Scotland. Luckily these crowds only brought their excitement and energy, no disruptions or hassles for me.
Emerging from the station into Edinburgh was quite dramatic. In addition to the pockets of heart-warming human interaction I encountered on the train, arriving that way was worth it just for the visual effect. Waverly station is right in the middle of Old Town and runs underneath Edinburgh castle. So, when I walked up to street level, the slope to the castle and through romantic old buildings was my first impression of the city. One thing I loved about Edinburgh was its geography. It sits under the watch of two extinct volcanoes — the smaller Castle Rock to the West, where the castle sits, and Arthur’s Seat to the East, a much higher and windier hill that stands over the official residence of the royal family in Scotland. Other hills rise around the center like hands of the land cupping the city in its palm. Some of the houses spill out of the land’s grasp and trickle around the coast of the North Sea.
The entrance to my hostel was nestled right underneath the Castle. I was met by a friendly reception immediately inside the door. To the right was the check-in desk, to the left was a locked cage full of big backpacks and sacks. Passed that was the kitchen door. People were coming and going with cups of afternoon coffee. The receptionists asked where I was from. I told them I was American but studying abroad in London. Ah, gotcha, they said, cool. With swarms of young people arriving from all over the world, I’m sure they had heard that story many times. After getting my key, I wandered further underground, passed a couple of themed lounges with high ceilings, and reached a narrow, traditional-looking staircase.
The room was large and filled with at least eight sets of bunk beds. Each had a storage compartment, a safe, charging outlets by the bed, and a curtain to maintain some sense of privacy. And, since this floor’s theme was Harry Potter, my bed had a wooden nametag that said “Ron Weasley.” They didn’t skimp on décor, because the walls were spattered with murals. The hostel became a home base with a strangely easy sense of community.
Edinburgh itself seemed to have an easy way about it. I mostly wandered around during my visit, and it was all lovely. The Royal Mile, a straight street at the center of Old Town, entertained me for an entire afternoon. With Six Nations going on, the number of kilted bagpipers on the street was probably double the normal. As soon as one was out of earshot, I’d catch the notes of another just up ahead for continuous ambiance. There were bookshops and whiskey tours and fabric stores filled with traditionally woven plaid fabric, kilts, and everything else. I finished my first night with dinner at the pub and a pool game with some rugby fans at the hostel and went to bed exhausted.
On my second day, I visited the Scottish National Gallery, took a bus to New Town just to see the difference, and walked up Calton Hill to see the unfinished National Monument. Bundled up, eyes watering from the wind, I watched a group of older and younger kids try to clamber up the bracket of the monument’s huge foundation. The older kids, already on top, were weaving around the giant stone pillars, trying to reach around them and touch each other’s hands from opposite sides. They couldn’t do it and broke out in laughter at their failure.
By the time they left, the sun had set. Above the reach of any streetlights, the hill was becoming so dark that I could no longer make out the people fifteen feet in front of me. I almost climbed on top of the monument but awkwardly slipped down a couple times. I chuckled at myself because I had thought that I would do better than those kids. I held onto the pillar to feel like the wind wouldn’t push me off the hill, and then I looked toward the city. The lights were all on — human constellations shining through the thick night where the stars faintly answered back. The horizon line between them was a yellow glow over Edinburgh. I took a breath in, then sat down, taking it in until my body could not warm itself against the cold wind anymore.
On my last day, I took another wander around Edinburgh, scooting between the old buildings that sat almost on top of each other, and found other streets, apartment courtyards, and secret allies. Back on a main street, I found a small old church, which was no longer a church and now had a souvenir shop and UNESCO Heritage display set up inside. I wandered around and tried to imagine the kinds of people who would have gathered here when it had first been built.
I saved Arthur’s Seat for last. After my night on top of the National Monument, it seemed like the perfect way to take in the city one last time. Every stranger I met eyes with shared the same spark of exhilaration that I felt on those windy, open hills. Everyone couldn’t help but smile. Besides feeling like I was going to get blown off the mountain, the most memorable moment was thanks to a man who was out for a run.
He was wearing just a tiny pair of running shorts and shoes; he let his long hair do whatever it wanted. He zipped passed me and a couple that I had made friends with as we were climbing up to the actual “seat” of Arthur’s Seat. By the time we got one bend away from the top, we could look ahead and see that he had stopped to enjoy the view in a rather unorthodox way. I have to note here that I cannot over-exaggerate how windy it was; I was scared to stand near the edge of any hill, afraid I might literally be blown over by its force. This man had walked out to the very edge of the cliff and was perched on it with his legs slightly ahead of his body and his arms behind him, gripping the rock face. His hair was wildly whipping in the wind, and he was bellowing at the top of his lungs toward the city. The sound of his voice came in faint wisps when the wind blew it our way, but it was definitely a blood-curdling howl. He looked like a wild man that had crawled from a cave in the Scottish hills. We walked around the bend and lost sight of him for about a hundred feet, but we saw that he was still screaming when we got to the peak of the hill. And he hadn’t stopped when we kept going and eventually lost sight of him for good. Well, he’s either a little insane or he knows something the rest of us don’t, I thought. Most likely both.
You can just make him out in the picture below.
The train back glided through darkness, so instead of gazing out the window, I read my book and wrote in my journal about how I didn’t want to go back to reality. This time it wasn’t a little girl and her family, but a tired boy and his father still painted blue for the game. The boy fell asleep before their stop and his dad scooped his floppy little body up to leave. I used to pretend that I was asleep so my mom would carry me inside and tuck me in bed, and I wondered if he was using the same tactics.
On my second and longer train back to London, I fell back into my journaling and back into deep thought. The gentleman in the booth across the aisle from me was reading with his brows gently knitted together. A woman came along. She was loud, friendly, maybe ten years older than me, American. She asked the man if the seat across from him was taken; he shook his head and returned to his reading. She announced that she was whooped and was therefore going to the concession car to get a beer and we would like one too. The man accepted, I politely declined. Was I sure, she asked. Yes, thank you, I replied.
It was uncomfortable to be yanked from my thoughts by her conversation, but she slowly drew me in as she broke through small talk with the old man and got on to more interesting things. She knew I was listening, I think, and continued to address me across the aisle with a nod or a glance. She began talking about her plans to take a trip to the highlands with her friends, then the man revealed that he was from northern Scotland and could tell her all about the highlands. With that, I finally joined in.
We listened to his descriptions of the highlands, we asked each other questions, we shared opinions and plans, and we began to feel like we had always been this familiar with each other. They finished their drinks, and at some point they both got off at their stops. I was left with my own thoughts again, but this time they swam around with something deeper. And that something made me thank the world for long train rides and friendly strangers.
--
--
I write short story, nonfiction, travel, and opinion. All art is original and all intentions are to share my humanity.

Title: Celebrate the New Year in Edinburgh
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Member-only story
--
Share
Scomo collapsed from a heart attack near the new commercial center that he detested. Hurried and busy pedestrians left him there, figuring he was a drunken tramp, until a feeble-minded woman knelt to care for him and discovered he was dead.
That’s how the writer George Scott-Moncrieff died in Edinburgh in 1974.
He loved Edinburgh, even though bulldozers and commercial developers had wrecked large parts of it.
Edinburgh is still lovable today despite the commercial-fueled bulldozer, says Alexander Larman in a recent essay in The Spectator, noting that Scotland’s capital “comes into its own” at New Years.
The Scots call the New Years “Hogmanay” and it consists of two days that the Scots celebrate like their Irish cousins celebrate March 17th.
Larman recommends Edinburgh at Hogmanay . . . or at any time.
“It’s a seductive place to visit,” says Larman, given its “combination of Georgian architecture, world-class museums and galleries, some fine independent shops, and top-notch restaurants and bars.”
If you’re going to Edinburgh, Larman recommends you take the train from London.
And if you can afford it, go first class on the London North Eastern Railway. It takes four hours, but it’s a great four hours.

Title: My London—Edinburgh—London 2017
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
2
Listen
Share
Four days earlier in the early morning of Sunday 30th July I’d arrived at Davenant Foundation School in Loughton east London. The location for the start of the 2017 London — Edinburgh — London Audax. One of Britain’s greatest cycling challenges, the route stretches over 1400km between the two capitals taking in some of the most stunning scenery the UK has to offer.
It’s a simple concept. You just need to collect a stamp on the brevet card at each of the 19 checkpoints along the route and complete the ride in 100 elapsed hours. (A 116 hour time limit is an option but, in for a penny…)
Prior to this I’d never ridden anything on such a scale. I’d completed multi-day stage races, but they involved only 3–4 hours in the saddle each day. Similarly with Lands End — John O’Groats which I completed 15 years previous. Riding for just 6–8 hours a day leaves plenty of time for recovery and feeding.
Breaking this ride down in the months prior to the start, it looked straightforward. A schedule of somewhere in the region of 350km per day for four days. Factor in the cumulative fatigue and the forecast bad weather, however, and things start to look interesting.
I started well. From a 07:15 roll out I covered 340km to Pocklington by about 21:30. Helped by an always-welcome tailwind and fresh legs, the miles slipped by — especially in the Fens north of Cambridge and up through Lincolnshire to the Wolds.
I had picked up a ride partner in the Fens; a guy from Manchester. Initially I had plans of continuing to Thirsk but he was keen to stop. I knew there were lumpy roads to come so decided to get a bed at Pocklington. I slept reasonably well — helped by the earplugs provided by the organisers.
Clear, dry and mild. The road to Thirsk was in poor condition and given that I’d have been riding it in the dark I was glad of my decision not to continue the previous night.
The first big hill of the ride came out of Barnard Castle. A long drag followed by Yad Moss. By this point the cross-tailwind we’d enjoyed further south had shifted to a cross/cross-head as we’d turned north west. Yad Moss became a savage drag all the way from High Force up to the top. The descent was quick, though the wind took the edge off top end speed.
I was expecting the weather to be poor in Brampton. But it was one of the warmest places on the whole ride. A quick stop for food and a stamp in the brevet card and onwards to Moffat.
I’d ridden the road to Moffat 15 years previously on my End-to-End jaunt. Let’s call it utilitarian. It’s pretty featureless and seems to be littered with truck stops. The route had turned north again meaning the wind was mostly to our sides and backs. Progress was quick but my ride partner from Manchester dropped away, complaining of aggravating a historic injury.
I reached Moffat soon after 20:00, my ride partner following slightly later informing me of his decision to bail. He was disappointed, as was I for him. All the preparation and build up to not even reach the half way point.
I rolled out of the control on my own as the sun was setting.
Continuing on the route of my ride 15 years earlier, I remembered the road out of Moffat to be glorious. A lovely, steady gradient up Devil’s Beef Tub through beautiful scenery. This particular evening there was hardly a car to be seen and just a couple of other riders’ flashing rear lights in the distance for company. Throw in a lovely sunset and still air; this was pretty close to cycling nirvana.
Descending the other side I passed a rider stopped at the side of the road. The reply to the usual “Got everything you need?” wasn’t the standard “Yeah, thanks.” but “Actually, no!” Heaving on the anchors I met Mike who was on puncture number six of the ride and had ruined his tyre levers.
I leant him my box-fresh set and before long we were both rolling towards Edinburgh, arriving soon after 01:00.
Day three slapped us in the face with a 06:00 wake up to wet weather after four hours sleep.
Turning south meant the wind would mostly be in our faces or, at best, cross-head. The road out of Edinburgh down to Innerleithen and then Eskdalemuir beyond was lumpy and windy. The rain passed and the sun shone occassionally between the dark clouds. The scenery was beautiful: rugged, bleak and remote. My legs took some time to come to me, the first three hours were hard but by lunch I’d recovered some form.
The checkpoints passed. I ate a lot of food; pretty much a three course meal with a side of carbs. at each stop. 8–9000 calories a day is a lot to replace.
Brampton was reached around mid-afternoon. After thinking this would be one of the wettest points on the route it had turned out to be not just dry but also very warm. I had a bag left at this control so changed into fresh kit (mmmmmmm!) and rolled out in the direction of Alston.
Yad Moss. Again. The windy, bleak slog-fest on the way north was playing on my mind. I needed to get over this and make good time towards Thirsk for the night.
The climb south wasn’t anywhere near as brutal as the route north. It seemed to pass quickly and with relative ease. Riding along the top was beautiful. So much so that I stopped to take one of my few photographs from the ride.
The day ended in Thirsk some time after 01:00. A huge feed and four hours sleep later, we were back on the road just after 06:30.
430km to do. This was it. At 11:15 the last 24 hours in which to complete this ride would begin its count down.
The roads were relatively flat down to the Humber Bridge from Thirsk. But then it started to get interesting. The wind was straight into our faces. Unrelenting like the little climbs; some up to 15%. Up and down we went. Small groups forming on the road to help each other to the next control at Louth.
By Louth stories were coming back from the Fens about the ferociousness of the wind. Tired bodies were scattered around the control. Allegiances were being made to ride across the Fens as groups. Strength in numbers.
I grew up on the edge of the Fens. It’s my natural riding environment. The opposite of the high mountains. Flat roads providing an opportunity to ride steady state for hours on end—more suited to my 78kg. Throw in the promise of wind and I was secretly relishing what was to come.
We gathered our group together and rolled out of Louth in the late afternoon.
The road to Spalding was as advertised. I did a 35km turn on the front of our group. For that hour and a half I was riding a spring Classic in Belgium; driving the head of the bunch, putting everyone in dificulties. Although I was really just holding a steady 22–25kmh and giving four others shelter.
Spalding was reached as the sun was going down.
180km to go. We started to formulate plans. Short stops at the control and a two to three hour sleep before London? Or, slightly longer stops at each control but continue all night to the finish? We opted for the latter.
And so we settled in for the night shift.
The wind continued and it started to rain but spirits were high. The group chatted and rotated turns on the front.
As the hours passed and the tiredness crept in, the chatter decreased and we became more singularly focussed on keeping tidy in the group. Don’t fall asleep. Hold the wheel. Breathe the chilly air deeply to keep the senses alert.
We gathered waifs and strays as we rode. All looking for company and the relative saftey of a large group with our combined illumination on the dark, potentially dangerous, roads of south Lincolnshire.
The last control points passed in a blur of tiredness.
Stop, get card stamped, take on caffeine, eat whatever is plain and easy to get down, get back on the bike, continue riding south.
The sun rose as we approached Great Easton. The final control before home. There were some seriously tired bodies. People catching 20 minutes sleep sat at their bowl of cereal. I was falling asleep. A double shot espresso gel saved for this very occasion perked me up and we headed off for the final 48km of this monster ride.
We rolled into Davenant School at 08:32 on Thursday 3 August. Card stamped at 08:35. 97 hours and 20 minutes after I’d rolled out of the gates.
What. A. Ride.
Here are a few hints and tips that worked well for me in the build up to, and during, the event. With something like this, everyone has their own approach so take what you like from the below. Your mileage will likely vary.
I carried arm, leg and knee warmers with me on the bike at all times. Add in a gillet, rain cape and wet weather gloves and I was fine for cool night riding and wet weather. Maintenance wise: Three spare tubes (only one used), CO2, multi-tool, tyre levers(!), cable ties, electrical insulation tape, spare cable, pucture repair kit.
I carried small packets of Dove wet wipes with me. They helped keep myself clean between applications of chamois cream which, by the end of the ride, was twice a day. They’re also great for moisturising after a day of wind burn. My wife told me to take lip balm but I forgot it. And boy did I finish with chapped lips! Take lip balm! Even a quick teeth clean at a control gives you an extra 2km/h for the next hour or so. So, small tube of tooth paste and tooth brush.
The food supplied at the controls is excellent. Pasta bakes, chicken supreme with rice, mild curries with rice, rice puddings, sponge puddings with custard, porridge, cereal, hot drinks, loads of fresh fruit and cereal/flapjack bars of all varieties for between controls.
You can see the bike I rode above. It performed fautlessly. Disc brakes really are excellent in wet weather and especially so when you don’t get to clean your bike between wet rides. None of that scretchy, gritty brake block on rims. The dynamo front hub meant I never had to worry about power for phone or Garmin. Although, make sure you get everything charged during the day so the light is at full power at night. I rode 39/53 and 29/11 never feeling over geared.
I have a day job and a busy family life. I don’t have the luxury of being able to string together huge rides regularly. I did one 440km ride and a few 100–200km back to back rides. I think the most effective training I did was a few 200–400km rides on 4 hours sleep in the two months leading up to L-E-L.
I used a Garmin 810 and saved each leg so as not to overload it. Rides longer than 100km seem to make my Garmin turn off and dump the data. I strung them together using FIT tools for the Strava bragging rights.
I found the organisation of the event to be excellent across every dimension. The vounteers were outstanding at every control. They seemed to really enjoy their roles and nothing was ever too much effort at whatever time of day or night. Outstanding!
--
--

Title: Alternative Tourism Experience — The Real Edinburgh
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
From the moment we all sat down around the table brainstorming, it was clear to us that everyone had a completely different idea on the task in hand. Some thought it was to find an obscure tourist experience, whilst myself and others thought it was maybe an app or something completely apart from the norm that would allow tourists to explore their surroundings.
To narrow our ideas down we brought in the help of a lecture to clarify the desired output from the task. It was at this point that we decided to Jazz up the idea of a day trip in the city, including Maps and Apps.
The main idea from the start was to have different independent business join together to create a day experience for tourists who wanted to see that REAL Edinburgh, and not the Edinburgh focused on chains and high street brands.
After becoming fairly confident on the idea we asked our Italian group member, Cecilia, to ask her friends and people she knew back home what they thought of this idea. The idea was given a positive backing so therefore we decided to go ahead with this.
We decided a walk round of Edinburgh would be beneficial to us and would allow us to gauge what independent businesses, obscure places we would like to have in our day trip.
We decided that best way to display/present our idea was to given an example of one of many day trips to see the REAL Edinburgh.
After deciding on the places we decided on a route that made the most sense and also fitted into the time slot of 10am — 10pm. By deciding on this route, it allowed us to create a map that would give the tourists an outline for their day trip whilst also giving them a memento of memorial value.
We decided that these maps could be picked up from Haymarket — The starting point of the trip — and each map would have a different day trip on each.
The day trip for our presentation was as follows
Overall the group worked Hard as a team and met on multiple occasions where one team member was unable to attend due to other commitments whilst keeping them in the loop via Facebook group chats.
Due to all 4 of us missing the primary lecture where the brief was given we felt behind on this task and worked extremely hard to be up to date and produce an Alternative tourist experience.
I feel with more time this idea could have been given a fully functioning app which worked in conjunction with the maps allowing tourists to build up a bank of obscure places and independent business’s creating a very personal memory bank.

Photography Walks: Edinburgh, Scotland
Walk Two: A Picturebook of a Short Stay in Scotland’s capital
It started out as a treat for our 12 year old daughter. She wanted to see the pandas in Edinburgh Zoo which is 245 miles (395K) away! A fresh urgency to fulfilling this request was the forthcoming removal of the pandas back to China.
We decided that a couple of nights stay was required and set off early on day one. The delights of an Air B+B awaited us. We are non-smokers and chose a non-smoking flat. The previous visitors clearly had no regard for this and the flat stank. And in the second bedroom the broken blind was hidden in the wardrobe. Grrrr. Open windows, emergency window coverings, copious amounts of air freshener and complaints to the owner. Well, we’ll never stay there again! Air B+B has served us well over the years but not this time.
As well as the zoo and pandas our daughter’s idea of a good time is shopping for clothes. So after the zoo mum and daughter went shopping and I took the opportunity to wander with my camera and catch up with them here and there.
One thing we did together was to visit the Royal Yacht Britannia which is now a tourist attraction on Edinburgh’s docks. Retired…

Title: Leading with life: a year in Edinburgh
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I stood shivering next to the sea at Wardie Bay, a huge grin plastered across my face. I had just done my first ever cold dip. My husband was looking at me bemused, surprised I had actually done it (we both know I’m more of a cup-of-tea-on-the-sofa type). I felt emotional, thinking about all the life we had squeezed into the past year and aware that our time in Edinburgh was coming to an end.
In April 2024 I moved from London to Edinburgh and now, just a little over a year later, I have moved back.
When I told people about this move their first question would often be ‘have you moved for work?’ To which I would reply ‘no, I moved for fun and work moved with me!’ Relocating to Edinburgh wasn’t driven by a job offer and it wasn’t a strategic career move. It was a move led by life.
Our tenancy agreement in London was coming to an end, we weren’t quite ready to buy and when it came to thinking about where to rent next I floated a question: ‘shall we leave London?’
We toyed with some more exotic options, but settled on the land of the deep fried mars bar and tattie scone. This was partly because I had visited Edinburgh before and always felt at home in the city. But it was also partly practical: it’s English-speaking, there was much more likelihood of us keeping our jobs, it’s not too far and it’s low risk because as a tenant you can hand in your notice and leave within 28-days (yes, really… Scotland does things better).
Both Jason (the husband) and I got the move signed off by work, bundled our possessions into the car and journeyed north.
Although lots of people have been delighted by our move, some have been a bit perplexed. Aside from the fact that we chose Scotland (why not Lisbon or Paris or somewhere… sunny?), and the fact we made the move knowing it would be temporary (why go to all that effort?), there was a third oddity tugging at people’s minds: why did we move if it wasn’t for work?
I find that last reaction particularly interesting, as it hints at a wider cultural phenomenon. Today, a large part of our identity is tied up in what we do for a living. Even that phrase ‘for a living’ doesn’t really make sense anymore — do we really just work for a living? Or do we work for a sense of self, the desire for fulfilment and, in some cases, the drive to attain a certain social status?
There is, of course, a mounting counter-movement that is pushing back against the way work is swallowing our lives whole, for example the rise of the four-day work week, or the increase in remote-working — which is expected to grow 25% by 2030. Demand for jobs with flexibility is on the rise, suggesting that more of us want to fit work around life, rather than the other way around.
As someone who has pivoted their career to the social/ environmental impact sector, it would be quite ironic if I thought that working for a bigger purpose was a bad thing. Of course I don’t. But I do believe that you can be career-motivated in general, and still seek out life experiences that have nothing to do with job prospects and may, even, negatively impact your career, albeit temporarily.
The important point is that it’s not a zero-sum game, it’s a pendulum swing. Sometimes work leads, sometimes it’s adventure and sometimes other responsibilities will take the limelight. (Or at least that’s how I think it should be).
We rented a flat in New Town, working from there most days, occasionally taking our laptops to nearby coffee shops. My arrangement with work was that I would come down to London once a month and spend two days in the office (the typical policy is two days a week in office). When I was in London it was chaotic and jam-packed, but when I returned to Edinburgh it was quiet and much more spontaneous (thanks to few social obligations).
Overall though, I would do it again in a heartbeat.
Not everyone has the ability to up and move — whether due to work, medical needs or the reality of family life, so understandably this is a privileged position to be in.
If you are in a position to prioritise an adventure — however big or small — here are some tips:
My time in Edinburgh isn’t a footnote, it’s a full chapter in my book of life. I still care deeply about my work, especially when it comes to using my working life to make a positive difference (however small), but I also care about living with intention.
And if you’ve made it this far, maybe you’re ready to do the same.
Why not try…
There’s more where that came from, so if you’re planning a trip don’t be afraid to ask for recommendations!

Title: Edinburgh + the Highlands, Trespassing Tips
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I made a new friend by happenstance. Recently I accidentally destroyed an old, precious book of mine, and April Smith, owner of Booksmith Conservation, restores them for a living (beautifully, I might add). She also completed an archaeological dig at the Macedonia-Greece border in the 1990s (!!🤓) — one of the places I will expand my research to in the coming years. Plus, her job is so cool; I was friendly-jealous and mesmerized by the process of book preservation. She’s taking a trip to Scotland this summer, and I remembered that I have a list of spots and tips I curated a while back for friends visiting the Highlands and Edinburgh I haven’t shared here yet. I wrote this quickly, soon after my last trip there (pre-COVID), but I imagine many of the same general things still apply. So it’s a bit hodge-podge in style, structure, and content, but that’s because Scotland trips don’t really need to be planned — Scotland plans you.
Highlands Lodging:
One thing to keep in mind is that most bed and breakfasts in the Highlands are not yet online (weirdly) — so we thought Portree was all booked up before arriving, but you really can show up, and all the hundreds of B&Bs you pass will have either a “vacancy” sign or a “no vacancy” sign. It’s a nice system if you want to walk around a bit and meet the (very kind) owners, who are always willing to let you glance at the room and see if it’s charming enough to suit your needs before locking in the (very affordable) deal.
Basically, this is my way of saying don’t pre-book anything in the Highlands. Just follow your intuition and let yourself be guided by the lovely locals.
Highlands Info:
Oban is spectacular. It won’t be difficult, but be sure you catch the sunset there. It’s life changing. And if possible, have fish ‘n chips from a place that has fresh catches every day.
The Isle of Skye is also gorgeous —even if you have gray weather (like we did), it comes in spurts and doesn’t really rain that hard, so don’t let it keep you inside. Bring a billed rain jacket if you have one—it’s what everyone wears.
I don’t know where you’re planning to stay, but I strongly suggest having dinner in Portree at least once. There is such an impressive collection of high-end seafood restaurants concentrated there. We found a new one we recommend the highest — but I’m sure they are all good. There are several fish ‘n chips places, too — but I had the best fish ‘n chips I’ve ever had in the little take-it-to-go place in the center if Portree. You’ll notice it just by walking around for five minutes because Portree is small. They definitely have fresh fish every day, most often from only an hour ago. Add the salt and vinegar and order a side of any of the homemade sauces that you tend to like elsewhere (like tartar sauce or curry sauce).
If you want to do a tour of Talisker, you’ll have to book it in advance — our way of seeing the distilleries was actually to just go to the bar and order a flight. Talisker’s bar wasn’t finished yet, but if you’re interested in buying a bottle, they will give you a taste. Talisker is the famous one, though, so it's a bit touristy (still worth a stop!). I enjoyed the smaller distilleries better — they were friendlier and felt more Scottish.
In general, when driving, don’t be afraid to make unplanned stops along the way! We found several little hiking paths that were well-marked and let you choose via signposts “waterfall versus lair,” etc. all along the way. We also made an unplanned stop in the (very small) town of Sligachan on Skye where we could try any whisky our heart desired for very cheap. The town is basically a little rest stop close to Talisker, but worth spending some time in if you don’t get to do a tour of Talisker (we skipped it). In short, the Highlands are perfect for exploring.
I’m sure you will learn this when you arrive, but just to give you a taste of the mantra: “There are no trespassing laws in Scotland” — so you can literally walk anywhere, go through any gate, and explore wherever your heart desires. The farmers you meet encourage it — and seem to be proud of this aspect of Scotland. They will tell you if the bulls are out (and still, you can go through), but otherwise, they truly don’t mind you taking hikes through their incredible properties, which, together, make up Scotland. :)
Portree Restaurants:
I was told the best ones are №1 and Scorrybreac restaurants, but we didn’t book in advance, and in the summertime, they tend to be full, so we didn’t get to try them.
There are several restaurants nearby of a similar caliber, which we just walked past and begged for a reservation at dinner time (most were full).
We ended up trying Dulce and Brose with reservations one evening. It was overhyped but still tasty. We also tried another one by waiting in the bar area until they gave us a table — and it was so good that we added it to Google Maps and gave it its first 5-star review. It was seriously amazing. The name is Caroy House (it’s in cursive and super nondescript, so easy to miss, but worth finding!!). I recommend the smoked haddock risotto, the hake, the white wines they offer, and any of the desserts, really. It was spectacular. (Update from 2024: looks like it might be closed, thanks COVID).
Also, try the bakeries in Portree — and the little sandwich shops and savory pie places (anywhere, really, if you see a nice-looking pie).
EDINBURGH (EDI)
Italian:
1. For a very fancy night, you could try for a reservation at Locanda De Gusti (102 Dalry Rd). The food is top-notch homemade Italian; but it’s a small place so I’d guess that they are full already for the dates you’re there. Still worth a try!
2. For a very close second, make a reservation at a place Divino Enoteca (5 Merchant St). This place is large, so it almost always can fit you in for a same-night reservation, but it still has low, gorgeous lighting and punch-you-in-the-face, delicious food.
3. Finally, if you haven’t had a chance to try one of Jaimie Oliver’s restaurants elsewhere in the UK, it’s always a decent option. Jaimie’s Italian (54 George Street) is technically a chain, but it still serves pretty remarkable and creative Italian food. It’s a good lunch option if you’re staying nearby, but it's not worth trekking to.
Indian:
There is incredible Indian options all over Edinburgh, and I’m yet to try a bad one.. but these are the ones I’ve tried and would highly recommend. Regardless of whether you’re into spicy food or not, these places are a life experience:
1. Dishoom Edinburgh (3a St Andrew Square): This place started in London but has a few more now because of how perfect it is. Small plates, try-everything sort of style + delicious and seriously amazing cocktails. Matt and I decided to eat here twice in one week once, and I would have eaten there again. Tip — ask to eat downstairs if they will let you! The vibe of the bar seating is cooler (both metaphorically and literally) than the upstairs, which gets very hot in the summertime.
2. Tuk Tuk Indian Street Food: a hipster-style BYOB place that is quick, easy, and delicious.
3. Kamasutra Indo Tapas Restaurant (16 Drummond St) — this place is a little further out (and by further out, it’s like a 20 min. walk from George Street versus everything else), but that might turn out to be a good thing if other places are fully booked. It’s strikingly good and affordable too.
4. Ghurka Cafe (27 Cockburn St) is the first Indian place I discovered, so it has a very special place in my heart. I’ve taken every guest who visited me in Edi, and it was always a crowd pleaser. It’s a no frills kind of place (for instance, I think they only serve beer and average quality wine), but the flavors of the food are so good it will make you want to lick your plate clean (my not-so-new friend Mary’s son memorably did this). And it’s actually Nepalese so the dishes are really close to northern Indian dishes, very rich and pleasing. The location is super central and usually quite full, but somehow, they have always managed to fit me in without a reservation. (Still, make one if you can!)
Scottish:
1. Arcade Bar, Haggis & Whisky House (48 Cockburn St): This is a delicious lunch spot. For an easy entrance into the world of haggis, try the haggis nachos. If you are all-in, order the traditional style full plate haggis. Grab a dram of whisky here, too, if you’re feeling it — they have everything. The service is a little slow as they are often understaffed, but it’s such a pleasant atmosphere inside + perfect food that you won’t mind. :)
2. Fish n’ Chips: You’ll have plenty of opportunities for fresh fish n’ chips in the Highlands, so you might not want it in Edinburgh in lieu of other options, but if you do, my only advice is to get it from a small, low-key sort of place you notice somewhere that clearly gets fresh fish every day and not from a pub.
3. The Edinburgh Larder (15 Blackfriars St): simple but locally-sourced, delicious breakfast cafe/deli.
4. Oink (34 Victoria St): This place roasts an entire pig every day and makes these delicious (reasonably sized) sandwiches with various homemade toppings such as sweet potato mash, cranberry sauce, apple sauce, haggis, etc. It’s Matt’s favorite “snack” in Edinburgh.
5. Indigo Yard (7 Charlotte Ln): This place has delicious beers on tap and really impressive food. I guess it’s called a gastropub? The atmosphere is really nice — make a reservation if you can, and if you just show up, they might be able to squeeze you into the garden/bar area.
EDI Cocktails:
There is an underground cocktail place in Edinburgh called Panda & Sons — the outside looks like an old-style barber shop, but if the door’s not already open, just open it and go downstairs (Update: I later learned this is called a Speakeasy 😂) . I’ll let the rest be a surprise. It was recently rated in the top ten for good cocktails in Europe. Weekends can be really packed, but the cocktail will still be perfect every time, and the vibes are always great.
EDI Sweets:
Mary’s Milk Bar. I’m not big on sweets, and I initially thought I was just noticing this place because it has my name on it. But one day, I tried it, and now, I can confidently say it’s one of the few sweet places I would wait in line for — each flavor is a masterpiece! I saw only after I’d been that it made it onto Somebody Feed Phil’s Scotland episode. 💁‍♀️ (Thanks for recommending that show incidentally, sister Ellen!)
EDI Tourist spots:
1. The Castle: You can walk to see the entrance of the castle without paying the fee to get in ($18). It is worth it to go in if you have a free afternoon. It’s not a pop-in experience though. If you go, I would recommend touring half of it, taking a good long break in the cafe, and then touring the rest. There’s just so much to see; it’s all so remarkable; and it’s much more enjoyable at a leisurely pace.
2. Holyrood Palace: I’ve never been inside, but I have been told it is epic.
3. Royal Yacht Britannia: If you have an extra day, I would recommend this option highly. Especially if you are even vaguely swayed by the drama of the royal family (isn’t everyone when it gets right down to it?). If you’ve watched the Crown, book your tickets NOW. It is a big thing to get there if I remember correctly — I think we split a taxi?? — I don’t remember. But if you have the time, I definitely recommend it. If you’re days are limited, it’s not worth missing a day in EDI for though.
4. Calton Hill (at day or night) + graveyards + Arthur’s seat: This is my top recommendation for Edinburgh. Just put on some comfortable shoes and walk around Edinburgh.. follow windy stone streets.. especially the little alleys (which are called “closes”). Get lost. You’re allowed to follow any of the closes that catch your eye. Read about the history of closes if you’re interested. And if you think the history of closes is fascinating…
5. …take a guided tour of the famous, the real, Mary King’s Close. You’ll get the full history of the original design of the city and be able to see it underground, fully preserved from ancient times. (This is the only guided tour I’d recommend, but I’m not really that into guided tours.. I’m sure there are other great ones in Edinburgh, and probably even free ones with various themes.)
6. The Royal Mile: This could be absolutely packed with people in the summertime, so it may be hard to get perspective on the layout with the crowds, but it’s pretty remarkable to see nonetheless. Both amazing and average street performers congregate there, practicing for Fringe season, and there will be hundreds of free shows every day.
7. Live music will be abundant.
8. Grassmarket is a good neighborhood as well for seeing street performers and will be slightly less crowded than the touristy spots of EDI. I also like the Queen Street Gardens neighborhood. The museums close to Queen Street Gardens are both free and have a very impressive art collection.
9. Fringe: If you’re going in August, you will run into the chaos that is the Fringe Festival. Most people from EDI leave for the festival but if you brave it, but you should definitely get ahold of a Fringe magazine when you arrive, even just to see the enormity of the event. I find it pretty overwhelming, actually and ended up just choosing a few highly recommended shows — such as some of the acrobatic ones, comedy shows, burlesque, etc. and then leaving the rest of my time open for walking in and out of free shows. Basically, every single venue in Edinburgh will have a show of some sort. It’s fun for a day or two, but like Vegas, the feeling of awe wears off almost as quickly as it comes.
In general, I’d recommend visiting EDI literally any month besides August.
EDI Lodging:
I would suggest booking a place in EDI in advance — just to be sure you get to stay in a comfortable spot in the center.
My favorite place to stay is actually a hostel called Kickass Hostel. If you’re there with 2–3 people, ask to book a private room with a view of the castle. It’s really amazing — especially if you don’t mind a basic room and shared bathrooms (Update: I’m kind of past the point of sharing bathrooms). But either way, they have a comfy cafe where you can hang out and plan your EDI day.
Or not. Because plans, like the land, are made to be trespassed through in Scotland.
༺═──────────────═༻
Final tips: take a few pics and write down some of the places you fall in love with unexpectedly (share with me) — and most of all, enjoy!

Title: The City of Capital
Content:

Share
Edinburgh’s decline into a theme park has been charted for years, and the recent victory to Save the People’s Story stands out as an exception against a backdrop of relentless social cleansing, homelessness (the Scottish capital is home to the largest number of people living in temporary accommodation) and culture-washing.
The city’s problems are structural — it is a city of capital rather than a capital city. It’s purpose is hard-wired into its streets and architecture. As William McIlvanney writes in his novel Strange Loyalties, Edinburgh was:
“…built to be a Hanoverian clearing-house of the Scottish identity. The very street names declare what’s happening, like an announcement of government policy in stone: you have Princes Street and George Street and Queen Street with, in among them, Hanover Street and Rose Street and Thistle Street. Any way you count it, the result is the defeat of Scottishness. This was an identity superimposed on the capital of Scotland, an attempted psyche-transplant: ‘Scottishness may have been a life but Britishness can be a career.’
But if Edinburgh’s problems are historic, and symbolic, it is not helped by its current leadership. We know that Cammy Day was forced to resign from his job as leader of the Labour administration in the capital following allegations he had bombarded two Ukrainian refugees with multiple messages on social media. The councillor, who was suspended by his party last weekend, faces a police investigation into claims he acted “inappropriately”.

It is Friday, the beginning of May, my usual morning to write my blog and I’m sitting in a hotel room in Edinburgh, Scotland. The sky is blue and cloudless and the air is a crispy 47°F.
My usual routine back home is placing my computer on the dining room table, quieting my mind and giving thanks while my Doodle Abbey rests at my feet. Today, I sit on a comfy bed with pen and paper. I asked for divine guidance and inspiration.
In response, I hear, “ You are beautiful.”
One of my favorite songs is “ Beautiful” by Gordon Lightfoot, a tune and lyrics that touch my heart. “You are so beautiful. I was made for you and you were made for me.”
Imagine God/Source/our Creator saying to you, my brother Bob, Marilyn, Ann, Alena, Paulette, Michael….all of us “You are beautiful.” Tears fill my eyes and joy fills my heart. Hear the words…. “ I was made for you and you were made for me.”
We are all the same energy made for each other, across continents across lifetimes and realities.
Hold that, feel it. Don’t let anything else in. You, your essence, your light, you, you are beautiful.
How does it feel to walk through your days as “ I am beautiful” versus “I am human, I am flawed, I have issues, blah, blah, blah.”
Try it, now, today, all day, all month. For the month of May, tell yourself I am beautiful.
Look for beauty, everywhere, every day in this month of May and write it down.
“Through rain or shine for such a long time. I’m telling you, you are beautiful.”
You’ve been beautiful since the day you were born and before.
It would mean so much to me if you would experience this. If you would close your eyes, take a deep breath, listen carefully and feel the powerful love given to you by three words “You are beautiful .”
With a smile on my face and joy in my heart, I am off to explore Edinburgh. Enjoy your Friday. Happy May!!

Title: Top 3 reasons to visit Charlotte Square in Edinburgh
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

The world is vast, beautiful, abundant and rich. Explore it.

--
Listen
Share
Update: the Principal Edinburgh Charlotte Square hotel is now the Kimpton Charlotte Square. Read the new review here.
With a castle view, a garden room indoors, and a gentleman’s travel collection on display, The Principal Edinburgh Charlotte Square is simply the most remarkable place to stay in New Town.
I blew into the hotel on a gusty early evening unprepared to be immediately charmed by this hotel. But charmed I was. The outside is grand while staying coyly understated. The Principal inhabits seven gorgeous Georgian townhouses and has been fastidiously refurbished with both expected and unexpected details.
Although I loved the masculine entry hall, I was distracted by the restaurant during check-in. Previously an outdoor courtyard, it is now an indoor garden room with a glass ceiling reminiscent of an atrium, draped in hanging ferns and styled with garden furniture. My husband and I enjoyed a full breakfast here both mornings of our stay and noticed happy chatting groups when we came in late in the evening. Another restaurant with a completely different vibe is tucked away at one end of the hotel. BABA serves food with an Eastern Mediterranean flair sprinkled with local staples, such as Scottish beef. At a contrast to The Garden, BABA is dipped in deep greens, reclaimed wood and wool rugs. Its moody evening feel is exciting, even before you see a menu.
Our tour of the room included a story — how Scottish! If The Principal was a person, he’d be Hamish, a gentleman with fine tastes who travels the world looking for the best of it. He’s collected books, textiles and trinkets which he displays on shelves for the pleasure of his guests. Just like the front desk staff, I picture Hamish as friendly and warm — as welcoming as this hotel.
As this was my first time staying at The Principal family of hotels, I was delighted with the complimentary sweets and savory snacks in the tuck box. The red corded telephone by the bedside was adorable as well, adding to the eclectic mix of old and new that works so flawlessly here. I was delighted to see that books are available to borrow from the front desk and hot tea is as easy to find as whisky. Some rooms have the best view in the country, a view of Edinburgh Castle. Even knowing this before I arrived, it was still breathtaking.
If you only have one day in this beguiling city, do these three things within walking distance of the hotel:
1. Visit the most besieged fortress in Great Britain, Edinburgh Castle. Try the Millionaire Shortbread in the café.
2. Tour the homes (now underground) of the average citizen during the time of the plague. I recommend The Real Mary King’s Close Underground Tour.
3. Eat at The Elephant House to absorb the ambience of the place where J.K. Rowling wrote much of the first Harry Potter book.
There’s only one place to stay in Edinburgh with such abundant charms and comforts, The Principal Edinburgh Charlotte Square. My thanks to Simon Willis and Tara D’Agostino for their kind assistance with this story.

Content:

Liberal Arts Blog — Sunday is the Joy of Humor, Food, Travel, Practical Life Tips, and Miscellaneous Day
Today’s Topic: Scotland (Part One) A Little Geography, Five Battles, Edinburgh (including the Castle and the Fringe)
Last time, the fourth and final part of a series on the counties of Ireland. Today, on to Scotland, but first a re-cap.
On 2/23 we covered the Dublin of James Joyce and Leopold Bloom, Trinity College, the Ha’penny, Samuel Beckett, and O’Connell bridges, and St. Stephen’s Green, On 2/16 we investigated Northern Ireland including Belfast, the “Peace Walls,” the “Giant’s Causway” and Finn McCool. On 2/9, the central west (Galway, Mayo, Sligo) featuring the Aran jumper, Boycott, and Yeats. On 2/2 the southwest (Cork, Kerry, and Clare) and the stories of Daniel O’Connell (the emancipator of Catholics) and Michael Collins (independence leader who fought in the Easter Rebellion and was assassinated in an ambush at age 31 in 1922).
Now — the land of lochs and firths, of highlands, lowlands, and uplands, of the Shetlands, the Orkneys, and the inner and outer Hebrides, of Edinburgh, Glasgow, and Aberdeen, of Robert Burns, William
Wallace, James Watt, James Clark Maxwell, Adam Smith, and Andrew Carnegie. And of the great clans — the MacKenzies, the Campbells, the Macleods, Stewarts, Douglases, Sinclairs, Macleans , Wallaces, MacGregors, Fergusons, and Gordons.
Are you Scottish? Have you been? Have you studied or lived there? What do you know about the northern third of island of Great Britain that the rest of us might not but would delight to learn?
Experts — please chime in. Correct, elaborate, elucidate.
GEOGRAPHY AND DEMOGRAPHY — note that firths are coastal inlets (like fjords) and lochs are lakes as in the famous story of the Loch Ness monster and the love song “Loch Lomond”
1. Scotland accounts for roughly a third of the island of Great Britain but has a population of only 5.5 million or about 8% of the United Kingdom. England: 56 million, Wales 3.2 million, Northern Ireland 1.9 million.
2. The border with England is only 92 miles long — as compared to its coastline of 6160 miles.
3. The North Channel separating Scotland from Northern Ireland is only 13 miles wide between the Mull of Kintyre in Scotland and Torr Head in Northern Ireland.
NB: 80% of Scotlands population is in the central lowlands which includes Glasgow (1 million) Edinburgh (half a million), Dunferline, Stirling, Perth, and Dundee.
FIVE HISTORIC BATTLES — Stirling Bridge (1297) Bannockburn (1314), Falkirk (1298), Folloden (1513), Culloden (1746)
1. Stirling Bridge (1297) William Wallace (1270–1305) and Andrew Moray (1265–1297) defeat English. Moray died of wounds from the battle. Wallace was later hanged, drawn, and quartered. Mel Gibson played Wallace in the film “Braveheart” (1995)
2. Bannockburn (1314) Robert Bruce defeats English leading ultimately to Scottish independence in 1328.
3. English victories against the Scots included: Falkirk (1298) Folloden (1513), and Culloden (1746).
The last English monarch to be killed in battle was James IV at the battle of Folloden. The Battle of Culloden ended the Jacobite rebellion which attempted to restore the Stuart monarchy. It was the last pitched battle on British land and resulted in mass evictions from ancestral lands, the banning of the tartan, and the disarming of the people.
EDINBURGH — THE CITY WITH A VOLCANIC PLUG IN THE MIDDLE UPON WHICH STANDS A CASTLE AND LEADING UP TO IT “THE ROYAL MILE” THROUGH THE “OLD TOWN” — have you been to the Edinburgh Fringe?
1. Edinburgh is bounded to the north side by the Firth of Forth and to the south side by the Pentland Hills.
2. “Recognized as the capital of Scotland since at least the 15th century, Edinburgh is the seat of the Scottish Government, the Scottish Parliament, the highest courts in Scotland, and the Palace of Holyroodhouse, the official residence of the monarch in Scotland.”
3. “The city has long been a centre of education, particularly in the fields of medicine, Scottish law, literature, philosophy, the sciences and engineering. The University of Edinburgh, founded in 1582 and now one of three in the city, is considered one of the best research institutions in the world. The financial center of Scotland, Edinburgh is the second-largest financial centre in the United Kingdom, the fourth largest in Europe, and the thirteenth largest internationally.”
NB: The Edinburgh Fringe is the “world’s largest performance arts festival which in 2024 spanned 25 days, sold more than 2.6 million tickets and featured more than 51, 446 scheduled performances of 3,746 different shows across 262 venues from 60 different countries. Of those shows, the largest section was comedy, representing 40% of shows, followed by theater, which was 26.6% of shows.” (see below)

QUOTE OF THE MONTH
“Make your own Bible. Select and collect all the words and sentences that in all your readings have been to you like the blast of a trumpet.”
- Ralph Waldo Emerson
My spin — then periodically review, re-rank, and exchange your list with those you love. I call this the “Orion Exchange” because seven is about as many as any human can digest at a time. Game?
LAST FOUR YEARS OF POSTS ORGANIZED THEMATICALLY:
PDF with headlines — Google Drive
ATTACHMENTS BELOW:
#1 A graphic guide to justice (9 metaphors on one page).
#2 “39 Songs, Prayers, and Poems: the Keys to the Hearts of Seven Billion People” — Adams House Senior Common Room Presentation, (11/17/20)
#3 Israel-Palestine Handout
NB: Palestine Orion (Decision) — let’s exchange Orions, let’s find Rumi’s field (“Beyond all ideas of right and wrong, there is a field. Meet me there” Rumi, 13 century Persian Sufi mystic)
YOUR TURN
Anything miscellaneous to share? Best trip you ever took in your life? Practical life tips? Random facts? Jokes?
Or, what is the best cartoon you have seen lately? or in the last 10 years? or the last 50?
Or what is your favorite holiday food? Main course? Dessert?
Fondest food memories? Favorite foods to eat or prepare?
This is your chance to make someone else’s day. Or to cement in your mind a memory that might otherwise disappear. Or to think more deeply about something dear to your heart. Continuity is key to depth of thought.

Title: Introducing the Edinburgh Inclusive Mind lab!
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Many years ago, I became the proud supervisor of not one, not two, but THREE PhD students and a part-time research assistant. Hurray me — I had a lab!
Now, clearly the word “lab” conjures images of test tubes and centrifuges, pipettes and petri dishes. Our research group has none of these things. But over time, the group of people associated with a given principal investigator (like me) and their shared resources (in our case, bubble guns and laptops rather than beakers and lab coats) has come to be known as a lab in a lot of scientific disciplines.
For us, the concept of the lab means a group of people who take an interest in each other’s work, help each other out when we’re stuck, and share ideas, resources and office space. We have a Code of Conduct to help set clear expectations for members of the group, and meet monthly to swap our latest news. Twice a year we have a half-day away day, sometimes focused on professional development and sometimes on just hanging out and having fun. Last autumn we had a session on writing a thesis and preparing for viva, but the most recent one included a foraging walk and then board games in a cafe!
My first challenge when deciding that my little team qualified as a lab group, was to come up with a name. I went to the pub with my husband and wrote down a series of keywords that described the work we were doing, and then saw which of these could be combined into a satisfactory and pronounceable acronym. And lo! DART was born — standing for development, autism, research, technology. Of course, I could have gone down the well-trodden path of the “Fletcher-Watson Lab” but honestly… *shudders*
Fast forward almost a decade and DART no longer seems like a suitable name for our little gang. “Research” has always bothered me as a keyword — I mean, obviously, we are researchers. “Autism” feels too narrow for what we do nowadays, which has a much broader focus on developmental diversity and trying to do work which is relevant and useful for multiple diagnosed and undiagnosed people. And it’s been a few years since I last did a project I could call “technology”.
So back to the drawing board, but roughly the same technique… Collectively we suggested words and — in a stroke of luck — this time we managed to organise them into an acronym that works for our largely-psychological research: MIND for mental health, interaction, neurodiversity, development. MIND though — there’s an awful lot of organisations out there with MIND as a name. That didn’t seem a good idea on its own, so Edinburgh MIND then?? Or maybe, there’s a chance to be clever and insert one more keyword into it all…
And so, the Edinburgh Inclusive MIND lab it is, or EdInMIND for short.
Nowadays this group has a rolling cast of about 10–16 members, as grant funding waxes and wanes. It is co-led by me and my close colleague, Catherine Crompton. While Catherine and I are both part of the Salvesen Mindroom Research Centre, our lab group is diverse and spans multiple parts of the University of Edinburgh — members may have a primary affiliation in the Division of Psychiatry, School of Philosophy Psychology and Language Sciences, Child Life and Health, Centre for Reproductive Health or Moray House School of Education and Sport. This diversity of perspective is one reason why we feel it’s important to have a lab identity which reflects our shared focus.
If you want to find out more about what we’re up to, the best gateway will be on this page where we link out to more specific projects and information — and back here, if you fancy going in a circle!

When I stepped foot in Edinburgh a few decades ago, I immediately fell in love with the place. That first sight of the city will never leave me, and I still adore how it holds its head high. Along with being beautiful, it is a highly educated and cultured city and has more graduates as a percentage than virtually any other place on the planet. It also hosts world-class innovation and research. While its infrastructure is never at a scale that the mighty London can achieve in terms of innovation, it is livable, walkable, and a fairly safe place to live.
In the city, I feel the ghosts of the past and of the great scientists, academics, business leaders and engineers who helped build the city and the country. This city, a few hundred years ago, showed the world how to take an enlightened approach to science and knowledge creation. In my university, too, I get to walk through John Napier’s Tower, and have the chance to convert his logarithms into something that provides the core of the security of the Internet — discrete logarithms.
And, for my PhD, I studied the work of James Clerk-Maxwell, and who’s created a unified theory for electromagnetic waves.
And, so, today, I am honoured to be elected as a Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh (FRSE) [here], and share a space with those who have truly advanced Scotland as a country. As you should possibly know, Scotland has a long track record for punching above its weight in terms of invention and enterprise. Current fellows include many great scientists and engineers who have made Scotland their home, such as Peter Higgs and Jocelyn Bell Burnell. Former fellows include James Clerk-Maxwell and James Watt, along with the inventor of the TV:
And I love the entry for Benjmin Franklin, ad who is “interested in Electricity”:
But, for me, the mightiest of all, and possibly one of the greatest scientists of all time is James-Clerk Maxwell:
As you can see he was born in Edinburgh, and studied at the Edinburgh Academy and at the University of Edinburgh. After he graduated, he became a Professor at Aberdeen University, and then onto Kings College and Cambridge.
Education has given me everything in my career. For those starting out in their career, my core advice is to advance your education as much as you can, and achieve your full potential. No matter your background, if you have a desire to succeed, you will in the end. In fact, never stop learning, and advance yourself every single day. And don’t just learn from a superficial point-of-view; dive in and learn things deeply. If you can, read up on the classic research paper that built your field and understand the current barriers that need to be broken down. Research is great fun and can have a great impact … so go make a dent in this world (Steve Jobs quote). So, go do that MSc or PhD that you have always wanted to do.
This city and this country have given me everything that I would ever want in my career. They have helped shape our research and teaching, and they have been there to support us in building up collaborations, in supporting partnerships, and in allowing us the space to grow. To share a space that James-Clerk Maxwell once occupied is a privilege I will never forget. I am so lucky, too, as I get to research and teach the subjects that I love (cryptography and cybersecurity) and teach students who will build our future.
