Title: An Edinburgh Christmas Ghost Story — tales from the graveyards of the Necropolis of the North
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Our dead are never dead to us until we have forgotten them — George Eliot.
In the dark corners of the burial grounds of early 19th Century Edinburgh, the Necropolis of the North as I like to call it, two entrepreneurial men met a rapidly rising demand for human bodies to be used for anatomical dissection. Using human remains for medical research was illegal in the UK and banned in much of Europe or extremely limited for what were largely religious reasons.
To that end and to practice their surgical skills and enhance their anatomical knowledge doctors were only allowed to dissect bodies of executed criminals, people deceased in prison and oddly, orphans or people who had died with no fixed abode. As medical schools became more common, the supply and demand for dead bodies exceeded a state of economic equilibrium and so people resorted to body snatching or when that resource dried up, murder — to keep the cold medical school mortuary shelves and marble slabs well stocked.
Step forward William Burke and William Hare!
At the time Edinburgh was the leading European city for anatomical research and so the aptly named ‘resurrection men’ robbed fresh graves of their homo sapiens contents until relatives decided to take matters into their own hands and essentially lock the grave and coffin shut using what were termed ‘mort-safes’ of which some fine examples still exist in the infamous Greyfriars Kirkyard and others. These enclosed the grave, tomb or mausoleum in heavy duty wrought iron bars and locks, that even todays gangs that run around London with battery powered angle grinders to steal expensive bikes would struggle to cut open. The Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh is still famed the world over as a leading surgical training today but by physically locking up the dead within their individual burial chamber, the supply of corpses rapidly dried up.
Out of interest, Surgeons’ Hall in Edinburgh, is the headquarters of the aforementioned Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh and houses the Surgeons’ Hall Museum with anatomical displays and surgical equipment which is well worth a visit when you’re in town. There is also a library and archive of the colleges work.
The present Surgeons’ Hall was designed by Edinburgh’s leading light architect William Henry Playfair and completed in 1832, and is a category A listed structure while Playfair will feature in my tales of Edinburgh graveyards shortly and so please don’t change channels just yet!
The museum is recognised as a collection of national significance by the Scottish Government and very popular with tourists and locals alike.
Measures to ensure graves were left undisturbed, such as the use of mort-safes (I did research deadlock and mortice lock for this piece but there is no evidence that the etymological beginning of these names are at all linked to the subject matter but they sound like they should be) only made the shortage of cadavers even worse and so the indigenous vagrant population quickly became lambs to the slaughter and all for a princely sum of around £7 which would be worth around £1,000 today and so not to be ‘sniffed’ at.
When the New Calton Burial Ground was built as an overspill and operational replacement to the Old Calton Burial Ground just half a mile to its east on Regent Road due to Waterloo Place being built, a special watchtower was built, specifically to stop people grave robbing, such was the commercial opportunity on offer!
The murders started after a tenant in one of Hare’s properties died suddenly and the pair sold the body to Dr Robert Knox who was a celebrated lecturer of anatomy and a zoologist, ethnologist and medical doctor in the city and who had established the above-mentioned museum of anatomy and pathology. Another lodger, suffering from a cold was killed for literally sniffing too much and putting off other potential tenants from renting rooms and so the murders continued with the tacit approval of Burkes wife and Hare’s partner and no doubt partly to support their increasingly extravagant and expensive lifestyle. They were caught when the body of Margaret Docherty was discovered who was suspected to have been suffocated but at that time, no one could prove this.
Hare was granted immunity from prosecution and so by way of the use of Kings evidence he provided the details of Docherty’s murder and confessed to all sixteen deaths colloquially known then as the West Port Murders while charges were laid against Burke and his wife for three of the deaths.
At trial Burke was found guilty of just one murder and sentenced to death. The case against his wife was found not proven. Burke was hanged shortly afterwards and his cadaver was dissected and his skeleton displayed at the anatomical museum of the Edinburgh Medical School.
Robert Knox was never charged with his connection to the murders despite public outcry but his reputation in Edinburgh was irreparably damaged and so in time the Royal College of Surgeons forced him to resign as the curator of their anatomical museum.
The Burke and Hare case hugely raised public awareness of the need for cadavers for medical research and contributed to the passing of the Anatomy Act of 1832 that gave surgeons and students legal access to bodies from workhouses, hospitals and prisons that were unclaimed 48 hours after death. It was also made possible for a person to donate a next of kin’s body for medical research. It was essentially ratified in response to public outrage at the illegal trade in corpses.
The Arthur’s Seat 17 small coffins discovery
Robert Louis Stevenson died in 1894 and is buried on Mount Vaea, its summit overlooking Apia, the capital of Samoa. Many years before he died, he composed his own epitaph — ‘Under the wide and starry sky, Dig the grave and let me lie. Glad did I live and gladly die, and I laid me down with a will’.
Stevenson, as we know was a world-renowned Scottish novelist and is best known for Treasure Island, The Strange Case of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde and Kidnapped among many other books, poems, essays and travel guides. The son of Thomas Stevenson and grandson of Robert, a family famed for building lighthouses and other civil engineering feats suggested that he acquired his love of writing from his mother’s side of the family, the Balfours. His alma mater was Edinburgh University and while his paternal family were reticent about him taking on a life as a wordsmith and not an engineer, the rest as they say is history aside from the equally ‘strange case’ of 17 tiny coffins.
In June 1836, a group of boys were rabbiting on Arthur’s Seat, when they came across a small cave on the North East side, its entry covered by a stone and inside they found 17 miniature wooden coffins along with some tiny, carved figures clothed in delicate but bespoke outfits. These are now on show at the National Museum of Scotland in Edinburgh.
It has been mooted many times that these coffins are in some way a memorial to the 16 victims of Burke and Hare and as Burke was hanged in 1829 that made 17 deaths and indeed 17 coffins, others suggest they’re linked to some form of witchcraft.
However, in 2014, the museum was sent a package containing another small coffin with a small body with an accompanying note containing a long quote from Robert Louis Stevenson’s work — The Body Snatchers, which was part inspired by the Burke and Hare murders. Spooky indeed!
Greyfriars Bobby and the ghostly kirkyard.
There is no doubt that the most ‘popular’ graveyard in the Auld Reekie is at Greyfriars Kirk and probably because of a certain pet dog and not a famous human being although being what some term ‘the most haunted place in Edinburgh’ does get the tourists flooding in and it’s all for free as our all the main galleries and museums in this great, but increasingly ‘Disneyfied’ city.
The existing church on the site was built in 1602, and people have been buried here before then, including James Hutton, who famously stated that ‘we find no vestige of a beginning — no prospect of an ending’ and was part of Edinburgh’s period of ‘Enlightenment’. He realised that the earth was far older than current religious beliefs of the time allowed for and spoke out about this despite having to defer to the status quo and John Porteous, who was the drill master of Edinburgh’s city guard. When an infamous smuggler was hung in 1736, people rioted and he was given an order to shoot over them but as things worsened, he asked the soldiers to fire on the mob, killing many. He was charged, imprisoned at the Tollbooth, captured by the angry throng and then lynched, ending up buried at Greyfriars a day later. You can read more about this in my blog that features ‘Heart of Midlothian’ by Walter Scott which features this historic event and local football team the Jam Tarts and also my boyhood heroes Spurs.
From Waverley to White Hart Lane:
https://medium.com/@DuncanHynd/from-waverley-to-white-hart-lane-d083327faa2b
Rumour has it that it could be the most haunted graveyard in the world and is named after a Franciscan Friary located on the site but no longer stands there and aside from the above famous people interred also contains the burial places of some grave robbers too.
One angry, even violent apparition that has been allegedly seen and heard by late night revellers, legend has it is a certain George MacKenzie who was a tormentor of a religious group of 17th-century Presbyterians. Apparently, his ghostly form was freed when a tramp broke into his tomb and he has been on the rampage ever since.
Another often mentioned Greyfriars spectre is that of Edinburgh surgeon James Borthwick who died in 1675 and who bizarrely by today’s standards was the initial teacher of anatomy in a special society of barbers and surgeons! I guess this makes sense as both used sharp instruments to either shave people or operate on them or both if they wanted them dead and likely where the name cut throat razor came from!
A member of the Scottish Parliament, Borthwick was responsible for the creation of the ‘Surgeon-Apothecary’ group in Edinburgh as he served his internship as what would be a modern day pharmacist initially and was then incorporated as a surgeon unusually without first having served a surgical apprenticeship but as the city had been gripped by the plague, membership levels where very low. His speciality was as an anatomy teacher to student surgeons when human dissection was a much needed but often dark art.
By way of an Edinburgh council remit in 1657, the Surgeon- Apothecary group were granted permission to work on patients as until then the surgeons and apothecaries had completely different areas of practice.
Borthwick died in 1676 and is buried in this infamous grave yard, his monument adorned with a life size, crazy, dancing skeleton carrying a scythe in the style of Father Time, a royal crown and the skull and cross bones, with an array of surgical devices displayed on the sides!
James Hutton the geologist mentioned above is buried in desecrated land that was once the ‘Covenantor’s Prison’ that held circa 1,200 prisoners in around 1679, people who were so called militant Presbyterians and believed in what was known as the National Covenant and whom George MacKenzie, representing the Crown but in his human form, persecuted. Some simply died in the grounds, some were executed for treason, some escaped, and some were freed after signing a bond of loyalty to the Crown and shipped via the Port O’Leith to the US.
If you like Harry Potter, Tom Riddell’s villainous monument is located here too.
The graveyard is famously, from a tourist’s perspective, forever associated with the legend of Greyfriars Bobby, a dog who guarded his dead owner’s grave for 14 years and who has a burial headstone at the entrance. There is a statue and water fountain of Bobby, whose brass nose is now very worn out at the corner of Edinburgh’s Candlemaker Row and George IV Bridge and ridiculously popular for selfies as shown above.
Depending on the narrative you believe, and there are quite a few the dog was either a Skye Terrier or a Dandie Dinmont, who died on 14 January 1872. The best-known variation is that Bobby belonged to John Gray, who worked for the Edinburgh City Police as a night-watchman, with Bobby his formal watch-dog. Gray, under other popular pseudonyms was a farmer, a gardener or other!
Lastly, the churchyard has claimed the burial of other historic figures such as Scottish architect William Adam, its first famous post humous occupant how famously designed Hopetoun House near Edinburgh and Duff House, very close to where I live out the spring and summer months in Banff on the Moray Firth to William Wright, who was a Scottish physician, botanist, infamously part of the slave trade and joint founder of the Royal Society of Edinburgh.
The leading architect of Edinburgh’s iconic buildings and graves gave his named to a popular pub too!
William Henry Playfair who infamously has a Wetherspoons pub named after him on Piccardy Place by the Vue cinema complex as a posthumous badge of honour was both a leading designer of landmark buildings and largely big-statement and non-conformist tombs in the Auld Reekie, mainly found in the remarkable Dean Cemetery, located high above the Water of Leith and the tourist hotspot that is Dean Village.
Born in 1790, Playfair died in 1857 and is buried in the same grave yard where some of his best work can be seen such as his pink pyramid tomb that inters Lady Sophia Rutherford and her husband Andrew Rutherford who was, among other illustrious jobs, the Lord Advocate of Scotland. His wife, Sophia Stewart died in 1852 where after Playfair built one of the most amazing memorials I have ever seen. The photograph below shows this and is in a line of tombs aptly named The Lord’s Row! His own memorial and the one to Lord Jeffrey are also worth a visit too. Francis Jeffrey qualified as a lawyer and was one of the co-founders of the influential magazine, the Edinburgh Review. He was editor, then became a politician and also the Lord Advocate.
His links to Burke and Hare are tenuous at best but it was he that designed the Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh building where the surgeon Robert Knox worked and where he purchased the bodies.
He also was the architect behind the National Gallery of Scotland, the Old College at the University of Edinburgh and the Royal Scottish Academy along with what was termed the east or third New Town and many other Edinburgh neoclassical land marks. The old, steep steps that lead from the top of the Mound, down to the National Gallery are called the ‘Playfair Steps’ in his honour.
Born in London, his father was also an architect and shortly after his death he was sent to Edinburgh to be educated by his uncle John Playfair, usefully a famous mathematician. His alma mater was the University of Edinburgh and after graduating he joined the team of celebrated architect William Stark and eventually joined the Freemasons.
William Playfair died in Edinburgh in 1857, and is also buried in the Lord’s Row on the western edge where he designed monuments for others as shown above.
Since his death and completed in 2004 ‘The Playfair Project’ joined by tunnel the two separate buildings making up the National Galleries and then most recently the southern building has undergone an amazing £38m transformation, with a huge new subterranean section built into the Mound and exiting onto Princes Street gardens with stunning views over Waverley and the old Nor Loch that showcases the very best of Scottish art, with Landseer’s Monarch of the Glen holding court in its new resting place on a huge wall at the end the new building.
While walking around Dean Cemetery recently, located high above Dean Village, sited on the banks of the Water of Leith, I came across the grave of Edinburgh artist John Bellany, noted for his almost impressionist or expressionist, stylised portrait paintings of Scottish icons such as Billy Connolly and Sean Connery, created in the early 90s. Connolly’s portrait called ‘The Entertainer’ is currently not on display but the one of Connery is still exhibited in the National Portrait Gallery today. Once you have seen a Bellany image, you will instantly always know when you see one again.
On the subject of Connolly and Connery, aside from being famous Scottish thespians and having portraits painted by Bellany, at a BAFTA ceremony in 1999, Billy was due to present Sean with a life time achievement award but couldn’t make the event and so over a live TV link from the US said to all the guests present and Connery and his wife ‘You’ve done awfully well for a man with a speech defect’ and ended ‘congratulations baldy, I wish I had your money!’. Praise indeed. Connery died in 2020 and the whole of Scotland will be in mourning when Connolly meets his maker and would pay good money to hear what he says to him.
Bellany was born in Port Seaton in Edinburgh and much of his work has the sea as a main theme which often diverges into his own psyche or human form. Other well-known images merge human and animal forms, often painted in an overtly menacing style, However, his portraits of well-known people such as Connolly, Connery and Ian Botham are the most recognisable for me especially with regards to the colour palette used. His painting style calmed down when he was diagnosed with cancer later in life and he died in 2013 aged 71. When in Edinburgh, it’s well worth looking out for his unique, contemporary works.
Sean Connery’s ashes were scattered in St Andrews.
Below are the two paintings in question and my own photographs from the Edinburgh galleries when they were on show and exhibited to the public.
Beware the Weeping Angels
The Seafield cemetery in Edinburgh, located beside the now defunct Restalrig Railway, a cycle trail and footpath between Leith and the long sandy beach at Portobello is well worth a walk around. Some of the memorials are seemingly straight out of a series of Dr Who.
For lifelong fans like me, the ‘Weeping Angels’ were really scary, ghost like alien creatures in the form of an angel who were introduced in 2007 and that if you blinked, the angel would be able to very rapidly move much closer to you and the end game being that if they can reach out and touch you then you’re sent back in time to a life of purgatory. They are unable to move while being watched by anyone living, including oddly themselves and are turned to stone when an eye is glanced upon them and so the angel below is quite a good representation, especially on a cold, dark day! When stone like, they cannot be harmed.
The then writer and creator Steven Moffat reckons that they are the most popular and frightening foe of the Doctor in that any stone statue could be one, but he would say that wouldn’t he. For me the Daleks and Cybermen will never be bettered but I am over sixty now!
They do really resemble female stone statues in the form of winged angels with draped robes that you might find in a Victorian graveyard like Seafield. However, as they move in closer to you they show off vampire like teeth and clawed fingers and in some episode they even had ‘babies’ that resembled demonic cherubs that laughed and made rather loud footsteps!
Weeping Angels can’t look at each other nor in a mirror and so shield their eyes to avoid paralysis, which is where they get their name from as it looks like they’re weeping but have the ability to send you back in time to an age when you didn’t exist or will ever exist. The resulting forces from this is their life blood.
There are many more nuances but we’ll leave that there!
The Scottish Enlightenment, in a very brief nutshell!
An amalgamation of free minds, ideas and publications was centred in particular in Edinburgh and also over Scotland generally during the second half of the 18th century and for decades prior to and after that. It was a movement of ideas and the debate of those ideas and in philosophy, the two men most prominent were David Hume and Adam Smith.
Edinburgh was then described as hotbed of genius while Voltaire wrote in 1762 rather contentiously that ‘today it is from Scotland that we get rules of taste in all the arts, from epic poetry to gardening’.
David Hume, a leading light in the movement was a philosopher, historian and economist who was best known for his influential beliefs in ‘empiricism, philosophical skepticism and metaphysical naturalism’ which is a view which holds that there is nothing but natural elements, principles, and relations of the type studied by the natural sciences and denies the existence of a transcendent God. Philosophical skepticism is an important form of scepticism in that it rejects knowledge claims that seem certain from the perspective of common sense.
Empiricism is the theory that all knowledge is based on experience derived from the senses and created by those who doubted the possibility of acquiring any knowledge beyond that of the contents of directly felt experience. He believed that ethics were based on emotion and sentiment rather than one’s moral compass.
His mantra that making lives better by finding differentiation between morality, religion, ethics, and society was critical to his ideas but hugely controversial for the time. Hume held that passions rather than reason rule the human psyche saying that ‘Reason is, and ought only to be the slave of the passions’.
His philosophy of religion, as with Hutton’s view on Geology included a rejection of miracles and the existence of a creator God, were especially controversial for their time and where being outspoken on such issues was sometimes dangerous and considered blasphemous, something we need to be careful not to repeat today.
His most famous line was that: ‘The life of man is of no greater importance to the universe than that of an oyster’.
Adam Smith was a social philosopher and a political economist while David Hume and Smith were very close friends.
Smith famously said that ‘Labour was the first price, the original purchase-money that was paid for all things. It was not by gold or by silver, but by labour, that all wealth of the world was originally purchased.’
He believed that wealth is created by hard work and self-interest. Smith’s suggestions that economies that are based on free markets, competition and capitalism are still the bedrock of economics and growth today.
As the self-styled father of economics, he wrote the book ‘Wealth of Nations’ and also suggested that ‘Goods can serve many other purposes besides purchasing money, but money can serve no other purpose besides purchasing goods. It is not from the benevolence of the butcher, the brewer, or the baker, that we expect our dinner, but from regard to their own interest’.
Hume died in 1776 and Smith in 1790
Hume is interred at the Old Calton Hill burial ground, just off Waterloo Place in a round, tower like tomb as shown above with a locked gate to keep out the grave robbers while Smith’s body lies in the Canongate Kirkyard close to Holyrood and he has a statue on the Royal Mile.
And finally, Sir Henry Raeburn Scotland’s finest painter…arguably
Raeburn was born Stockbridge, just north of the city centre of Edinburgh and is depending whom you talk to is arguably the best known of all Scottish painters and is buried in St Cuthbert’s churchyard, located at the west end of Princes Street and across the road from the Caledonian Hotel. His formal portraits are instantly recognisable, with legends such as Sir Walter Scott, part of his prolific portfolio, just pay a visit to the National Portrait Gallery on Queen Street to find out!
He actually commissioned and installed his monument and grave at St Cuthbert’s well before he died in 1823, hence including him in my story.
However, perhaps the most famous painting accredited to him and I say that advisedly, may well not be by him at all and is not really a recognised portrait either.
The Reverend Dr Robert Walker skating on Duddingston Loch or colloquially known as ‘The Skating Minister’ was acquired by the National Galleries of Scotland in 1949 for a song and is one of their most popular paintings both to view and as part of its merchandise offering and so they are not going to give up on its provenance despite many believing that Henri-Pierre Danloux, a French immigrant who was based in Scotland at the time, was the painter. Some say that Raeburn simply painted the face and not the majestic motions of the holy man on the ice.
In Michelle Sloan’s great book ‘The Edinburgh Skating Club’ she takes a ‘novel’ approach to the painting’s narrative where her main character Alison Cockburn, who was employed and friends with the Scottish Enlightenment philosopher David Hume whom we’ve met above, colludes with his sister, Katherine Hume to live as a man so as to become a member of the prestigious and men only club.
In a coincidental nod to the toxicity of gender reform politics in Scotland these days whereby it was stated that you could self-certify as a woman after a few months of simply deciding to be one, this makes for a remarkably contemporary novel but one full of local historic Edinburgh landmarks, characters and times past.
The background story is set in modern times and catalogues an art historian’s efforts to attribute the work to Danloux and ‘out’ the outlandish fact that Rev Walker might just have been a woman about to win a very big, life changing bet! It’s a great read and a good whodunnit.
Raeburn at the age of 28 moved to London where he met and was hugely inspired by portraitist Joshua Reynolds returning to Edinburgh in 1787 where he started to paint portraits of the Auld Reekie’s rich and famous and was hugely sought after and successful despite being largely self-taught.
He was knighted in 1822 just a year before he died and shortly thereafter was appointed His Majesty’s Limner for Scotland. A limner is an illuminator of manuscripts, or more generally, a painter of ornamental decoration.
Raeburn was especially well known in Scotland as the outstanding portrait painter of members of the Scottish Enlightenment and probably painted in excess of 225 acknowledged pieces.
When the Leith based shipping business, Henry Raeburn and Company, collapsed at the end of 1807, he was declared bankrupt and was left to paint portraits and act as a property developer to pay off creditors for the rest of his life.
His painting of Walter Scott in 1822 was one of Raeburn’s undoubted highlights, someone who also was left bankrupt by a series of poor business decisions and overspending. Later in life he chased warmer weather in Italy by way of a lift on a UK naval frigate but suffered a stroke on his way home, he died in 1832 at Abbotsford, where he is buried. The portrait shows Scott deep in thought at the height of his writing career.
Raeburn’s self-portrait was designed to project himself as the premier painter in the land especially to his peers down in London and painted this as his diploma picture for entry into London’s Royal Academy. He painted in York Place in a New Town house that had large north facing windows and special shutters to create the ultimate conditions for is work. He never made it back to London to paint and died in 1823 and is buried in his chosen resting place at St Cuthbert’s kirkyard at the very west end of Princes Street gardens.
I ain’t afraid of no ghosts — The Ghostbusters song
For me, I’m a great proponent of the new assisted dying law and hope that it becomes part of the statute soon, just as a back stop for those so ill, they can’t bear it any longer. I’ll have a ‘pure cremation’, whereby without any fuss, they take me away in a black bin bag, return me in an urn and I get chucked out into the Moray Firth!
If it was mandatory to have an epitaph I would go for Clement Freud’s idea when he said before he died…it will simply bear my name, and then the date of my death beneath the words ‘best before’.
I don’t believe in ghosts but I wouldn’t want to spend a night alone in Greyfriars, it is a cold, dark and scary place but if graveyards are your thing, the Necropolis of the North or the Auld Reekie is well worth a visit.
I prefer the Cullen Pet cemetery near my home in Moray where I find the messages of love for lost pets far more moving and relevant to me, however in the past stupid EU rules closed it down, but after Brexit, people can once again bury pets themselves and say whatever they like about them.
Go see!
Duncan Hynd — December 2024 blog — An Edinburgh Christmas Ghost Story.

Title: Four lessons in behaviour change advertising from the Edinburgh Fringe
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Or what the world’s biggest arts festival taught Leith planner, Claire Wood, about how to be better at her job.
Every August, Edinburgh hosts the biggest arts festival in the world. This year’s Fringe boasted over 55,000 performances of over 3,500 shows. Interestingly, it featured more shows about ‘social issues’ than previous years.
As someone who works for an ad agency and so spends a good portion of her time thinking about social issues and how advertising can persuade people to change harmful habits, I was curious to explore whether you can do the same with theatre. After all, the shortest show I saw this year lasted less than eight minutes. And even eight minutes gives you a better crack at encouraging people to change than a 30 second ad.
Of course, the context is different. Usually (though the Royal Mile in the Fringe is an exception), you actively choose a piece of theatre where you might bump into advertising content. And you usually plump for a particular production because some aspect of it appeals — the creative team, the topic, the actors. Few people actively seek out advertising as a reflection of their world view. (Is last week’s Nike campaign an honourable exception? Discuss.)
But assuming both do their jobs right, whether advertiser or theatre maker, both are creating content that they hope their audience will want to discover. So can we learn anything from theatre makers about how best to persuade people to change their ways? I think so — as follows:
Sometimes, the reasons you might want to behave differently are obvious. Most people now accept that it’s good to wear seatbelts when you’re driving and it’s bad to smoke, for example. But often, in order to persuade people to consider change — or disrupting a pattern — it helps if they understand the context, or the reasons why change is good.
Closed Doors was a quick-witted feisty piece of theatre by Glasgow performance poet, Belle Jones in collaboration with Novasound. Following a Police evacuation of a Glasgow tenement, three women from very different backgrounds are forced to confront the assumptions they’ve made about each other. Topical in these times of terrorist threats, firebombs and foiled plots, Jones’ message — that we should judge less and talk to each other more — is beautifully delivered.
From one woman’s story to another. Earlier this year, the Scottish Government passed a bill that recognised that domestic abuse isn’t only physical; it can also be psychological. ‘Coercive control’ will soon be easier to prosecute though the law will rely on victims coming forward to seek help.
Never Vera Blue was a devastating study of a woman trapped in an abusive relationship. Developed in partnership with the Gaia Centre in Lambeth, the peculiar ways in which coercive control can be exercised were thoroughly explored and the protagonist found a way out. Easy to say but not so easy to do.
By showing an understanding of the peculiar individual misery of an abusive relationship — and then dramatising an escape, Futures Theatre hope to both raise awareness of the problem, of how insidious and invidious coercive control can be and to inspire more people to take action.
2. Showing can help — but sometimes you have to tell
The Half Moon Shania briefly touched on a topic close to our client Drinkaware’s heart: sexual harassment in the night time economy. The musical explored a female punk band’s attempts to hit the big time in an industry all too ready to take advantage of wannabes. Burnt Lemon Theatre had ample opportunity (and didn’t really take it) to land a message about how you could behave if you see someone being harassed on a night out — but then they were making a piece of theatre, not a self-help manual.
At the other end of the spectrum were a bunch of shows that had a very explicit call to action. Part of Death on the Fringe, both User Not Found and Sit With Us For A Moment And Remember took on the tricky topic of grief. At Dante Or Die’s User Not Found, the audience listened to most of the play through headphones but were asked to take them off for the final scene —emphasising the importance of human contact. And I don’t want to ruin the climactic moment of Lincoln Company’s Sit With Us… to be found on a park bench overlooking Edinburgh’s extinct volcano but it was a beautiful reminder of the importance of being there for people.
Both, by building empathy — or at least intrigue in the case of Sit With Us — left a more lingering impression than a poster might.
3. Advocacy is as much as we can hope for
Beyond actually getting people to do the thing you hope they’ll do (CPR! Joining the organ donor register!), urging them to talk about it with friends and family can also be helpful to raise awareness and start to shift attitudes. With organ donation, it’s vital as consent is everything.
Leo Burtin’s The Midnight Soup is intended to do exactly that. As well as having one of the Fringe’s smartest marketing strategies — a ticket for his show also includes your dinner.
Under the auspices of talking about his grandmother’s unexplained suicide, Burtin invites a small audience to help him make soup. As we chop, he tells us about his gran, using her sudden death as a prompt for his audience to discuss their own attitudes towards and preparations for their own end of life care.
The experience of preparing food together, Burtin explained afterwards, helps break down a typically British awkwardness and encourages conversation. The Fringe was a temporary stop off. He’s more usually found taking the show to community centres and care homes — his soup cooker is portable!
Interesting for us advertisers as our field and experiential activity is usually intended to do something similar. We often rely on visual eye candy to attract people to the stand — and then field staff to convey our message. Maybe we need to be thinking harder about how we involve our audiences in the debate.
4. Empathy is everything
Whether we’re trying to persuade people to do an icky bowel cancer test or to drink a little bit less alcohol, we need to show that we understand our audience. Telling without sympathy and / or empathy is only lecturing. And who ever has responded well to that?
And maybe that’s where theatre has the advantage. You’ve bought a ticket for a show — and thereby given permission to whoever it is to talk at you for the next fifty minutes. Where we’re trying to persuade people to take time out of their to do lists and pay attention to us for a frantic thirty second slot. Poor us.
But we could also learn that with enough energy, creativity and vitally, ability to listen, it’s easy (easier, anyway) to empathise with your audience. I’ll Have What She’s Having was a cracking insight into what it is to be young, female, trying your best to have it all but buckling under the pressures of needing to be seen to have a perfect life on social media. Grassmarket Projects’ Where It Hurts looked at the NHS in its seventieth year. A homage to its collective grace and tenacity and a yowl of frustration at escalating demand, it reminded us that lots of health issues can’t be set in plaster and left to heal.
Aside from being a stunning show — I’m eternally grateful to David Amers for telling me at least three times that it was the best thing he’d seen this Fringe — Electrolyte by Wildcard was a stunning study of mental ill-health and the power of friends to help you through. You can read all the books you like about the disorientation, discombobulation, isolation and fear that goes with mental health problems but this young company turned all of that into an hour and ten minutes of gripping, glorious story-telling. Wildcard deliberately set out to give the “unknown and disenfranchised” a voice, thereby empowering them to take action. And Electrolyte does just that, with literal bells on.
And maybe that’s why the Edinburgh Fringe is a little bit like crack cocaine for me. Three weeks, 3,500 shows in a city that’s barely built to cope and every time you step off the street into another dim cavern, you’re bumping up against someone else’s little slice of life in all its unapologetic, fierce, feisty glory. Stories worm their way into your mind and your heart in a way that a textbook will always struggle to do. It might make for an empathy overload. But it’s also a greedy planner’s dream.

Title: My experience studying abroad
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Member-only story
--
Share
When arriving in Edinburgh, Scotland, I had little to no expectations for this trip. With finals being so close to leaving, I didn’t feel I had the time to research these places. I thought the city was beautiful, as I’ve never seen anything like it before. The architecture was amazing, I have never seen so many Gothic buildings. My time here left me with so many beautiful photos. Something I didn’t expect to see here though, was little to no local people! I had no clue that most people who live here are not from the area.
After experiencing the beautiful city of Edinburgh, Scotland, I fully expected Dublin, Ireland, to be very similar. Instead, Dublin was so vivid when I arrived, the city felt more alive than Edinburgh. When comparing them, I would say Edinburgh is like a small tourist town. While Dublin has the tourist town feeling with all of the gift shops, there is so much more to it! I noticed just walking the streets of Dublin I saw so many restaurants and shops I wanted to go back to. The area we went to in Scotland felt almost too geared towards tourists, as a majority of the stores there had the exact same items.
In Dublin, I saw more attractions, retail stores, and restaurants in between…

Title: Paths for posteriors
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
Last week I was trundling down Leith Walk’s infamous cycle lane and realised that I was having a deeply unpleasant time.
It’s wasn’t the ongoing threat of HGV drivers mounting the kerb, or drivers blasting through STOP signs at the junctions, or having to swerve around the pedestrians squeezed into the cycle lane by the preposterously narrow pavements.
No. It was the dreadful surface quality. Despite a warning from Spokes, the cycling advocacy group, the entirety of this critical active travel route has been hand laid, meaning that while drivers enjoy a beautifully smooth surface on the carriageway, cyclists have to put up with buckarooing their way down the Walk.
This was something worth quantifying, in the hope that the same mistake won’t be made again. Deploying the in-built accelerometer on my phone, I set out to test the primary cycle corridors in the city. I used the busy North Meadow Walk (NMW) as my baseline; it has a good surface, with a few bumps and rough patches.
On NMW I recorded a low median figure— that is, the middle number in all the observations my phone made as I cycled along. I think this is the best way to measure the general condition of the surface as it is not as affected by the very large bumps that come with potholes and other aberrations.
The paths of the north Edinburgh path network, or NEPN, tend to be the smoothest in the city. The new city-centre-west-to-east-link (CCWEL) is also of good quality on this measure.
“Bumps” are how I describe the fluctuations in the surface that can make life miserable for cyclists. To capture the size and frequency of such bumps, I calculated the 95th percentile of recorded acceleration for each of my journeys in Edinburgh. That is, the value at which a particular bump will find itself in the top 5% of all bumps for that particular path.
The same sequence of paths appears, though this time CCWEL doesn’t perform quite as well.
These are the sort of thing that can throw you from the saddle, or knock your panniers off. The 0.999 quantile.
The most severe bumps are found on Leamington Walk, with the Innocent Railway Path also suffering from a particularly awful surface on this measure. CCWEL scores very well, while on-road cycle paths typically do worse.
I gave equal weighting to each of the three measures described above and found that the worst surface you can find in Edinburgh is on Leith Walk’s northbound cycle lane. No surprise.
This was followed by those on McDonald Road and the direct route between Kings Buildings and central campus of Edinburgh University. The worst paths tend to be those that encounter heavy vehicle traffic, or were constructed some time ago.
That makes the brand new cycle-only paths on Leith Walk, Picardy Place and outside Toppings particularly woeful.
I also cycled down the carriageway of Leith Walk and found that for all three of my measures, it’s significantly better than the adjacent cycle lanes.
The most severe bumps have been plotted on this interactive map.
I used a google pixel phone, quadlock phone mount and the Physics Toolbox app to measure acceleration as I cycled along, measuring linear acceleration and recording my position via GPS.
I used the square of acceleration in this analysis on the assumption that discomfort does not correlate 1:1 with acceleration.
My phone made roughly 50 observations per second; after data cleaning, I had nearly half a million observations to play with.
Caveat — my phone isn’t the best measurement tool in the world, and the statistics I have contrived aren’t perfect either. However, I assert that they will be consistent with the experience of most cyclists in Edinburgh.

Title: On the Mysterious Dolls of Arthur’s Seat, Edinburgh
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I’ve been enjoying Simon Young and Chris Woodyard’s podcast Boggart and Banshee, which deals with all manner of fairy encounters, witchcraft, and supernatural accounts.
Their most recent episode covers the mysterious dolls found near Arthur’s Seat in Edinburgh in June 1836. Local boys found a crevice on the hill containing seventeen dolls, a series of male wooden figures about 3–4 inches, clothed in various fabrics and interred in tiny pine coffins. Based upon the amount of decomposition, the dolls had been placed relatively recently. Eight of these dolls have survived until today at the National Museum of Scotland, which has put together an informative page on these finds with all manner of videos and photos of the dolls.
Simon and Chris advance the view that these dolls are used in the practice of malefic magic. Based upon the different fabrics used, they believe that these dolls represent particular victims selected by a local cunning person, wrapped in pieces of stolen clothing and placed in coffins to cause death.
I’m somewhat up in the air on this. Certainly, there is a great deal of local variation and interpretations of many different magical techniques, so depositing images in this manner is not necessarily out of the realm of practice. Yet this does leave several questions open.
One of the most common magical experiments recorded in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries was the creation of two wax images to recover goods lost through theft. Calling upon angels to assist, the magician was told to put the wax close enough to the fire to be heated… but not too close, lest it cause injury. This technique was still known in Britain in the 1850s, as it appears in the magical notebook of the Liverpool cunning man William Dawson Bellhouse. So our hypothetical Edinburgh cunning person is likely to have known for a much less involved method to cause death through image magic.
This is by no means definitive, of course — a magician might not have heard of this technique, or lacked access to wax for some reason, or wanted to cause a long lingering death (see below), or any number of other possibilities.
Another question is the method of deposition. The most likely place to deposit malefic magic directed against a person is on their property — either in secret, so as to work its sorcery through proximity as long as possible, or openly, as a warning to the person. There are other models, of course. Yet I have trouble understand why a cunning person would use a cavern atop a high hill near a major urban center, returning to the site seventeen times. Why not bury each coffin individually elsewhere, in the manner suggested here? Why risk discovery of the assemblage by repeated visits?
What would be an alternative explanation, then? I think previous examiners have missed the most obvious clue — and those of you who have been following my roleplaying accounts know what it is.
We have a set of entirely male figures — according to some, made to appear as soldiers — hidden in a cave on a major geographic feature named after King Arthur. Could it be that these dolls are a tribute in honor of the Once and Future King, who is often credited with resting with his knights in caverns across Britain until he comes forth again to save the land?
Admittedly, I’d feel better about this theory if there was a doll discovered that had a crown. But some of the dolls were destroyed, and given that they were in various degrees of decomposition, it’s likely any hypothetical “Arthur” doll would have been the first added and in the worst shape of all.
I’d be interested to hear what you think. Is this plausible? Am I missing something?
--

Today I’m going to take you on a walking tour through old Edinburgh. This piece was originally written as a script for an armchair audio tour. It incorporates stories about historical figures like Mary, Queen of Scots, the body snatchers Burke and Hare, William Wallace and Robert the Bruce as well as tales of ghosts and witches, and a sprinkling of architecture. It is intended to be read out loud and listened to on a rainy afternoon by a roaring fire with a glass of single malt whisky to hand. Slàinte mhath!
Edinburgh, the capital city of Scotland, is my hometown. It regularly makes the top ten lists of best places to live in the world and best cities to visit. In summer, because Edinburgh is so far north, you can enjoy about 18 hours of daylight. The Old Town is a World Heritage Site and stretches along a ridge from Castle Rock down to the Palace of Holyroodhouse.
Edinburgh is built on seven hills which provide a dramatic backdrop to the city’s skyline. These hills include Arthur’s Seat, an ancient volcano that provides panoramic views of the city and beyond, and Calton Hill, home to some of Edinburgh’s most iconic monuments.
Now, close your eyes, and take a deep breath. The weather today is cool, with a breeze that carries the fresh salty air from the nearby North Sea. Feel the damp, misty air on your face. Exhale and relax.

Title: History in Geography-Edinburgh’s Royal Mile
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
There is this idea that if you know an area, a city, you can look up its main street and see years of history having already been made. The geography of it literally recalls history just in looking. There’s where this happened, here’s where that happened. . .
Take a look down Edinburgh Scotland’s Royal Mile, and you surely see down a millenium. Starting at the west end, there’s Edinburgh Castle, site of more than a few siege takings. In it was born a king, and in it one died, as well. The king born was King James of Scotland, son of Mary Queen of Scots. He was later asked to be the king of England as well. His mom had his dad killed, it is rumored, in the castle. At best, the whole thing was a shady ordeal. Mary, Queen of Scots was not born in it, but she ruled from it for a number of years.
Maybe you think of a queen as someone in her 40’s or 50’s, but no, Mary was a maiden of some 20 something years when she returned to Scotland from France to rule the people of Scotland. But she is another story.
Come out from the castle to the promenade where the Tattoo is held. This tattoo is a military celebration of sorts, held every year during the Edinburgh International Festival in August. At this tattoo several different military regiments from all over Scotland come to show off their skills, uniforms and Scottish pride for all the world to see, and it is quite a show. It is best to take in the later of the two evening events, as the fireworks are more spectacular later on. In August, it is broad daylight at 9:30 pm! So, the good watching is around 11:30.
The Royal Mile is not the official name of the street, it is more an honorary title given to it. This is actually more than a mile, from Edinburgh Castle to Holyrood Palace, at the east end. The Royal Mile actually has 4 street names given to it. The street numbering system has them running out of numbers in short order, so they just change the street name every few blocks, and that takes care of it. Two of those names were done away with, and one assigned to that portion.
Coming from the promenade is Johnston Terrace, which extends east to Bank Street. At this corner is a speakeasy known as Deacon Brodie’s Tavern. Deacon Brodie was a highly respected cabinetmaker; well at least during the day. At night, it was a different story. He was known to be a robber in the night hours. One time he was caught in the coffers of the national treasury. He escaped then and fled the country. He then wrote a note to someone he knew in Edinburgh, from what he thought was a secure location. Authorities were able to determine this so-called secure location, went after him, placed him under arrest, brought him back to Scotland, and hung him on gallows he had himself built for someone else. It was his double life that inspired the Robert Louis Stevenson epic novel, “Doctor Jekyll and Mr Hyde”.
At Bank Street, the mile becomes High Street, a name which stays with it for most of its length. Walk half a block east on High Street, cross the street, and you see one landmark, the Heart of the Lothian, built into the brickwork just a few feet out the door of St. Giles Cathedral. Scotland is divided into several regions, and Edinburgh is in the center of the Lothian Region. So, the Heart of the Lothian is dead center of this region. In much earlier days, there was a prison on this site.
As I said, this Heart of the Lothian is but a few feet away from the head worship center of the Church of Scotland, St. Giles Cathedral. The Presbyterian Church worldwide has its origins here. What we call the Presbyterian Church, in Europe, is called the Church of Scotland. Its most famous preacher and head was John Knox, a Scot himself, born in Gifford. Knox was himself a disciple of John Calvin of Germany, but when he took his own stand in Scotland it was at St. Giles, and he re-established the church there. Knox was in the pulpit while Mary was on the throne just up the street, and he was heard to speak of the need for dethroning for her deeds. To re-establish St. Giles as such took evicting some adherents of the Church of England. They left and started Old St. Paul’s Episcopal Church.
The Royal Mile runs downhill, west to east, and there are some cross streets, but to facilitate passage down the hill to the north, and indirect access to patrons on the Mile, stepped passageways called closes where built here and there between buildings. It is in these closes that other establishments were located. There are many closes up and down the Mile, and each has its own history.
Step out the east door of St. Giles, take but a few steps, and you arrive at a round structure with a gabled roof known as the Mercat Cross. This was an ancient assembly point for people of the town. They assembled there to hear governmental decrees, proclamations, and to witness public hangings.
One website describes it thus: “the old center of town- marketplace, news-stand, pulpit and gallows . . . it was a real one stop shop!”
The present Mercat Cross does not stand where the original did, but that location is marked by a cross laid into the sidewalk. It was the center of the old Edinburgh.
Going a block or so east on the mile, one arrives at Tron Kirk. Kirk is Scottish for church. (Talk about the US and the UK- two countries separated by a common language!) Now before Knox arrived at St. Giles, the Church of England had pretty well dispatched the Church of Scotland out of the place. They went a block east and built the Tron Kirk.
Actually, it was called “The Bishop’s War, where the king tried to introduce Episcopal structure into the Church of Scotland. He actually took over St. Giles and made it the seat of the Bishop of the Church of England.
So, the Church of Scotland people, refusing this intrusion, went and built the Tron Kirk. The building itself is no longer a church, but its physical structure remains as a visitor center.
Cross the street again, and head east from North Street, walking until you get to a large building called Carrubbers Christian Center. Carrubbers was founded back in the 19th Century in the Carrubbers Close, as a mission. Dwight L. Moody came and brought his chief musician Ira Sankey, and together they raised enough money to build this large 4 story evangelistic center. Originally built with a two-story worship center, the lower floor was converted to other uses in recent years. The center has been a beacon of hope to Edinburgh since its inception and remains so today. It has a library, a meeting hall, and dorm rooms on the top floor for university students as well as visiting clergy.
Go further east, on that side of the street, and the building that juts out and establishes a new position for the fronting buildings is the home of the preacher from the cathedral up the street, John Knox. Knox lived here during his years when he pastored at St. Giles Cathedral. His years pastoring St. Giles were also his last. He died in this house. I will warn you, though, that the people who marked his life with this museum were not terribly kind to his message of the Gospel or his dealings.
Going further down the street one more block, the Royal Mile changes its name to Canongate, a city gate from early days of the town. On Canon Gate, one walks the rest of the mile to Holyrood Palace, the annual accommodations for the Queen of England in June. The royal family also spends a month in the north of Scotland, at Balmoral Castle.
To look up the Royal Mile is to look up into history, and it always reminds you. A sea mist, called a haar, can roll in though, and you won’t see past a block, they are so thick. But you’ll never forget where you’ve been!

A Memphis born and raised writer, with a genuine affection for the music that was also born here.

Last time I lived in Edinburgh it was 1993. I moved there with a bunch of friends after university. As you might expect from a group of people who’d spent more time in the pub than in the lecture theatre, none of us had managed to get a proper graduate job.
It was the middle of a recession so we figured we’d go hang out in Edinburgh, continue the party lifestyle, do some temp work and maybe even find a job to make our parents proud.
At that time no one had heard of She Who Must Not Be Named, although funnily enough 1993 was the year that she moved to Edinburgh. She’d already sketched the outline for the Harry Potter books but in 1993 J.K. Rowling began writing in cafes such as Nicolson’s (now Spoon) and no doubt was influenced by the city’s history and architecture.
Our Edinburgh at that time revolved around nights out at indie and alternative clubs like the Mission in Victoria Street, Evol or FBI in the Cowgate, various pubs in the Grassmarket and around the University, live music at the Preservation Hall or the Ensign Ewart and visits to the many art galleries and museums (all of which were free).
We’d walk all over the city and I truly loved it. But all good things come to an end, and…

Title: I’m a Little Edinburgh Fringe Worm with no cash, so please read this and share as if it’s poignant so people come to my show
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
Nobody cares about the fact I’m going to Edinburgh Fringe and neither should they. I’m a comedian going on a jolly for a couple of weeks in a great city with loads of my pals and trying to make people laugh. Yes it’ll probably bankrupt me and I’ve done everything in my power to not lose money hand over fist but even so, nobody is forcing me, it’s fucking great at it’s core (once we overthrow the Tories up there charging thousands for August rents). I could use this piece to get extremely angry about class and how it’s easy to do it if you’re secretly loaded, but we all know that, so allow me to drivel on for 800 words (681 from here on in, OK and that used up five, we’re nearly there) and hopefully encourage you to tweet the link to this piece with one of the following quotes above the link so people think I’ve made some sort of life-changing point;
My show is about…..WOMEN. Does that make you uncomfortable?! Probably not. You might even know one. It came from working in women’s media and being told every day what to be angry at, what to be turned on by, what to be repulsed by, who to be angry at and why you must always, every single day, be told how to ask for a pay rise. There’s an entire industry dedicated to books about work. Can you believe it? Titles like ‘How To Get What You Want At Work And Shag Your Colleague Respectfully’ and ‘How To Boss Bitch Your Way Into Millions Of Pounds And Shit On Everyone You Know.’ People buy them! Where is the book that says ‘Here’s How To Never Fill In A TimeSheet Ever Again’ — I would buy that. Read books about shagging and love and mad stuff! Not the thing you do all day! I digress.
My show is about how sometimes I’m not angry at the right things and I do stupid shit and that true equality is ripping the piss out of men and women. The day Mother’s Day cards contain a joke is the day Gloria Steinem can have a quick fag break to relax before cracking on with the serious stuff.
And of course, there are properly awful things going on for women at the moment, but you all know about that too. I’m just inviting you to come and laugh at me for 45 minutes in the back of a pub and maybe sling me a tenner at the end for my efforts. (If you don’t, you’re sexist) A lot of Edinburgh shows are about something moving, poignant, tragic or dark, I’m here to tell you that my parents are both alive, sadly were very supportive of me, and never ask me if I’m going to get married. They fed me almost exclusively Findus Crispy Pancakes and Spaghetti Hoops for about 12 years as well so in many ways, they’re legends. I’ve got nice pals, big dark roots that I can’t afford to dye, and my life has mostly been pretty good, despite my job on the ASDA checkout and Morrisons chicken counter, so you can see my issue. In many ways, making a show out of almost exclusively stupid sexual decisions is actually harder. No pun intended. Well it is now, I wrote it and then realised.
Please come and see Woman In Progress at Southsider, 6th — 17th August, at 5.45pm. You won’t regret it, straight away at least. It’s with PBH Free Fringe, so just pay what you want at the end!
Follow me on Instagram if you liked this [at]alexandrahaddow
Thanks and hopefully see you there!

Title: Living Like a Local: A Guide to Edinburgh’s Best Hidden Gems
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
As a frequent visitor to Edinburgh, I’ve had the opportunity to explore some of the city’s best-kept secrets. While it’s easy to get caught up in the popular tourist attractions, there’s so much more to this beautiful city that often goes unnoticed. Here’s my personal guide to some of Edinburgh’s best hidden gems.
St. Bernard’s Well — Tucked away in the Dean Village, this hidden gem is a peaceful haven away from the hustle and bustle of the city. The well was built in the late 18th century and has a unique design that is said to be based on the Temple of Vesta in Italy. The tranquil setting and stunning architecture make it the perfect spot for a quiet moment of reflection.
The Writers’ Museum — While many visitors flock to the Edinburgh Castle or the National Museum of Scotland, the Writers’ Museum is often overlooked. This hidden gem celebrates the lives and works of three of Scotland’s most famous writers: Robert Burns, Sir Walter Scott, and Robert Louis Stevenson. The museum is located in a 17th-century building just off the Royal Mile and is filled with fascinating artifacts and exhibits.
The Royal Botanic Garden — While not exactly a hidden gem, the Royal Botanic Garden is often overshadowed by other popular attractions in Edinburgh. The garden boasts a vast collection of plant species from around the world, as well as stunning views of the city. It’s the perfect place for a leisurely afternoon stroll or a peaceful picnic.
Stockbridge — This charming neighborhood is just a short walk from the city center, yet it feels like a world away. With its eclectic mix of independent shops, cafes, and restaurants, Stockbridge is a great place to explore and soak up the local culture. Don’t miss the weekly farmers’ market, which is brimming with fresh, locally sourced produce.
The Sheep Heid Inn — Tucked away in the charming village of Duddingston, this historic pub is said to be the oldest in Scotland. The pub’s unique attraction is its skittle alley, a game similar to bowling that’s fun for all ages. It’s a great spot for a pint and a game of skittles with friends.
And now for a joke related to this post — Why did the writer bring a map to the Royal Botanic Garden? To find the roots of all the hidden gems! Okay, maybe it’s not the best joke, but I hope it made you smile.
As a frequent visitor to Edinburgh, I can say that these hidden gems are some of my favorite places in the city. Whether you’re a first-time visitor or a seasoned traveler, I hope this guide inspires you to explore all that Edinburgh has to offer.
Originally published at http://nomadnonsense.blog on February 23, 2023.

Title: Edinburgh — This Majestic City: ‘The mix old and modern, tradition and innovation was intoxicating’
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

This publication brings together interesting articles related to cyber security.

--
Listen
Share
I stepped foot in Edinburgh many decades ago and immediately fell in love with the place. That first sight of the city will never leave me, and I still adore the way it holds its head high. It was the strongest against Brexit, it has more graduates as a percentage than virtually any other place on the planet, and it hosts world-class innovation and research. While its infrastructure is never at a scale that the mighty London can achieve in terms of innovation, it is livable, walkable, and a fairly safe place to live.
And, so, I just loved this quote [here]:
The mix of old and new, tradition and innovation, sums up my city. Around its ancient building exists world-leading research and innovation, and, like Glasgow, it is focused on technology and scientific advancements. The city nurtured three of our cybersecurity spin-outs, and I believe we could not have succeeded as well as they did without the help of the city — in supporting investment, collaborations, and most of all, attracting the talent needed to build high-impact companies. While Brexit was a major spanner in the works, the city has managed to showcase its economic resilience — more to do with its people and businesses than by politicians — and continues to build its place on an international stage.
For students, it’s a great place to come and study and is in the Top 10 cities of the world for this. In the QS World guide, the rankings for the best city to study are [here]:
For a relatively small city, a Top 10 finish is amazing. But, it’s not a big city, and that’s a good thing! Many people can live and work within an area that allows you to walk to work, or, at least, get a bus. In fact, Edinburgh buses are great. While we have a new tram, most Edinburgh people still use the bus to get around. You are typically just 30 minutes away from anywhere in Edinburgh.
And, so, if you like hills — Edinburgh has seven of these, and an extinct volcano to walk around. For beaches, you choose whatever style you like, and for parks, you’ll find one at every turn. But, the best thing, is that it is a truly enterprising and innovative city, that prides itself on its love of education and scientific advancement.
Cities are key to our future. They are economic drivers and places to innovation. Care for your city, and let it live.

Title: Edinburgh
Design System Day 2023
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
This week in Edinburgh, GDS hosted its first in-person Design System Day conference. Here are a few of my highlights from the day.
Dynamic Earth felt like a strangely appropriate place to host Design System Day 2023: the giant globe hanging above our heads was a fitting metaphor for the planetary consequences of national scale design decisions.
Samantha Ernstzen and Jennifer l’Anson reflected on the process of creating the Scottish Government Digital Design System.
Their purpose was refreshingly succinct:
“to enable teams within the Scottish public sector to design and build digital products that are accessible, usable and consistent for people accessing public services in Scotland.”
Adoption is always a challenge. Even with a strong design system, people can still put together bad forms with good components! We’ve all seen examples of digitised forms recreating the paper original, mirroring the many-boxes-per-page approach of the pre-digital era.
The challenge isn’t just educating government departments in how best to use a design system, it’s also getting external suppliers to embrace it.
Mandating use of an existing design system isn’t enough: we need to support agencies and consultancies in adopting it and implementing it successfully!
Ciandelle, Calvin and Steve gave a quickfire summary of all the updates GOV.UK have been making, including improving accessibility.
One newly released development is the Exit this page feature. It allows a user to quickly close down a page if they are in danger: particularly useful for those suffering domestic abuse. It may look like just a small button, but took about five years of work to research and implement!
Massive news: designers were delighted to hear that a new crown’s gonna drop — watch this space for a slightly modified GOV.UK logo coming soon!
Katrina Birch facilitated a fantastic panel on trauma-informed research and design.
70% of people have experienced trauma, and 1 in 10 will suffer from PTSD at some point in their life. We should be aware of trauma and the risk of vicarious trauma when conducting user research around difficult topics. Shout out to Chayn, getting an honourable mention for their excellent resources on the topic.
Tash Willcocks closed out the day with her thoughts on the elephant in the room: teams.
Design systems are enablers of scale and consistency, but developing and establishing them requires conditions of high trust and psychological safety.
In short, to save the parrots, we must use the shallot and master the elephant (I promise it made sense, you had to be there).
Thanks so much to all the volunteers and GDS-ers that made Design System Day 2023 possible: it was a glorious gathering of passionate practitioners!
A final quote from the day, sums up nicely the role of design in most organisations:
“We’re not here just to build components and patterns. We make impact through multiplier effects.”
Looking forward to next year!

Content:

HOW TO MAKE THE BEST OF IT
I recall standing outside the Pleasance Dome flyering my show a few years ago.
I was exhausted and knew I had to fill a big room and faced losing cash so I was anxious and desperate to make sure people came to see me.
I had rented a good flat and paid for amazing posters and had what I believed to be a fabulous show.
Then I spotted a couple of people who had seen me at a showcase show and had taken my flyer after the gig as they liked my stuff. I brightened up and as I approached them I watched a comedy promoter hand them two free tickets to his latest newly signed act’s show.
They took them. They were FREE.
He had a HUGE wad of free tickets and was giving them to people all around the Pleasance Dome. I lost the sale. I watched and my heart sank as people didn’t give a fuck how funny I had been at the 1pm showcase show.
They had free tickets and free is everything in this current climate.
No doubt the fringe this year yet again will release the BEST EVER SALES AT THE FRINGE and sit back as they manipulate the figures and the PR will spin it good.
I know that the figures aren’t always true, for ONE BIG SELL OUT there are hundreds of smaller shows underwriting them in the big venues and those comics were doing it on their own cash in the hope of a crowd.
Performers go home skint, owing money and are artistically broken.
I have no issue with the big paid venues, I just see issues that the Free Festival can resolve.
On the last weekend of the last few fringe’s I watched BIG NAMED ACTS give away TWO for ONES on the last Thursday and Friday. That’s not a great financial sign and was I aggressively flyered for a comic whose face graces the BILLBOARDS to buy tickets for his ‘EXTRA SOLD OUT SHOW’ which is a weird oxymoron. It can’t be sold out and still have tickets to sell.
Also audience members must be horrified to find out they had paid full price for tickets and realised half the audience were in for free or HALF PRICE and that’s an insult to early bird ticket buyers.
People were so scared of losing face.
This year am back at The Counting House Ballroom as is my daughter comedian Ashley Storrie.
Last year both me and Ashley had a BUMPER run and played to full rooms every day. I had people sitting on the floor of my venue and Ashley had people standing in her room and outside for a chance to get in.
They put cash in the buckets. We left with a profit, a very good profit if truth be told. We also told the crowds if they donated silver and bronze coins we gave that to the homeless and later on we dished it out fairly round the city’s street collectors.
I encouraged other comics and acts to get up and pitch their shows to my big comedy loving full capacity crowd. I tweeted about other comics gigs and helped flyer for other shows. It felt like THE FRINGE.
The people who came to the shows were brilliant.
Dealing with hard cash was weird. I felt like a mid price day time sex worker, I haven’t had that much money in my bag in years. We generally don’t carry much cash as a society now. It reminded me of when I owned a pub and used to count the takings.
People no longer see the Free Festival shows as ‘well it’s free it must be shit’ and I don’t believe they ever did. This is a nice neat rumour and label put on it by the same people who resent the free shows but have no issue giving out free tickets at a paid venue for a show that can’t shift a ticket.
When I did all the big “paid” venues I made thousands of pounds but the financial cut left to me was woeful and I STILL made a profit am one of the few who did. My accountant was stunned by the business model that means you pay for seats in advance and a venue is guaranteed their cash and cut NO MATTER WHAT before you step foot in the capital. The artist takes all the risk. Every seat you dont sell the venue has already been paid for that, the loss is not theirs….it’s YOURS.
Think of it this way…
Imagine you hired a bus with twenty seats, you paid the company for twenty seats….if you only sold 6 of those seats, you lose money.
Now think of that in a 200 seater venue at the fringe where the market is SATURATED with comics giving away FREE SEATS AND TWO FOR ONE SEATS every single day. Now you see my point.
Tax was a well worn phrase when talking about the free venues.
“Yes, but do the free festival comics declare their takings?” one comedy promoter asked me.
I don’t think anybody has the right to assume anyone is fucking their taxes based on a dislike of their business model. If you have an issue with people not paying their due tax please go check some Tory peers before you nitpick at comics you avaricious cunts. While you are at it please make sure the big venues who boast “BEST YEAR EVER” are not putting their profits into an offshore account to avoid taxes in UK.
I pay my tax.
I love the fringe and the past few years doing free fringe shows means I have loved it more. It felt like the old days. It felt good and it felt fair.
I encouraged the people who were skint and living under austerity to come see our shows for free. I also encouraged people who saw the show to take money OUT OF THE BUCKET if they needed some cash.
some tips for acts putting on a FREE SHOW….
Me and My daughter Ashley Storrie are back at the Counting House this year.
--
--
I am an award winning Scottish stand up comedian. writer and actor. I podcast weekly and wrote my autobiography Handstands in the Dark —

Today marked the conclusion of our journey. We had been traveling for nine days and were eager to get home. It had been a while since we had unwinded and slept in our bed at home.
Another reason was my spouse wasn’t feeling well. Our outing in Stonehaven yesterday gave him the chills. We were lucky he did not become ill while traveling, as it would have derailed our entire itinerary.
However, on our final day in Edinburgh, we had one more day of exploring before ending our trip.
After leaving our cabin, we headed towards Dundee on the Tay estuary. Around 11 am, we reached the magnificent city of Dundee. Everything appeared wonderful, and the weather was ideal.
Fun Fact: In 2014, Dundee was recognized by the United Nations as the UK’s first-ever UNESCO City of Design.
We went to a cafe and had a tuna sandwich with coffee. We strolled beside the Tay River. The River Tay is the longest river in Scotland and the seventh-longest in Great Britain.

Title: How was my experience at Edinburgh University and student Accommodation?
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
In the heart of Scotland lies a city steeped in history, culture, and academia: Edinburgh. Home to one of the world’s most prestigious universities, the University of Edinburgh, the city attracts students from all corners of the globe. Among the many challenges that come with starting a new chapter in a different city, finding the perfect accommodation stands as a pivotal moment in a student’s life.
Picture this: a vibrant young student, full of ambition and excitement, stepping foot into the historic cobblestone streets of Edinburgh. For many, this marks the beginning of an incredible journey towards higher education and personal growth. But behind this exciting new chapter lies a quest for the perfect place to call home during these formative years.
For Jamie, a student hailing from London, the search for student accommodation Edinburgh was both thrilling and daunting. Having been accepted into the University of Edinburgh’s prestigious business program, Jamie found himself faced with the task of finding accommodation that suited not only his budget but also his need for a conducive environment for studying.
The quest began online, scrolling through countless listings and options. From shared flats to purpose-built student accommodations, the choices seemed endless. Each listing had its unique charm, promising proximity to the university, modern facilities, and a vibrant community of fellow students.
After much deliberation, Jamie narrowed down his options to a few promising prospects. He decided to visit Edinburgh in person, a decision that would prove invaluable in his search. Stepping into the city, he was greeted by its rich history and the blend of old-world charm with a bustling modernity — a juxtaposition that captured his heart instantly.
His first visit was to a student housing complex located conveniently close to the university. As he walked through the doors, he was met with a lively atmosphere — students chatting in the common areas, engaging in study groups, and overall, a sense of community that was palpable. The rooms were modern, compact yet cozy, equipped with all the essentials a student could need. The allure of being surrounded by like-minded peers was tempting.
However, Jamie wanted to explore other options before making a decision. He ventured into the heart of the city, where charming old buildings were converted into student flats. The historic ambiance was undeniable, but the rooms were often smaller and lacked some of the modern amenities he had seen in the purpose-built accommodations.
Then came the visit to a shared flat — a common choice among students looking for a more independent living experience. The prospect of living with a few roommates excited Jamie. The flat was spacious, with each room uniquely decorated, reflecting the personalities of its occupants. The idea of creating a home away from home with fellow students felt appealing, fostering a sense of camaraderie.
After careful consideration and weighing the pros and cons of each option, Jamie ultimately chose to reside in the purpose-built student accommodation. Its proximity to the university, modern amenities, and the vibrant community it offered aligned perfectly with his aspirations for his university life.
Settling into his new accommodation, Jamie found himself surrounded by a diverse group of students — each with their own stories, cultures, and ambitions. The communal spaces became a hub for socializing, studying, and forging lifelong friendships.
Living in student accommodation in Edinburgh wasn’t just about having a place to stay; it was an integral part of Jamie’s university experience. It became the backdrop for late-night study sessions, impromptu gatherings, and the formation of lasting bonds.
As Jamie delved deeper into his studies, he realized that the choice of accommodation had a profound impact on his overall university journey. The convenience, the sense of community, and the support from fellow students made navigating the challenges of university life more manageable.
Looking back, Jamie reminisces about the thrill of finding the perfect place to live in Edinburgh. It wasn’t just a roof over his head; it was the cornerstone of his university adventure — a place where he didn’t just reside but truly belonged.
For any student venturing into the vibrant city of Edinburgh, the quest for accommodation may seem like a daunting task, but it’s a journey filled with choices that shape an unforgettable university experience — a journey much like Jamie’s, filled with exploration, decisions, and ultimately, a place to call home.
