Title: I believe in ‘Yellow’
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I was in the amazing Edinburgh Royal Botanic Gardens in April admiring the newly emerging spring daffodils when I had an epiphany, trees do in fact go to heaven, who knew!
A proponent of the daffodil is the end of life charity, Marie Curie who adopted it as their logo in 1986 offering hope, courage and support to all those who are touched by them. They started life delivering radiotherapy to women in the 30s.
She wore her yellow sun-bonnet,
She wore her greenest gown;
She turned to the south wind
And curtsied up and down.
She turned to the sunlight
And shook her yellow head,
And whispered to her neighbour:
“Winter is dead.”
Daffodowndilly, a poem by A.A. Milne
The first yellow daffodils of spring are a precious time of year for me. As A.A. Milne rightly points out they signify the end of a cold, black and white winter, a chance to wave goodbye to bad weather and offer a sense of timely rebirth with hope and a new beginning for the upcoming year.
Their arrival, a perennial gift from nature with their much-needed boost of colour is all I need from a faith, a non-spiritual conviction for me that never seems to disappoint, yellow on yellow, year on year and with impeccable timing! An unlikely yellow antidote to death, dying and goodbye!
The plant’s ‘bulbus’ (Latin) has a layer of dried skin, which serves as protection, and helps ensure that the bulb remain moist and properly insulated. There’s also another important function that it serves. Not only does this layer serve as a defence for this year’s plant, but it also carries the embryo for the plant or flower that’s going to bloom the following year.
Understanding that different kinds of daffodils follow their own pace is important. Growth primarily depends on the temperature of the soil as well as the amount of daylight that the plant receives and therefore the length of the day. Up here in Scotland we wait a month or more longer than in London where I grew up, for their arrival.
In the northern hemisphere they flower in spring and down in the southern hemisphere in our autumn, their spring. It’s magical stuff!
The daffodil plant generally thrives when the temperatures in the soil are between 50/60 degrees. As the sun begins to spend more time in the sky and the days begin to lengthen, the plant starts to grow more quickly.
Brodie Castle on the Moray Firth is one of the best places to see daffodils. They have a world-famous collection of well over 300 varieties and these always flower very late and are often at their best in late April and early May. I always enjoy a trip over to Brodie, located between Forres and Nairn just to see this yellow carnival at one of the National Trust for Scotland’s best kept secrets. Some varieties are around 150 years old like my favourite one above.
Another amazing display of yellow occurs around the same time, although with climate change it does flower from time to time all year-round, is from gorse.
Otherwise known as Whin and Furse and also Fuzzy Bush it starts its major flowering in late March and April and lasts here well into June. The overt coconut smell when in full bloom on a warm day is a very recognisable scent, one that you can also cook with if you flavour a dish with the flower petals.
It really is a ubiquitous, invasive plant in Northern Scotland especially by the coast and according to BBC’s Spring Watch; whom I tweeted this question last year, it flowers at odd times all year round simply to benefit from any early pollinators that are hanging around, out of season, who knew?
It also importantly has its own flower fairy:
When gorse is out of blossom,
(Its prickles bare of gold)
‘Then kissing’s out of fashion’,
Said country-folk of old.
Now Gorse is in its glory
In May when skies are blue,
But when its time is over,
Whatever shall we do?
O dreary would the world be,
With everyone grown cold —
Forlorn as prickly bushes
Without their fairy gold!
But this will never happen:
At every time of year
You’ll find one bit of blossom —
A kiss from someone dear!
The ‘Gorse Fairy’ is one of Cicely Mary Barker’s flower fairies that were first published in 1923.There are 170 original and individually accurate botanic illustrations, coupled with charming fairy images based on real children from Cicely’s sister’s nursery school. Each one also has a unique poem attached as above. The picture shown is on my wall at home, the verse in my book!
If you play golf on any of the world-famous links courses here, the ones played by the sea on the sand dunes and your ball lands in a gorse bush, you will have another, unmentionable name for this plant. As a rule of thumb and one which sadly missed gold commentator Peter Allis once advised, if you actually find it, take it out, drop it under penalty and ‘take your punishment son’. Never try to play it, you will regret it!
As with the daffodils, how these plants work out when to flower, never ceases to amaze me. Other yellow spring coastal gifts here are bird-foot trefoil, broom (often confused with gorse but safer!), aconites and the common dandelion.
The after-life of a tree
While once again in the Edinburgh Botanic Garden I also came across the following sign explaining how old trees that die do in fact have an ‘after-life’ or go to ‘tree heaven’ if you like. This very old sweet chestnut started to die back a few years ago and so the plant undertakers at Inverleith cut it down and left some of the main trunk in situ and the large boughs on the ground providing a habitat for other life such as bats, insects and birds.
However, this tree has suddenly lifted the lid on its coffin and surprisingly this spring, some new shoots and leaves have appeared. You can’t it seems keep a good tree down and yet another great example of nature providing hope and rebirth for the future despite looking death full in the face.
A.A. Milne — Writer and Poet
Alan Alexander Milne (1882 –1956) was a British author, poet, and playwright best known for his books about the bear Winnie-the-Pooh along with Christopher Robin, Tigger, Piglet and others. Christopher Robin was actually his son and who after a trip to the Zoo in London Milne wrote the original Winnie the Pooh story based on a tame bear, that they saw there named Winnipeg.
Milne was primarily a playwright before the massive success of Winnie-the-Pooh largely overshadowed all his previous work. Milne served in both World Wars, as a lieutenant in the Royal Warwickshire Regiment in the First World War and as a captain in the Home Guard in the Second World War. despite being a pacifist. He oddly had a degree in Maths whereby Trinity College, Cambridge, was his alma mater and was a useful cricketer. He bequeathed his original Pooh writings to the college.
Based on the fact that many of Milne’s philosophical sayings, poems and Winnie-the-Pooh quotes are often recited at funerals which I’ll come to later, he too saw the arrival of daffodils as a new beginning as per his poem at the start of this blog, added to the fact he was overtly a pacifist it seems that he did not speak out much on the subject of religion at all.
He did however, use religious terms to explain his decision, while remaining a pacifist, to join the Home Guard: ‘In fighting Hitler we are truly fighting the Devil, the Anti-Christ … Hitler was a crusader against God’
His best-known comment on the subject was remembered on his death:
The Old Testament is responsible for more atheism, agnosticism, disbelief — call it what you will — than any book ever written; it has emptied more churches than all the counter-attractions of cinema, motor bicycle and golf course.
He also wrote in the poem ‘Explained’:
Elizabeth Ann
Said to her Nan:
Please will you tell me how God began?
Somebody must have made Him.
So who could it be, ‘cos I want to know?
So, it seems that Milne was probably agnostic and veering on a non-believer but one who following a pretty religious upbringing in the late nineteenth century found it hard to completely let go as it was in those days and explaining that out loud, even harder.
It’s still difficult for me to tell my mother that I am an atheist and have been for many years following a similar childhood, where she is quite in disbelief and overtly saddened by my views.
Anyway, this blog is about the rebirth that nature brings us each year and one that is quite independent of any otherworldly beliefs and one that the ‘Scottish Enlightenment’ here began to address in the mid-eighteenth century questioning religion and allowing freedom of debate on subjects such as art, politics, science, medicine, engineering and especially philosophy that was, in those days difficult to contemplate in public.
That blog is here if you want to read it: Money can’t buy love, as the Beatles once suggested but it can buy a better death. However, contemplating ‘assisted-dying’ might well become part of a new ‘Scottish Enlightenment’ very soon!
https://medium.com/@DuncanHynd/money-cant-buy-love-as-the-beatles-once-suggested-but-it-can-buy-a-better-death-202150c6d2db
So yes, I definitely do firmly believe in yellow these days!
However, with a nod to the divine, it seems that Hindus see yellow as the colour of knowledge and learning. Lord Vishnu’s dress is yellow symbolizing his representation of knowledge.
Lord Krishna and Ganesha also wear yellow dresses while both Christians and Hindus associate yellow, seen as the colour of fire with renewal and purity and so while not the same, seemingly not a million miles away from my amateur philosophy above!
Winnie-the-Pooh
Milne’s bear was so much more than the famous animated hero of our childhoods and one that many Disney cartoons later featured. He and his friends were very much into philosophy with Milne using the characters to express many of his own beliefs. You probably wouldn’t have thought about using Pooh bear to find quotes about death, dying or saying goodbye to someone you love and so I have selected a few here that are in line with this article, secular in nature.
Death:
‘If you live to be a hundred, I want to live to be a hundred minus one day, so I never have to live without you.’
‘If ever there is tomorrow when we’re not together, there is something you must always remember. You are braver than you believe, stronger than you seem and smarter than you think. But the most important thing is, even if we’re apart… I’ll always be with you.’
‘Wherever they go, and whatever happens to them on the way, in that enchanted place on the top of the forest, a little boy and his bear will always be playing.’
‘I used to believe in forever, but forever’s too good to be true.’
Life:
‘Some people care too much. I think it’s called love.’
‘How do you spell love?’ said Piglet, ‘You don’t spell it, you feel it, said Pooh
‘Rivers know this, there is no hurry. We shall get there some day.’
‘Sometimes,’ said Pooh, ‘the smallest things take up the most room in your heart’
Goodbye:
‘How lucky I am to have something that makes saying goodbye so hard.’
‘But, of course, it isn’t really good-bye, because the forest will always be there… and anybody who is friendly with bears can find it.’
Airbnb offers a new feature when booking holidays, one where a death has occurred of a famous person at some time in the past!
In his writing prime, A.A. Milne lived at Cotchford Farm in Hartfield, East Sussex, the house, gardens and surrounding woods and country side inspired his children’s books. However, it is now available as a holiday let on Airbnb, but that is not the whole story!
The large country house has gained notoriety as it was also the home of Rolling Stones original member Brian Jones, who was found dead in the outdoor swimming pool in 1969, his death officially recorded as ‘misadventure’.
Around the grounds it is said that there are statues of the main characters in Milne’s books and poems, including Christopher Robin, Owl and an old sundial with images of Piglet, Tigger and Roo that also features words such as, ‘This warm, sunny spot belongs to Pooh, and here he wonders what it’s time to do’.
The Airbnb listing stated that you can ‘stay in the former home of A.A. Milne, Christopher Robin and Winnie The Pooh’ while mentioning that the property was a welcoming family home and historic building while Brian Jones was among other owners since the Milne family had it.
Some pictures located in the house have seemingly documented the chaos associated with the finding of Jones’s body in the pool and others showed Jones standing with the statues. It also seems that Christopher Robin, was not a great fan of being included in his father’s books and they sadly went their separate ways before Milne died there in 1956. An ill-fated property perhaps?
The Marie Curie charity began by delivering radiotherapy to women in 1930, who knew! They use the daffodil as the icon for their amazing end of lifecare charity for a reason.
This charity is the leading one in the UK that deals with dying, death and goodbye but it had roots in a subject close to my heart.
The Marie Curie charity really started life at the Marie Curie Hospital in Hampstead, London in 1930 where the ‘radiological treatment of women suffering from cancer and allied diseases’ was undertaken in what was a very early, specialist radiotherapy centre. Staffed only by women it had facilities for both radium and x-ray therapy with in and out-patient facilities. Amazingly in 1944, most of the hospital was razed to the ground in the blitz whereby their radium radioactive sources, safely stored in steel containers took, it seems three weeks to find in the rubble, probably much to the relief of the local RPA, if indeed they had one in those days!
In 1948 the rebuilt hospital parted ways from the newly born NHS, which Bevan had famously described as a ‘great and novel undertaking’ so that the name of Marie Curie could be established in the charitable medical field. Known initially as the ‘Marie Curie International Memorial Foundation’ it primarily investigated the needs of cancer patients and the best ways of helping them.
The first Marie Curie Home for cancer patients was opened in 1952, based in an old National Trust property in Fife while during the 1950s and early 1960s, the charity opened a further nine Marie Curie Homes in specially adapted but old buildings all over the UK while the charity’s main remit was to help cancer patients who needed nursing directly at home. Another aim was to make a substantial contribution to cancer research, especially into its causes and treatments.
From the 1960s onwards all Marie Curie Homes would be specially designed and newly built. The first was opened in Belfast in 1965. A similar, larger building followed in Edinburgh in 1966.
Their 24/7, day and night nursing service for cancer patients continued to grow throughout the 1960s while further specialist, dedicated laboratories opened for cancer research work.
From the early 1980s, ‘Marie Curie Homes’ and later the newly named ‘Marie Curie Hospices’ moved away from providing long-term nursing care to cancer patients, and became increasingly focused on hospice care, a field that they are now renowned for world-wide with the ability to offer palliative care for more patients, who were more seriously ill and usually for shorter periods of time.
The link to daffodils began in Scotland in 1986 in what was termed their first ‘daffodil appeal’ using live daffodils as a hand out similar to the poppy appeal. This continued to grow throughout the 1990s when they incorporated the daffodil into their logo, where it remains today.
They developed innovative fundraising partnerships with major companies and opened their first high street charity shops while in 1995, the Marie Curie Memorial Foundation became Marie Curie Cancer Care.
They launched their first national campaign called ‘supporting the choice to die at home’ and diversified to allow for the treatment of all terminal illnesses and not a charity just aimed at cancer patients. They successfully helped more terminally ill people remain in their homes, reducing the need for emergency hospital treatment, allowing more people to die at home and saving the NHS money.
Research efforts were focused on finding better ways of caring for terminally ill people and their families through palliative care research programs while establishing a major grants programme, awarding around £1 million every year to fund palliative care research projects, on a competitive basis becoming one of the UK’s leading funders of palliative care research.
In October 2014, the name was reduced to simply ‘Marie Curie’, to reflect the work to support people affected by all terminal illnesses.
Their main focus today is to assist people to make the right plans and preparations and to find the information and support they need when confronted with dying themselves or for family and friends facing bereavement. This includes prioritising social inclusion as some communities they have discovered get disproportionately less support than others at the end of life.
The Marie Curie Policy
‘We’re determined to fight for a world where everyone gets the best experience they possibly can at the end of their lives’.
Their ‘Better end of life’ report is here if you want to find out more on this amazing charity:
https://www.mariecurie.org.uk/policy/better-end-of-life-2022
And then the swallows return, the bluebells come out and we move on again!
PS. I wanted to add a section on music, an important part of my own life and am aware of the use of yellow in a few well-known hits, The Beatles and Coldplay come to mind. However, just as I write this latest piece, UK rapper ‘Big Zuu’ who also doubles as a brilliant ‘pop-up’ celebrity chef on TV has released his new song, its’ simply called Yellow! It’s great, shows off his musical talent in a different light and so I simply had to include it!
Duncan Hynd — June 2023 blog

Title: Developing A Regenerative Futures Fund #12: Inching Closer To Launch
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Hello from the world I’m embroiled in, where I’m way deeper than knee-deep in developing a new long-term unrestricted £15m pooled fund that shifts power to local people to make decisions on a cohort of community orgs in Edinburgh to lead place-based systems change across some big themes - poverty, racial inequality and injustice and climate change (phew — and yes I do have a bad habit of long sentences!).
Last week I wrote an update and thanks to our amazing learning groups as we come to the end of this chapter of co-design. I also have shared this with a group of people who have been advising, following along, supporting and cheering on.
Reminder that our learning groups have been a mix of individuals via End Poverty Edinburgh, community organisations, and funders and public sector partners — if you’d like to read more here is a blog that talks about this.
After I sent that I thought… I have an almost ready-made blog here.
So here is the (slightly edited) April 2024 update on Regenerative Futures Fund:
From March 2024 we have moved into a new phase of the project which means bringing the learning groups as they have been since the late 2022 / early 2023, to a close.
In March 2024 we created a condensed version of the detailed operational plan, which can be accessed here on the EVOC website.
We are also hoping to do an open Q&A session for community organisations in Edinburgh soon.
A few updates (and thanks!):
As ever, keen to chat with anyone who would like to meet to talk any aspect through, you’d like to get involved. Amazingly, there is SO much more to share than what’s in this update (I’ve missed so many things, it probably needs another blog!) — but I’m always to happy to chat over anything here and missing bits.
An information / conversation session coming soon — for Edinburgh community orgs.
And our ‘funders progressing proposals’ group has been meeting regularly since January if anyone from funding orgs would like to know more about that in terms of joining as a funding partner by contributing to the pooled fund.
Phew!
Finally — In 2023 I set myself a challenge to do 42 swims in my 42nd year and happy to report I am on track although I will be in the sea 4 times between now and next Saturday! Happy to have achieved a wee personal goal alongside a busy work year, and look forward to more swims in my 43rd year and beyond. Here is a pic of my favourite local swimming spot in early April ❤️
Please do email me on leah.black@evoc.org.uk or find me on LinkedIn (that’s where things seem to be happening now) if you’d like to chat 😁

Title: University of Edinburgh Releases First Tool in Decentralization Index
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Weekly news and developments from within the Cardano ecosystem. From new project launches to updates of existing protocols, everything you need to know can be found here.

--
Listen
Share
3/4/2024
As decentralization becomes a central theme within the blockchain community, there’s an increasing recognition of the need to systematically evaluate the levels of decentralization within blockchain networks. In response to this need, the University of Edinburgh has spearheaded the creation of the Edinburgh Decentralization Index (EDI). This initiative aims to provide a detailed and open-source framework for evaluating blockchain networks, highlighting the industry’s shift towards distributed ecosystems and emphasizing the critical need for transparency and standardization in blockchain assessments.
On March 1st, 2024, the unveiling of the EDI Dashboard’s alpha version represented a significant step forward in blockchain transparency. Spearheaded by the University of Edinburgh and funded by a grant from Input Output Global (IOG), this open-source index was a result of a collaborative effort with multiple universities. By pooling their diverse academic insights and technical expertise, the partnership aimed to ensure the tool’s relevance and adaptability across different blockchain contexts.
The Decentralization Index is crafted to be objective and unbiased, with the aim of developing into an industry-wide accepted benchmark for assessing decentralization as it progresses over time.
The Edinburgh Decentralization Index (EDI) employs a variety of metrics to evaluate the decentralization levels of Layer 1 blockchains, including Bitcoin, Bitcoin Cash, Cardano, Ethereum, Litecoin, Tezos, and Zcash. Understanding these metrics can help stakeholders assess the robustness and fairness of different blockchain networks.
Nakamoto Coefficient: This metric indicates the minimum number of entities required to control over 50% of mining or staking power, thus highlighting potential vulnerabilities in the network’s decentralization. A higher Nakamoto Coefficient suggests a more resilient and distributed network, making it a crucial measure for assessing security against collusion or attacks.
Gini Coefficient: By measuring the inequality within the distribution of block production, the Gini coefficient helps identify the balance of power within the network. A lower Gini coefficient indicates a more equitable distribution, which is essential for ensuring that no single entity has disproportionate control or influence over the network.
Shannon Entropy: This measure of information entropy quantifies the unpredictability and diversity of block producers. Higher Shannon entropy suggests a more decentralized network, reflecting a varied and unpredictable block production that enhances network security and fairness.
Herfindahl-Hirschman Index (HHI): The HHI measures market concentration to evaluate the diversity of block producers. Low HHI values denote a decentralized network with a balanced distribution of power among participants, which is vital for preventing dominance by any single entity.
Theil Index: This index measures the redundancy in a population, with lower values indicating a more equal distribution of block production. By assessing the diversity of participation in the network, the Theil index provides insights into the network’s decentralization and operational fairness.
Max Power Ratio: Representing the proportion of blocks produced by the most dominant entity, this metric sheds light on the extent of control exerted by the largest block producer. A lower max power ratio is preferable for a healthy, decentralized ecosystem, ensuring no single participant overly influences the network.
Tau-Decentralization Index: This index measures the concentration of power by identifying the minimum number of entities controlling more than a specific fraction (e.g., 66%) of mining or staking power. It offers a nuanced view of network control, essential for understanding deeper layers of decentralization beyond the majority control.
These metrics collectively offer a multi-dimensional view of blockchain decentralization, providing valuable insights for users, developers, and regulators to understand and improve the distributed ecosystems of various blockchains.
The Edinburgh Decentralization Index (EDI) aims to reshape the blockchain landscape by providing a standardized approach to evaluating decentralization. This could significantly impact the future of blockchain technology, potentially paving the way for widespread adoption. As businesses, institutions, and nation-states begin utilizing blockchains for various purposes like identity management, payment systems, and governance, it could lead to increased adoption of blockchain technologies across both public and private sectors. This, in turn, would drive innovation and enhance efficiency.
By offering clear metrics for decentralization, the EDI facilitates more informed decisions by governments and organizations. For instance, a country might choose to adopt a blockchain like Cardano for its stablecoin initiative. Such applications could enhance public trust in blockchain and stimulate broader usage across various sectors.
Furthermore, with the EDI placing decentralization at the forefront, current and future blockchain systems are likely to be encouraged to become more decentralized and incorporate features such as on-chain governance. This emphasis on decentralization could lead to increased adoption of blockchain technologies for both public and private applications, thereby driving innovation and efficiency.
As the blockchain and cryptocurrency industry focuses more on decentralization in the future, the development of the Edinburgh Decentralization Index (EDI) by the University of Edinburgh will play a crucial role and lay the foundation for future metrics by which blockchains are measured. Moving forward, with the EDI emphasizing decentralization, it will be poised to encourage the adoption of more decentralized approaches within blockchain systems, fostering innovation and efficiency across both public and private applications.
You can view the Edinburgh Decentralization Index Dashboard at the following link: http://blockchainlab.inf.ed.ac.uk/edi-dashboard/#/consensus

Title: Cycling in the Scottish Borders
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
A week’s adventure loop from Edinburgh
Venturing out on a cycle tour in August 2020 as Scotland gradually emerges from the coronavirus lockdown was a complicated decision, fraught with factors we’d never had to consider on bicycle trips before. First the question of whether we should even leave home for a week, and add our needs for accommodation, food, and facilities to the burden placed on other towns. Then, whether we could manage proper handwashing and social distancing from the saddle. And not least, if we were to encounter any injuries or difficulties along the way, could we manage that ourselves without putting others at risk?
The choice to travel during a pandemic is an individual one, based on personal circumstances, capacities, and acceptance of risk. We were certain we didn’t want to board a train or a plane unnecessarily, but a self-supported bicycle camping trip seemed a reasonable form of recreation, and although we planned to be away for a week we were never more than 60 miles away from home in case we needed to return quickly. We packed our face coverings, hand sanitiser, puncture repair tools, and first-aid kit; counted ourselves extremely fortunate to be in good health with time off from work; and hit the road.
Day 1 encompassed 40 miles from Edinburgh down to Innerleithen, following the brilliant National Cycle Network Route 1 along traffic-free paths and quiet roads out of the city, over the Moorfoot Hills and down into a beautiful valley beside the Leithen Water. It was a hot, pre-thunderstorm day and our legs were decidedly unused to hills after being inside for months, but it was still a joyful experience to finally be released from the cramped confines of the city and be flying along on two wheels.
In Innerleithen we visited with friends, and the next morning had a lovely breakfast outdoors at the Café Sitooterie.
Notes on the route: brilliant off-road cycle paths (converted from former railway lines so mostly flat) all the way from Edinburgh to Bonnyrigg. From Bonnyrigg the route is on-road on minor B roads with little traffic. No villages or services for 20 miles until Innerleithen; we picked up sandwiches and snacks at the Bonnyrigg Co-op.
Day 2 took us from Innerleithen down to the Ruberslaw Wild Woods Camping site a few miles from Denholm. We followed NCN Route 1 along a gorgeous riverside path and through quiet woods, rolling up and down hills to Melrose. Melrose is a lovely town with an historic Abbey (one of the stops on the Four Abbeys local cycle loop) but it was closed under coronavirus restrictions. The town itself was quite busy so we stopped at another Co-op to buy some bagels and peanut butter (by now our classic bike touring lunch menu) along with groceries for a camp dinner, and had a picnic in Gibson Park.
Notes on the route: between Caddonfoot and Tweedbank the NCN slips off the road and down a tiny dirt path next to the river, well-hidden by trees and bushes. We missed the sign and instead turned right across a newly-surfaced cycling and pedestrian bridge — which was fabulous infrastructure, even if it was the wrong direction (for us). Although NCN 1 follows the river most of the way to Newtown St Boswells, it’s not flat; we tackled about 1,000 feet of elevation gain including a good climb out of Melrose.
From Melrose we cycled on to Newtown St Boswells, where we had to leave the NCN and scout our own route south to Denholm. Navigation was a bit tricky since many of the minor roads were unsigned, but we wound our way through the countryside and arrived at the campsite around 6:30pm. We’d been lucky to get a booking in advance, since so many campsites are fully booked for weeks due to high demand. Ruberslaw is a well-run and pretty fancy campsite, with a central Hub with showers, phone charging and Wifi, and a shared open-air kitchen with a microwave and electric tea kettle! We’d opted to camp in one of their forest pitches, so after checking in we had to hike-a-bike up a grassy farm track to our spot in the woods.
Day 3 was a “rest” day. We were staying a second night at Ruberslaw but had to change sites since we hadn’t been able to book two nights in one spot. So we packed up camp and carried our gear with us 8 miles to Hawick (pronounced “Hoyk”) which was the closest town with a grocery store. As always seems to be the case, avoiding the main roads usually at least doubles the climbing, so it turned out to be a fairly strenuous “rest day” ride. In Hawick we had lunch outside at the Damascus Drum cafe and picked up some food to cook in camp before cycling 8 miles back (this time on a flatter route).
Day 4 brought 1,200 feet of elevation gain on foot, and another 1,600 feet on bikes. We spent the morning climbing Ruberslaw itself (“law” being a common word in Scotland for a hill, from the Anglo-Saxon word hlāw). The thunderstorms had finally broken overnight, so we left our wet tent to dry out a bit and hiked through the mist and purple heather up to the summit.
We left camp around 12pm and cycled on minor roads through Jedburgh up to Kelso. The rain caught up with us as we arrived in Kelso, notable for having a cobbled square with all cobbled roads leading into it —this is quite the experience on bikes (I call it the Cobble Wobble). All the cafes were closed and we were contemplating soggy takeaway sandwiches from Greggs until we happened to spot a nearby pub with a covered outdoor picnic table and made a dash for that just as the clouds burst open again. We tucked ourselves and our bikes under the awning and had an excellent lunch. (The name of the pub was, of course, The Cobbles — highly recommended).
We waited out the rain as long as we could then left Kelso looking for NCN Route 1 again (we missed the turn, but our alternate route on the back roads through Stichill and Leitholm was virtually traffic-free and mostly flat). The rain came down hard again for about 5 minutes, which was plenty of time to get us thoroughly drenched, even in our waterproof gear. Luckily we had 14 miles to dry out before we reached Swinton. We stayed overnight with some kind and covid-conscious Airbnb hosts who let us dry out our tent in their airing cupboard.
Notes on the route: after Jedburgh we turned north on the B6400 towards the tiny hamlet of Nisbet and then followed the Borders Abbeys Way for awhile. The section of the Borders Abbeys Way east from Nisbet is a rocky gravel track; for a paved road option go a bit further along the B6400 and take the next right.
Day 5, heading for the seaside! It was a short 17-mile ride from Swinton to Berwick-upon-Tweed in sunny weather. We cycled over the River Tweed and crossed the border from Scotland into England, then rejoined NCN 1 in Norham. We took a brief break in the shade and had a look round the Norham Castle ruins, then carried on, crossing over the 200-year-old Union Chain suspension bridge and following a separated cycle track briefly alongside the A1, then a bridleway over the hill into Berwick.
We set up camp at the Seaview Caravan Park on the outskirts of Berwick, and spent the rest of the sunny afternoon on the beach. (The Caravan Park was ok, not much accommodation for tents other than a small patch of lawn alongside the road, but lovely views and good facilities for toilets, showers, and washing-up sinks.)
Day 6, so long, sunshine. A thick fog rolled in overnight and beclouded the whole coast. We had a second night booked at the Caravan Park and had planned a day ride out and back to Lindisfarne National Nature Reserve and Holy Island, about 15 miles down the coast. Holy Island is connected to the mainland by a tidal causeway which is flooded by the sea twice a day, but the safe crossing window that day was between 12:10pm — 9:20pm so we had plenty of time. We followed NCN 1 all the way, which is a fantastic adventure over grassy clifftop paths (unpaved for most of the route). We were quite glad not to be hauling heavy panniers but met a few loaded touring cyclists who seemed to be having a great time. We intended to stop at the lone Londis shop near Beal for provisions, but instead came across the Barn at Beal Restaurant & Campsite so had coffee and very good sandwiches there instead.
Day 7 turned out to be our longest distance day, cycling 50 miles from Berwick-upon-Tweed to Yellowcraig Beach. We had takeaway breakfast rolls and coffee from the Mule on Rouge Cafe in Berwick, picked up some bread and cheese for lunch on the road, and cycled out on NCN 1, connecting to NCN 76 as we left town. NCN 76 was our route for most of the day; we left it briefly at Foulden to head inland and skipped the scenic loop to Eyemouth (saving those miles and hills for another day). We had lunch on the side of the road, picked wild blackberries, and rolled through the lovely town of Dunbar and then into North Berwick (not to be confused with Berwick-upon-Tweed).
Notes on the route: NCN 76 is mostly on-road, using quiet minor roads but with a 5-mile stretch on the A1107 from near Reston to Cocksburnpath. It’s a fast road but there weren’t many cars and drivers gave us plenty of space. After Bilsdean there’s a separated cycle way next to the A1 (crossing the A1 is required at one point, at a guided crossing) which takes you past Torness Nuclear Power Station. Not long after it’s a traffic-free path into Dunbar, and then it’s mostly on the John Muir Way (a mix of quiet roads, traffic-free paths, and grassy tracks) into North Berwick and on to Yellowcraig Beach.
After a short break in North Berwick we pedalled another 3 miles on to Yellowcraig Beach to wild camp for the night. There was a handful of other tents spaced out across the dunes when we arrived, and signs permitting responsible camping, so we waved hello to our distant camping neighbours, pitched our tent, and made macaroni cheese on the beach.
Day 8 was a straightforward journey from Yellowcraig Beach back home to Edinburgh, following a familiar route on the NCN 76. Glad to be back safely, and grateful for the dedicated folk at Sustrans who have built the fantastic National Cycle Network for everyone to travel along.
Total distance and elevation gain: 232 miles, 9,875 feet

Title: Summer journey to begin learning UX in University of Edinburgh
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
During 2022 summer, I participated in a summer programme — student-led, individually-created course — in the University of Edinburgh. What this course about is students themselves design the course that they plan to study and use reflective framework to develop personal and professional skills throughout their learning process.
It is a good way to learn knowledge or skills outside of one’s major and with the guidance from the university, students are able to individually conduct reflective report regarding their study path — a meaningful assessment method on what students have learnt.
When I think about what I want to learn during the summer, a question popped out: what else can I create with the background of studying psychology?
It turns out that User Experience (UX) Design is an area connect tightly to psychology as it involves knowing users and solving their problems. Therefore, I decided to learn in more details how a UX designer conduct a project and what skills are required along the way.
The project that I choose to carry on is to solve a problem that I accidentally saw in the newspaper in which it talks about Nigeria’s stock market may need more than technology to thrive. Therefore, with the hope to have an accessible app for people with little investment knowledge to use, I decided to design an iOS app that can make users find it more easily to invest stocks online.
Project Showcase:
To have the prototypes like the picture showed above, I need to acquire several skills:
This programme requires two reflective reports to be submitted as a way of assessing students’ ability to self-trace what has been doing well and what can be improved.
To achieve a distinct grade, reports should show the writers’ reflection framework when reviewing their study processes. In particular, students’ critical reflection is important as it can shows that they are not only paying attention to what goes well but also taking into account areas that can be improved. For example, though I noticed that my learning process of using Figma is efficient in terms of time-management, the way I learn only relies on having my project done. If there is more self-exploration when learning to use Figma, my learning pathway can be more diverse.
Although in most of the time, this programme test people’s ability to self-study, each student is assigned to a tutor who will provide advice with how to improve their reflective ability.
Finally, I got an A with all the assessment being reviewed by my tutors. What this programme is about is not only the mark that I got, but truly teaches me the importance of learning process rather than the outcome.
Before enrolled in this programme, I rarely thought about what I want to do as my career. Although I am glad to being able to learn Psychology, there are so much choices that I can make to further my career.
With this programme experience, I decided to learn the UX design further and hope to being able to produce more projects that are useful for the real-world. Although I am lack of certain design skills, I believe this story told me that when one person decided to be the teacher and teach himself/herself, the power of learning is unbelievable.
--
--
I am a third year student at the University of Edinburgh studying Psychology. I am interested in UX Design and HCI in general.

Title: 900th Birthday
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Member-only story
--
Share
on Edinburgh’s Royal Mile
St Giles High Kirkis celebrating its 900th birthday in style by getting some marvellous new lights installed. This really does cement its place on the Edinburgh skyline as the finest spire or sticky up bit (SOSUB) and I’d be prepared to roll up my sleeves and go bareknuckle with anyone who disagrees.
This long view shows the SOSUBS of (left to right) Edinburgh Castle, The Hub spire, then (in the background) the Scottish National War Memorial at the castle, St Giles crown spire, and The Tron Kirk spire.
You’re basically looking at a compressed Royal Mile squished into one frame with a 500mm lens.
The view from the street is pretty impressive too, especially when the haar rolls in from the North Sea and the beams of light continue into the sky. If only St Giles could work out a way to get £1 from everyone who takes a photo of the spire from the Royal Mile they could pay the leccy bill and a whole lot more.

Title: Edinburgh: The City I Keep Leaving
Content:

I am, at heart, a homebody and perhaps that is why part of me is forever shocked I don’t live in my birth city. It’s especially dumbfounding given just how sensational Edinburgh, Scotland is as an abode: knock it out the park architecture everywhere the eye can see; it’s a manageable size (everything is basically ten minutes away from everything else); it is a place of international significance, historically (the birthplace of the Age of Enlightenment) and now (the city’s population doubles in size every August for its miscellany of festivals (International, Fringe, Book, Jazz)).
I left Edinburgh for the first time in 2000, aged seventeen to go to university (destination: Oxford) and returned in 2003, only to leave it again in 2012, aged twenty-eight (destination: London) hoping to leave behind my broken-heart and to kickstart my life as a blindsided singleton.
Plenty of people leave cities in those sorts of circumstances, but in the case of the 2012 departure, I do rather regret doing so, for it gave rise to a prolonged, complex grief from which I sometimes doubt I have yet fully recovered.
At the time, it felt like the whole city had been contaminated by a betrayal I had experienced at the hands of a boy I thought…

Edinburgh Festivals 2015 Impact Study
Quality of events and record numbers drive the world’s Festival City
Earlier this week, Festivals Edinburgh and BOP released the findings for the 2015 Festivals Edinburgh Impact Report. With the help of more than 30,000 survey respondents, our report quantifies the economic, social and cultural impact of the twelve Edinburgh Festivals represented by Festivals Edinburgh. The report confirms the significant contribution that Edinburgh Festivals make to the quality of life, international reputation and economic strength of Edinburgh and Scotland.
Key findings from our study show that:
The study takes a holistic approach to assessing impact that considers social, cultural and economic effects. This approach of assessing the ‘all-round’ value of the Festivals was ground breaking when BOP pioneered it for the 2010 Festivals Impact Study, and was the first study of its kind — not just for the twelve Edinburgh Festivals, but more widely in the Festivals and events sector.
This current study follows on from the methodology developed in 2010 and provides the first directly comparable data on the impacts of the Festivals at a five-year follow-up stage.

I didn’t think that mice were good at climbing… until I rented a flat in Edinburgh!
If you’ve ever visited Edinburgh you’ll have noticed that much of the city is comprised of stone tenement flats. These ‘apartment blocks’ are usually 3 or 4 storeys high, often with a row of shops on the ground floor. Many date back to the 19th century, and most of them have rows and rows of chimneys on their terraced rooftops.
I’ve lived in several of these tenement flats, and visited many more. They are popular with students and young couples alike.
Being built of solid stone, with wood and plaster walls, there are gaps a-plenty. There are cracks around the skirting boards, in the backs of cupboards, around the old boarded up fireplaces (Edinburgh’s nickname of Auld Reekie comes from the smog emanating from the densely packed flats with a coal fire in each room!).
The tenements have been loved and lived-in by generations of Edinburghers. They provide a great place to live for people who enjoy the buzz of a capital city. They also provide the ideal place to live and bring up your family if you are a mouse!
3 of my flats were on the top floor. These were all on the third floor (fourth if you include ground floor). My flat in Marchmont had incredibly high ceilings, so I was a long way up! You can imagine my surprise when I first heard scratching noises behind a wall. I initially put it down to the students who lived next door.
The next sign that we had furry friends was when I repeatedly found myself cleaning up my flat-mate’s cornflakes on the kitchen worktop. How could he leave such a mess every day?! After a week of daily cleaning I picked up the cereal packet to wipe underneath, and a cascade of cornflakes tumbled from the box.
A mouse had eaten its way through the cardboard.
Soon after the kitchen incident I arrived home one afternoon to find myself face to face with a very well-fed brown and grey mouse, standing quite unperturbed in the middle of the living room floor!
Our eyes met, and for several seconds he sat up and stared right back at me. Without any fear, he then continued munching away on the biscuit crumbs he had found under the table, or down the side of the sofa.
I ran at him, not quite knowing what I would do if I caught him. The mouse nonchalantly ducked back through the tiny crack in the wall, just under the window, and was gone.
It was then that I decided the only way to deal with this was call out the pest control people. A friend had recommended a local mouse control company in Edinburgh so I gave them a call and they arrived the next day.
It was only then that I realised that Edinburgh tenements had the perfect network of tunnels, nooks and crannies which were ideal for mice to travel freely between floors, and build nests in the warm cavities behind those old walls.
The main thing I learned was to NOT LEAVE FOOD LYING OUT. I became an ardent fan of tupperware containers. In the end I didn’t have to kill any mice. I cleared up any traces of food, and blocked off the hole they were using to enter my flat. I presume the mice now visit the other kitchens in that block of flats — the ones that still have cornflakes lying out on the worktop.

I had wanted to post our travel journey chronologically but that just hasn’t happened, we’ve been too busy in some places and I’ve been just plain lazy in others. Perhaps I will write more about the other places our travels have taken us — Miami/New York (USA), Dominica (Caribbean), Havana (Cuba), Lisbon/Vilamoura/Carvoeira/Sintra (Portugal), Marbella/Malaga/Ronda (Spain), and Athens/Sifnos (Greece) and Dublin/Greystones (Ireland) — later. Chandler has been counting how many accomodations [AirBnB, hotels, TrustedHousesitters pet sits] we have stayed at since leaving Los Angeles 13 weeks and 5 days ago, and we are officially at # 26.
He started counting after seeing a couple of retired YouTube travel vloggers declare that they had stayed at 11 places in two months and they called their pace “insane”… he did the math and realized we “won”, yah and sigh.
We are now in Scotland. We started by exploring Edinburgh, which I loved, and then we went to the Scottish Highlands which I love even harder.
Edinburgh was stunning, it looks like every indie movie you have ever seen set in Scotland, cobblestone roads, castles built hundreds of years ago perched on rock formations formed thousands of years ago. But we kept reading things about “Edinburgh’s dark past” [truthfully they seem a little proud of it] so finally I googled it. Here are some of the juicy-awful results:
Edinburgh had some of the largest witch hunts in Europe with hideously sadistic torture methods, burning alive at the stake was one of the kinder methods and of course the bubonic plague in the 16th and 17th century.
“In 1456, a defensive wall was built around the Old Town. Problem was, no one wanted to live outside it, so as the population grew, people were packed together in increasingly unsanitary, greasy, moldy conditions. The only way to expand was upwards, so buildings got taller until they were up to 14 stories high, but had no toilets or running water. Residents would throw their waste out of their windows, shouting “gardyloo” as an advance warning, but it didn’t always work, and passers-by would get covered in poo.” [Source: Buzzfeed]
“Pestilence spread particularly rapidly in the tenement-filled, poverty-stricken, unhygenic conditions of the Royal Mile, and the council reacted with particularly brutal measures. When an outbreak hit the crowded Mary King’s Close, they ordered it to be bricked up, trapping over 300 infected and non-infected residents in their homes.” [Source: Buzzfeed]
But by the time we reached Edinburgh on June 4th, 2024 it was pretty damn civilized. We went to a little vegan options restaurant, had a couple of craft cocktails, and retired back to our AirBnB, certainly one of the prettiest I have been in, located in a historic building a block from the train station.
And as Taylor Swift was performing that weekend at Murrayfied Stadium, a herd [a gaggle, a flock, a swarm…a murder?] of Swifties descended upon Edinburgh. But as much as I hate crowds, they were so pink and sparkly and happy that it was hard to be annoyed at them. I almost joined them as ticket prices were “a bargain” compared to the U.S.A.; great seats could be had in Edinburgh for less than $500 as opposed to $2000 in L.A. and New York. But we didn’t, I fought my FOMO and won.
I thought I loved Scotland after seeing Edinburgh but man, it wasn’t until we got to the Highlands that I decided I really love it here. Despite the fact that it looks like every fantasy tale you’ve ever read as a child, with a demon possibly poised behind every moss-covered tree in the forest, that what is that sound-did I lock the door feeling I always had in the middle of the night in Los Angeles was gone. I felt safe. At last.
I really didn’t realize how the constant stress levels affected me both as a police officer in South Los Angeles and as a woman feeling vulnerable in her own home, but there was a palpable release when that feeling left me. It’s like a big warm hug and someone squeezing poison out of your system.
Crime is very low, air is clean, no natural disasters, and there are hardly any even predators, dogs are pretty much all floofs [and anyone who knows me knows I have loved and rescued bully breeds forever, but still, it is nice to walk a block without some ferocious sounding pack of dogs barking at you like my old neighborhood in Los Angeles], you are more likely to get hurt by a cow or a deer than anything else here. A cow or a deer.
How often could I take a walk in Los Angeles and not run into a single person, only hear the wind and the birds? In my entire life I can’t think of many places I can say that about. The beauty in Scotland is gob smacking, photos do not do it justice, epic mountains, rivers, forests and streams, Scotland has sights that are similarly as wondrous as Iceland without the swaths of humanity we encountered there.
Chela Landau’s youtube.com of a
Chandler saying goodbye to our Air BnB dog — Chela Landau’s youtube.com of
AirBnBs in Scotland bear no resemblance to any other place I’ve been. They ask you about your preferences, they stock the kitchen with vegan food, they meet you at the door and they often hug you when you leave.
At our AirBnB in Redcastle, Scotland the hostess showed us a “bothy” which we had access to during our stay with them, in U.S. terms it is like a man-cave shed, this one was small and cozy, had a wood burning stove and many candles. It was fabulous the one night we used it to read Harry Potter by candle light, intimate and romantic and exciting. Quite frankly though, the decapitated deer head staring at me with dead black eyes over the stove made me balk at going again back the next night as Chandler wanted.
But we were so content at our Redcastle AirBnB with it’s gorgeous garden and firth view, that we rarely ventured out except to get groceries at a market near us, which had a beautiful assortment of freshly grown fruit and vegetables.
After we got staples to eat the booze hunt was on, we found the local supermarket pretty well stocked [funny to see Jack Daniels in the foreign liquor section]. Looking for a local whisky for Chandler, I was corrected when I called it “Scotch”, they said that I should call it simply “Whisky” or risk insulting a Scotsman. (Yes, Scots remove the “e” in whiskey).
I have to say I’m a bourbon lass, I just can’t quite get behind that taste of moss in my drink, I will do better but for now it is tiny careful sips. I do love the stories however, I like the stories better than the actual whisky.
Any real whiskey drinker will know about “The Angel’s Share”; in medieval times when they would come to check on the barrels of whisky and they would have lost a third of the barrel’s contents to condensation, they believed that it was lost to the angels who had come down from heaven to sample their stock, and they figured in the loss as an offering that would make the angels smile upon them.
One of my favorite bourbon whiskeys is an American bourbon named Angels Envy in a sly wink to the folklore [athough in a bar we saw the sign “We have Whisky and Bourbon”, as though bourbon was a child of a lesser god and not worthy to be called whisky.
Anyhow, enough for today, we are going to Isle of Skye next and then Inverness to take a plane to Amsterdam, where we plan on settling in the Netherlands to begin our new lives; actually our new lives have begun, and every day is cherished.

I headed out at 10 but not before requesting a bottom bunk for tonight. Last night was hell! It goes without saying that I had to use the loo at least half a dozen times last night. Sometimes I don’t need to go at all or more usually, just once! I’m strong but not invincible. I was singing this song as I descended the spiral staircase. I was going to have a good day if it killed me.
My plan B was to buy some disposable adult nappies. Don’t laugh. They are the best invention since Scottish toasties which is what I’m having for breakfast right now. Filled with haggis, caramelised onion chutney and matured cheddar cheese. In the spirit of full disclosure, I did go to the Snax Cafe first, hoping for a full Scottish breakfast but I couldn’t get through the door — no I’m not that fat! — it was filled with people all waiting for food. It’s smoko time for the construction workers in the area. So I’m in the Snax Bakehouse next door where I’m enjoying a window seat and my coffee and Scottish toastie.

Member-only story

There are two things that strike me every time I walk the streets of Edinburgh.
The first is that nearly everyone is carrying tote bags full of groceries. So many flats in the city don’t have storage space, so grocery shopping is a daily errand.
The second is the incredibly disciplined behaviour of the dozens of dogs being walked by their owners that pass by me every day.
Their behaviour is invariably impeccable, regardless of age or breed.
They walk at their master’s side, many on leash, some not, keeping step, and seldom varying their focus from looking straight ahead. They don’t seem to take note of anyone or anything they pass by, including fellow canines. They don’t stop to exchange sniffs or even to sniff any of the myriad enticements at their level. Never has a passing pooch glanced up at me, hoping for a pat. One dog I noticed that did let its attention drift to the undergrowth of a shrub moved hastily along when its owner said: “Come along, love.”

Title: The Only Fun in Town: A Primer for Edinburgh’s Experimental Music Scene
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Listen

*** Originally published (in slightly edited form) on http://brightsurroundings.wordpress.com, February 25, 2019 ***
Edinburgh’s music scene has always been, to an extent, fairly eclectic. Trad-folk pubs stand adjacent to metal bars, and indie kids nod their heads to glitzy guitar pop before hard techno nights on the Cowgate every weekend. While this diversity is self-evident, it’s impossible to ignore the fact that within each genre or sub-scene, artists tend to adhere to certain ideas of musical safety or appropriateness at their respective venues. I am by no means questioning the validity or talent of any of these bands — there are a huge host of genuinely fantastic acts who fall into this description that I actively support — but I would like to direct attention towards some of the city’s more obscure and boundary-pushing music which tends to be ignored by the scene as a whole.
By writing this article, I hope to present a primer for anyone interested in discovering more about Edinburgh’s incredible outsider and experimental musicians who are stretching genre limitations and forging their own paths within the city’s scene. This is not necessarily a definitive list; there is likely a myriad of under-the-radar performers who have escaped my attention so far, but I would like to stress that — as far as I’m aware — this group remains on the fringes of the scene. Consider my thoughts, listen to the music, go to see the acts play live — supporting these people will not only benefit the individuals, but will also foster support and encouragement for artistic experimentation in general. Dig in!
Oharasix: https://oharasix.bandcamp.com/
The experimental and the electronic always go hand-in-hand, as both tendencies tend to strive for sonic and technological innovation. Josh Corkill’s output under the ‘Oharasix’ moniker perfectly embodies this approach: digitally manipulated samples and loops combine to create an unsettling landscape of warped club tracks, dominated by rhythmic glitches and pumping techno-inspired kicks. This stuff is an audiophile’s dream, as Corkill’s manic production is jittery, maximalist and wholly unique. The two live releases available on the Oharasix bandcamp page are the best examples of his skill, as both performances are rife with repetitive, glassy synth stabs which fly around and punctuate the underlying beats of every piece. Having witnessed Josh perform at Sketchy Beats last year, I can fully recommend catching him live whenever you get the chance — using just Ableton and a modest MIDI controller, he has a prodigious ability to sculpt industrial noise into a seamless and infectiously dance-able mix.
Smiling Suns:
https://soundcloud.com/smilingsuns
Serving as the aural antidote to the noise of Oharasix, Smiling Suns is an ambient project centred around organic instrumentation and minimal arrangements. The anonymous musician’s SoundCloud page is home to some truly compelling compositions where art music, post-rock and folk collide. Appropriately titled, 2017’s Quiet Songs II is a collection of tranquil musical sketches, constructed sparsely on acoustic piano, accordion, and slide guitar. Smiling Suns’ bio lists both Stars of the Lid and Godspeed You! Black Emperor as influences, and it is easy to observe their mark on the affective melodies of ‘Rhema’ and ‘Baby Steps,’ but an immediate sense of individuality underpins the form of every track. ‘Duror’ features a stunning chorus of reverberating classical guitars which float over a droning accordion, and the lo-fi warmth of ‘Falling’ is mesmerising. This really is one of the hidden gems of the Edinburgh scene (and with such expert concealment of identity, Smiling Suns may well remain hidden) — I’ll be keeping an eager ear to the ground for new material in the future.
Aamber Glass:
https://northtsar.bandcamp.com/album/a-new-year-dithered-dreamer-doused-in-rays-of-sun-cutting-through-the-skyline-of-east-finchley
To continue with the theme of anonymous ambient artists, Aamber Glass is an equally elusive creator of intriguing and understated soundscapes. Only one release has been issued under the mysterious handle — 2018’s evocative ‘a new year’ / ‘dithered dreamer doused in rays of sun cutting through the skyline of east finchley.’ This limited edition cassette consists of two separate “bodies of work.” The first is a series of individual compositions, in which ethereal synth loops are accompanied by echo-drenched field recordings. A personal highlight is the track ‘susanna,’ where a chopped-up, tremolo-laden chord trembles above ghostly background noise and continuously overlapping synth melodies. On the second side of the tape, Aamber Glass builds a mammoth 20-minute wall of modulating drones. We are guided through turns melancholic and tumultuous towards a slowly-fading finale. It is a grandiose, meditative effort which is unabashedly experimental. I genuinely mean it when I say that art of this scope and dedication sets the bar high for any prospective avant-garde composers.
Harry Bongo: https://harrybongo.bandcamp.com/
Perhaps one of the best-known faces on the city’s scene is Mr. Harry Bongo: drummer for numerous noisy instrumental acts, contemporary classical composer and beloved cheese DJ, Bongo is Edinburgh’s diversity personified. Particularly arresting is his solo output, which sees Harry take complete creative control as he crafts an array of beautiful minimalist works. I use the tag ‘minimalist’ tag here with reference to the art music movement rather than production — while such comparisons are reductive, echoes of Reich, Glass and Riley are everywhere on his releases, as repeating mallet sequences evolve into rich climaxes of strings, guitars and percussion. Harry’s self-titled 2016 album displays the breadth of his oeuvre: centrepiece ‘Vessels’ begins with a pulsating groove (which isn’t too far removed from Reich’s Music for 18 Musicians ), and this quickly morphs into an intense, cinematic swirl of computerised arpeggios and throbbing drums. Pieces such as ‘Prague’ and ‘Ashes’ are more restrained, with layers of lush strings and field recordings creating a warm sense of space. After an almost two-year break, Harry released ‘Three in Four’ in late 2018, a hectic single which twists and turns, weaving samples of Björk talking about her TV over frantic drum loops, distorted pianos and wild, echoing synth bleeps. Without giving too much away, I can recommend keeping an eye out for an imminent release — Bongo is back (and in good form, too).
Joe Coghill:
https://soundcloud.com/joecoghill
According to a short biography on the Glasgow International website, Joe Coghill is “a multi-disciplinary artist, musician and experimental publisher,” and so he neatly represents a kind of avant-garde mindset that is crucial to a revitalisation of the scene. “His practice,” it goes on to explain incorporates “video, performance, social sculpture, facilitation and media distribution” (one example of this is his curation of an exhibition at Edinburgh’s Fruitmarket Gallery inspired by no-wave composer John Margotti.) While it’s obvious that Coghill’s work isn’t limited to audio, the small amount of his works available online are incredible displays of experimental electronics. Fans of IDM bastions Aphex Twin and Squarepusher will be particularly at home with the material on his SoundCloud page, which closely resembles one of RDJ’s famed audio dumps: the mammoth collection of twisted samples and glitchy, granular atmospheres features esoteric track titles such as ‘bv,mt Eye’ and ‘Ae_frag.aef2dream’ (a cheeky nod to Autechre, perhaps?) Despite the obvious influences of these pieces, Coghill’s approach is far from derivative. His paranoid sequences and ceaseless folds of noise are refreshingly imaginative, and provide a welcome break from the monotonous tech-house of Edinburgh’s clubs. Dive in!
Mixed Signals: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCj_Jrf-g6BPebK7CXKjDLBg
…And now for something completely different. Live double bass and laptop electronics form the crux of Mixed Signals’ sound, providing a base for a tapestry of sinister drones, eerie vocal snippets and chopped-up field recordings. Long-form, slow-burning pieces are the specialty of these local experimenters, who have concocted a special brand of “mesmerising doom.” As the ensemble tend to operate as a live unit, they don’t currently have a lot of material online — however, their Youtube channel is home to two intriguing examples of their work. ‘The Door to Desolation’ is a 16-minute jam recorded live at the Black Medicine Basement, and ‘Taster Sounds’ is “not polished, not prepared, just a bit of an improvised draft of a taster of a teaser.” Although both of these are presented as spontaneous compositions, they are impressive statements of unique musicianship and an unorthodox approach. Both videos display the band’s love of serpentine beats and menacing synth pads punctuated by swathes of maverick double bass. In addition to the striking music, the videos themselves are incredible — clips which seem to be pulled straight from Norwegian “slow TV” are juxtaposed with unsettling, handwritten phrases and abstract sprays of light. This fits in with the tendency of local avant-garde creators to foray into the world of multimedia, and adds an interesting audio-visual edge to the group’s vision. Keep an eye out for Mixed Signals on the local circuit, as their live show is one of the scene’s most immersive experiences.
Liam Baker:
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/liambaker.music.poetry/
Youtube: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8T6r5QiBtww&feature=youtu.be
On the subject of multimedia, Liam Baker is a prolific creator of harrowing music, stunning poetry and exploratory film projects. At first glance, Liam’s music isn’t perhaps as out-there as some of the others on this list, but both his subject matter and his approach to creation are more than deserving of the “experimental” tag; consider the self-made video for ‘Consumatum Est (It Is Over),’ in which Liam sings a funereal melody and accompanies himself on classical guitar from the comfort of his own bathtub. His dynamic live performances consist of spoken word and solemn acoustic ballads, which marry such gloomy subjects as death, drug use and gentrification with a healthy dose of black humour. I once had the pleasure of watching Liam perform to a room full of avid punks and metalheads, and you could literally hear a pin drop from start to end; the remarkably attentive silence was testimony to Liam’s enigmatic stage presence and the powerful delivery of his lines. As with Joe Coghill and Mixed Signals, Liam’s music makes up a small fraction of his overall creative output: he’s one of a select group of all-round creatives who are fully stretching their limits and showcasing the possibilities of being an “artist” on Edinburgh’s underground circuit.
[Header photo by Ellen Beskow.]
Support your local scene.

I visited National Museums Scotland (NMS) and Scottish National Gallery (SNG)in Edinburgh and experienced some stunning pieces. Below I have shown and written about a few of the designs I took a liking too from NMS however I couldn’t share any of my favourite pieces from SNG as no photography was allowed due to the possibility of people creating forgeries.
This exact skeleton of the giant deer is the first ever complete version. This was given over to the university of Edinburgh as, at the time (1921), it was one of the world’s best natural history collections. It was then given over to the National Museums Scotland and remains there still. These skeletons are important as they help with discovering what animals have become extinct in the past. What I find most interesting is how fresh and recent this skeleton looks due to how well its been preserved but it is in fact 12,300 years old. I find skeletons like this very interesting as you get to see every tiny (and giant) bone put in the body and see how different and delicately designed every body is. It’s not everyday you have that opportunity. Lastly, I like the placement of this piece as it’s right at the entrance to all the animals exhibits and I feel it’s successful in catching your eye and dragging you towards that area of the museum.
This piece is about our path throughout life. In this you can see the figures in the circles are symbolic for perishing, rebirth and transforming. The golden thread wrapped around the figures is meant to show its leading the way out of this maze, symbolizing their life line. I enjoy this piece through the depth and reality of the meaning Kinnaird brought to it; it really made me reflect on my own life and how fragile it really is. Moreover, the colours are very vibrant and I feel that the prominent red colour suggests blood and health whereas the blues and purples suggest an ambition (possibly to escape the maze?) and peace.
This design is a printed textile piece which was created for Liberty & Co and Hull Traders. The material used was screen-printed woven cotton satin. The main colours used in this piece are pinks, reds and oranges which suggests a warm atmosphere. I think that McNish may have used these colours to match title of “Painted Desert” as when you think of a desert you typically think of an isolated, sandy area where there is a blistering heat. I like the abstract vibe and colour scheme to this piece of design as I feel they are in harmony with each other due to their wild, creative style.
Artist, Eduardo Paolozzi, played around with geometric shapes and designs for this piece with a variety of colours and shades. This particular piece was the first ever designed for Wedgwood. The materials consist of screen-printed porcelain. I am intrigued by Paolozzi’s use of shapes and the intricate detail put into each small section of the plates. Personally, I am a big fan of geometric work and believe that Paolozzi done a fantastic job at presenting his style here. The colours used throughout are mostly warm colours and shades with a few cold colours in contrast which I feel just adds to how eye catching they are.

When I first stepped outside of the Edinburgh Airport, I realized I had no plans on what I wanted to do and see during my short week in the city. I didn’t know anyone else on the trip besides my roommate, and I didn’t know what I would do in Edinburgh. I hadn’t researched much, because my roommate had a million places she wanted to visit. I knew she would pick some pretty stunning attractions as she loves traveling abroad and has done so before.
Our first destination was a two hour walking tour across the city with a lively English tour guide named Georgia. I followed along and found so many beautiful sights; I had my camera open on my phone for the entire two hours! I listened intently as she brought us to each destination, stopping to learn of the city’s history and value. My favorite stop was the Supreme Court of Scotland, a massive stone building with beautiful arched doorways. I turned a full 360 to see it all, and was met with very intricate stained glass windows. We were only there for a few minutes, as we had to make our way through the rest of the city. After a full day of travel, we went home and fell right asleep to prepare for our first full day exploring Edinburgh, Scotland.
The next day we were up bright and early for our first class. The building our classes were held in was full of chandeliers and stunning pink painted walls. I couldn’t believe…

Title: Pain and Suffering – A Reflection from Elephant Cafe, Edinburgh
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I am writing this from The Elephant Cafe in Edinburgh, famously known as one of the places where J.K. Rowling began crafting the magical world of Harry Potter. Sitting here, surrounded by creativity and history, I found myself reflecting deeply – not on spells or magic, but on something equally powerful: the human experience of pain and suffering.
Pain and suffering are often used interchangeably, but they are not the same. Pain is physiological – it’s a natural part of being alive. We feel it when we are hurt, physically or emotionally. Suffering, on the other hand, is psychological – it is the narrative (our interpretation of the event) we attach to that pain. We suffer when we replay painful events in our minds, hold on to guilt, or worry about an uncertain future.
The truth is, pain is unavoidable, but suffering can be avoided.
The Root of Suffering
Suffering arises when we resist what is. When we wish things were different, when we fight against reality, we create inner turmoil. But when we accept pain as part of our journey, suffering begins to dissolve. Acceptance does not mean we like the pain – it means we stop adding layers of mental and emotional resistance to it.
A Shift in Perspective: We Are Spiritual Beings
What helps me reduce suffering is a spiritual perspective that has profoundly changed my life.
I believe we are spiritual beings having a human experience. Before we are born, our spirit chooses the lessons it needs to learn in this lifetime. It chooses life situations, relationships, and even challenges that are aligned with those lessons. In fact, the more evolved the spirit, the more intense the lessons it chooses.
Think of the world as a giant school, where nearly eight billion unique courses are happening at the same time. Spirit learns these lessons through life situations we experience in our human form. But when we are immersed in the human experience, we forget our true nature. We resist the lessons our spirit came here to learn, and in that resistance, we create suffering. It islike a student refusing to study – he fails and has to repeat the class. Likewise, our soul may have to revisit the same lessons in future lives.
How Do We Break the Cycle?
The key is acceptance – not passive resignation, but deep inner alignment with the purpose of our soul/ spirit. When we stop fighting our circumstances and instead ask, “What is my spirit trying to learn through this?”, we shift our suffering into understanding, and our pain into growth.
Sometimes, the lesson might be patience. Other times, it may be resilience, compassion, or learning to see from a different perspective. When we embrace this idea, we begin to navigate life with more grace and strength.
We may not have control over the cards life deals us, but we do have the power to play them wisely. Life does not expect perfection. It asks only that we do our best, learn, evolve, and keep moving forward. That is all our spirit truly seeks.
Sitting here, inspired by the place where a story changed the world, I hope these reflections help you find your own strength. Whether you are facing pain or walking through suffering, remember: you are not just a body or a mind – you are a spirit on a journey. And every life situation, especially the painful ones, is part of your evolution.

Title: When The Music’s Older
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
2
Listen
Share
Enjoying an experience is not a constant single note. I enjoyed the break I just took, but I didn’t walk around Edinburgh with a constant fixed grin on my face.
Anyone who says I did — is probably related to me.
I enjoyed the trip there and back as well — slowly, by car, with overnight stops — but the ninety-minute stopped-traffic experience on the M6 isn’t something I will want to replicate if/when there’s a next time.
Having time to ask “Where is the gift in this?” made me notice the light snowstorm of blossom wafting in around us from the verge, but I don’t think I would have ticked the “Stop and notice the flowers” box if I’d been given the option.
For the trip, I hauled out my ancient case of CDs and played them in random order. Some CDs were easy to skip through, but there were a few happy surprises.
I have Dusty Springfield, The Doors, The Stranglers and Deva Premal left over for my next outing in the car. That’ll be a day.
Edinburgh is a tolerant, good-humoured city. I liked the buses (capped fares), and in particular, I liked watching the drivers chatting away (briefly) at their change-overs. Every one of them needed to stop again and adjust their nearside mirror.
I remember Red Kite Cafe for brunch and Cobbled Roastery for coffee and one day we had a good lunch at The Pantry. One night we went all the way to the Radio Rooms in Berwick-upon-Tweed for Hunter & McMustard.
Browsing the shop-fronts in Stockbridge, we talked — somewhat more seriously than not seriously at all — about the distinctive Scottish cuisine that has evolved out of deep-frying everything from Mars bars to pizzas. Do click that second link.
You don’t know until you’ve tried. I wanted to ask what difference air-fryers might make, but missed the moment.
We walked through the Royal Botanic Gardens (without visiting the cafe), and sat for a while on a bench in The Meadows. That was the sunniest day.
Edinburgh is a tolerant, etc., city of cobbled streets, green spaces and small coffee shops and cafes. There’s a National Gallery and a National Portrait Gallery, and in the centre, always bagpipes playing somewhere.
Blackwell’s is the bookshop to visit. There are also Warhammer and Forbidden Planet if you need more storytelling.
I was overnight in a “Single Octo Glamping Pod” at the Drummohr caravan site on the edge of Musselburgh (26 bus into Edinburgh). Fridge, kettle, under-floor heating. Heart 80s Radio playing in the shower block. Their record collection includes Alison Moyet, Human League and Duran Duran; my CD collection doesn’t.
And then the journey home.
Curving motorway through Cumbria and the Lake District — yes, I did stop at Tebay — and then the heavier traffic and older, occasionally elevated, roads through the Midlands, and then — yes, I did stop at Gloucester — the wide open skies and stretching-away rivers of the Somerset Levels.
I spent most of it daydreaming ways in which I was going to be much more efficient when I got home. I would do this, and this, and organise that, and there would be no more procrastination.
And now I’m home.
And I think I’ll be much more efficient — tomorrow.
In case this needs saying, there are no affiliate links in this story. I just got carried away with all the looking-up and linking.
The National Portrait Gallery is worth a visit for the building and the chance to sit down. There’s a cafe. And pictures. Some people are well-served by their portrait artists; some … not so sure.
Lothian Buses runs an ad for its app on a screen in its buses. First, the ad tells you to scan the QR code to get the app, and then — I liked this — the ad gives you detailed instructions on how to scan a QR code.
Helpful. If I’d been staying longer, I would have scanned the QR code.
Or at least, worked out how.
