Title: Bye Bye Edinburgh Fringe 2024.
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
2
Listen
Share
Dear Kin, Supporters, Friends, and Enemies,
Some of you may know I was currently planning to attend the Edinburgh Fringe 2024, with my debut hour “Burning Down The House.”
Some of you may have kindly made a donation to my GoFundMe appeal to get up there. (Will discuss this more & the action plan for it now a bit later in this post).
Some of you may have even experienced a WIP show, where each time a different audience member was comedically “saved,” from the apocalypse/a burning building by the end of the night.
It turns out the person I need to save most is me.
I’ve been doing a very good job at pretending for a while now, that I am not in physical pain from having Covid.
I’ve been in hospital several times for severe pain & breathing problems, there have been times where I’ve found myself unable to function cognitively with brain fog and memory problems, crying in the street unable to make a choice, or know where I am and I was recently diagnosed with Costochondritis, an inflammation of my ribs & chest, that could become chronic and lifelong if I don’t rest & focus on an anti-inflammatory diet & lifestyle.
So in true cosmic joke style it turns out the person on fire the whole time was me!
I have decided to really listen to and prioritise my physical body and needs and dare to imagine what a different way of doing things & living might look like…
I have also realised that so much of my creative work so far has been built on ignoring my body, it’s needs & any physical or emotional pain I might actually be in.
I wonder what kind of creative work I would make if I wasn’t always in survival mode?
What kind of work would I make if the source of all my material wasn’t just trauma & pain?
What would I make if my life was more easeful, held and had community, care & joy in it?
I have to admit for a long time now, sustaining a creative career in the arts has largely involved me pretending I am on an equal footing to others, when in fact I’ve been struggling with access to affordable stable housing & a lack of any supportive, nourishing context in my personal life, that would make true exploration, risk taking, play and expression possible.
Like many others I have bought into the punishing story that if I just worked hard enough, or contorted myself correctly, at some point my day would come..I’d get the shot to express myself, or say something, or be met with the resources that could liberate me from the chaos of surviving and afford to buy a stable home.
But right now my body is howling, saying what about now?
What about living right now?
And making choices that mean no one gets burned down in the making of things.
If the price of success and “a future” is your physical health, I’d say it’s too high.
My people pleasing self, still worried about letting people down, sat on the floor crying, making up excuses & justifications and blatant lies for how much ibuprofen could achieve!? How I had been met with motivating external validation in getting so many people to help fund this & bring it to life…
Including a network of incredible humans on a GoFundMe page & the Phoebe Waller-Bridge spirit of the fringe fund (it’s not called that I know, but I’m an annoying twat and I’ve been enjoying pissing people off by calling it the Hot fleabag priest award).
I also got some money from the Best in Class bursary, I have a big supportive agent & a lush director offering her time & energy for free…all these resources and a good venue and time slot, so that should make it ok to destroy myself right!?
Because I’m so bloody lucky!?
Yet with all of those things combined: A GoFundMe, a working class bursary, money from the fleabag God’s, an agent who will front some costs, a director in kind…I’m still only half way there to covering it!
With costs of accommodation & venue/tech/marketing fees, I’m still looking at coming away pulverised and in debt or best case scenario breaking even with a side of burnt ribs.
Also I simply cannot push or mask anymore, there’s not enough caffeine, ibuprofen or sugar that would get me through!
I should clarify here. The fleabag hot priest award will be returned to someone who needs it (don’t think it’s even arrived yet) and I’ve just returned the Best in Class bursary.
Also I am going to explain the options for the amazingly generous GoFundMe donations here:
I raised a whopping 2,319 quid on my Go Fund Me from some deeply generous souls, in a challenging time for many with rising living costs.
I’d love to return these funds to anyone who needs it, my email address is: charliegeorgecomedy@gmail.com please send me your bank details and I will be able to do this for you, please please don’t be afraid to do this, if you need it, it’s yours.
Another option available is that I had already started to make lifestyle changes as advised by medical professionals I’d seen since having Covid and begun reducing my gig schedule and volunteering at a local farm near where I live in Kent.
Getting my hands in the soil has been so healing for my nervous system and breathing and learning about growing has been transformational even in a short time.
This farm is challenging the “cost of living” crisis by providing affordable veg box schemes to the local community & offering some free in partnership with a local food bank. I’d love to offer your donations to this & my continued work with it, as they are doing great things for the community.
If you’d be happy for this option, you can also email me & I will ensure it goes there and can keep you updated on the work we’re doing. I regularly post pictures from there on insta anyway covered in dirt!
I was also going to offer another option of me doing a more accessible version of the show with access needs considered in London and this money would go towards that!…
But let me discuss that with my agent team and see what’s possible for showcasing my stand up in an accessible way and I will keep you posted/do an announcement…
Many of you know I’m late diagnosed neurodivergent and am committed to access & disability so would love to do something that supported other people who are living with chronic conditions who would find a festival environment too challenging to see work in…watch this space!
For now, I’m not sure where I’m at with gigs and gig life and the toll it takes on the body…
I’m honouring my final few contracted commitments over the summer, with lots of space for rest, healing and recovery in between.
My body has said a clear no to this model & format for expression right now.
Maybe yours says yes!
If so I salute you, go for it, play, experiment, take big risks, have fun!
All we have is now.
Say what you want to say & bring forth your gifts.
I still believe we all have them and they all have equal value and worth.
I love the arts & creative expression, it has always given me the opportunity, the dignity & the daring to examine, express and celebrate life!
I’ll never stop making.
I just need to find a different, healthier, slower way…
So for now, I’m out of the game.
Thanks for all your support and/or hatred of me & my work thus far, it’s all been really useful for the soil!
x Big Love.
Charlie George aka Kali Varghese*

After a few months of absence from posting anything on Medium or my WordPress blog, I am hoping the past week marks a turning point. This writing hiatus has been mainly due to dealing with the shock and grief of my dear sister’s death in December, exacerbated by what I am calling Political Depression: a feeling of paralysis in the face of catastrophic global events (about which I hope to write soon). And losing the inspiration I found from my experience of moving from Sheffield to the Aberdeenshire coast: once I had seen a full year through, I felt I have nothing new to say.
Nothing to do but to get away! It’s been hard to make time for a break for various reasons, but last week we managed to book a couple of nights in Edinburgh, a city we barely know, and do a pure tourist visit.
Just coming out of Waverley station into the spring sunshine with the expansive haven of Princes Street Gardens running through the city centre, and the castle on the rocky mound above, was an immediate lift to the spirits.

If I see one more Instagram post with the caption “Sing me a song of a lass that is gone” I’ll scream.
Scotland is full of tourists, taking snaps and posting them, but I’ve noticed one thing when I read about their trips.
They hardly ever mention Glasgow.
Have you even really seen Scotland if you haven’t been to Glasgow? A lot of people seem to think “it’s a waste of time” that could be better spent in Edinburgh or Glen Coe. Or checking off Outlander locations.
They are so wrong. Add it to your bucket list. Stay a while and absorb the vibe of the city. Glasgow rewards time spend there — and you will fall in love with the place!
Well, Outlander did get one thing right — Scotland is a tribal culture!
Think about the football teams. Rangers vs Celtic; Hearts vs Hibs. If you want to avoid a fight make sure you say you support Partick Thistle. All of this is based on old sectarian rivalries. Protestants vs Catholics.
But there’s city rivalry too. Glasgow is the friendly, blue-collar, ‘real’ Scotland. Edinburgh people are…

It was great to meet more of the Travel Massive community at Travel Massive Edinburgh’s first event of 2021, on Thursday 28 January.
After introductions and updates from the Travel Massive Edinburgh chapter leaders Lesley, Susan and Katy, with a focus on the role of communities, including Travel Massive and Women in Tourism, we heard from Susan Russell, Head of Marketing, Underbelly, on how for the first time, Edinburgh’s Hogmanay had gone completely digital in 2020.
Susan shared some of the impressive audience engagement statistics and reminded us of the powerful combination of drone technology, poetry, music and film in the video clips she shared. We learned that the Edinburgh’s Hogmanay Fare Well piece has been viewed over 6.2 million times (direct views) on social channels and has generated around 650 pieces of media coverage. 150 drones were used in the piece, and this was Scotland’s first ever swarm drone show.
Josh Ryan-Saha, Director of Traveltech for Scotland, introduced the cluster’s aims and objectives and shared updates, also focusing on the power of community and letting people know how they can get involved.
We were then introduced to one of the entrepreneurs in the Traveltech for Scotland community, Elaine Ford, who shared information about her early-stage start-up, Electrek Explorer, a mobile app for electric vehicle tourism, offering opportunities for collaboration across the tourism sector in Scotland and striving to develop a solution towards a greener economy.
The event generated some great industry chat and facilitated valuable connections between members which was great to see. We look forward to more events in partnership with the Travel Massive community and thanks also to Ian Cumming and Maria Stoyanova of Travel Massive for their isupport for Traveltech for Scotland.
Watch the Travel Massive Edinburgh event recap video here, catch Edinburgh’s Hogmanay Fare Well again, including the poetry and music from the event. Watch Elaine Ford talk about start-up Electrek Explorer.

Title: Edinburgh, Scotland and the Romance of a Train
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Listen
Share
“Piled deep and massy, close and high; Mine own romantic town”
-Sir Walter Scott, Marmion
In Peterborough, the station where I had transferred onto my train, I had thought about how the blankets of grey across the sky do not mean gloom. They just mean a cloudy day. Yes, no sun. But also, no sun in my eyes. The muted tones were becoming synonymous with the UK in my mind.
But that day, by the time the train was gliding toward Edinburgh, those grey clouds had broken up enough that tides of sunlight washed over the land between them. The hills and farmland sped by, but I was sitting still. Laughter bounced up the cabin. A family was sitting behind me a few rows back, and at the heart of their babble was a high note of wonder — a little girl, enraptured by everything.
“Woooah! Woooah!”
“It’s another train!” exclaimed a deep, gravely voice. He animated his voice to match her bright wonder.
“Look grampy,” she chimed, “here it comes! WOOOAH!!”
Their chatter pulsed through the continuous hum of the train, then fell back under it again and again, as tidal as the waves of sunlight breaking through outside. Occasionally, amused laughter burst from the whole group. I smiled. The world was new and bright to her, and she was bringing that gift to the whole cabin. It was going to be a good weekend, I thought. Later, a group of rowdy guys took their place in the back. It wasn’t hard to make out their loud voices, but I could only understand every fourth word through their thick Scottish accents.
When I got off the train in Edinburgh, I was surprised to find a flood of people exiting the station with me, many of them donning green and orange. The woman in the tourist information booth told me there was a big rugby match today: Six Flags Ireland vs. Scotland. Luckily these crowds only brought their excitement and energy, no disruptions or hassles for me.
Emerging from the station into Edinburgh was quite dramatic. In addition to the pockets of heart-warming human interaction I encountered on the train, arriving that way was worth it just for the visual effect. Waverly station is right in the middle of Old Town and runs underneath Edinburgh castle. So, when I walked up to street level, the slope to the castle and through romantic old buildings was my first impression of the city. One thing I loved about Edinburgh was its geography. It sits under the watch of two extinct volcanoes — the smaller Castle Rock to the West, where the castle sits, and Arthur’s Seat to the East, a much higher and windier hill that stands over the official residence of the royal family in Scotland. Other hills rise around the center like hands of the land cupping the city in its palm. Some of the houses spill out of the land’s grasp and trickle around the coast of the North Sea.
The entrance to my hostel was nestled right underneath the Castle. I was met by a friendly reception immediately inside the door. To the right was the check-in desk, to the left was a locked cage full of big backpacks and sacks. Passed that was the kitchen door. People were coming and going with cups of afternoon coffee. The receptionists asked where I was from. I told them I was American but studying abroad in London. Ah, gotcha, they said, cool. With swarms of young people arriving from all over the world, I’m sure they had heard that story many times. After getting my key, I wandered further underground, passed a couple of themed lounges with high ceilings, and reached a narrow, traditional-looking staircase.
The room was large and filled with at least eight sets of bunk beds. Each had a storage compartment, a safe, charging outlets by the bed, and a curtain to maintain some sense of privacy. And, since this floor’s theme was Harry Potter, my bed had a wooden nametag that said “Ron Weasley.” They didn’t skimp on décor, because the walls were spattered with murals. The hostel became a home base with a strangely easy sense of community.
Edinburgh itself seemed to have an easy way about it. I mostly wandered around during my visit, and it was all lovely. The Royal Mile, a straight street at the center of Old Town, entertained me for an entire afternoon. With Six Nations going on, the number of kilted bagpipers on the street was probably double the normal. As soon as one was out of earshot, I’d catch the notes of another just up ahead for continuous ambiance. There were bookshops and whiskey tours and fabric stores filled with traditionally woven plaid fabric, kilts, and everything else. I finished my first night with dinner at the pub and a pool game with some rugby fans at the hostel and went to bed exhausted.
On my second day, I visited the Scottish National Gallery, took a bus to New Town just to see the difference, and walked up Calton Hill to see the unfinished National Monument. Bundled up, eyes watering from the wind, I watched a group of older and younger kids try to clamber up the bracket of the monument’s huge foundation. The older kids, already on top, were weaving around the giant stone pillars, trying to reach around them and touch each other’s hands from opposite sides. They couldn’t do it and broke out in laughter at their failure.
By the time they left, the sun had set. Above the reach of any streetlights, the hill was becoming so dark that I could no longer make out the people fifteen feet in front of me. I almost climbed on top of the monument but awkwardly slipped down a couple times. I chuckled at myself because I had thought that I would do better than those kids. I held onto the pillar to feel like the wind wouldn’t push me off the hill, and then I looked toward the city. The lights were all on — human constellations shining through the thick night where the stars faintly answered back. The horizon line between them was a yellow glow over Edinburgh. I took a breath in, then sat down, taking it in until my body could not warm itself against the cold wind anymore.
On my last day, I took another wander around Edinburgh, scooting between the old buildings that sat almost on top of each other, and found other streets, apartment courtyards, and secret allies. Back on a main street, I found a small old church, which was no longer a church and now had a souvenir shop and UNESCO Heritage display set up inside. I wandered around and tried to imagine the kinds of people who would have gathered here when it had first been built.
I saved Arthur’s Seat for last. After my night on top of the National Monument, it seemed like the perfect way to take in the city one last time. Every stranger I met eyes with shared the same spark of exhilaration that I felt on those windy, open hills. Everyone couldn’t help but smile. Besides feeling like I was going to get blown off the mountain, the most memorable moment was thanks to a man who was out for a run.
He was wearing just a tiny pair of running shorts and shoes; he let his long hair do whatever it wanted. He zipped passed me and a couple that I had made friends with as we were climbing up to the actual “seat” of Arthur’s Seat. By the time we got one bend away from the top, we could look ahead and see that he had stopped to enjoy the view in a rather unorthodox way. I have to note here that I cannot over-exaggerate how windy it was; I was scared to stand near the edge of any hill, afraid I might literally be blown over by its force. This man had walked out to the very edge of the cliff and was perched on it with his legs slightly ahead of his body and his arms behind him, gripping the rock face. His hair was wildly whipping in the wind, and he was bellowing at the top of his lungs toward the city. The sound of his voice came in faint wisps when the wind blew it our way, but it was definitely a blood-curdling howl. He looked like a wild man that had crawled from a cave in the Scottish hills. We walked around the bend and lost sight of him for about a hundred feet, but we saw that he was still screaming when we got to the peak of the hill. And he hadn’t stopped when we kept going and eventually lost sight of him for good. Well, he’s either a little insane or he knows something the rest of us don’t, I thought. Most likely both.
You can just make him out in the picture below.
The train back glided through darkness, so instead of gazing out the window, I read my book and wrote in my journal about how I didn’t want to go back to reality. This time it wasn’t a little girl and her family, but a tired boy and his father still painted blue for the game. The boy fell asleep before their stop and his dad scooped his floppy little body up to leave. I used to pretend that I was asleep so my mom would carry me inside and tuck me in bed, and I wondered if he was using the same tactics.
On my second and longer train back to London, I fell back into my journaling and back into deep thought. The gentleman in the booth across the aisle from me was reading with his brows gently knitted together. A woman came along. She was loud, friendly, maybe ten years older than me, American. She asked the man if the seat across from him was taken; he shook his head and returned to his reading. She announced that she was whooped and was therefore going to the concession car to get a beer and we would like one too. The man accepted, I politely declined. Was I sure, she asked. Yes, thank you, I replied.
It was uncomfortable to be yanked from my thoughts by her conversation, but she slowly drew me in as she broke through small talk with the old man and got on to more interesting things. She knew I was listening, I think, and continued to address me across the aisle with a nod or a glance. She began talking about her plans to take a trip to the highlands with her friends, then the man revealed that he was from northern Scotland and could tell her all about the highlands. With that, I finally joined in.
We listened to his descriptions of the highlands, we asked each other questions, we shared opinions and plans, and we began to feel like we had always been this familiar with each other. They finished their drinks, and at some point they both got off at their stops. I was left with my own thoughts again, but this time they swam around with something deeper. And that something made me thank the world for long train rides and friendly strangers.

Title: Celebrate the New Year in Edinburgh
Content:
Sign up

Sign in
Member-only story
--
Share
Scomo collapsed from a heart attack near the new commercial center that he detested. Hurried and busy pedestrians left him there, figuring he was a drunken tramp, until a feeble-minded woman knelt to care for him and discovered he was dead.
That’s how the writer George Scott-Moncrieff died in Edinburgh in 1974.
He loved Edinburgh, even though bulldozers and commercial developers had wrecked large parts of it.
Edinburgh is still lovable today despite the commercial-fueled bulldozer, says Alexander Larman in a recent essay in The Spectator, noting that Scotland’s capital “comes into its own” at New Years.
The Scots call the New Years “Hogmanay” and it consists of two days that the Scots celebrate like their Irish cousins celebrate March 17th.
Larman recommends Edinburgh at Hogmanay . . . or at any time.
“It’s a seductive place to visit,” says Larman, given its “combination of Georgian architecture, world-class museums and galleries, some fine independent shops, and top-notch restaurants and bars.”
If you’re going to Edinburgh, Larman recommends you take the train from London.
And if you can afford it, go first class on the London North Eastern Railway. It takes four hours, but it’s a great four hours.

Title: My London—Edinburgh—London 2017

Four days earlier in the early morning of Sunday 30th July I’d arrived at Davenant Foundation School in Loughton east London. The location for the start of the 2017 London — Edinburgh — London Audax. One of Britain’s greatest cycling challenges, the route stretches over 1400km between the two capitals taking in some of the most stunning scenery the UK has to offer.
It’s a simple concept. You just need to collect a stamp on the brevet card at each of the 19 checkpoints along the route and complete the ride in 100 elapsed hours. (A 116 hour time limit is an option but, in for a penny…)
Prior to this I’d never ridden anything on such a scale. I’d completed multi-day stage races, but they involved only 3–4 hours in the saddle each day. Similarly with Lands End — John O’Groats which I completed 15 years previous. Riding for just 6–8 hours a day leaves plenty of time for recovery and feeding.
Breaking this ride down in the months prior to the start, it looked straightforward. A schedule of somewhere in the region of 350km per day for four days. Factor in the cumulative fatigue and the forecast bad weather, however, and things start to look interesting.
I started well. From a 07:15 roll out I covered 340km to Pocklington by about 21:30. Helped by an always-welcome tailwind and fresh legs, the miles slipped by — especially in the Fens north of Cambridge and up through Lincolnshire to the Wolds.
I had picked up a ride partner in the Fens; a guy from Manchester. Initially I had plans of continuing to Thirsk but he was keen to stop. I knew there were lumpy roads to come so decided to get a bed at Pocklington. I slept reasonably well — helped by the earplugs provided by the organisers.
Clear, dry and mild. The road to Thirsk was in poor condition and given that I’d have been riding it in the dark I was glad of my decision not to continue the previous night.
The first big hill of the ride came out of Barnard Castle. A long drag followed by Yad Moss. By this point the cross-tailwind we’d enjoyed further south had shifted to a cross/cross-head as we’d turned north west. Yad Moss became a savage drag all the way from High Force up to the top. The descent was quick, though the wind took the edge off top end speed.
I was expecting the weather to be poor in Brampton. But it was one of the warmest places on the whole ride. A quick stop for food and a stamp in the brevet card and onwards to Moffat.
I’d ridden the road to Moffat 15 years previously on my End-to-End jaunt. Let’s call it utilitarian. It’s pretty featureless and seems to be littered with truck stops. The route had turned north again meaning the wind was mostly to our sides and backs. Progress was quick but my ride partner from Manchester dropped away, complaining of aggravating a historic injury.
I reached Moffat soon after 20:00, my ride partner following slightly later informing me of his decision to bail. He was disappointed, as was I for him. All the preparation and build up to not even reach the half way point.
I rolled out of the control on my own as the sun was setting.
Continuing on the route of my ride 15 years earlier, I remembered the road out of Moffat to be glorious. A lovely, steady gradient up Devil’s Beef Tub through beautiful scenery. This particular evening there was hardly a car to be seen and just a couple of other riders’ flashing rear lights in the distance for company. Throw in a lovely sunset and still air; this was pretty close to cycling nirvana.
Descending the other side I passed a rider stopped at the side of the road. The reply to the usual “Got everything you need?” wasn’t the standard “Yeah, thanks.” but “Actually, no!” Heaving on the anchors I met Mike who was on puncture number six of the ride and had ruined his tyre levers.
I leant him my box-fresh set and before long we were both rolling towards Edinburgh, arriving soon after 01:00.
Day three slapped us in the face with a 06:00 wake up to wet weather after four hours sleep.
Turning south meant the wind would mostly be in our faces or, at best, cross-head. The road out of Edinburgh down to Innerleithen and then Eskdalemuir beyond was lumpy and windy. The rain passed and the sun shone occassionally between the dark clouds. The scenery was beautiful: rugged, bleak and remote. My legs took some time to come to me, the first three hours were hard but by lunch I’d recovered some form.
The checkpoints passed. I ate a lot of food; pretty much a three course meal with a side of carbs. at each stop. 8–9000 calories a day is a lot to replace.
Brampton was reached around mid-afternoon. After thinking this would be one of the wettest points on the route it had turned out to be not just dry but also very warm. I had a bag left at this control so changed into fresh kit (mmmmmmm!) and rolled out in the direction of Alston.
Yad Moss. Again. The windy, bleak slog-fest on the way north was playing on my mind. I needed to get over this and make good time towards Thirsk for the night.
The climb south wasn’t anywhere near as brutal as the route north. It seemed to pass quickly and with relative ease. Riding along the top was beautiful. So much so that I stopped to take one of my few photographs from the ride.
The day ended in Thirsk some time after 01:00. A huge feed and four hours sleep later, we were back on the road just after 06:30.
430km to do. This was it. At 11:15 the last 24 hours in which to complete this ride would begin its count down.
The roads were relatively flat down to the Humber Bridge from Thirsk. But then it started to get interesting. The wind was straight into our faces. Unrelenting like the little climbs; some up to 15%. Up and down we went. Small groups forming on the road to help each other to the next control at Louth.
By Louth stories were coming back from the Fens about the ferociousness of the wind. Tired bodies were scattered around the control. Allegiances were being made to ride across the Fens as groups. Strength in numbers.
I grew up on the edge of the Fens. It’s my natural riding environment. The opposite of the high mountains. Flat roads providing an opportunity to ride steady state for hours on end—more suited to my 78kg. Throw in the promise of wind and I was secretly relishing what was to come.
We gathered our group together and rolled out of Louth in the late afternoon.
The road to Spalding was as advertised. I did a 35km turn on the front of our group. For that hour and a half I was riding a spring Classic in Belgium; driving the head of the bunch, putting everyone in dificulties. Although I was really just holding a steady 22–25kmh and giving four others shelter.
Spalding was reached as the sun was going down.
180km to go. We started to formulate plans. Short stops at the control and a two to three hour sleep before London? Or, slightly longer stops at each control but continue all night to the finish? We opted for the latter.
And so we settled in for the night shift.
The wind continued and it started to rain but spirits were high. The group chatted and rotated turns on the front.
As the hours passed and the tiredness crept in, the chatter decreased and we became more singularly focussed on keeping tidy in the group. Don’t fall asleep. Hold the wheel. Breathe the chilly air deeply to keep the senses alert.
We gathered waifs and strays as we rode. All looking for company and the relative saftey of a large group with our combined illumination on the dark, potentially dangerous, roads of south Lincolnshire.
The last control points passed in a blur of tiredness.
Stop, get card stamped, take on caffeine, eat whatever is plain and easy to get down, get back on the bike, continue riding south.
The sun rose as we approached Great Easton. The final control before home. There were some seriously tired bodies. People catching 20 minutes sleep sat at their bowl of cereal. I was falling asleep. A double shot espresso gel saved for this very occasion perked me up and we headed off for the final 48km of this monster ride.
We rolled into Davenant School at 08:32 on Thursday 3 August. Card stamped at 08:35. 97 hours and 20 minutes after I’d rolled out of the gates.
What. A. Ride.
Here are a few hints and tips that worked well for me in the build up to, and during, the event. With something like this, everyone has their own approach so take what you like from the below. Your mileage will likely vary.
I carried arm, leg and knee warmers with me on the bike at all times. Add in a gillet, rain cape and wet weather gloves and I was fine for cool night riding and wet weather. Maintenance wise: Three spare tubes (only one used), CO2, multi-tool, tyre levers(!), cable ties, electrical insulation tape, spare cable, pucture repair kit.
I carried small packets of Dove wet wipes with me. They helped keep myself clean between applications of chamois cream which, by the end of the ride, was twice a day. They’re also great for moisturising after a day of wind burn. My wife told me to take lip balm but I forgot it. And boy did I finish with chapped lips! Take lip balm! Even a quick teeth clean at a control gives you an extra 2km/h for the next hour or so. So, small tube of tooth paste and tooth brush.
The food supplied at the controls is excellent. Pasta bakes, chicken supreme with rice, mild curries with rice, rice puddings, sponge puddings with custard, porridge, cereal, hot drinks, loads of fresh fruit and cereal/flapjack bars of all varieties for between controls.
You can see the bike I rode above. It performed fautlessly. Disc brakes really are excellent in wet weather and especially so when you don’t get to clean your bike between wet rides. None of that scretchy, gritty brake block on rims. The dynamo front hub meant I never had to worry about power for phone or Garmin. Although, make sure you get everything charged during the day so the light is at full power at night. I rode 39/53 and 29/11 never feeling over geared.
I have a day job and a busy family life. I don’t have the luxury of being able to string together huge rides regularly. I did one 440km ride and a few 100–200km back to back rides. I think the most effective training I did was a few 200–400km rides on 4 hours sleep in the two months leading up to L-E-L.
I used a Garmin 810 and saved each leg so as not to overload it. Rides longer than 100km seem to make my Garmin turn off and dump the data. I strung them together using FIT tools for the Strava bragging rights.
I found the organisation of the event to be excellent across every dimension. The vounteers were outstanding at every control. They seemed to really enjoy their roles and nothing was ever too much effort at whatever time of day or night. Outstanding!

Title: Alternative Tourism Experience — The Real Edinburgh
Content:

Sign up

From the moment we all sat down around the table brainstorming, it was clear to us that everyone had a completely different idea on the task in hand. Some thought it was to find an obscure tourist experience, whilst myself and others thought it was maybe an app or something completely apart from the norm that would allow tourists to explore their surroundings.
To narrow our ideas down we brought in the help of a lecture to clarify the desired output from the task. It was at this point that we decided to Jazz up the idea of a day trip in the city, including Maps and Apps.
The main idea from the start was to have different independent business join together to create a day experience for tourists who wanted to see that REAL Edinburgh, and not the Edinburgh focused on chains and high street brands.
After becoming fairly confident on the idea we asked our Italian group member, Cecilia, to ask her friends and people she knew back home what they thought of this idea. The idea was given a positive backing so therefore we decided to go ahead with this.
We decided a walk round of Edinburgh would be beneficial to us and would allow us to gauge what independent businesses, obscure places we would like to have in our day trip.
We decided that best way to display/present our idea was to given an example of one of many day trips to see the REAL Edinburgh.
After deciding on the places we decided on a route that made the most sense and also fitted into the time slot of 10am — 10pm. By deciding on this route, it allowed us to create a map that would give the tourists an outline for their day trip whilst also giving them a memento of memorial value.
We decided that these maps could be picked up from Haymarket — The starting point of the trip — and each map would have a different day trip on each.
The day trip for our presentation was as follows
Overall the group worked Hard as a team and met on multiple occasions where one team member was unable to attend due to other commitments whilst keeping them in the loop via Facebook group chats.
Due to all 4 of us missing the primary lecture where the brief was given we felt behind on this task and worked extremely hard to be up to date and produce an Alternative tourist experience.
I feel with more time this idea could have been given a fully functioning app which worked in conjunction with the maps allowing tourists to build up a bank of obscure places and independent business’s creating a very personal memory bank.
